site_title: China drafts new data measures, defines 'core data'
summary: China has published new draft measures for its data security law, defining "core data" as information that poses a "serious threat" to the country's national and economic interests. The law, implemented on September 1, requires companies to classify data into categories, including ordinary, important, and core data. Important data is described as having an "obvious cascading effect" across industries, while core data is deemed to cause "major damage" if disrupted. The new measures aim to bolster the law's enforcement and address criticisms of its ambiguities, including the lack of definitions for data.

site_title: ABB launches world's fastest charger to plug into surging e-car market
summary: ABB has launched the world's fastest electric car charger, the Terra 360 modular charger, which can charge up to four vehicles at once and fully charge any electric car within 15 minutes. The device is aimed at business clients and will be available in Europe by the end of the year, with plans to expand to other regions in 2022. The launch follows a growing demand for electric vehicles, with global registrations increasing by 41% in 2020 to 3 million cars, and sales rising by 140% in the first three months of 2021.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close week on weak note
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed the week on a weak note, with the Hang Seng Index easing 0.36% to 24,575.64, following three days of gains. The decline was attributed to data showing China's factory activity contracted in September, the first time since February 2020, and traders' cautious stance on US debt ceiling talks. Markets in Hong Kong and mainland China were closed on Friday for holidays.

site_title: Singapore convicts nine people in Southernpec shipping fuel theft case
summary: Nine people in Singapore have been convicted and sentenced to up to three years in jail for cheating buyers out of $337,000 worth of shipping fuel by tampering with measuring equipment on bunker tankers. The group used industrial strength magnets to manipulate Mass Flow Meters, recording higher sales volumes than delivered. The syndicate operated between December 2018 and April 2019, with the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore, Singapore Police Force, and Attorney-General's Chambers investigating the case. Southernpec (Singapore), the fuel services provider, is now in liquidation.

site_title: Ho Ching to chair Temasek Trust from April 2022
summary: Temasek Trust has announced the appointment of Ho Ching, the outgoing CEO of Temasek Holdings, as its chairman from April 1, 2022. Ho Ching will also join the trust's board on October 1, succeeding S Dhanabalan. The changes come after Dhanabalan, who has been chairman since 2015, will remain on the board as chairman emeritus. The trust's board also includes new appointees Benny Lim, Teo Ming Kian, and Tow Heng Tan, effective January 1, 2022.

site_title: UK economy grows 5.5% in Q2 before slowdown
summary: The UK economy grew 5.5% in Q2, surpassing the initial estimate of 4.8% due to revised data from the health sector and updated methodology. This brings the UK's GDP growth to tie with Germany and surpass Italy among G7 developed countries. However, economists predict a slowdown due to post-lockdown bottlenecks, including supply shortages, and warn of potential interest rate hikes to combat inflation. The Bank of England has signaled a first interest rate hike since the pandemic, with inflation expected to rise above 4%.

site_title: Asia: Most markets track Wall St up but traders still on edge
summary: Asian markets mostly rose on Thursday, tracking Wall Street's gains, despite lingering concerns over surging inflation and interest rate hikes. Investors are also on edge due to the US debt stand-off and the prospect of a historic US default. Central bank officials, including Jerome Powell, downplayed concerns about inflation, which has soared this year due to supply chain problems. The global economic recovery is slowing, with a spike in Covid infections, and China's factory activity contracted in September for the first time since February 2020.

site_title: China urges banks to avoid housing speculation to curb Evergrande risk
summary: China's central bank urged banks to avoid housing speculation and stabilize land and housing prices amid concerns over Evergrande's debt crisis. The People's Bank of China stressed that "houses are used for living, not speculation" and warned against using real estate as a short-term economic stimulus. The move aims to curb speculation in the property sector, which has been tightening regulations to address Evergrande's potential collapse, saddled with over $300 billion in liabilities.

site_title: Mapletree bets US$3b on two US logistics portfolios
summary: Mapletree Investments has acquired two US logistics portfolios worth approximately US$3 billion, adding 141 income-producing assets to its portfolio. The acquisition will give the company scale and interest to create a fourth US-focused private fund with a fully seeded portfolio of 155 logistics assets. The US logistics sector is expected to remain resilient, with record tenant demand, rents growing, and historic lows in vacancy. Mapletree's acquisitions are seen as a strategic move to expand its portfolio and generate stable income at an acceptable risk level.

images.alt_text: Food and drink imports to the UK could be hit with tariffs of £9.3 billion a year (S$16.7 billion), lifting supermarket prices, if the country crashes out of the European Union (EU) without a deal, according to a study.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims rise; second quarter GDP revised higher
summary: US weekly jobless claims rose 11,000 to 362,000 for the week ended Sept 25, marking the third straight week of increase. Economists attribute the rise to factors such as wildfires, Hurricane Ida, and the Delta variant of Covid-19. Despite this, economic activity appears to be picking up, with total card spending increasing. The US economy's second-quarter GDP was revised higher to a 6.7% annualized rate, driven by pandemic relief money. However, growth estimates for the third quarter are below 5% due to the Delta variant and raw material shortages.

images.alt_text: The 99-year leasehold, 5,121.4 square metre (55,130 square foot) site, at the junction of Cross Street and Club Street, has a maximum gross floor area of 24,310 sq m and could yield up to 390 rooms.

site_title: Europe: Equities on course to end volatile September on bright note
summary: European stocks rose 0.6% on Thursday, extending gains after a volatile week, as defensive sectors such as real estate, healthcare, and food and beverage led the way. The Stoxx 600 index is on track to end September with a 2.7% loss, following a seven-month winning streak. Investors are shifting away from high-growth sectors due to concerns over slowing global economic growth and higher inflation, with miners rebounding from sharp declines. Key stocks include H&M, which rose 1.9%, and Diageo, which gained 2%, while Boohoo tumbled 10.3% due to freight inflation and wage concerns.

site_title: New feature allows BT subscribers to 'gift' stories
summary: The Business Times (BT) has introduced a new feature allowing subscribers to "gift" stories to non-subscribers, including colleagues, friends, and family. This feature, available on the BT website, enables subscribers to share exclusive articles, market analyses, expert commentary, and opinion pieces with others. There is no limit to the number of articles that can be gifted, and the feature aims to increase accessibility to BT's content.

site_title: MAS seen on hold as Covid-19 pandemic drags on: Reuters poll
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), is expected to keep monetary policy on hold at its October review, as highly transmissible coronavirus variants spread locally and globally, threatening the pace of economic recovery. Analysts predict the economy will grow 6-7% this year, with record high daily cases in Singapore and a deteriorating Covid-19 situation. The MAS may consider tightening monetary policy in April 2022, but for now, it will maintain its exchange-rate based policy settings unchanged.

site_title: IOI's lone bet on Marina View is on an endemic future, 7 years on
summary: IOI Properties won a government land tender for a 99-year leasehold site in Singapore's Marina View area, securing the site for S$1.508 billion, or S$1,379 per square foot per plot ratio. The sole bidder, IOI, may have been deterred by the site's huge total development cost and major hotel component, but the company has experience in the hospitality segment and could potentially benefit from the site's future residential component. The government's efforts to support business travel and leisure tourism in Singapore may also support the hotel's development.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB raises target price of industry laggard ESR-Reit to S$0.538
summary: CGS-CIMB has raised its target price for ESR-Reit to 53.8 Singapore cents, citing the Reit's healthy operational and financial performance, Covid-19 resilience, and lower cost of funding. Analysts expect improvements in the industrial leasing market and stable rental income, with a potential DPU yield of 5.8%. The Reit's inclusion in the FTSE EPRA Nareit index is expected to improve trading liquidity and lower its cost of capital. The analysts remain positive on the Reit, predicting greater price upside driven by improved operating metrics and accretive acquisitions.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes down for fourth straight session
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index closed down for a fourth consecutive session, falling 0.31% or 91.63 points to 29,452.66. Investors remain cautious ahead of the US debt ceiling bill deadline, fearing a potential government shutdown. The dollar fetched 111.92 yen, slightly down from 111.98 yen in New York, despite a cheaper yen benefiting Japanese exporters.

site_title: Temasek-backed Covid-19 test provider Oxford Nanopore soars in London trading debut
summary: Oxford Nanopore Technologies, backed by Temasek, made its London trading debut, rising 32% to 545.50 pence, valuing the company at £3.4 billion. The IPO saw £350 million raised, with strong demand for fast-growing tech stocks in the UK. The company provides Covid-19 test kits to the National Health Service and sequencing technology to track virus variants. Its market value has increased by about $1 billion since its last funding round, making it one of the UK's most valuable startups.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks posts biggest monthly drop since March 2020
summary: South Korean stocks posted their biggest monthly decline since March 2020, falling 4% in September, as investors assessed the impact of rising energy costs on inflation and a broad sell-off in tech shares. The benchmark Kospi rose 0.28% to 3,068.82, while the won weakened and bond yields rose. Analysts cited downside risks from the China Evergrande debt crisis and US debt issues, increasing market volatility. Foreigners were net buyers of 34.8 billion won worth of shares, while the Kospi has risen 6.80% this year.

site_title: URA launches residential sites at Lentor Hills Road, Jalan Tembusu for tender
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has released three residential sites at Lentor Hills Road and Jalan Tembusu for tender under the second half 2021 government land sales (GLS) programme. The sites will be sold to developers for residential use, with the aim of meeting the demand for housing in Singapore. The announcement comes as the market continues to navigate the post-pandemic recovery and the impact of rising interest rates on the property sector.

site_title: Keep ESG disclosures to useful metrics, benchmarks, say investment managers
summary: Investment managers at Ecosperity Week emphasized the need for companies to focus on providing useful ESG (environmental, social, and governance) data, rather than overwhelming investors with excessive information. While there has been progress in ESG reporting, panellists noted that only 20% of ESG data points have a material impact on financial performance, and more can be done to make data accessible. Mandatory disclosures are necessary for investors to make informed decisions, and ensuring verifiable and transparent data is crucial.

site_title: ASMI partners LEAP201 to provide migrant workers with group life, critical illness insurance
summary: The Association of Singapore Marine Industries (ASMI) has partnered with LEAP201 to provide group life and critical illness insurance to over 35,000 migrant workers in the marine and offshore engineering (M&OE) sector. The Care4MigrantWorkers (C4M) scheme offers coverage of up to S$10,000 for non-work-related accidents and 37 critical illnesses. ASMI member-companies can purchase the scheme for S$3 per worker per year, a 66% discount from its usual price. The subsidy is limited to the first 10,000 migrant workers who sign up for at least two years.

site_title: Broker's take: South-east Asia a growth market for China education sector
summary: DBS Group Research expects the private education sector in South-east Asia to experience significant growth potential, driven by China's tightening policies on private education. The region's countries, such as Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam, offer friendly regulations for international schools and private universities. With shrinking household sizes and emerging economies, the international education market in the region is expected to post a compound annual growth rate of 5-18% over the next five years. China's K-12 education providers may turn to this growth opportunity, with synergies between South-east Asian and Chinese education operators also emerging.

site_title: Facebook-backed Indian social commerce platform Meesho raises US$570m
summary: Meesho, an Indian social commerce platform backed by Facebook and SoftBank Group, has raised US$570 million in a funding round led by Fidelity Management & Research Company and B Capital Group, valuing the company at US$4.9 billion. Founded in 2015, Meesho allows social media users to sell products, taking a cut from actual sales. Existing investors, including Prosus Ventures, SoftBank Vision Fund 2, and Facebook, also participated in the funding round.

site_title: New office set up to accelerate green bond efforts: Lawrence Wong
summary: Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced the establishment of a new office to accelerate the government's efforts in green bonds. The Green Bonds Programme Office will develop a framework for green bond programmes, engage the industry, and manage investor relations. The office aims to support the government's sustainability goals and follows the National Environment Agency's recent establishment of a S$3 billion multicurrency medium-term note and green bond framework. The office's creation underscores the government's commitment to promoting green finance and reducing its environmental impact.

site_title: Cosco Shipping International to sell 60% stake in Singapore unit for US$42.4 million
summary: Cosco Shipping International agreed to sell a 60% stake in its Singapore unit, Cosco Shipping Singapore, for US$42.4 million to Cosco (HK) Shipping, a wholly owned subsidiary of China Cosco Shipping Corporation. The company cited a strategic decision to streamline its conglomerate structure, focusing on its core logistics business. The sale will allow Cosco Shipping International to expand its logistics business in South and South-east Asia, while retaining a 40% stake in Cosco Shipping Singapore.

images.alt_text: Cosco Shipping International said the proposed transaction represents its strategic decision to streamline its current conglomerate structure to increase focus on its core logistics business.

site_title: Vietnam's biggest city to start lifting Covid-19 curbs to spur business
summary: Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam's largest city, will start lifting its COVID-19 curbs on Thursday, allowing businesses and social activities to resume after four months. The city's 9 million residents will no longer need travel permits, and checkpoints will be lifted. Industrial parks, construction projects, and restaurants can reopen, but authorities prioritize accelerating inoculation, focusing on workers and those over 50. The city aims to spur the economy and restore normalcy while coexisting with the virus, which has claimed over 19,000 lives in the country.

site_title: Singapore eyeing R&D in mmWave to create niche in the area of 6G
summary: Singapore aims to establish a niche in 6G technology by investing in research and development, particularly in millimeter-wave (mmWave) frequencies. The country plans to deploy significant capital and talent to develop world-class research in this area, with the goal of creating innovative semiconductor technologies to power its digital economy. The government hopes to attract top talent from both local and international sources, with plans to redesign technician jobs and offer competitive salaries to encourage Institute of Technical Education and polytechnic graduates to join the industry.

site_title: US trade officials delay decision on new solar tariffs
summary: The US Commerce Department has delayed its decision on new solar tariffs, seeking additional information from anonymous domestic solar manufacturers who requested the duties on panels from Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam. The delay comes amid concerns that imposing tariffs would harm the US solar industry and disrupt the global market. The Commerce Department has set a deadline of October 6 for the manufacturers to respond to a series of questions, with a decision expected within 45 days. The move has been met with opposition from the US Solar Energy Industries Association, which claims the petitioners have no case.

site_title: Exodus of Hong Kong bankers accelerates in chase for China deals
summary: Global lenders are accelerating the relocation of bankers from Hong Kong to China due to the city's strict quarantine rules, which limit bankers to three trips to the mainland per year and require a minimum of two weeks in isolation. UBS, Credit Suisse, and JPMorgan Chase are among the banks shifting staff to China, where they can access the world's second-largest economy. The move is driven by the desire to expand dealmaking opportunities and avoid higher tax rates in Hong Kong, where China's tax rate is as high as 45% compared to Hong Kong's 15%.

site_title: Two more seniors die from Covid-19, taking Singapore's death toll to 95; 2,478 new cases reported
summary: Two more seniors in Singapore have died from Covid-19 complications, bringing the death toll to 95. The two victims, an 79-year-old female permanent resident and an 87-year-old female citizen, were unvaccinated and had underlying medical conditions. There were 2,478 new cases reported, including 535 seniors above 60. A new cluster of 29 cases has been linked to a nursing home, and six new clusters have been linked to migrant worker dorms.

site_title: Australian housing borrowing booms, regulators ready new lending rules
summary: Australian home lending expanded at its fastest annual pace since 2018 in August, with outstanding home loans rising 0.6% and annual growth reaching 6.2%. Record-low mortgage rates have fueled the surge in debt, driving house prices up 18.4% annually, the fastest pace since 1989. Regulators are concerned about the mounting risks to financial stability and are preparing new lending rules, with the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority set to release an information paper on macroprudential policy.

site_title: Hot stock: Jardine Matheson up as much as 4.7% on proposed US$250m share buyback
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings proposed a US$250 million share buyback plan, with its shares reaching a high of US$53.45, up 4.7% or US$2.42. The plan aims to reduce capital and is in line with the group's capital allocation policy. The company reported a net loss of US$117 million for the first half of 2021. The share buyback plan is part of the group's efforts to return gearing to historic levels over the medium term.

site_title: China's high-end military technology touted at biggest air show
summary: China showcased its high-end military technology at its largest air show, highlighting advancements in drones, fighter jets, and engines. The WZ-7 Xianglong drone and J-20 fighter jet demonstrated capabilities in reconnaissance and electronic warfare. China is also developing a "loyal wingman" drone and expected to launch heavy-duty rockets in 2028. In commercial aircraft, China is working towards self-sufficiency in key technologies, with the development of a domestic engine for the C919 narrowbody plane.

site_title: China's factory activity contracts for first time since Feb 2020
summary: China's factory activity contracted for the first time since February 2020, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 49.6 from 50.1 in August. This contraction is attributed to the relatively low prosperity of energy-intensive industries, exacerbated by power blackouts and local government restrictions. The move has led to concerns over the stability of the real estate sector and a potential slowdown in economic growth, with experts warning that the pace of slowdown may pick up without a change in government policies.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open slightly higher on Thursday on cheap yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by a cheaper yen that boosted Japanese exporters. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.13% and the Topix index edged up 0.04%. Traders remain cautious about a potential US government shutdown. Despite this, the benchmark indices continued their upward trend, with the Nikkei 225 reaching 29,583.13 and the Topix at 2,039.17.

site_title: Aims Apac Reit to acquire Woolsworth HQ in Sydney for A$463m
summary: Aims Apac Reit has announced its intention to acquire the Woolworths headquarters in Sydney for A$463.3 million, with the total acquisition cost reaching A$494.3 million. The property, built in 2005, is a corporate campus with significant development potential. The acquisition is expected to be transformational for the Reit, strengthening its foothold in Sydney's resilient business park market and significantly enlarging its portfolio value by 26.6%. The property will be acquired at a net property income yield of 5.17%, and the proposed acquisition is expected to be distribution per unit accretive.

site_title: Indonesia Parliament commission, government agree on major tax changes
summary: Indonesia's Parliament finance commission and government agree on major tax changes, including a value-added tax (VAT) rate change. The commission approved the changes, which will be brought to a wider parliamentary vote. The agreed-upon tax changes aim to support lower-income groups by exempting basic necessities, education, health, and social services from VAT. This move is seen as a step towards reducing the tax burden on the lower-income population.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 12.91 points, or 0.83%, to 1,534.74. Losers outnumbered gainers 247 to 139, and trading volume reached 315.36 million lots worth RM142.05 million.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.4% to 3,087.88, following a mixed trading session on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers 80 to 47, with banking stocks gaining ground. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.3%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also ended higher. Asian markets, including Tokyo, followed suit, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.1%.

site_title: Toyota's financial services arm signs S$150m transition loan with DBS to grow EV sales
summary: Toyota Financial Services Singapore has signed a S$150 million transition loan with DBS to grow electric vehicle sales in Singapore. The sustainability-linked revolving credit facility will support the adoption of more electric vehicles in the country. DBS notes that the transport sector is a significant emitter of greenhouse gases, and the loan aims to contribute to a climate-aligned future. The loan demonstrates the company's commitment to global decarbonisation efforts and enhanced access to electric vehicles in Singapore.

site_title: Australian housing credit climbs 0.6% in August
summary: Australian housing credit increased 0.6% in August, its fastest annual pace since early 2018, driven by buyers borrowing to enter the red-hot market. This lifted annual growth to 6.2% for outstanding home loans and 4.7% for total credit outstanding. Business credit also rose 0.6%, boosting annual growth to 3.4%.

site_title: Japan's Rakuten Group to start preparing for bank unit IPO
summary: Rakuten Group, a Japanese mobile phone and online shopping mall operator, plans to prepare for an initial public offering (IPO) of its online banking unit, Rakuten Bank. The IPO aims to raise funds for the fintech business and enable swift management decisions. Rakuten Bank had 186.8 billion yen in net assets as of March. Analysts believe the IPO could help mitigate financial pressures resulting from investments in the company's mobile unit. Details on the IPO size and valuation are not available.

site_title: Australia: Miners, financials help shares snap two-day loss
summary: Australia's shares advanced 1.1% to 7,274.30, snapping a two-day loss, driven by gains in miners and financials. The S&P/ASX 200 index was on track for its first quarterly loss since 2020. Heavyweight miners, including Piedmont Lithium, rose 0.7%, while financials like Zip and the "Big Four" banks gained between 1.8% and 1.6%. Despite a partial recovery in US and European markets, investors sought to mitigate losses amid a heavy sell-off.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge lower at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly lower on Thursday, following a three-day gain, due to concerns over the Evergrande crisis and US debt ceiling talks. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.69% to 24,494.26. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.16% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.64%. Investors remain cautious amid the uncertainty surrounding global markets.

site_title: 'YOLO' generation of investors is ready for anything, even a crash
summary: A new generation of young investors, known as the YOLO generation, has entered the stock market, cashing in on the booming trend despite some older investors' skepticism. Born after 1999, these investors are largely unaware of past market crashes and are confident in their portfolio decisions, with 72% feeling confident in June. However, experts warn that overconfidence and taking on debt can lead to a "wake-up call" if the market declines. Many young investors are adapting to market shifts, prioritizing lesser-known names and understanding the influence of central bank policy, which may help them better prepare for a potential crash.

site_title: Former CapitaLand chief executive Lim Ming Yan to join HDB board on Oct 1
summary: Former CapitaLand CEO Lim Ming Yan will join the Housing and Development Board (HDB) board on October 1, 2021, for a two-year term. Lim has extensive experience in the real estate industry, having served as CapitaLand's president and CEO from 2013 to 2018. He currently chairs Workforce Singapore and the Singapore Business Federation. The appointment was announced by the Ministry of National Development (MND) in a joint press statement with HDB.

site_title: Stocks to watch: iX Biopharma, Sembcorp, Keppel, Chip Eng Seng
summary: iX Biopharma inked an agreement with CRPCG for the licensing, supply, and distribution of Wafesil, a sublingual sildenafil wafer for male erectile dysfunction, in China. Sembcorp Industries successfully launched a S$675 million sustainability-linked bond with a 2.66% coupon rate. Keppel Corporation completed the construction of two offshore substations for Ørsted, supplying green power to 1 million households in Taiwan. Chip Eng Seng Corporation's subsidiary was appointed as the replacement main contractor for a Build-To-Order housing project.

site_title: New Zealand business outlook improved in September: ANZ survey
summary: New Zealand business sentiment improved in September, according to an ANZ Bank survey, with a net 7.2% of respondents expecting the economy to deteriorate over the year ahead. This is a significant improvement from the previous month's 14.2% pessimism level. Meanwhile, a net 18.2% of respondents expected their own businesses to grow in the next 12 months, down from 19.2% last month. The results suggest that New Zealand's economy is showing signs of resilience despite ongoing challenges, including the ongoing lockdown in Auckland.

images.alt_text: New Zealand business sentiment improved in September as forward-looking activity indicators remained robust, including in Auckland, which is still under a coronavirus lockdown, an ANZ Bank survey showed on Thursday.

site_title: Palihapitiya says SPAC slowdown separated 'wheat from chaff'
summary: Venture investor Chamath Palihapitiya, known as the "SPAC King," believes a recent slowdown in the SPAC market is necessary to separate "wheat from chaff." He advocates for sponsors to put up more at-risk capital, aligning their incentives with investors. Palihapitiya, who has launched 10 SPACs and backed several others, suggests that sponsors should contribute a significant portion of the SPAC's funds, rather than just receiving warrants and founder shares. He remains bullish on the long-term health of SPAC deals, calling it a "meaningful revolution in the capital markets."

site_title: Lian Beng clarifies pay of key execs is based on overall group performance
summary: Building contractor Lian Beng Group clarified that its key executives' pay for FY2021 was higher due to the group's overall improvement in profitability, despite lower net profit. The company attributed this improvement to better performance in property development and other business segments. The group's remuneration included a bonus component based on overall profitability, which was influenced by government grants and additional operating costs incurred during the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Taiwan sees upside from China power curbs if orders shifted
summary: Taiwan may benefit from potential shifts in China's exports if China's power curbs negatively impact its exports. China's power crunch, caused by tight coal supplies and emissions standards, could lead to an "order transfer effect" for Taiwan, allowing manufacturers to shift production to the island. This could provide an upside for Taiwan's economy, according to Taiwan Central Bank Governor Yang Chin-long.

site_title: CapitaLand China Trust obtains maiden S$150m sustainability-linked loan from UOB
summary: CapitaLand China Trust (CLCT) has secured a S$150 million sustainability-linked loan from UOB, its manager. The loan is based on pre-determined sustainability performance targets, including carbon emission, energy, and water usage reductions. CLCT achieved significant reductions in these areas in 2020, and the loan proceeds will be used for general working capital and corporate funding requirements. This is CLCT's maiden sustainability-linked loan, marking a significant step towards its sustainability goals.

site_title: LOGOS gets S$64.4m green loan for Tanjong Penjuru Crescent property
summary: PROPERTY group LOGOS has secured a S$64.4 million green loan to redevelop its 2 Tanjong Penjuru Crescent industrial property into a modern six-storey logistics facility. The S$108 million project, in partnership with CSC Holdings, will incorporate the property's existing sustainability features and include a high-specification workshop. The green loan, backed by Standard Chartered and RHB, includes a green interest rate swap linked to the property's green certification, which received a BCA Green Mark Platinum award in April 2021.

site_title: US 'lost' the 20-year war in Afghanistan: top US general
summary: US General Mark Milley admits the US "lost" the 20-year war in Afghanistan, stating it did not end on desired terms with the Taliban in power in Kabul. The war was deemed a strategic failure, with a cumulative effect of decisions made over two decades. Factors contributing to the US defeat include missing opportunities to capture Osama bin Laden, invading Iraq, and not effectively dealing with Pakistan as a Taliban sanctuary. The US pulled out troops in August, following an agreement reached with the Taliban by former President Donald Trump.

site_title: Japan's August factory output falls 3.2% m-o-m: government
summary: Japan's factory output declined 3.2% in August from the previous month, lower than the 0.5% decline forecast by market analysts. The Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry downgraded its assessment, stating that industrial production is "stalling." However, manufacturers expect a 0.2% growth in September and a 6.8% increase in October. This marks a mixed picture for Japan's economy, with some sectors showing resilience while others continue to struggle.

site_title: Hong Kong layoffs in line with South-east Asia strategy: YouTrip CEO
summary: YouTrip, a fintech startup, has laid off 10 employees in Hong Kong, about a third of its workforce, as part of its strategy to "double down" on South-east Asia. The move is part of the company's efforts to strengthen its Singapore office, which will house critical functions and leadership. The affected employees have been provided with outplacement support and severance. YouTrip plans to expand its workforce in Singapore, adding 50 roles for product development and engineering, and setting up an innovation lab. The CEO, Caecilia Chu, believes the layoffs won't impact growth plans.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: Singapore's central bank is expected to keep monetary policy on hold at its October review due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. Mapletree Investments acquired two US logistics portfolios for US$3 billion. Oxford Nanopore, backed by Temasek, soared 32% in its London trading debut. A new office was set up to accelerate green bond efforts, while former CapitaLand CEO Lim Ming Yan joined the HDB board on October 1. Singapore shares rose 0.4% amid a mixed regional market.

images.alt_text: MAS is expected to leave monetary policy on hold at its October review, analysts say, as highly transmissible coronavirus variants spread locally and across the world, threatening the pace of economic recovery.

site_title: Britons turn more pessimistic about outlook for economy
summary: A UK opinion poll found Britons have become more pessimistic about the economy, with 28% expecting it to be in a worse state in 12 months, up from 20% in August. Rising energy prices and inflation have put pressure on household budgets, with 50% worried about keeping their homes warm this winter and 30% struggling to meet their budgets. The Bank of England has raised its inflation forecast to above 4%, and the Confederation of British Industry reported slower growth among businesses, citing labour and materials shortages.

site_title: China's regulators tighten scrutiny of FX dealers: sources
summary: China's regulators are tightening control over the country's currency market, pressuring banks to trade less and in smaller ranges as part of a broader effort to curb speculation. The moves follow recent curbs on financial risks, including dampening commodity price rises and banning cryptocurrency transactions. The scrutiny aims to stabilize the yuan at a sensitive time when US policymakers prepare to withdraw monetary stimulus and China is poised to ease monetary policies. Regulators have embedded themselves on currency trading floors, urging banks to price customer deals faster and in tighter ranges to reduce trading banks' profit.

site_title: UK car output falls 27% in August amid chip shortage
summary: British car production plummeted 27% in August due to a global semiconductor chip shortage and summer shutdowns. Output reached 37,246 cars, with exports to Australia, US, and China declining, while sales to the EU were down 4.9% and domestic sales rose 3.3%. Carmakers and suppliers face ongoing challenges, with constraints expected to persist through 2022.

site_title: RBNZ signals interest in central bank digital currency, seeks feedback
summary: New Zealand's Reserve Bank (RBNZ) is seeking public feedback on the potential use of a central bank digital currency (CBDC). The move follows global interest in CBDCs, with many countries exploring their use. RBNZ Assistant Governor Christian Hawkesby stated that a CBDC could improve efficiency, protect monetary sovereignty, and mitigate operational risks. The bank notes declining cash use and innovative private money developments, while other central banks, such as those in Australia and Singapore, are conducting cross-border payments trials using CBDCs.

site_title: Audience Analytics debuts on Catalist at S$0.315, up 5% from IPO price
summary: Audience Analytics, a data analytics firm, debuted on the Catalist board at S$0.315, a 5% increase from its IPO price of S$0.30. The company raised S$5.5 million through its fully-subscribed IPO, with net proceeds dedicated to general working capital and business expansion. Audience Analytics aims to grow its business intelligence and growth analytics services using artificial intelligence, and posted a net profit of S$2.9 million for FY2020.

site_title: YouTube cracks down on anti-vaccine misinformation
summary: YouTube has announced it will remove videos and high-profile users spreading false claims about approved vaccines being dangerous, expanding its efforts to combat health misinformation around Covid-19 and other diseases. The platform has already banned posts about Covid-19 treatments and has removed over 130,000 videos for violating its policies. Channels of known vaccine misinformation spreaders, including Joseph Mercola, Sherri Tenpenny, and Robert F. Kennedy Jr., will be terminated. The new policy aims to address misinformation about routine immunizations and vaccines linked to chronic health effects.

images.alt_text: Video-sharing giant YouTube has already banned posts that spread false myths around coronavirus treatments, including ones that share inaccurate claims about Covid-19 vaccines shown to be safe.

site_title: Gold holds near seven-week low on robust dollar, Fed taper fears
summary: Gold prices hovered near a seven-week low due to a strong US dollar and expectations of the Federal Reserve reducing stimulus measures. Spot gold rose 0.2% to $1,729.83 per ounce, while US gold futures gained 0.4%. The dollar index steadied near a year's high, increasing gold's cost for buyers in other currencies. US central bankers, including San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank president Mary Daly and Philadelphia Fed Bank president Patrick Harker, indicated the Fed will begin reducing asset purchases by year-end, but interest rate hikes are still unlikely.

site_title: iX Biopharma inks agreement to distribute erectile dysfunction drug in China
summary: iX Biopharma has agreed to distribute Wafesil, a sublingual sildenafil wafer for erectile dysfunction treatment, in China through a 10-year licensing and distribution deal with CRPCG. The agreement allows both parties to tap into China's vast healthcare market. Under the terms, CRPCG will obtain marketing authorization, manufacture and distribute Wafesil, and make upfront and licensing fee payments to iX Biopharma. This marks the first deal between the two companies following a strategic cooperation framework agreement in April 2021.

site_title: Bank of Japan's Kuroda projects economic recovery to pre-Covid levels by early 2022
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda projects Japan's economy will recover to pre-Covid levels by the end of 2021 or early 2022, despite weak consumption and inflation below 2%. The Bank of Japan will maintain its massive stimulus regardless of the new government's policies, aiming to achieve 2% price stability. Kuroda also expressed optimism about a recovery in consumption and capital expenditure, citing steady progress on vaccinations and easing of pandemic restrictions.

site_title: Sygnum, SBI and Azimut Group launch US$75m VC fund focused on digital asset space
summary: Sygnum, SBI, and Azimut Group have launched a US$75 million venture capital fund focused on digital assets, with an emphasis on pre-Series A and Series A companies in Europe and South-east Asia. The fund will support companies developing blockchain and DLT infrastructure, decentralized finance solutions, and regulatory technology tools. With the digital asset space projected to store up to 10% of global GDP by 2027, the fund aims to capitalize on the significant venture capital inflows into the industry, citing a 6% share of global venture capital funding taken by crypto firms this year.

site_title: Britney Spears' father removed as singer's guardian
summary: Britney Spears' father, Jamie Spears, was removed as her guardian by a Los Angeles judge on Wednesday, replacing him with a temporary conservator "in the best interests" of the pop singer. The decision comes after a hearing to fully terminate the guardianship is expected before the end of the year. Jamie Spears was ordered to turn over all conservatorship assets, and a full termination of the guardianship is anticipated.

site_title: China's farmers face more pain as power crunch drives up feed costs
summary: China's livestock sector is facing increased feed costs due to power outages, which have shut down at least half of soybean crushing plants in northern and north-eastern China. This has led to a 220 yuan (S$46.30) price jump for soymeal, a critical protein in pig, chicken, and fish feed. Farmers are already struggling with low hog prices, and the price increase will further squeeze them, with pig farmers losing over 500 yuan per hog last month. The power outages are also affecting the country's growth outlook, with many analysts downgrading the economy's growth prospects.

site_title: UN Security Council to meet Thursday on North Korea: diplomats
summary: The UN Security Council is set to meet on Thursday to discuss North Korea's latest development, the testing of a new hypersonic gliding missile. The meeting, requested by the US, Britain, and France, will take place behind closed doors. The discussion aims to address the apparent advance in North Korea's nuclear-armed nation's weapons technology, but no joint statement is expected. This move comes as North Korea continues to escalate its military activities, sparking international concern. The meeting's outcome remains uncertain, but it highlights the growing tension between North Korea and the international community.

site_title: G-7 finance ministers make some progress on tax deal, UK says
summary: G-7 finance ministers reached a joint position on a landmark global corporate tax deal, with a common understanding on some key issues to support a final agreement within the OECD Inclusive Framework in October. The deal includes a global minimum corporate tax rate of 15% and measures to squeeze more money from tech giants. Progress was made on open issues, but a sticking point remains on how large multinationals should be taxed. The OECD is expected to produce updated proposals in the coming days, with a critical moment for negotiations next week.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise on AstraZeneca, ASM strength
summary: European stocks rose on Wednesday, driven by AstraZeneca's 4.2% gain after acquiring a rare disease drugmaker, and ASM's 3.9% increase after raising earnings forecasts. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.6%, despite a 2.2% decline in the previous session. Investors appeared to be undeterred by growing concerns over interest rate hikes and the global tech sector's decline. The benchmark Stoxx 600 is on course to end September 3.2% lower, but still with marginal gains on the quarter.

site_title: Central bank heads see shortages as key limit to recovery
summary: Major central bank heads say acute supply bottlenecks are driving inflation and hindering economic recovery from the pandemic. The European Central Bank's Christine Lagarde and US Federal Reserve's Jerome Powell attribute shortages in raw materials and key components to inflation, citing uncertainty around when these bottlenecks will resolve. The Bank of England's Andrew Bailey notes that these shortages are "really holding back the economy" and pose a challenge for uneven growth. The effects of these shortages are expected to persist into next year, with inflation remaining above the central banks' goals.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed as markets gird for higher interest rates
summary: US stocks were mixed on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 rising 0.3% and 0.2% respectively, while the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.2%. Investors reassessed equity bets amid expectations of higher interest rates, following a jump in US Treasury yields after the Federal Reserve signals plan to taper its bond-buying stimulus. Tech shares, including Micron Technology, dropped due to disappointment over the chip company's outlook and product shortages.

site_title: 'Tension' between jobs, inflation the chief challenge facing Federal Reserve: Powell
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell says resolving the tension between high inflation and elevated unemployment is the central bank's top priority. Powell acknowledges the potential conflict between the Fed's two goals, stable prices and full employment, and notes that managing this trade-off will be challenging. The Fed has lifted inflation forecasts for this year to 4.2%, more than twice the targeted level, and sees a pace easing in 2022 to 2.2%. Powell expects interest rate increases to be "a ways off" but notes that the Fed may need to make trade-offs between the two goals.

site_title: Should there be more transparency around pricing at property launches?
summary: A recent property launch in Singapore, Pasir Ris 8, raised questions about transparency in pricing. The 487-unit, 99-year leasehold project saw six upward price revisions in a day, with units selling for over S$2,000 per square foot. Experts suggest greater transparency, such as displaying prices upfront and implementing a cooling-off period, to ensure buyers make informed decisions. They also propose measures like registering price lists with the Urban Redevelopment Authority and providing consumers with educational resources. This could help level the playing field and improve the resale value of the property.

site_title: WP proposes changes to Singapore's draft anti-foreign interference law
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) in Singapore has proposed amendments to the draft anti-foreign interference law, aiming to increase oversight and transparency. The proposed changes include allowing appeals to the High Court, defining statutory board chief executives as "politically significant persons," and creating a public registry of such individuals. The WP's amendments also seek to clarify the definition of "politically significant persons" and ensure that the law does not stifle Singaporeans' freedom of speech. The Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) has stated that it supports the principles of the Bill but has not objected to the WP's proposed amendments.

site_title: Consensus builder Kishida set to become Japan's next PM after party vote
summary: Former Japanese Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida won the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) leadership race, virtually ensuring he will succeed Yoshihide Suga as prime minister within days. Kishida defeated Taro Kono in a second-round run-off vote, with a focus on rebuilding the economy, reducing income disparity, and strengthening security ties with the US and other partners. His consensus style is expected to help him consolidate power within the party, with a likely election by November 28, a task of rebuilding the economy after the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: The struggle to create art in a pandemic
summary: Singapore's top theatre companies are set to revive performances with at least 10 shows in October, after a year-long hiatus due to the pandemic. Theatre practitioners share their struggles, adapting to digital platforms and pivoting to new formats. Despite the challenges of falling income and unemployment, they express joy in the creative process. The Singapore Writers Fest is also upcoming, while a home designed for a multi-generational family showcases innovative design solutions.

site_title: Oil prices slip as US inventories rise, despite Opec's slow road to adding supply
summary: Oil prices slipped on Wednesday, with Brent crude settling down 45 cents to $78.64 a barrel and US oil prices ending down 46 cents to $74.83 a barrel. US crude inventories rose by 4.6 million barrels, exceeding expectations, despite Opec's plan to maintain its slow supply addition. The US dollar's strength also pressured the market, making oil more expensive worldwide. US oil production has not recovered to pre-Hurricane Ida levels, and Opec is unlikely to increase supply beyond its existing 400,000 barrels per day deal.

site_title: Lucid to start deliveries of electric cars in Oct with higher range than Tesla
summary: US startup Lucid Group Inc will start delivering luxury electric sedans with a driving range of 837km, surpassing Tesla's Model S, in late October. The company has received over 13,000 reservations and aims to produce 90,000 vehicles per year. Lucid's top-end Lucid Air Dream Edition boasts a higher range and has received a government rating, leading to a 23% jump in shares. CEO Peter Rawlinson attributes the company's advantage to battery technology and costs, but notes that cost effectiveness remains a challenge.

site_title: Amazon launches Astro, a voice-controlled robot
summary: Amazon has unveiled Astro, a voice-controlled robot that can autonomously patrol homes and respond to voice commands. The device, priced at $1,000, features a screen on wheels, embedded cameras, and a periscope to expand its field of view. Astro will be sold on an invitation-only basis and will cost $1,500 after the initial price. The robot is part of Amazon's efforts to expand its smart-home gadget market, which has seen significant growth with its voice-controlled Echo smart speakers and Alexa software.

site_title: US debt crisis looms with solution elusive in deeply divided Washington
summary: The US government is on the verge of a debt default, with Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warning that it will run out of cash on October 18 unless Congress raises the federal borrowing cap. The debt limit was reinstated on August 1 with the country's debt at $28.4 trillion. Lawmakers are divided, with Democrats seeking to raise the cap without Republican support, while Republicans refuse to help due to disagreements over spending plans. The impasse has fueled a selloff on Wall Street, with investors warning of dire consequences, including a debt default that could plunge the economy into a death spiral.

site_title: Three more UK power suppliers collapse as energy crisis deepens
summary: Three UK power suppliers, Igloo Energy Supply, Enstroga, and Symbio Energy, have collapsed amid the country's energy crisis, taking the total number of utilities to ten in the past two months. The 233,000 customers of the three utilities will be allocated another supplier by regulator Ofgem, with about 1.6 million customers forced to switch supplier since August due to rising gas and power prices. Energy regulators and business minister Kwasi Kwarteng warn of more supplier collapses this winter, citing the "extreme price shock" caused by high gas prices.

site_title: Covid hit F&B hard, consider their input for new measures
summary: A Singaporean restaurant owner, Ivan Brehm, criticizes the government's COVID-19 measures, arguing they unfairly target the food and beverage industry. However, experts note that dining in restaurants increases the risk of COVID-19 transmission due to close proximity and airborne transmission. A group of over 500 restaurants and local companies has proposed feasible solutions to revive the industry. Authorities are advised to adopt measures that balance restrictions on dining with the need for fiscal aid to the struggling industry.

site_title: Oceanus jumps 17.6% after exiting SGX watch list
summary: Oceanus Group, a seafood supplier, jumped 17.6% to a three-month high after exiting the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) watch list. The group, which had been on the list since 2015, demonstrated profitability since 2020 and recorded a net profit of $5 million in the first half of 2021. Its total market capitalisation stands at $971.9 million. Oceanus has been granted four extensions to exit the watch list and has submitted audited financial statements and a consolidated segmental profit and loss statement to SGX.

site_title: China targets Evergrande risks with 10b yuan bank deal
summary: China has agreed to purchase a 20% stake in Shengjing Bank from embattled developer Evergrande Group for 10 billion yuan, aiming to limit financial sector contagion. The sale will settle debts with the lender, but won't directly aid Evergrande in paying massive debts to bond holders and homebuyers. The move is part of China's efforts to mitigate risks in the financial sector.

site_title: Hatten Land agrees to operate 1,000 crypto mining rigs in Malaysia
summary: Hatten Land, a Singapore-based property developer, has agreed to operate 1,000 cryptocurrency mining rigs in Malaysia, repurposing its retail mall infrastructure in Melaka. The rigs will be built in phases from 2021 and will generate proceeds for the company and its joint venture partner, Frontier Digital Asset Management. This venture aims to utilize existing retail mall space for digital activities such as crypto mining and e-commerce.

site_title: Parade of the 'minis' on Indo-Pacific's geostrategic fashion runways
summary: A growing trend in the Indo-Pacific region is the emergence of "minilateral" alliances, where a small group of countries collaborate on critical issues. This approach is seen as more effective than traditional multilateral organizations, which have struggled to achieve global cooperation due to bureaucratic inefficiencies and conflicting interests. Examples of minilaterals include the Quadrilateral Security Dialogue, the Lancang-Mekong Cooperation Mechanism, and the Malacca Straits Patrol arrangement. While minilaterals have the potential to address specific threats and urgent issues, concerns remain about their impact on global governance and the potential for rival blocs to form.

site_title: No time to wait, as world premiere for new Bond movie finally happens
summary: Daniel Craig walked the red carpet for the world premiere of the new James Bond film, No Time To Die, in rain-swept London. The film, Craig's fifth and final outing as Bond, was repeatedly postponed due to the pandemic and will be released in cinemas only, with theaters hoping to attract audiences. The film marks a new era for the franchise, with a diverse cast and a darker tone, and speculation is mounting over who will take over the role of Bond. The film is set to be released in Britain, Singapore, and the US on October 8.

site_title: Dollar at 2021 highs even as US govt shutdown looms
summary: The US dollar reached a 2021 peak against rival currencies despite a looming US government shutdown, driven by investor concerns over a global slowdown, rising energy prices, and higher US Treasury yields. The dollar index rose 0.3% to 93.990, its highest level since November 2020, while the euro fell 0.4% to an 11-month low. Traders are watching for signs of policy support withdrawal from central banks, with the Federal Reserve and European Central Bank panelists scheduled to discuss at an ECB forum.

site_title: Vietnam's 2021 GDP outlook at risk as virus curbs crimp
summary: Vietnam's 2021 GDP growth outlook is at risk due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, with the country's statistics office forecasting a 2.5% growth rate, below the official target of 6.5%. Tough anti-virus policies have disrupted supply chains, shuttered factories, and crimped output, particularly in the export-dependent economy. The government's official target range of 6-6.5% growth is considered "impossible" now, and economists predict a slow recovery if the virus is not well controlled.

site_title: Banks are really cashing in on ESG bonds
summary: Banks are generating more money from underwriting ESG-related bond sales than from issuing debt for fossil-fuel companies. In 2021, banks earned $3.6 billion in fees from ESG bond sales, more than double the $1.6 billion from fossil-fuel debt sales. This trend is driven by growing demand for environmentally-friendly bonds and regulatory pressures to address climate change. Top banks, including JPMorgan Chase and BNP Paribas, are increasingly relying on ESG-related debt instruments, with some generating up to 31% of their debt underwriting fees from ESG sources.

site_title: Kitchen Culture to unwind unapproved payment; CAD report lodged against interim CEO
summary: Kitchen Culture Holdings, a Singapore-based household furniture distributor, is unwinding two transactions and a transfer of $480,010 to support e-commerce merchants without board approval. The company has also lodged a report with the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) against interim CEO Lincoln Teo, alleging he carried out the transfer without requisite approval. Former CEO Lim Wee Li lodged the report, which is now under investigation by the CAD. The board will cooperate with authorities if needed.

site_title: China seeks to quell power crunch fears, as coal prices soar, winter nears
summary: China's state planner has urged railway companies and local authorities to rapidly transport vital coal supplies to utilities amid a power crunch in key regions, particularly in the northeast. The order comes as coal prices soar to record highs, threatening industrial output and household heating. Power rationing has been implemented in some areas, and officials have sought to reassure residents that power will be available for household use and heating. China is considering increasing industrial power prices and has signed medium- and long-term coal contracts to ensure supply.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corporation's subsidiary CES Engineering & Construction has been appointed as the replacement main contractor for the Build-To-Order housing project at Marsiling Grove in Woodlands. Four contractors, including Teambuild Engineering & Construction and Newcon Builders, will complete the construction works after former main contractors went bust. Keppel Corporation completed the construction of two offshore substations for Ørsted in Taiwan, contributing to the supply of green power to one million households. Kitchen Culture Holdings is unwinding transactions and transferring funds without board approval, amid allegations of misconduct by its interim CEO.

site_title: Importance of 'greening' Singapore's power mix
summary: Singapore aims to peak carbon by 2030 and halve it by 2050, with plans to incorporate more renewable energy sources like solar and regional power grids. Solar is considered the most promising renewable energy solution, but faces challenges like intermittency and land scarcity. The government targets 3% of solar energy supply by 2030 and is investing in energy storage solutions and innovative projects to overcome space constraints. Regional grids, like the Laos-Thailand-Malaysia-Singapore Power Integration Project, also offer potential benefits, with financiers like OCBC setting targets to support green projects.

site_title: What's gone wrong in the fight against vaccine nationalism?
summary: Covax, a global COVID-19 vaccine-sharing program, is struggling to meet its initial forecast of 2 billion doses by the end of 2021, with only 280.5 million doses distributed as of September 15. The program's shortfall is attributed to vaccine nationalism, with high-income countries prioritizing booster shots and vaccinating children before low-income countries receive their first doses. The WHO has called for a moratorium on boosters until the end of 2021 to address vaccine inequality, but national priorities continue to override global needs.

site_title: Temasek and HSBC team up to catalyse infrastructure projects
summary: Temasek and HSBC have partnered to establish a debt financing platform focused on sustainable infrastructure projects in South-east Asia. The platform aims to dispense over US$1 billion of loans within five years, targeting renewable energy, water treatment, and sustainable transport projects. The joint investment of up to US$150 million will help bridge the significant funding gap in Asia for sustainable infrastructure, addressing climate change challenges. The partnership, supported by the Asian Development Bank and Clifford Capital Holdings, seeks to catalyze significant capital flows to the sustainable infrastructure space.

images.alt_text: "Neither private nor public sector can close the financing gap alone - but by working with Temasek, the ADB and Clifford Capital, we can deploy significant amounts of blended finance for projects... that would otherwise go unfunded." - Noel Quinn, HSBC's group CEO.

site_title: How an 11-foot-tall 3D printer is helping to create a community
summary: In Nacajuca, Mexico, a community of 500 3D-printed homes is being built by New Story, a San Francisco non-profit organization, in partnership with Echale and Icon. The homes, which were made using an 11-foot-tall 3D printer, are designed to be durable and withstand natural disasters. The project is part of a growing trend in the 3D printing industry, which is expected to reach $55.8 billion by 2027. The homes are being built at a cost of $167.05 per month, significantly reducing the cost of housing in the region, where half of the residents live below the poverty line.

site_title: All falls down: Is Biden facing a perfect storm?
summary: US President Joe Biden is facing a "perfect storm" of challenges, including a Delta-driven surge in COVID-19 cases, a fiscal crisis, and growing humanitarian problems at the southern border. His approval ratings have surprisingly tied with those of former President Donald Trump, with 48% of respondents favoring Trump and 46% favoring Biden. This shift has emboldened Trump to consider a 2024 presidential run, and Republicans are exploiting Biden's problems to block his spending bills and potentially lead to a government shutdown and economic catastrophe.

site_title: Walmart to hire 150,000 US store workers ahead of holiday season
summary: Walmart plans to hire 150,000 US store workers, mostly permanent and full-time, ahead of the holiday season. The move comes as retailers offer pay raises and incentives to retain staff. This is similar to rival Target's decision to provide extra work hours for its retail employees. The hiring effort aims to ensure sufficient staffing during the peak holiday shopping period, which starts after Thanksgiving.

site_title: Global inflation adding to Singapore business, consumer woes
summary: Singapore's economy is facing potential price pressures due to global supply chain disruptions and rising commodity prices, despite the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) restrained inflation outlook. Wholesale prices have risen sharply, with input costs for firms increasing at a faster rate than prices charged to clients, squeezing margins. Manufacturers face higher production costs, and the regional producer price index has climbed to levels last seen in the global financial crisis. However, some experts believe Singapore's economy can manage inflation, and a rapid economic recovery could offset price pressures, driven by demand and vaccination efforts.

images.alt_text: Selena Ling of OCBC says: "Global supply chain disruptions, being reflected in shortage of key components and/or delayed production, as well as higher shipping costs, have contributed to rising input cost."

site_title: Underinsurance against climate change puts Asia's growth at risk
summary: Climate change poses a significant risk to Asia's growth, with the region facing a substantial gap between insured losses and actual losses. Insured losses from natural catastrophes in Asia have been under 5% of overall losses since 1980, with emerging markets having even lower insurance penetration rates. Experts, including Munich Re and Allianz, warn that underinsurance is prevalent in Asia, particularly in South-east Asia, and that the region's growth could be undermined by its lack of insurance coverage. Improving technology and risk assessment are seen as key solutions to address the growing impact of climate change.

site_title: Filipino boxer Pacquiao quits boxing with the presidency in his sights
summary: Philippine boxing legend Manny Pacquiao announced his retirement from boxing to pursue a presidential bid, citing the "hardest decision" of his life. The 42-year-old, who has a 62-8 win-loss record, thanked his fans and trainer Freddie Roach before retiring. Pacquiao, a senator and 2022 presidential hopeful, aims to tackle poverty and corruption, but his ambition faces criticism, with detractors questioning his intellect and ability to lead the country.

site_title: Building an AI-enabled Asean for the intelligent revolution
summary: South-east Asia is in its infancy when it comes to Artificial Intelligence (AI), with only 15% of businesses in the advanced stages of AI implementation. Despite its potential to address everyday issues, AI adoption is hindered by inadequate data infrastructure, outdated data, and lack of investment. To overcome these challenges, organizations must break down silos, invest in workforce retraining, and encourage knowledge sharing. With the potential to uplift 10-18% of the region's GDP by 2030, South-east Asia is at a critical juncture to take the lead on the intelligent revolution and harness the benefits of AI.

site_title: G-20 extraordinary meeting on Afghanistan to be held on Oct 12
summary: Italy's Prime Minister Mario Draghi announced an extraordinary G-20 meeting on Afghanistan for October 12 to discuss strategies for the crisis. The meeting, which will also involve Qatar, the IMF, World Bank, and UN, comes amid concerns over the risk of migrants and the Taliban's human rights record. The Taliban has announced plans to restore severe punishment, including amputations and executions, and curb women's rights, making recognition of the administration impossible for Rome. The meeting aims to lay down a strategy to prevent Afghanistan from becoming a haven for militants and avoid a humanitarian catastrophe.

site_title: Argentina to restart beef exports to China
summary: Argentina has lifted a cap on beef exports to China, allowing cattle farmers to freely export beef to the top consumer of the meat. The move comes after protests and threats by farmers to halt local trading in cattle and grains. The cap, imposed earlier this year, was intended to reduce rising prices, but analysts say China primarily buys a beef cut not popular in the domestic Argentine market. The decision is seen as a relief for farmers, with the head of the Coninagro association calling it "the message that producers needed."

site_title: Yves Saint Laurent returns to Eiffel Tower runway
summary: French fashion house Yves Saint Laurent returned to the Eiffel Tower runway for its first in-person fashion show in over a year and a half, as part of Paris Fashion Week. The show featured skin-tight bodysuits and sharply tailored eveningwear, with models walking down a catwalk under the glittering monument. The event marked the return of in-person fashion shows in the industry, which were paused during the peak of the Covid-19 pandemic. The show was attended by celebrities, including K-pop star Rose and French actress Catherine Deneuve, and was well-received by the audience.

site_title: Poorest nations should not be left behind in race to net-zero emissions
summary: The world's poorest nations are at risk of being left behind in the global transition to net-zero emissions, despite accounting for 63% of global emissions. Developing countries need significant funding to aid their net-zero transition, with the International Institute for Environment and Development estimating they require $200 billion from 2020 to 2025. The COP26 conference must deliver on promises for a "fair, equitable and robust" response to climate change, with nearly 100 developing countries endorsing a five-point plan for solidarity, fairness, and prosperity.

site_title: H&M takes aim at US$293b market for branded merchandise
summary: H&M launches Creator Studio, a platform that allows musicians to sell branded merchandise globally through on-demand printing. The venture aims to tap into the $293 billion licensed merchandise market. Creator Studio partners with Sweden's Doors, a platform for artists to manage online concerts and fan engagement. The service offers a risk-free revenue opportunity for musicians, with a minimum order of one item that can be fulfilled within days. This move allows creators to focus on building meaningful relationships with fans while limiting financial risk.

site_title: London taxi drivers say fuel crisis isn't getting better
summary: London taxi drivers say a fuel crisis is worsening, with nearly a week of panic-buying failing to alleviate shortages. Most fuel sites remain shut, with long queues and disputes among drivers. The Licensed Taxi Drivers Association (LTDA) has requested a government order to restrict refuelling to key workers, but this has been met with dismissal, with the government stating it's not a national emergency. As a result, 20-25% of LTDA members have been forced to stay off work, with some waiting in line for hours to find petrol.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore office rents rose 0.2% in Q3, marking the first increase since Q4 2019, according to Knight Frank's quarterly office market bulletin. The prime-grade office rents in Raffles Place/Marina Bay precinct increased to S$9.98 per square foot per month. Meanwhile, a 70,302 sq ft Hillview redevelopment site is up for collective sale at S$106m, and US$2t is needed over the next decade to green South-east Asia's infrastructure. Dyson posted a 6% rise in FY2020 revenue and kickstarted a £2.75b investment programme.

images.alt_text: The real estate consultancy firm reported that prime-grade office rents in the Raffles Place/Marina Bay precinct grew for the first time since Q4 2019, with rents rising by 0.2 per cent quarter on quarter (qoq) to S$9.98 per square foot per month.

site_title: Four contractors roped in to finish five BTO projects after Greatearth went bust
summary: Four contractors, Teambuild Engineering & Construction, Newcon Builders, Welltech Construction, and CES Engineering & Construction, have taken over finishing five Build-To-Order (BTO) housing projects that Greatearth Construction and Corporation could not complete due to liabilities. The projects, which involve nearly 3,000 buyers, are expected to be completed between 2022 and 2023, with a two- to three-month delay. Greatearth owed at least S$70 million to creditors, and its liquidators worked closely with the Housing Board to bring on new contractors quickly.

site_title: JPMorgan's Erdoes says bank has a 'lot of stamina' for China
summary: JPMorgan's CEO, Mary Erdoes, stated that China remains an investment opportunity despite concerns over a regulatory crackdown and Evergrande's debt troubles. Erdoes said the bank has "a lot of stamina" for staying in China, citing the lack of concern among analysts, traders, and portfolio managers on the ground. JPMorgan has recently won approval for full ownership of its China securities venture and taken control of a Chinese mutual fund joint venture, amid global firms capitalizing on China's opening financial market.

site_title: Carousell needs to scale up quickly in property, auto verticals as it mulls exit strategy
summary: Carousell, a Singapore-based online classifieds platform, is expanding into high-ticket categories such as property and autos to boost growth. The company plans to spend $100 million on acquisitions, including potential buyouts of used car platforms like sgCarMart in Singapore. To gain market share, Carousell needs to perfect the user experience, build credibility and security, and develop an aggressive pricing structure. The company's valuation has reached $1.1 billion, and it aims to achieve profitability within the next three to four years. A public listing or trade sale is also being considered as an exit strategy.

images.alt_text: Carousell is said to be considering a public listing in the US through a merger with a special-purpose acquisition company, according to a Bloomberg report in June.

site_title: Hong Kong government to wind up Lai's Next Digital media group
summary: Hong Kong's Financial Secretary Paul Chan has submitted a petition to wind up Next Digital, the media group owned by jailed tycoon Jimmy Lai, citing public interest. The move follows an investigation report and evidence from the Securities and Futures Commission, which also believes it's in the public interest to wind up the company. Next Digital had previously aimed to go into liquidation and its board of directors had resigned. The company's assets were frozen and shares suspended from trading since June.

site_title: Vietnam's lockdown hits big brands
summary: Vietnam's prolonged coronavirus lockdown has disrupted global supply chains, causing shortages among major brands like Nike and Gap, which rely heavily on the country's manufacturers. Lockdowns, checkpoints, and travel restrictions have created long delays, affecting truck drivers and businesses trying to move goods in and out of the country. The crisis has also impacted the textile industry, coffee supplies, and car production, with companies like Toyota slashing production due to virus issues. The lockdown is expected to have a long-term impact on Vietnamese manufacturing, with many brands considering temporary production elsewhere.

images.alt_text: From shoes and sweaters to car parts and coffee, Vietnam's strict and lengthy coronavirus lockdown has sparked product shortages among worldwide brands such as Nike and Gap which have grown increasingly dependent on the South-east Asian nation's manufacturers.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher after steep losses
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, rebounding from the previous day's losses, as Treasury bond yields retreated. The Dow Jones rose 0.1%, the S&P 500 advanced 0.3%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index climbed 0.5%. The gains came despite ongoing budget talks in Washington, which have raised concerns of a default on US government debt and a potential government shutdown. Market participants are cautiously optimistic, citing a history of brinksmanship leading to last-minute agreements that avert a default.

site_title: Rolls Royce announces fully electric car for late 2023
summary: Rolls-Royce has announced its first fully electric car, the "Spectre", set to be available in late 2023. The luxury vehicle will be part of the brand's plan to transition to all-electric vehicles by 2030. CEO Torsten Mueller-Otvoes emphasized that the Spectre is not a prototype and will be tested in the fourth quarter of 2023, with first deliveries expected in the same period. The announcement follows the brand's previous presentation of two electric-powered prototype models.

site_title: Temasek-backed ABC World Asia leads US$100m round in Indian online tutoring company
summary: ABC World Asia, backed by Temasek, has led a $100 million Series E funding round in Indian online tutoring company Vedantu. Vedantu, founded in 2014, offers live online classes across K-12 and test preparation segments. The funding is expected to close in the next few weeks, with ABC World Asia citing Vedantu's innovative technology and focus on improving educational outcomes as reasons for the investment. This is the fund's second investment in India this year, following a January investment in agritech company Cropin.

site_title: Eight more die from Covid-19 complications; 2,268 new cases in Singapore
summary: Eight Singaporeans aged 72-90 have died from Covid-19 complications, with six unvaccinated and two partially vaccinated. The total number of deaths this month stands at 38, and 93 since the start of the pandemic. 2,268 new cases were reported, with 1,810 in the community and 448 among dormitory residents. The total number of cases in Singapore now stands at 94,043, surpassing 2,000 cases for the first time.

site_title: HSBC appoints ex-Google exec as Singapore-based head of platforms for commercial banking
summary: HSBC appoints Aman Narain, former Google executive, as head of platforms for global commercial banking based in Singapore. Narain previously led digital and marketing transformation at Schroders and held leadership positions at Standard Chartered. His role will focus on embedding solutions into digital platforms used by clients, aligning with HSBC's strategy to leverage digital adoption.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.83 points to 1,547.65 on Wednesday, with 3.668 billion lots traded worth RM2.711 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 580 to 398.

site_title: Samsung fined US$47m for price fixing in Netherlands
summary: Samsung has been fined US$46.9 million by the Netherlands' competition watchdog ACM for price fixing in the country. The electronics maker allegedly urged retailers to raise prices of its televisions if they were sold below Samsung's preferred market rate, undermining competition among online stores. Samsung maintained it did not force retailers to use its price advice, but the regulator found its behavior distorted competition and raised prices for consumers. Samsung plans to appeal the fine.

site_title: Deutsche Bank hiring spree marks its return to junk credit swaps
summary: Deutsche Bank is resuming its trading of credit-default swaps, specifically targeting high-yield space, after six years of absence. The move aims to gain an edge over competitors in Europe and the US, where liquidity in the cash bond market is decreasing. The bank has hired 24 traders to focus on this area, signaling a return to the asset class. This move is part of Deutsche Bank's broader strategy to increase revenue growth and follows a cost-cutting drive.

site_title: World food costs at risk of soaring as China faces tough harvest
summary: China is facing a difficult harvest season due to a severe energy crunch, which may lead to a surge in world agriculture and food prices. The country's top agricultural provinces, including Jilin, Liaoning, and Heilongjiang, are particularly affected, with some plants asked to suspend or cut output to conserve electricity.
