Analysts highlight "buy" rated stocks Press Metal, OM Holdings, and Malaysia Smelting Corp as potential beneficiaries of a commodity super-cycle. The 12MP aims to turn Malaysia into a high-income economy by 2025 and eradicate abject poverty.

site_title: AA Reit's Koh Wee Lih to join Keppel Reit manager as CEO
summary: Keppel Reit's manager announced Jude Chan's replacement, Koh Wee Lih, as its new CEO starting Dec 1, following Paul Tham's departure on Oct 20. Koh Wee Lih brings over 25 years of experience in real estate investment, asset management, and redevelopment. He will succeed Paul Tham, who is stepping down to pursue other opportunities. Units of Keppel Reit closed flat on the news, while AA Reit's units closed down 0.7%.

site_title: Brokers' take: KGI starts coverage on LHN with 'outperform', S$0.49 target
summary: KGI Securities has initiated coverage on LHN Limited with an "outperform" recommendation and a target price of S$0.49, citing the growing co-living trend, reopening borders, and shipping industry boom as key drivers of the company's growth. Analyst Megan Choo expects solid FY2022 revenue growth from LHN's space optimisation and facilities management segments, as well as its logistics management segment. LHN's shares closed 6.4% higher at 33.5 cents on the news.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as miners drag on China power concerns
summary: Australian shares ended lower on Tuesday, falling 1.47% to 7,275.6 points, dragged down by heavyweight miners amid concerns over China's power shortage. Major miners BHP Group, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals fell between 2.3% and 5.6%, while technology stocks fell 2.85%. Energy shares rose 4.34%, led by Beach Energy and Oil Search, amid concerns over tight oil supply.

site_title: Colosseum kits and plastic flowers help Lego's earnings double
summary: Lego has doubled its earnings in the first six months of 2021, driven by strong sales of its Star Wars building sets and flower bouquets made from plastic bricks. The company's physical stores have seen a resurgence in traffic and revenue, with 174 new stores planned this year. Despite rising costs, Lego's operating profit more than doubled to 8 billion Danish crowns, while revenue grew 46% to 23 billion crowns. The company attributes its success to its physical store presence, which it believes will continue to attract new customers.

site_title: China's domestic aviation manufacturers see expansion in post-pandemic boom
summary: China's domestic aviation manufacturers are expected to gain a larger share of the market due to the country's post-pandemic boom in travel. The Airshow China exhibition in Zhuhai showcased China's growing aviation industry, with Commercial Aircraft Corp of China (COMAC) ramping up production of the 90-seat ARJ21 regional jet. The country's aviation regulator may hinder foreign plane-makers, such as Airbus and Embraer, from gaining certification and sales. COMAC forecasts a need for 953 regional jets over the next 20 years, and the country's policies favor home-grown planes.

site_title: JTC launches industrial site at Gambas Way for tender
summary: JTC has launched a site at Gambas Way (Plot 3) for tender, marking the second of four confirmed list sites for the second half of 2021 under the industrial government land sales (IGLS) programme. The site will be available for sale regardless of demand, following the IGLS programme's schedule. This move aims to provide developers with opportunities to acquire industrial land.

site_title: Adnoc completes bookbuilding for drilling unit IPO raising over US$1.1b
summary: Adnoc, the state oil giant of Abu Dhabi, has completed bookbuilding for the IPO of its drilling unit, Adnoc Drilling, raising over US$1.1 billion. The offering was oversubscribed, with total gross demand exceeding US$34 billion. The IPO will be the largest ever listed on the Abu Dhabi Securities Exchange, bolstering the UAE's equity capital markets. Adnoc will retain an 84% majority stake in the unit, while Baker Hughes will hold 5%, and Helmerich & Payne will hold 1% through its IPO cornerstone investment.

site_title: Europe: Tech slide, China woes weigh on stocks
summary: European stocks fell 0.4% on Tuesday, marking a third consecutive decline, due to a surge in government bond yields and concerns over China's slowing economy. The slowdown in profit growth at China's industrial firms, coupled with a power crisis threat, weighed on investor sentiment. Technology stocks fell 1.9% as banks received support from rising interest rates. Energy stocks rose 1.1% due to a rally in Brent crude futures above $80 per barrel, while mining and healthcare shares were among the few bright spots.

site_title: Temasek-backed Vertex expects at least US$400m in new South-east Asia/India fund
summary: Vertex Ventures, backed by Singapore's Temasek, plans to raise at least $400 million for its next fund focusing on South-east Asia and India, with the goal of deploying it in 2023. The firm, which has $5 billion in assets under management, has a history of successful investments, including Grab, Nium, and HappyFresh. As capital pours into the region, Vertex expects valuations to correct, but notes that India and South-east Asia are attractive investment opportunities.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end lower on Evergrande, China power shortage worries
summary: South Korean stocks closed lower on Tuesday, following broader Asian markets, due to concerns over China Evergrande Group's fate and a widening power shortage. The Kospi fell 35.72 points or 1.14% to 3,097.92, with chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix declining 1.80% and 0.96%, respectively. The won weakened to a one-year low, and the benchmark bond yield rose. Foreigners were net buyers of 10.7 billion won worth of shares, while US Treasury yields touched a three-month high.

site_title: Japan's Chubu Electric to buy 20% stake in Vietnam renewable energy firm Bitexco
summary: Japan's Chubu Electric Power Co will buy a 20% stake in Vietnamese renewable energy firm Bitexco Power Corp for an undisclosed sum. The move aims to gain a foothold in Vietnam's growing renewable energy market and expand its green energy portfolio. This comes after Chubu's joint venture with Tokyo Electric Power Company Holdings, JERA, invested US$1.58 billion in the Philippines to boost its presence in the country. The deal is part of Japan's efforts to increase its renewable energy investments in Southeast Asia.

site_title: Singapore should step up to help emerging countries with net-zero transition, says BlackRock CEO
summary: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink urges Singapore to play a key role in facilitating the global transition to net-zero emissions, particularly for emerging countries. Fink believes Singapore's success and advanced economy give it a responsibility to contribute to the dialogue and provide financing for emerging nations. He estimates that the global energy transition may require up to $50 trillion in capital, with public-private partnerships being crucial to move the needle. Fink also emphasizes the need to lower the "green premium" to make sustainable projects more viable.

site_title: South-east Asia startup deals hit record high in H1: report
summary: South-east Asia saw a record high of 393 startup investments in the first half of 2021, with a total of US$4.4 billion raised. This represents a 19% increase from the same period last year. However, the number of mega-deals (above US$100 million) decreased significantly, accounting for only 45% of investments. Indonesian startups received the majority of the capital, followed by Singapore startups. Despite lower total capital raised, the region attracted more capital than Latin America but less than India.

site_title: For Asean economies, key response to global tax reforms should be to improve non-tax draws: report
summary: Asean economies should focus on improving non-tax competitiveness to counter global tax reforms, according to a report by the Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office (AMRO). The proposed global minimum tax rate of 15% may harm economies with lower tax rates, while populous countries like China and Japan are likely to benefit. Economies such as Indonesia, Malaysia, and Vietnam may need to raise their non-tax attractiveness to continue attracting foreign investment.

site_title: Airlines demand virus-busting seats to ease Covid deep-cleaning
summary: Airlines are demanding the use of virus-busting seats to ease deep-cleaning procedures, citing the time and cost constraints of current protocols. Industry lobby IATA recommends using vacuum cleaners, wipes, and disinfecting belts and buckles to maintain cleanliness. Companies like Safran are conducting tests on fabrics with integrated biocides, and sprays that can be applied to existing seats, aiming to lighten procedures and reduce costs. The development of virus-killing seat coverings could help reduce the $4.2 billion jet-seat market's reliance on manual cleaning, easing the industry's recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Nintendo says 'Donkey Kong' area to open in Universal Studios Japan in 2024
summary: Nintendo plans to open a "Donkey Kong" themed expansion in its "Super Nintendo World" at Universal Studios Japan in Osaka, Japan in 2024. The area will feature a roller coaster, interactive experiences, and a 70% increase in themed space. This follows the opening of a "Super Mario" themed area earlier this year, which was delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Alibaba offers WeChat Pay on some apps at Beijing's behest
summary: Alibaba has added WeChat Pay as a payment option on some of its apps, including Ele.me, Damai, and Kaola, following Beijing's request. This move widens the gap between Alibaba's and Tencent's ecosystems. WeChat Pay is not available on Alibaba's flagship Taobao app, but the company is working to introduce multiple payment methods on the platform. The move aims to better serve consumers and find common ground with peers, despite the ongoing rivalry between the two internet giants.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end lower
summary: Tokyo stocks ended lower on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index slipping 0.19% and the Topix index falling 0.29%. The decline was driven by falls in high-tech shares, amid investors' concerns over a potential US government shutdown. The benchmark indices closed at 30,183.96 and 2,081.77, respectively.

site_title: Microsoft CEO says failed TikTok deal 'strangest thing I've worked on'
summary: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella described the failed TikTok deal as "the strangest thing I've ever worked on". The deal collapsed in September 2020 after then-US President Donald Trump ordered TikTok to separate its US version from Chinese parent ByteDance due to national security concerns. Nadella expressed interest in bringing Microsoft's security and cloud expertise to TikTok, but noted the deal's collapse and the uncertainty surrounding current US government efforts to review national security concerns.

images.alt_text: Microsoft's near-acquisition of social media app TikTok last year was the "strangest thing I've ever worked on", chief executive officer Satya Nadella said on Monday.

site_title: Singapore's population shrinks 4.1% y-o-y to 5.45m in June 2021 due to Covid-19
summary: Singapore's population decreased 4.1% to 5.45 million in June 2021, the first year-on-year decline since data collection began in 1970, due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The citizen population dropped 0.7% to 3.5 million, while permanent residents fell 6.2% to 490,000. The non-resident population also declined 10.7% to 1.47 million, mainly due to foreign employment decreases. The median age of the citizen population increased to 42.5 years, and the proportion of those 65 and above is expected to reach 23.8% by 2030.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
This is the first time there has been a year-on-year decrease in both the citizen and resident populations since these data were first collected in 1970.

site_title: China's industrial profit growth slows for sixth month in Aug
summary: China's industrial profit growth slowed for the sixth consecutive month in August, rising 10.1% year-over-year to 680.3 billion yuan. The slowdown is attributed to high commodity prices, Covid-19 outbreaks, and shortages of key components. Industrial production rose at its slackest pace since July 2020, with momentum weakened by domestic Covid-19 outbreaks, high raw material prices, and a campaign to cut carbon emissions. China's vast manufacturing sector faces gathering headwinds, with experts predicting further declines in industrial profit growth in coming months.

site_title: Advent seeking US$500m from The Learning Lab sale
summary: US private-equity firm Advent International is considering selling its Southeast Asian operations of The Learning Lab, a Singapore-based tutorial centre chain, with a minimum sale price of US$500 million. The sale process is being worked on with Rothschild & Co. and discussions are at an early stage. Advent invested in The Learning Lab in 2014 and has a significant stake in the company, which operates in Singapore and several other countries. The sale decision has not been made, and the company's representative declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: Singapore's Forge Ventures launches debut US$21.9m fund
summary: Singapore-based venture capital firm Forge Ventures has launched its debut fund, raising US$21.9 million at first close. The fund has led three investments across three countries, including Vouch, Dropezy, and Marathon. It has a limited partner base of founders and operators of technology companies, including Airbnb, Carousell, and Grab. Over the next three years, Forge Ventures aims to build a concentrated portfolio of 15 companies, focusing on Singapore and Indonesia, with a goal of supporting founders closely through its network of collaborators and advisers.

site_title: Brent crude price jumps above US$80 a barrel
summary: Brent crude oil prices jumped above $80 a barrel for the first time in almost three years, driven by surging demand and supply concerns as the world recovers from the pandemic. The price increase, 0.9% in morning Asian trade, is attributed to the easing of lockdowns and vaccination rollout, as well as an energy crunch in the northern hemisphere. Crude stockpiles have shrunk, and despite Opec and other major producers increasing output, the rally in the commodity shows no signs of slowing, with experts predicting it still has "legs".

site_title: F&B, retail outlets in Singapore's CBD hurt by work-from-home measures
summary: F&B and retail outlets in Singapore's central business district (CBD) have been severely impacted by the month-long work-from-home directive, which began on September 27. Sales have plummeted, with some businesses estimating a 20-80% decline, as customers shift to online platforms or stay home. Many establishments have been forced to close temporarily or reduce staff, with some considering salary cuts or reducing store hours. The prolonged uncertainty over the return of the office crowd has left businesses in the CBD feeling frustrated and uncertain about their long-term viability.

site_title: China, HK shares rise as real estate stocks jump on central bank promise
summary: Chinese shares rose on Tuesday, led by real estate stocks, after the central bank pledged to protect consumers exposed to the housing market. The CSI300 index rose 0.4% and the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.5%. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index added 1.5% as property and tech shares rebounded. China's central bank injected more cash into the banking system, while the Shenzhen government began investigating Evergrande's wealth management unit. The real estate index surged 6.8%, its biggest intraday jump in seven months.

site_title: Ford announces US$11.4b investment for electric vehicle production
summary: Ford plans to invest $11.4 billion in electric vehicle production, building four new plants in Kentucky and Tennessee that will create 11,000 new jobs by 2025. The investment, part of a $30 billion commitment, will support the company's goal to create a sustainable American manufacturing ecosystem and accelerate its progress towards carbon neutrality. Ford expects 40-50% of its global vehicles to be fully electric by 2030. The investment is seen as a key step in the US shift to electric vehicles, with the company's CEO saying it will create good jobs that support American families.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS says oil proxies should remain in favour; raises price estimates
summary: DBS Group Research raised its oil price forecasts for 2021 and 2022 due to higher demand in winter months. The 2021 Brent crude average price forecast now stands at $67-72 per barrel, up from $65-70/bbl, while the 2022 forecast rises to $70-75/bbl. The research team cites strong demand from other parts of the world and limited supply concerns, making oil proxies such as China's CNOOC and Thailand's PTT Exploration & Production (PTTEP) attractive investments.

site_title: Activision Blizzard to create compensation fund for workplace harassment victims
summary: Activision Blizzard agreed to create a $18 million compensation fund for workplace harassment victims, following allegations of sexism and discrimination. The company will also donate remaining funds to charities promoting women's advancement in the video game industry. The US Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed a complaint stating employees were subjected to "severe or pervasive" sexual harassment. Activision Blizzard implemented a management shakeup in August and apologized for the misconduct, with CEO Bobby Kotick vowing to make the company an inclusive workplace. The company faces ongoing investigations and complaints.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly down on taper worry, eyes on debt limit
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday due to concerns over US borrowing costs and the debt ceiling crisis. Investors are worried about the potential collapse of Chinese developer Evergrande, which has eased for now, and the impact on the global economy. The US Federal Reserve is expected to begin tapering its monetary policy, which could lead to higher interest rates and volatility in the markets. The debt limit saga in Washington has also sparked unease, with a default on US debt obligations next month potentially sparking a massive financial crisis.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Tuesday's open; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% to 3,089.84 at the opening of Tuesday's trading, with 73 losers outnumbering 55 gainers. The decline was attributed to investor concerns over a potential US government shutdown, which is due by September 30. The US market also experienced a mixed close, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.2%, the S&P 500 down 0.3%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index down 0.5%.

site_title: Don't write off China, Evergrande is no Lehman: DBS CIO
summary: DBS' chief investment officer Hou Wey Fook says China's stock market may experience a 30-40% decline, but the country's long-term fundamentals remain unchanged, with 6% annual growth expected. Unlike the Lehman crisis, Evergrande's collapse is manageable and won't trigger global contagion. DBS favours large Chinese banks with sustainable dividend yields and the A-share market, citing conservative payout ratios and low exposure to real estate development loans. The bank also expects a stronger market in the long run, driven by inclusive growth policies and a transparent regulatory roadmap.

site_title: Hot stocks: VCPlus, FJ Benjamin see heavy trading on Tuesday morning
summary: Shares of FJ Benjamin and VCPlus experienced heavy trading on Tuesday morning following separate announcements. FJB signed an omnichannel solutions agreement with Lazada Singapore, while VCPlus's trading activity was not specified in the article.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.47% to 24,323, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.14% and the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.31%. Investors remain cautious due to the ongoing debt crisis at Chinese property giant Evergrande.

site_title: Femtech startup Ease raises US$1.3m led by Insignia
summary: Ease, a femtech startup focused on women's health services, has raised US$1.3 million in seed funding led by Insignia Ventures Partners. This is the largest round in South-east Asian femtech, addressing the industry's underfunding. Ease launched a mobile application for booking doctor appointments, tracking contraception, and managing health indicators. Founded by Guadalupe Lazaro and Rio Hoe, the startup aims to create a comprehensive ecosystem of products and services for women's health, with potential for scalable impact across Asia and beyond.

site_title: Bank of Japan policymakers warned of Japan's recovery delay, China risk
summary: Bank of Japan policymakers warned of a potential delay in Japan's economic recovery due to the ongoing state of emergency and its impact on consumption. Despite robust exports and capital expenditure, some policymakers expressed concern over overseas risks, including a possible slowdown in China's economy. The BOJ kept monetary policy steady but cut this year's growth forecast due to the pandemic's strain. The government is set to lift pandemic curbs next month, which may boost the economy with pent-up demand. Policymakers remain vigilant to risks, including the impact of US long-term interest rates on emerging economies.

site_title: Japan's Aso urges joint monetary, fiscal policies to spur inflation
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso urged the government and Bank of Japan to implement joint monetary and fiscal policies to boost inflation to 2% target. Aso criticized the BOJ's monetary policy, saying it has its limit, and expressed concerns about the side effects of prolonged easing. Japan's core consumer inflation remained flat in August, bolstering the view that inflation won't reach the target until 2023. Aso's remarks marked a rare departure from the BOJ's responsibility for monetary policy.

images.alt_text: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso called on Tuesday for a combination of monetary and fiscal policies to help boost inflation towards the Bank of Japan's 2 per cent inflation target, saying easy money policy has its limit.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index down 0.28% at 30,156.42, and the Topix index down 0.23% at 2,083.01. The decline follows a mixed close on Wall Street, where investors are watching for a US government shutdown.

site_title: World Bank says Delta variant slowing economic growth in East Asia and Pacific
summary: The World Bank reports that the East Asia and Pacific region's recovery has been slowed by the spread of the Covid-19 Delta variant, with economic growth forecasts downgraded for most countries. The region's growth is expected to be 2.5% in 2021, down nearly 2 percentage points from April forecasts. China's economy is projected to expand by 8.5%, while the rest of the region is expected to experience a reversal of fortune. The World Bank recommends accelerated vaccination and testing to revive economic activity, but warns that only deeper reforms can prevent slower growth and increasing inequality.

site_title: S&P lowers growth forecast for Asia-Pacific amid Covid-19, China uncertainty
summary: S&P Global Ratings lowered its growth forecast for the Asia-Pacific region to 6.7% due to the persistent Covid-19 pandemic and uncertainties in China. The report revised its 2021 growth forecast for China to 8% from 8.3%, citing weak private demand recovery. Despite lower expectations, the general outlook for the region is stabilizing as vaccination coverage increases and policies become more tolerant of Covid-19 outbreaks. Key countries, such as New Zealand and Singapore, are expected to have faster growth in 2021.

images.alt_text: The Asia-Pacific growth outlook for the remainder of 2021 has weakened amid the persistent Covid-19 pandemic and uncertainties relating to the China market, according to a S&P Global Ratings report.

site_title: ADDX tokenises global private equity fund
summary: Digital securities exchange ADDX has tokenised an allocation from a global private equity fund managed by Partners Group, allowing individuals to access the traditionally illiquid asset class. The fund, launched in 2007, has exposure to over 500 global private companies with a 12.7% year-to-date performance. Tokenisation enables monthly subscription and redemption, a rare feature for private equity funds. This move aims to "democratise" private markets, with Partners Group's head describing it as a "milestone" for the industry, and ADDX's chief commercial officer stating it will redistribute wealth from institutions to individuals.

site_title: Biden gets Covid-19 vaccine booster shot
summary: US President Joe Biden received a Covid-19 vaccine booster shot on Monday, receiving a third Pfizer dose. Biden emphasized the importance of vaccination, stating that a significant minority of Americans refusing even one shot is causing harm to the country. He urged Americans to get vaccinated, citing that 77% have received at least one dose, but nearly a quarter remain unvaccinated. The booster shot is available to those 65 or older, as well as those with high-risk medical conditions or frequent exposure to the virus.

site_title: New York hospitals fire, suspend staff who refuse Covid-19 vaccine
summary: New York hospitals began firing or suspending staff who refused to get vaccinated against Covid-19, with some hospitals postponing elective surgeries and curtailing services due to staff shortages. The state's mandate for healthcare workers to receive at least one shot by September 27 has resulted in about 5,000 unvaccinated employees, with 95% of nurses vaccinated. The move aims to address low vaccination rates in the state, with Governor Kathy Hochul considering employing the National Guard and out-of-state medical workers to fill staffing shortages.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Frasers Property, Jumbo, Lian Beng, VC Plus
summary: Frasers Property priced a second tranche of fixed-rate notes due 2028 at 3% per cent, with shares ending flat at S$1.13. Jumbo Group opened a new outlet at Jewel Changi Airport, while Lian Beng Group disclosed higher remuneration for key executives due to government grants received during the pandemic. VCPlus acquired technology consultancy firm APEC Solutions for S$5 million, a strategic move to accelerate business growth.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Tuesday, down 3.21 points, or 0.21%, to 1,529.84. Losers outnumbered gainers 252 to 157, with a trading volume of 222.87 million lots worth RM103.77 million.

site_title: Boeing showcases eco-friendly tech as industry faces pressure
summary: Boeing showcases eco-friendly tech, including a 737 MAX 9 flying demonstrator equipped with drag-reducing features and recycled carbon fibre cabin sidewalls, as the aviation industry faces pressure to cut emissions. Boeing aims to achieve 100% sustainable aviation fuels by 2030 and is focusing on sustainable aviation fuels (SAF), which are made from used cooking oil and animal fat. This is in contrast to rival Airbus' plans for a hydrogen-powered airplane from 2035, with Boeing considering SAF and generational technology leaps as a longer-term play.

site_title: US: Mixed day for stocks amid government shutdown worries
summary: US stocks closed mixed on Monday, with financial and oil-linked equities rising, but the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index falling. The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended up 0.2% at 34,869.37. Investors are bracing for uncertainty over a potential US government shutdown, with lawmakers having until September 30 to pass a funding bill. Petroleum producers ExxonMobil and Chevron jumped over 2% as oil prices strengthened, while JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America also rose over 2% on the 10-year US Treasury yield advance.

site_title: Australia's Aug retail sales fall 1.7%, still beat forecasts
summary: Australia's retail sales declined 1.7% in August, beating forecasts for a 2.5% drop, as half the population was stuck in coronavirus lockdowns. The decline follows a 2.7% drop in July, with the A$360 billion retail sector accounting for 18% of gross domestic product. Further weakness is expected in September due to lockdowns in major cities.

images.alt_text: Australian retail sales dived a third straight month in August as half the population were stuck in coronavirus lockdowns, although the drop was not as severe as analysts feared.

site_title: Frasers Property to issue second tranche of notes due 2028 at 3%
summary: Frasers Property's wholly-owned subsidiary Frasers Property AHL priced S$100 million in fixed-rate notes due 2028 with a 3% coupon, forming a single series with the S$200 million sustainability notes issued earlier. The notes will be issued on Sept 30 and mature on Oct 9, 2028, to finance or refinance qualifying assets. Net proceeds will be used under Frasers Property Australia's sustainable finance framework. OCBC is the sole lead manager for both tranches, and shares of Frasers Property ended flat at S$1.13 following the announcement.

site_title: Australia: Shares track Wall Street lower; gold loses shine
summary: Australian shares fell 0.62% on Tuesday, tracking a decline in Wall Street's tech-heavy Nasdaq index. Tech stocks, including Megaport and Appen, dropped 2.2% and 3.4%, respectively, while gold stocks fell 3.1% to their lowest level since March 2020. Energy stocks rose 3.2% to their highest level in over two months, driven by firmer oil prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 7,338.50 points.

site_title: Medline begins US$7.77b junk bond sale to fund jumbo buyout
summary: Medline Industries, a medical supply company, is selling $7.77 billion in junk bonds to fund its $30 billion leveraged buyout by private equity firms Blackstone, Carlyle, and Hellman & Friedman. The deal, led by JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs, includes a secured 7.5-year portion and an unsecured eight-year portion. The offering is the largest since Valeant Pharmaceuticals sold $8.5 billion in 2015 and ranks as the third largest dollar-denominated junk-bond deal. The deal is expected to be robust, with demand from asset managers and investors.

site_title: Oil up on tight supply, Brent crude nears US$80 a barrel
summary: Oil prices surged for a fifth consecutive day, with Brent crude reaching its highest level since October 2018 and nearing $80 a barrel. Tight global supplies, driven by the Delta variant's impact and Hurricane Ida's disruption to US production, are expected to continue to drive prices. Goldman Sachs raised its year-end forecast for Brent crude to $90 per barrel, citing a larger-than-expected supply-demand deficit. Global demand is expected to reach pre-pandemic levels by early 2022, with US supply constraints contributing to higher prices.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: VCPlus, a gold miner listed on the Catalist, acquired technology consultancy firm APEC Solutions for S$5 million, issuing 172.4 million new shares to APEC Solutions' director Cedric Yap Kun Hao. Jumbo Group opened a new Tsui Wah outlet at Jewel Changi Airport, while Lian Beng Group reported a slight increase in remuneration for its key executives due to government grants for Covid-19 operating costs.

site_title: Singer R. Kelly found guilty on all counts in sex abuse trial
summary: Singer R. Kelly was found guilty on all nine counts, including racketeering, of leading a decades-long sex crime ring. The New York jury deliberated for nine hours before delivering the verdict, which could result in up to life in prison. Kelly faces sentencing on May 4. He was also convicted on all eight charges of violating the Mann Act, an anti-sex trafficking law. Kelly's attorney plans to consider an appeal, and he still faces prosecution in three other jurisdictions.

site_title: US to press for semiconductor relief at EU tech meeting
summary: US President Joe Biden will meet with European Union officials to address the semiconductor supply shortage, which has impacted the US economy, at the inaugural technology ministerial in Pittsburgh. The shortage has hindered auto production and driven prices higher. The meeting aims to strengthen the transatlantic trade and economic relationship, with a focus on near-term disruptions and longer-term supply reliability issues. The US and EU will also discuss joint action on China's trade practices, including unfair trade policies and practices.

site_title: Pfizer launches mRNA flu vaccine trial
summary: Pfizer has launched a clinical trial to test an mRNA influenza vaccine, designed to improve on current flu vaccines with an efficacy of 40-60% against a disease causing up to 650,000 deaths annually. The trial will recruit over 600 Americans aged 65-85 to compare the safety and immune response of single, double, and quadruple strain mRNA vaccines versus conventional vaccines. Developed in collaboration with BioNTech, the mRNA technology aims to provide faster and more flexible production, enabling Pfizer to explore mRNA medicine against other respiratory viruses, cancer, and genetic diseases.

site_title: Crunch time for Biden as Congress debates historic agenda
summary: US President Joe Biden's economic agenda faces a critical test as Congress debates historic legislation worth nearly $5 trillion, including infrastructure and social programs. The House and Senate are set to vote on the bills, which include a $3.5 trillion social welfare package and a $1.2 trillion infrastructure bill. Failure to pass the legislation could lead to a government shutdown and debt default, with Biden warning that "it's going to be a week from hell."

site_title: Gold prices dip on rising dollar, bond yields
summary: Gold prices declined 0.1% to $1,748.01 per ounce, hurt by a stronger US dollar and rising Treasury yields. Investors await cues from the Federal Reserve on monetary policy, with a potential trigger for bond "taper" tied to the September employment report. US Treasury yields rose to a three-month high, increasing the opportunity cost of holding gold. Silver, platinum, and palladium also fell, while China's central bank injected cash into the banking system amid concerns over Evergrande's wealth management unit.

images.alt_text: Gold prices eased on Tuesday, hurt by a stronger dollar and rising US Treasury yields, while investors awaited more cues from Federal Reserve officials on the central bank's monetary policy shift.

site_title: Federal Reserve officials involved in stock trading to retire
summary: Two senior Federal Reserve officials, Robert Kaplan and Eric Rosengren, will retire in the coming week amid controversy over their stock trading in 2020. Kaplan, who leaves on October 8, and Rosengren, who moves up his retirement to September 30, engaged in large trades during the Covid-19 pandemic. Fed Chair Jerome Powell announced plans to review ethics rules regarding investing, despite stating the officials had not violated existing rules. The officials praised by Powell for their work, citing Kaplan's focus on monetary policy and Rosengren's emphasis on financial stability.

site_title: Europe: Shares end lower; German stocks rise on election relief
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index ended lower on Monday, despite German shares reaching 10-day highs as the federal election outcome reduced the chances of a left-wing coalition forming a government. Germany's DAX rose 0.3% while the pan-European Stoxx 600 fell 0.2%. The outcome is seen as a relief, allowing the centre-left Social Democrats to form a government with the Greens and liberal Free Democrats by Christmas.

site_title: Google dominance in Australia online advertising harms businesses: regulator
summary: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) has found that Google dominates the country's online advertising market, harming publishers, advertisers, and consumers. Over 90% of ad clicks passed through Google services in 2020. The ACCC calls for new rules to rein in Google's power, citing concerns over conflicts of interest, anti-competitive self-preferencing, and lack of transparency about data use. The regulator seeks special powers to address data imbalance and force Google to separate data between business units or share with competitors.

images.alt_text: Google dominates Australia's online advertising market to the point of harming publishers, advertisers and ultimately consumers, the country's antitrust regulator said, calling for new rules to rein in the Big Tech giant.

site_title: US cryptocurrency promoter, formerly based in Singapore, pleads guilty to advising North Korea
summary: Virgil Griffith, a US cryptocurrency promoter and former hacker, pleaded guilty to advising North Korea on using virtual money to evade international controls. Griffith, 38, launched projects in 2018 to provide cryptocurrency services to North Korea, despite violating US Treasury bans. He faces a 20-year prison sentence and had previously attended a conference in Pyongyang, where he spoke about evading sanctions. Griffith's guilty plea was announced by the Southern District Court of New York, with a ruling to be announced in January 2022.

site_title: As Americans spend, credit card debt is ticking back up
summary: US credit card debt is rising, with 42% of those with debt adding to their balances since the pandemic began. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reports a $17 billion increase in credit card bills in the second quarter of 2021, to $790 billion nationally. This trend reversal is attributed to the end of stimulus checks and expanded unemployment benefits. Credit card debt can be challenging to escape, with average interest rates over 16% and 40% of those carrying a monthly balance having been debt-free from credit cards since 2018.

site_title: 39 Canadian miners trapped underground for 24 hours
summary: Thirty-nine Canadian miners were trapped underground for 24 hours after an accident cut off access to the main exit at a mine in eastern Canada. The Brazilian mining company Vale, which owns the mine, reported that the rescue crew reached the miners and is moving them up via a secondary egress ladder system. None of the miners were injured and they had access to food and water. The rescue operation is expected to be completed by Monday evening.

site_title: Hyundai scion turns to wealthy clans, leveraged buyouts for impact fund
summary: Kyungsun Chung, a Hyundai scion, is launching Sylvan Capital, a Singapore-based impact investing firm that uses leveraged buyouts to drive environmental, social, and governance (ESG) changes in businesses. The firm aims to close a US$400-500 million inaugural fund by next year, with more than half of the funding committed from backers including the Hyundai family and Asian business clans. Chung's approach involves buying majority stakes in companies worth US$100-500 million, aiming to generate a 25% annualized return while improving ESG credentials.

site_title: Analysts brush off impact of China power curbs on soft commodity players
summary: China's power crackdown to cut energy intensity by 3% for 2021 has cast uncertainty over the commodities and materials sectors. Analysts covering the sector say the impact on soft commodity players such as Wilmar International and Golden Agri-Resources is minimal, with paper and glass industries expected to face supply disruptions. The agricultural commodities industry, particularly soya bean-crushing plants, has been affected, with production cuts expected to last until after China's Golden Week holiday. However, analysts expect the impact on prices to be short-term and say underlying demand and supply dynamics are the more critical factors.

site_title: TikTok says it has over 1 billion users
summary: TikTok announced it has surpassed 1 billion active users, just four years after its launch by Chinese group ByteDance. The platform gained over 300 million users since July 2020, driven by its popularity during the pandemic. Initially focusing on 15-second videos, TikTok now offers up to three-minute videos to attract a wider audience. The platform is looking to monetize its traffic, having accelerated into advertising last year and introducing a feature to directly purchase products from content creators. This milestone cements TikTok's position as a leading social media platform.

images.alt_text: TikTok said on Monday it now has more than a billion active users, just four years after the hugely popular video-sharing app was launched by Chinese group ByteDance.

site_title: Berlin votes to expropriate big landlords amid anger over rents
summary: Berlin voters overwhelmingly supported a referendum to expropriate large property companies' housing, with 56% backing the proposal. The measure, which isn't legally binding, could transfer 226,000 apartments into public hands if enacted, including those of Deutsche Wohnen. Proponents argue the government should control rising housing costs, while opponents warn it could halt investment and modernization plans. The vote puts pressure on politicians to carry out the measure, which could cost around 29-39 billion euros to implement.

images.alt_text: Berlin has estimated that the city needs 20,000 new homes annually to accommodate the growing population.

site_title: Thai central bank seen to hold key interest rate at record low
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, is expected to hold its key interest rate at a record low of 0.50% amid easing of coronavirus restrictions and a flagging economy. The decision is based on a Reuters poll of 23 economists, with 20 predicting the rate will remain unchanged and three anticipating a quarter-point cut. The Bank of Thailand will announce its new forecast on Wednesday, with Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput stating that growth might not reach 1% this year.

site_title: Dear Evan Hansen hits wrong notes as Shang-Chi stays top of US box office
summary: Dear Evan Hansen, the Universal Pictures adaptation of the Broadway musical, underperformed in its debut weekend, collecting US$7.5 million from 3,365 North American theatres. Despite negative reviews and Covid-19 concerns, the film's losses are expected to be modest, given its US$28 million production budget. The movie musical's poor performance contrasts with the success of Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings, which stayed atop the US box office for its fourth weekend, adding US$13.3 million in ticket sales and surpassing Black Widow as the highest-grossing movie of the year.

site_title: Global oil demand seen reaching pre-pandemic levels by early 2022 as economies restart
summary: Global oil demand is expected to reach pre-pandemic levels by early 2022 as economies recover, but spare refining capacity may weigh on the outlook. Despite a rise in Covid-19 infections, demand for petrol and diesel is expected to grow. Oil producers and traders warn that unused refining capacity may limit profit margins. The International Energy Agency forecasts global oil demand to average 96.1 million barrels per day in 2021 and 99.4 million barrels per day in 2022.

site_title: Pavilion Energy eyes S-E Asia markets for gas expansion
summary: Pavilion Energy, a Singaporean energy company, is expanding into South-east Asian countries such as Vietnam and Myanmar to meet growing demand for natural gas. The company's interim CEO, Alan Heng, said there are opportunities to supply gas to markets dependent on domestic gas and coal. Pavilion is also building an emissions business to help liquefied natural gas (LNG) transition to greener targets. The post-pandemic economic improvement is driving energy demand, leading to higher prices, and the company is strengthening its gas supply network to support Singapore's renewables infrastructure.

site_title: Electric supercars in race to lose weight, power up and cool down
summary: Supercar makers are racing to electrify their vehicles before combustion engines are phased out due to climate change. Companies like Ferrari and Mercedes-Benz are investing in startups like Yasa, which has developed high-performance electric motors weighing 23kg, a fraction of traditional V12 engines. Yasa aims to reduce costs and increase efficiency, while other companies, such as Saietta and Lotus, are exploring weight-loss strategies through advanced materials and motors. The electric supercar market is expected to rise nearly 50% to 223,000 cars by 2026, with luxury brands leading the charge.

site_title: PropertyGuru to bet on fintech, S-E Asia markets as it gears up for SPAC listing
summary: PropertyGuru, a Singapore-based online real estate firm, is set to go public through a merger with a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) called Bridgetown 2 Holdings, backed by billionaire Peter Thiel and Hong Kong tycoon Richard Li. The deal is expected to raise US$431 million and values the combined entity at around US$1.35 billion. PropertyGuru's growth story is expected to rest on leveraging opportunities in South-east Asia and its fintech & data business segment, which is projected to swell to US$28 million by 2025. The company's expansion plans include acquiring businesses in Malaysia and Thailand, and branching out into adjacent services such as home services and operating systems for developers.

site_title: Digitalising our SMEs - benefits, costs and considerations
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face significant challenges in digitalising and internationalising due to resource constraints and lack of economies of scale. Despite government initiatives, many SMEs struggle to adopt digital technologies, citing financial sustainability, compatibility, and cybersecurity risks. To support SMEs, the government must assume an empathetic stance and offer tailored solutions, while consumers can play a crucial role by buying local brands. SMEs contribute significantly to the urban economy, driving innovation and entrepreneurship, and their decline could have devastating effects on the built environment and urban landscape.

site_title: Changing hands
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content: 

Stocks in Europe and the US declined due to bank and healthcare concerns. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats from the US government. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss shortfalls. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade. An Indonesian court detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's new CEO.

site_title: US environment agency urged by 21 states to toughen vehicle emissions rules
summary: A group of 21 US state attorneys general and major cities urged the Biden administration to finalize stricter vehicle emissions rules, surpassing the proposed 10% efficiency boost and a fleet average of 22.11km per liter by 2026. The states claim automakers have enough time to meet tougher rules, and the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy (ACEEE) also called for greater stringency, arguing the proposed standard would only lead to an 8% electric vehicle market share by 2026.

images.alt_text: The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) in August called for reversing the Trump-era loosening of vehicle emissions rules with a new plan to boost efficiency 10 per cent in the 2023 model year and aim for a fleet average of 22.11km by litre by 2026.

site_title: US beats Europe to reclaim golf's Ryder Cup
summary: The US team, led by a new generation of golfers, reclaimed the Ryder Cup with a 19-9 rout over Europe, the largest margin of victory in the current format. Young players like Collin Morikawa, Collin's debut securing the winning point, and rookies like Jon Rahm, Sergio Garcia, and Scottie Scheffler made significant contributions. The US team's youthful energy and talent proved too much for the European veteran players, marking a new era for US golf.

site_title: Moulin Rouge! wins big as Tony Awards return to Broadway
summary: The Tony Awards returned to Broadway after a 18-month hiatus due to the pandemic, honoring the best in theatre with a ceremony that was livestreamed before the main event. Moulin Rouge! won 10 awards, including best musical and best actor, while The Inheritance took home four awards, including best play. Other winners included A Soldier's Play, a revival of A Christmas Carol, and first-time winners such as Aaron Tveit and 90-year-old Lois Smith. The ceremony marked a new look for the awards, with a focus on live theatre's return to New York.

site_title: Risk appetite returns as Evergrande fears ebb
summary: Risk appetite returned in the currency market, with the Australian dollar rallying and the yen dipping to a nearly three-month low as concerns over China's Evergrande Group's debt fears receded. Rising commodity prices and higher US yields also contributed to the Aussie's gain, while the yen was pressured. The dollar index hovered near its range, and the euro traded little changed. The People's Bank of China injected a net 100 billion yuan into the financial system, easing concerns about market contagion.

site_title: Outcome uncertain as Japan's ruling party heads to vote on next PM
summary: Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) is set to vote on Wednesday for its next prime minister, with the winner likely to succeed Yoshihide Suga as premier due to the party's majority in the lower house. The outcome of the election is uncertain, marking the most unpredictable race since Shinzo Abe's surprise comeback in 2012. The LDP has not announced its candidate, fueling uncertainty about who will lead the country. The winner will likely succeed Suga, who has been unpopular, and take office on September 29.

site_title: AirAsia X posts record quarterly loss of US$5.9b
summary: AirAsia X, a subsidiary of AirAsia Group Bhd, has reported a record quarterly loss of US$5.9 billion, its ninth consecutive loss, due to a multi-billion-dollar provision to cover debts. The airline made an accounting provision of RM23.8 billion to its creditors, resulting in a net loss of RM24.6 billion. Revenue dropped 20.9% to RM72.3 million. The airline plans to operate a reduced fleet, return excess aircraft, and negotiate with creditors to reduce lease rental rates and maintenance costs, with a proposed restructuring scheme to be presented by the end of October.

site_title: Alibaba invests US$200m in Ninja Van; GeoPost remains largest shareholder
summary: Alibaba invests US$200 million in Ninja Van, a Singapore-based logistics startup, alongside existing backer GeoPost, which maintains its 40% stake as the largest shareholder. The investment brings Ninja Van's valuation to approximately US$1.85 billion, more than double its valuation last year. The startup, which specializes in last-mile logistics and supply chain solutions, has operations in six regional markets and may pursue an initial public offering in the US as early as next year.

site_title: Malaysia pledges spending, green goals in five-year economic plan
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob unveiled a new five-year economic plan, boosting infrastructure spending and introducing a carbon tax to achieve climate change goals. The country aims to grow 4.5-5.5% annually and improve its financial position by 2023. The plan prioritizes green initiatives, with a focus on reducing carbon emissions and increasing green technologies. Malaysia's economic growth is expected to be driven by a combination of domestic and foreign investment, with the government targeting significant investments in infrastructure and renewable energy.

site_title: Germany's Chancellor-in-waiting wants to form pragmatic government
summary: Germany's Finance Minister Olaf Scholz is poised to become the country's next Chancellor after his party, the Social Democratic Party (SPD), won a slim victory in the parliamentary elections. A three-party coalition of the SPD, Green Party, and Free Democratic Party (FDP) is expected, with investors optimistic about a stable government. Scholz faces significant economic and geopolitical challenges, including inflation, stagnant economy, and rising public debt. His predecessor, Angela Merkel, will continue to serve as Chancellor until a new government is formed.

images.alt_text: Olaf Scholz, whose Social Democratic Party (SPD) won 25.7 per cent of the vote last Sunday, faces many challenges.

site_title: Johor to submit plan to reopen Malaysia-Singapore land border
summary: The Johor state government plans to submit a proposal to reopen the Malaysia-Singapore land border, allowing up to 30,000 people to commute daily across the two land checkpoints. The proposal, known as the Daily Commuting Arrangement (DCA), aims to cater to Malaysians working in Singapore and those studying abroad. However, Singapore's sharp increase in daily Covid-19 infections and Malaysia's need to refine the proposal's health and safety protocols may hinder the reopening of the borders, with the current status at the "proposal stage."

images.alt_text: The Johor state government intends to submit a proposal to Putrajaya on its plans to set up a border reopening scheme that would allow Malaysians in Singapore to commute back and forth daily across the two land checkpoints.

site_title: All eyes on whether China will bail out Evergrande or allow controlled detonation
summary: China's fate in deciding whether to bail out or allow a controlled detonation of Evergrande, the country's most indebted property developer, remains uncertain. Evergrande missed the "three red lines" for financial health, prompting intense pressure from new borrowing constraints. Beijing's options are being weighed, with some experts suggesting a debt restructuring plan, liquidating non-core assets, and allowing the profitable real estate part of the business to continue operating. A full bailout seems unlikely, with a partial bail-out for assets connected to social stability being a more probable outcome, potentially involving local governments and state-owned enterprises.

site_title: Time for strategy of responsible resilience among international companies in Myanmar
summary: Myanmar's military coup in February has led to an extended period of crisis, making it essential for international companies to adopt a "responsible resilience" strategy. This involves combining tough short-term decisions with a long-term commitment to the country, prioritizing positive impacts on Myanmar citizens. Companies must focus on smart survival, making painful decisions about jobs while maintaining ethical judgment, and tap into their ingenuity to find immediate solutions. Ultimately, staying in the country may be the harder choice, but it could also contribute to Myanmar's eventual revival, making it a gamble worth considering.

site_title: PayNow-DuitNow linkage may lower cash use when borders open
summary: Singapore and Malaysia plan to link their real-time payment systems, PayNow and DuitNow, starting in the fourth quarter of 2022, allowing for faster and cheaper transfers between the two countries. This move aims to reduce cash use when travel borders reopen. The linkage will benefit individual and corporate customers, while banks and fintech players with strong digital capabilities will gain an edge. However, the exchange rate and competition from non-bank remittance services, such as Wise, may impact the market, potentially reducing fee income for banks and remittance firms.

images.alt_text: Singapore's largest remittance corridor connects with Malaysia, and this pipe will soon see quicker payments flow through once the two countries' real-time payment systems link up next year.

site_title: EV maker Polestar to go public at US$20 billion valuation via SPAC
summary: Polestar, a Swedish electric car maker, plans to go public through a merger with a blank-cheque firm backed by billionaire Alec Gores and investment bank Guggenheim Partners at a valuation of US$20 billion, including debt. The deal includes US$800 million in cash proceeds and a US$250 million private investment in public equity. Polestar, backed by Volvo Car Group and Leonardo DiCaprio, aims to sell 290,000 vehicles per year by 2025 and plans to launch three new models by 2024, including the Precept, a larger sedan.

site_title: Troubled Thai rail operator targets 600b baht in land projects
summary: The State Railway of Thailand (SRT) has established a company to manage and monetize its valuable properties, aiming to generate 600 billion baht (S$24.2 billion) in revenue over 30 years. The move is part of a plan to modernize the rail enterprise, which has accumulated 44,000 hectares of land and billions in liabilities due to decades of losses. The SRT will focus on its core transport services, allowing private companies to use its lines for freight and people, and introducing battery-powered trains to supplement diesel-powered services.

site_title: US pivot to Asia should promote cooperation, and include joining CPTPP
summary: The US strategic pivot to the Indo-Pacific region has led to increased cooperation among the US, Australia, Japan, and India, known as the Quad. The group aims to promote a free, open, rules-based order to counter China's growing assertiveness. However, some regional partners are cautious about the potential for escalating tensions between the US and China. The Quad has evolved into a multilateral grouping focused on cooperation, including a joint plan to provide COVID-19 vaccines and address climate change. The US should reassess its decision not to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) to affirm its leadership position in the region.

site_title: China's power crunch begins to weigh on economic outlook
summary: China's power crunch, caused by tight coal supplies and emissions standards, is dragging on the country's economic growth rate. The crunch has affected various industries, including heavy industries such as aluminium, chemicals, and soya meal. China aims to cut energy intensity by 3% in 2021 to meet climate goals, with provincial authorities enforcing tougher emissions curbs. This may slow China's GDP growth, putting pressure on policymakers to address the issue.

site_title: Panic buying leaves up to 90% of fuel pumps dry in major British cities
summary: Panic buying in the UK has led to up to 90% of fuel pumps drying out in major cities, exacerbating a supply chain crisis caused by a post-Brexit shortage of truck drivers. Despite government warnings to refrain from panic buying, queues of cars and empty pumps persisted, forcing many stations to close. The Petrol Retailers Association reports 50-90% of its members' sites dry, and the government has suspended competition laws to allow firms to share information and coordinate their response. A plan to issue temporary visas for 5,000 foreign truck drivers has been proposed.

site_title: Is pivoting to property a good strategy for companies diversifying?
summary: Singapore-listed department store Isetan posted a net profit of S$1.3 million for the first six months of the year, despite facing significant losses in the past. The group will close its store at Parkway Parade next year and continue to operate stores at Shaw House, Tampines Mall, and Nex. This comes as the retail industry continues to struggle with online shopping, with Robinsons shutting its last physical department store in Singapore earlier this year. The trend highlights the risks and challenges of diversifying into property for companies, but also presents opportunities for those who adapt.

site_title: Brent rises to near US$80 a barrel on global energy crunch
summary: Brent oil prices surged to near US$80 a barrel, driven by a global energy crunch. Supply struggles to catch up with fast-rising demand, with inventories falling sharply ahead of winter. Goldman Sachs predicts Brent could hit US$90 a barrel by year-end, citing a larger-than-expected deficit in the market. OPEC+ is expected to meet on Oct 4 to review its output policy, amid concerns of a natural gas crisis boosting world oil consumption by 6% if gas prices stay high.

site_title: World's No 1 stock owner gets nod to purge portfolio of CO2
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund, the world's largest stock owner, is set to commit to net zero carbon dioxide emissions by 2050, according to the newly elected Labour Party. The fund, which owns 1.5% of the world's stocks, has been urged to use active ownership strategies to achieve this goal. The move follows a government-commissioned report recommending carbon reduction goals consistent with the Paris Agreement. The Labour Party's climate spokesman, Espen Barth Eide, said companies without ambitious net zero goals will be in the crosshairs, and companies will need to have "credible and accountable plans" to access capital from the fund.

site_title: Biden aims to rival China's belt and road in Latin America
summary: The US, under President Biden, is planning to launch a competitor to China's Belt and Road initiative in Latin America. US Deputy National Security Adviser Daleep Singh will travel to Colombia, Ecuador, and Panama to discuss infrastructure projects with local officials and business leaders. The goal is to engage in projects with higher environmental and labor standards, and full transparency for financial terms. The US aims to counter China's influence and provide alternative infrastructure development opportunities, with over $40 trillion in infrastructure needs projected for developing countries by 2035.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.99 points to 1,533.05, closing higher on Monday. The index saw a volume of 4.372 billion lots worth RM2.977 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 587 to 424.

site_title: Adopting Bitcoin as legal tender makes little sense for El Salvador
summary: El Salvador has adopted Bitcoin as legal tender, despite concerns over its economic viability. The country's previous adoption of the US dollar as legal tender led to monetary stability, and giving up monetary independence carries significant costs. Bitcoin's volatility and lack of stability make it an unsuitable choice for a national currency. The move is also seen as economically dangerous for developing countries, particularly due to the risks of facilitating illegal transactions and harming the environment through mining.

site_title: Facebook holds off on Instagram app for the under-13 set
summary: Facebook has paused development of an "Instagram Kids" app for children under 13, following criticism of the app's potential impact on young people's mental health. The decision comes amid internal research showing Instagram's negative effects on teenage girls, as reported by The Wall Street Journal. Facebook still plans to build a more "age-appropriate" Instagram product, but will instead focus on parental control features and work with regulators and experts. This pause is seen as a temporary measure, with some calling for tougher laws to restrict tech platforms' targeting of children.

site_title: Jumbo opens Tsui Wah outlet at Changi Airport amid Covid-19 restrictions
summary: Jumbo Group has opened a new Tsui Wah outlet at Jewel Changi Airport, despite Covid-19 restrictions. The outlet, occupying 3,240 sq ft, has a maximum seating capacity of 123 seats, but is currently capped at 88 seats due to social distancing measures. The company also plans to reopen its closed outlet at The Heeren in November. Jumbo's shares closed 1.7% lower due to the announcement.

site_title: Japan plans to lift emergency in all regions: NHK report
summary: Japan plans to lift its Covid-19 state of emergency in all regions at the end of September, according to a report by NHK. The emergency, which covers 19 prefectures, will be lifted if Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga receives approval from a government panel of advisers. Current measures include early restaurant closures and restrictions on non-urgent outings. Despite a recent drop in cases, authorities are considering keeping some curbs in place to prevent a spike in infections if the country opens up completely. Over 57% of Japan's population is now fully vaccinated.

site_title: Team-Metal's foresight and customer-centric approach pay off
summary: Team-Metal, a precision metal components maker, has successfully navigated the challenges of the disk drive and printer manufacturing industry in Singapore by adopting a high-mix low-volume (HMLV) business model. The company's focus on diversified industries, such as medical and life sciences, and its customer-centric approach have enabled it to capitalize on the rapid growth of these sectors. With a compounded annual revenue growth rate of 7% from 2017 to 2019, Team-Metal has proven its HMLV business model to be successful. The company's strong corporate culture, KPI system, and open management approach have also contributed to its success.

site_title: China vows further curbs on 'disorderly expansion' by tech firms
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration vows to take further steps to curb "disorderly expansion" by tech firms, citing areas of concern as shared economy, online healthcare, and smart delivery. Vice-Minister Sheng Ronghua emphasized the need for stronger regulation, building a solid legal foundation for anti-monopoly efforts and preventing capital's disordered expansion. The move could impact firms like Meituan and Baidu, and comes after China's crackdown on monopolies and data sharing, with the goal of promoting healthy growth in these sectors.

site_title: Hong Kong moves to woo friends and visitors, guard financial hub status
summary: Hong Kong has launched a bid to improve its global image, releasing a report that accuses the US of hurting the city's business climate by supporting "black-clad violence" and imposing sanctions on Chinese and Hong Kong officials. The report also praises the national security law for restoring order and improving Hong Kong's prospects. Amid ongoing tensions between China and the US, Hong Kong has also partnered with a South Korean entertainment company to promote the city through Korean dramas and variety shows, aiming to woo visitors and maintain its status as a financial hub.

site_title: US should re-engage as a constructive world leader
summary: The US should re-engage as a constructive world leader by abandoning protectionist policies and embracing the open multilateral trading system, the rule of law, and private enterprise. This approach, which has led to China's economic growth, is in contrast to the US's current policies, which are curtailing its economic growth, undermining its alliances, and weakening its global power. The US should strengthen its alliances, such as the Trans-Pacific Partnership, and demonstrate a better alternative to China's state-sponsored industries. This would yield superior results and preserve the US's global leadership role.

site_title: Lian Beng says Covid-19 government grants helped boost remuneration for key execs
summary: Singapore building contractor Lian Beng Group revealed that government Covid-19 grants, which helped mitigate additional operating costs, contributed to higher remuneration for key executives in FY2021. The company's net profit declined 9% to S$26.1 million, driven by a 7.5% drop in revenue due to the pandemic. Lian Beng attributed improved profitability to its property development and other business segments, not just the grants.

site_title: US: Tech mega-caps, chip-makers drag Nasdaq lower at open
summary: US stocks experienced a decline at the open on Monday, with the Nasdaq Composite dropping 93.52 points, or 0.62%, to 14,954.18. The decline was attributed to investors shifting focus to economic growth stocks amidst increasing confidence in a recovery. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 58.73 points, or 0.17%, and the S&P 500 opened lower by 13.36 points, or 0.30%. The tech-heavy Nasdaq index was the primary driver of the decline, as investors swapped it for stocks linked to economic growth.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: Singaporeans aged 35-54 were the most impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic, according to a Prudential study. The study found that this age group experienced significant financial losses due to the pandemic. The exact financial impact is not specified in the article.

site_title: Users in Singapore can no longer buy or trade crypto on Binance.com from Oct 26
summary: Binance will restrict Singapore users from October 26, prohibiting fiat deposits, trades, and purchases of cryptocurrency via Binance.com. This move comes after a warning by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and follows earlier curbs, including the removal of mobile app listings in Singapore's app stores. The ban aims to create a sustainable ecosystem for blockchain technology and digital assets, but raises questions about how cryptocurrency businesses should operate outside their home jurisdictions.

site_title: Leonardo DiCaprio-backed Polestar valued at US$20b in SPAC deal
summary: Polestar, an electric vehicle maker backed by Volvo and Leonardo DiCaprio, has agreed to go public through a merger with a blank-check company, Gores Guggenheim Inc, at a US$20 billion valuation. The deal will provide US$1.05 billion to bring three new models to market within three years. Polestar has existing models and access to Volvo's production network, setting it apart from other auto upstarts. The company aims to achieve 290,000 deliveries by 2025 and a 9% margin on earnings. Volvo will invest up to US$600 million in Polestar, increasing its stake to nearly 50%.

site_title: VCPlus furthers fintech ambition with S$5 million acquisition
summary: VCPlus, a Catalist-listed gold miner, has acquired technology consultancy firm APEC Solutions for S$5 million. The consideration will be paid via the issuance and allotment of new shares to APEC Solutions' director and shareholder, Cedric Yap Kun Hao. This acquisition aims to further VCPlus' fintech ambition, allowing it to grow its capabilities in the blockchain and fintech technology sector.

site_title: Rock group Queen open London store
summary: Queen, the British rock legends, have opened a pop-up store on London's Carnaby Street to mark five decades of performances. The store, "Queen The Greatest," features memorabilia, including a Rubik's cube, Monopoly board, and guitars signed by Brian May. The two-level shop takes visitors through Queen's career, from their early days in 1971 to the 2010s. The store is open for three months and features a unique pinball machine, concert footage, and the band's greatest hits. The store marks a significant milestone for the band, despite the death of lead singer Freddie Mercury in 1991.

site_title: B2B fintech startup Aspire raises US$158m from DST Global, fintech founders
summary: B2B fintech startup Aspire has raised US$158 million in a Series B round led by DST Global and other investors, including fintech founders. The funding will be used to expand its integrated finance platform across South-east Asia. Aspire's platform allows businesses to manage local and international payments, expenses, invoices, and more in one place, aiming to simplify the complex finance operating needs of businesses. The company believes it can build the operating system for the South-east Asia digital economy, mirroring the success of integrated platforms in sales and communication.

site_title: Europe's IPO market roars back to life, but where are the SPACs?
summary: Europe's initial public offerings (IPOs) have seen a resurgence, raising $8.5 billion in the third quarter, the highest amount in a decade. However, the market for special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs), which have been a major trend in the US, is largely absent. Despite a flurry of activity before the holiday season, no new SPAC deals have been announced since July. The European Union's markets watchdog has warned of risks associated with SPACs, and demand has dried up due to poor performance, regulatory crackdowns, and waning market sentiment.

site_title: STI up 1.27% despite retightening of Covid-19 measures
summary: Singapore shares rose 1.27% on Monday despite tightened Covid-19 measures, with the Straits Times Index (STI) ending at 3,100.30. Top performers included CapitaLand Investment and local banks, which gained 7% and 2.1-2.2% respectively. However, ComfortDelGro fell 2.6%. Analysts note that while the manufacturing sector may remain resilient, the services sector may face pressure under current restrictions.

site_title: Analysts brush off impact of China power curbs on soft commodity players Wilmar, Golden Agri
summary: China's power crackdown, aimed at reducing energy intensity, has cast uncertainty over the commodities and materials sectors. However, analysts covering the sector do not see any cause for concern, as the impact on soft commodity players like Wilmar International and Golden Agri-Resources is expected to be minimal. The power restrictions primarily affect soybean-crushing plants in Jiangsu and Tianjin provinces, with other agri commodities like sugar and coffee not being affected. Analysts predict that the power cuts may extend until after China's Golden Week holiday, potentially delaying Chinese purchases and impacting US soybean exports.

site_title: Singapore to develop carbon credit trading marketplace to support decarbonisation, sustainability
summary: Singapore plans to develop a carbon credit trading marketplace and services ecosystem to support decarbonization and sustainability. The marketplace, called Climate Impact X (CIX), will connect buyers and suppliers of carbon credits, leveraging technology such as satellite monitoring and blockchain. The platform aims to provide price transparency and improve trust and transparency in international carbon markets. The move is part of Singapore's efforts to become a leading hub for decarbonization and sustainability, with partnerships with international players and local companies.

site_title: Malaysia's AirAsia X reports record quarterly loss of US$5.9b
summary: Malaysia's AirAsia X reported a record quarterly loss of US$5.9 billion, eight times more than a year ago, due to a multi-billion-dollar provision to cover debts. This was the ninth consecutive loss for the airline, which widened to RM24.6 billion (S$7.9 billion) from a RM305.2 million loss a year ago. The airline's operating costs increased due to the provision, marking its largest quarterly loss to date.

site_title: Singapore's power gencos fall under scrutiny amid spike in spot electricity prices
summary: Singapore's spot electricity prices surged in July, reaching a multi-year high, and are now under scrutiny by the Energy Market Authority (EMA) amid possible anti-competitive practices. The Uniform Singapore Energy Price (USEP) skyrocketed to S$1,514.86 per megawatt-hour and S$2,036.02 per megawatt-hour, prompting electricity retailers to raise fixed-price plans by 10-20%. The EMA is reviewing the factors that led to the price volatility and has submitted a report to assist in fulfilling its obligations to prohibit anti-competitive agreements and abuse of a dominant position.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin week slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose slightly on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index gaining 0.07% to 24,208.78. The gains were muted due to concerns over the Evergrande crisis. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.84% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 1.14%. The small gains were a relief for investors after a tumultuous trading session.

site_title: Panic buying leaves up to 90% of fuel pumps dry in major British cities
summary: Up to 90% of fuel pumps in major British cities ran dry on Monday due to panic buying, exacerbating a supply-chain crisis caused by a post-Brexit shortage of lorry drivers. This shortage, triggered by the Covid-19 pandemic, threatens disruptions and price rises in the UK economy, particularly in the run-up to Christmas. The crisis comes after the UK government spent millions to avert a food shortage, and just days after ministers warned against panic buying.

site_title: Brokers' take: Pace of mergers, restructuring likely to pick up in Singapore
summary: Singapore companies are expected to see an increase in mergers and acquisitions, privatisations, and restructuring in the near to mid-term due to low interest rates and cheap market valuations. Analysts predict that deals will be driven by digitalisation, sustainability, and government initiatives, with government-linked companies, high-growth small and mid-cap listed companies, and late-stage startups likely to be involved. Companies such as AEM Holdings, Ascendas Reit, DBS, Singtel, and Wilmar International are expected to be active in the market, with some potentially splitting into separate segments or undergoing restructuring and IPOs.

site_title: SGX, Temasek digital asset JV announces partnership with 10 global banks
summary: Marketnode, a digital asset joint venture between Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Temasek, has partnered with 10 global banks, including Barclays, HSBC, and Standard Chartered, to accelerate the usage of its platform and co-create distributed ledger technology (DLT) solutions. The partnerships aim to build an end-to-end DLT-enabled fixed income infrastructure and provide market input towards product development. Marketnode's product launches, including digital issuance services and ESG bond data, are expected to play a key role in this effort.

site_title: Biden team aims to rival China's Belt and Road in Latin America
summary: The Biden administration is planning a US-led infrastructure initiative in Latin America, dubbed "Build Back Better for the World," to rival China's Belt and Road program. US Deputy National Security Adviser Daleep Singh will scout potential projects in Colombia, Ecuador, and Panama, focusing on environmentally friendly and transparent projects. The initiative aims to address $40 trillion in infrastructure needs worldwide by 2035, with potential projects including solar power plants, digital technology projects, and investments in women-owned businesses. This move is seen as a counter to China's Belt and Road program, which has gained raw materials, trade links, and geopolitical leverage.

site_title: Politics as much as economics driving UK to join USMCA
summary: The UK is exploring joining the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), a North American trade pact, amid a lack of a bilateral trade deal with the US. UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's push for USMCA membership may be driven by disappointment over a US bilateral deal during the current Biden term, which faces opposition due to the Northern Ireland Protocol. The USMCA, originally signed in 1994, has been a cornerstone of economic relations in North America, but its implementation has been marred by controversy, including tensions with Mexico and Canada over worker rights and dairy markets.
