This move aims to secure supply and take advantage of economies of scale, with Daimler planning eight gigafactories in Europe and globally.

site_title: Covid-19 booster shots to be expanded to 50-59 age group from Oct 4
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health has announced that fully vaccinated individuals aged 50-59 will start receiving Covid-19 booster shots on October 4. The booster will be available to those who have completed their primary vaccination regimen at least six months ago. The reduced dosage for the Moderna vaccine booster has been recommended to 50mcg, which is sufficient to boost immune response significantly. The move aims to address the higher risk of underlying comorbidities and severe illness among this age group.

site_title: F&B firms frustrated by return to two-person rule
summary: Food and beverage operators in Singapore expressed disappointment and frustration over the government's decision to reduce social gathering and dine-in numbers to two for a month, citing revenue losses and complicated rental waiver processes. Many felt the measure was too harsh and didn't account for the low number of emerging clusters of infections in the industry. The government has raised the Jobs Support Scheme support level to 25% and introduced a two-week rental waiver for qualifying tenants, but operators still highlighted rent as a continued pain point.

images.alt_text: F&B players say they will face cancelled reservations that have taken months to rebuild, and that the curbs are being imposed without the industry being consulted.

site_title: Evergrande woes to take toll on China property sale and drive M&A
summary: China Evergrande Group's debt crisis is denting homebuyer sentiment and forcing developers to cut prices, signaling deeper consequences for China's economy and property sector. Evergrande, the country's second-largest developer, is struggling with $305 billion in debt and has halted building work at many projects. The crisis is expected to accelerate consolidation in the overcrowded property sector, with some analysts predicting a wave of mergers and acquisitions. Home prices are also expected to decline, with growth in China's property sales slowing to 15.9% in the first eight months of the year.

site_title: Wall Street influencers are making US$500,000, topping even bankers
summary: Financial influencers, like 25-year-old TikToker Austin Hankwitz, are making significant earnings by promoting robo-advisors and other financial products to young investors on social media. Hankwitz's videos have attracted millions of followers, and he earns up to $8,000 per post. Other influencers, such as Haley Sacks, have partnered with firms like Wealthfront, charging thousands of dollars for sponsored content. The finance industry is taking notice, with companies investing heavily in influencer marketing to reach younger audiences. However, there are concerns about the lack of transparency and regulation in the industry, with some influencers posting questionable or misleading advice.

site_title: China adds 460 billion yuan in liquidity in past week to soothe nerves
summary: China's central bank injected a net 460 billion yuan (S$96.27 billion) into the financial system in the past week to alleviate concerns stemming from Evergrande Group's crisis. This move aims to ensure sufficient liquidity and meet demand for funds before China's week-long holiday at the start of October. The cost of borrowing overnight fell to 1.68%, the lowest level since late July, and the benchmark Shanghai stock index rose 0.7% this week.

site_title: S$650m in support for firms hit by tightened Covid-19 restrictions amid exponential surge in cases
summary: Singapore is rolling out S$650 million in support measures for businesses affected by tightened Covid-19 restrictions, which kick in on September 27. The package includes a 25% wage support under the Jobs Support Scheme, rental waivers, and rental relief. The measures aim to slow the pace of infection numbers, buying time for the authorities to stabilise the healthcare system and add new capacity. Despite the tightening, the government remains committed to reopening plans and has left many parameters unchanged.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip on Evergrande woes, weak German business morale
summary: European stocks fell on Friday, with the Stoxx 600 index down 0.9% and retail stocks declining 1.7%, amid concerns over China Evergrande's potential default and weak German business morale. A survey showed German business confidence fell for the third straight month, while the region-wide index had previously rallied. Investors also weighed the upcoming German elections and rising energy prices, which could fuel inflation concerns.

site_title: Lukewarm China land sales signal impact of property crackdown
summary: China's property market continues to cool, with land auctions receiving tepid interest. In Hangzhou, nine out of 10 land parcels went unsold during the second batch of centralised land bidding, a significant drop from January when all four parcels were auctioned at the upper end of prices. The cooling comes amid concerns over China Evergrande's debt crunch, which may lead to a more conservative land acquisition strategy among developers. Home sales by value slumped 20% in August from a year earlier, and the Chinese authorities have introduced over 400 new property regulations this year.

site_title: Hong Kong tycoon Richard Li's insurer FWD files for long-awaited US IPO
summary: Hong Kong-based insurer FWD, backed by billionaire Richard Li, has filed for a US$100 million initial public offering (IPO) in the US, which could potentially raise $2 billion to $3 billion based on investor feedback. The company manages $62.5 billion in assets and has secured commitments from investors including Li Ka Shing Foundation, PCCW, and PCGI Holdings, with PCGI holding a 73% stake in FWD prior to the IPO. FWD aims to list in the fourth quarter, with the final offering size and timing subject to market conditions.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as Evergrande worries persist
summary: US stock indexes opened lower on Friday, following a strong two-day rally, amid worries about debt-laden China Evergrande's spillover. The Dow Jones fell 0.01%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.25%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 0.60%. Nike's sales forecast cut also contributed to the decline. The market continues to be impacted by ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Powell says economy is adjusting to demands of a 'new reality'
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated the economy is experiencing "fundamental shifts" as people and businesses adapt to a "new reality." This shift is seen as an opportunity for businesses, particularly small ones, to showcase creativity and adaptability. Powell's comments come as the Fed Listens event kicks off, aiming to gather on-the-ground information about the recovery. The event marks a review of the Fed's longer-run strategy, which was announced in 2020 with a new framework for monetary policy targeting average inflation.

site_title: Chinese gaming firms vow self-regulation amid crackdown on teen addiction
summary: Chinese gaming companies, including Tencent Holdings and NetEase, have pledged to regulate their industry to combat gaming addiction. Over 200 gaming firms have signed a statement, which includes the use of facial recognition to identify minors, amid a crackdown on teen addiction. China has introduced new rules limiting under-18s' gaming time to three hours a week, and companies worry about further actions against the industry.

site_title: New York, London keep top spots in global financial centres index
summary: New York and London held the top two spots in the latest Global Financial Centres Index, with New York retaining the top spot and London maintaining its second-place position. Chinese cities, including Hong Kong and Shanghai, experienced a decline in ratings. The results suggest that the financial services sectors in New York and London were able to sustain performance despite changes in working practices during the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Bank of China, HSBC among first to trade on new bond link
summary: A new bond link, the Southbound programme, launched in Hong Kong, allowing Chinese investors to purchase debt overseas. Bank of China, HSBC, and Standard Chartered are among the first to trade on the new channel. The programme aims to boost China's offshore bond market and increase issuance of Dim Sum and ESG-compliant notes. Analysts expect it to bring offshore and onshore yields closer, but note that initial investor sentiment may be risk-averse due to recent market turmoil.

site_title: Gold prices firm as softer dollar, Evergrande woes lift appeal
summary: Gold prices rose 0.6% to $1,753.50 per ounce, rebounding from 1-1/2-month lows, due to safe-haven demand amid concerns over China Evergrande's debt crisis. A softer dollar also increased the metal's appeal. Analysts expect gold to trade in a $1,740-$1,780 range in the near term. However, bullion prices may come under pressure in the medium term due to central banks' tapering of pandemic-era stimulus, with UBS predicting gold prices to fall to $1,600 by mid-2022.

site_title: Tighter rules will buy time to roll out booster shots and vaccinate more: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced tighter Covid-19 restrictions, effective from Monday, to slow the exponential rise in cases. Gatherings are limited to two people, dining in is reduced to two, and the number of people allowed to dine in was previously five. The measures will last a month and will be reviewed in two weeks. The government aims to deliver booster shots and vaccinate those still not vaccinated, and is expanding hospital capacity to ensure the healthcare system is not overwhelmed.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Friday, down 7.28 points to 1,532.06. The market saw 561 losers versus 425 gainers, with a total volume of 4.785 billion lots worth RM3.342 billion.

site_title: Richard Li's insurer FWD files for long-awaited IPO
summary: FWD Group Holdings, an Asian insurer backed by billionaire Richard Li, has filed for a US$100 million initial public offering (IPO) in the US. The company, which manages $62.5 billion in assets, aims to raise $2-3 billion. FWD has secured commitments from investors, including the Li Ka Shing Foundation, PCCW, and PCGI Holdings, and has agreed to a strategic partnership with Apollo Global Management. The insurer reported a net profit of $205 million in the first six months of the year, a significant improvement from a net loss last year.

site_title: Home recovery woes: SAF, PA co-opted to help clear backlog
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Health (MOH) is expanding Community Treatment Facilities (CTFs) to cope with the Covid-19 backlog. The CTFs, which will have a higher level of medical care, will be partnered with hospitals for seamless escalation to acute hospitals. The government is also increasing resources for hotline manning and telemedicine, and has enlisted the help of the Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) and People's Association to support the program. With the expansion, Singapore aims to handle 2,000-2,500 new cases daily, and has opened a new CTF at NTUC Health Nursing Home (Tampines) with 250 beds.

site_title: STI slips 0.49% on Evergrande, pandemic concerns
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.49% on Friday, capped by concerns over China Evergrande Group's debt and the rising Covid-19 wave. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 15.09 points to 3,061.35, despite overnight gains on Wall Street. Asian markets mostly fell amid caution, with Japan's benchmark rising 2.06% and Taiwan's up 1.07%. The US Federal Reserve's announcement on tapering strengthened arguments for policy normalisation, but lower growth forecasts show caution is still warranted.

site_title: China deems all crypto-related transactions illegal in crackdown
summary: China's central bank has deemed all cryptocurrency-related transactions as illegal and must be banned. The People's Bank of China stated that cryptocurrencies, including bitcoin and tether, are not fiat currency and cannot be circulated on the market. This move comes as the nation aims to meet carbon goals and root out crypto mining, which is considered an urgent task. As a result, bitcoin dropped as much as 4.5% and other crypto-related stocks tumbled, while the nation's economic planning agency emphasized the importance of the crackdown.

site_title: Southern Alliance Mining's H2 net profit jumps 257 per cent to RM96.7m
summary: Southern Alliance Mining (SAM) reported a 257% jump in net profit to RM96.7 million for the half-year ended July 31, driven by increased iron-ore concentrate sales revenue. Revenue rose 108% to RM235.3 million, and earnings per share increased 254%. The company attributed its growth to strong demand momentum, particularly in Malaysia, and plans to diversify into gold-mining operations. Despite a correction in iron-ore prices, SAM remains confident in its growth prospects.

site_title: Dine-in, social gathering sizes cut to 2 for a month from Sept 27 amid exponential case surge
summary: Singapore will reduce dine-in and social gathering sizes to groups of two from Sept 27 to Oct 24 amid an exponential rise in Covid-19 cases. Fully vaccinated diners can still eat in at regular establishments, while unvaccinated customers are allowed in hawker centres and coffee shops. Households are limited to two unique visitors per day, and social gatherings should not exceed one per day. Work-from-home is the default for employees able to do so, and those unable to work from home are encouraged to do antigen rapid tests weekly.

site_title: Malaysia's central bank to launch alternative reference rate
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia (BNM), will launch the Malaysia Overnight Rate (MYOR) as an alternative reference rate, aiming to offer market participants more flexibility and hedging options. The MYOR will be calculated as the volume-weighted average rate of unsecured overnight ringgit interbank transactions, running in parallel to the existing Kuala Lumpur Interbank Offered Rate (KLIBOR). This move is expected to provide market participants with more options for managing interest rate risk.

site_title: Britain to do whatever it takes to resolve trucker shortage
summary: Britain has vowed to take measures to resolve a trucker shortage that has closed petrol stations and strained supermarket supply chains, with Transport Secretary Grant Shapps stating the government will "do whatever it takes" to alleviate the issue. The shortage, exacerbated by a post-Brexit shortage of truck drivers and a global shortage of truckers, has led to temporary closures of petrol stations and raised fears of a food supply crunch. However, hauliers and logistics companies caution that there are no quick fixes and that any changes to testing or visas may be too late to address the pre-Christmas shortages.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks post weekly decline as Evergrande debt woes continue
summary: South Korean shares declined 0.07% on Friday, marking a weekly drop of 0.49%, amid concerns over China Evergrande's debt burden. The benchmark Kospi fell 2.34 points to 3,125.24. Foreigners were net buyers of 77.3 billion won worth of shares. The Korean won weakened, while the benchmark bond yield rose. Evergrande's offshore bondholders were reportedly not paid interest payments by a Thursday deadline, fueling worries about the property developer's fate.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish week with another loss
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week with losses, with the Hang Seng Index dropping 1.30% to 24,192.16, amid uncertainty over Evergrande's bond payments. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.80% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.70%. The losses were attributed to the lack of information from Evergrande, which has been struggling financially. The decline in Hong Kong stocks was part of a broader market downturn in Asia, with other markets also experiencing losses.

site_title: S$650 million more to help sectors hit by renewed tightening of measures
summary: Singapore announces S$650 million in support for sectors affected by renewed Covid-19 restrictions, including wage support for employers and rental waivers for tenants. The measures, effective from Sept 27 to Oct 24, aim to cushion businesses in sectors such as F&B, retail, and tourism. The government will also provide rental relief and wage support for taxi and private hire car drivers. The funding comes from higher-than-expected revenues collected to date, with no further draw on past reserves.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop at open following gains
summary: Europe's main stock markets dropped at the open on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.2% to 7,065.72 points, and the eurozone's Frankfurt DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices losing 0.6% and 0.5% respectively. The declines were attributed to bank and healthcare sectors. The focus is now on US-EU trade talks, with tariff threats lingering. Despite this, global equities had a largely positive week, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq indices reaching fresh records.

site_title: Structural changes will keep Asian economies resilient despite expected US Fed tightening
summary: Asian economies are expected to remain resilient despite US Federal Reserve tightening due to lower reliance on external financing and significant foreign reserves. Currencies such as the Singapore dollar and Taiwan dollar are in good stead, and Asian central banks may keep interest rates at record lows. While a sharp depreciation in the yuan could threaten the foreign exchange outlook, most Asian currencies are expected to make gains against a softening US dollar as economic growth picks up in 2022. Structural changes in the region, including diversification and upgrades in technology and manufacturing, also offer investment opportunities.

site_title: Factory output tipped to prop up Singapore economy in 2021 despite looming cool-down
summary: Singapore's factory output rose 11.2% in August, driven by the electronics cluster, despite a slowdown in the biomedical industry. Electronics production grew 15.4% and precision engineering 22.9% due to strong demand for semiconductor-related products. Despite a looming supply-side cap, analysts expect manufacturing to sustain the economic recovery this year, with full-year GDP growth forecast at 7.1%. The biomedical industry's dip in output is seen as temporary, with global Covid-19 vaccine production expected to support external demand.

site_title: Analysis: For Xi and China Evergrande, a delicate balancing act
summary: China's President Xi Jinping faces a delicate balancing act as the country's property giant, China Evergrande Group, struggles with a US$305 billion debt crisis. Evergrande's borrow-to-build model, enabled by the government's reliance on property sales, has created a conundrum for Xi, who aims to impose financial discipline without fuelling social unrest. The stakes are high, with Xi poised to secure an unprecedented third five-year term, and the crisis has sparked concerns about the repercussions of a messy collapse, with analysts warning of potential social instability and widespread economic risks.

site_title: Electronics propel Singapore factories to 10th straight month of growth in August
summary: Singapore's factory sector experienced its 10th consecutive month of growth in August, with a 11.2% year-on-year expansion, beating expectations. The electronics cluster drove the growth, with a 15.4% increase, while the biomedical sector declined 0.6%. Other industries, including precision engineering, chemicals, and transport engineering, also showed significant growth. The overall industrial production increased by 5.7% on a seasonally adjusted basis, with biomedical manufacturing contributions excluded.

site_title: Saint Laurent says it will stop using fur in its collections
summary: French high-end fashion brand Saint Laurent will stop using fur in its collections starting next year, joining a growing list of global companies. Kering, its parent company, also announced that Brioni will cease fur use, making all Kering houses fur-free. This decision follows years of lobbying by animal rights groups, including People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA), which protested Saint Laurent's use of fur in a 2021 campaign featuring supermodel Kate Moss. Several other luxury brands, including Gucci and Balenciaga, had previously dropped fur from their collections.

site_title: Edmund Tie inks MOU with One RHT to create digital real estate solutions
summary: Edmund Tie, a real estate consulting firm, has entered into a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with One RHT to create digital real estate solutions. The partnership aims to provide investors with more choice and flexibility, leveraging the growing momentum of real estate tokenisation in Singapore. One RHT will advise Edmund Tie on various subjects, including tax compliance, tokenisation, and intellectual property protection. The MOU is aligned with Singapore's greening of real estate, with One RHT's team of sustainability consultants offering environmental, social, and corporate governance solutions.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks surge at close after US rally
summary: Tokyo stocks surged 2.06% on Friday, driven by US market rallies, easing concerns over Evergrande's financial troubles. The Nikkei 225 index rose 609.41 points to 30,248.81, while the Topix index advanced 47.20 points to 2,090.75. This follows US market gains and amid US-EU trade talks, and comes after a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks.

site_title: Daimler takes 33% stake in European battery cell venture ACC
summary: Daimler's Mercedes-Benz is taking a 33% stake in battery cell manufacturer Automotive Cells Company (ACC) alongside Stellantis and TotalEnergies. The partnership aims to develop cells and modules in Europe, ensuring the region remains at the heart of the auto industry. ACC will supply Mercedes-Benz with battery technology starting in the mid-decade, and the cells produced will be 95% recyclable. Daimler plans to invest over $1 billion and has set a goal of becoming all-electric by 2030, with plans for eight gigafactories in Europe and the US.

site_title: Vietnam delays reopening resort island over low vaccination rate
summary: Vietnam has postponed the reopening of Phu Quoc resort island to foreign tourists until November due to a low vaccination rate among residents. The island initially planned to welcome vaccinated tourists in October but failed to meet inoculation targets, citing insufficient vaccine supplies. As of now, only 2.9% of residents in the hosting province have received two doses, and the country's overall vaccination rate stands at 7.3%. Authorities plan to allow up to 3,000-5,000 visitors per week, with compulsory Covid-19 tests and a possible seven-day quarantine period.

images.alt_text: Vietnam has pushed back a plan to re-open the resort island of Phu Quoc to foreign tourists until November, after failing to meet targets for inoculating residents due to insufficient vaccine supplies, state media reported.

site_title: Amazon launches service aggregating video streaming apps in India
summary: Amazon has launched Amazon Channels in India, a service that aggregates video streaming apps, allowing Prime customers to subscribe to multiple services on a single interface. The service, available on Prime Video, includes streaming services from Discovery, Lions Gate Entertainment, and Mubi, among others. The move aims to boost subscriptions and provide a single platform for customers to access multiple streaming services. Amazon's head of Prime Video in India, Gaurav Gandhi, believes the service will benefit both customers and partners, improving the reach and distribution of content.

site_title: Tycoons make billions from Russian property in pandemic boom
summary: Russian property tycoons have amassed billions in wealth during the pandemic, driven by a government-mandated mortgage-subsidy program and a housing boom. Sergey Gordeev's PIK Group has seen its net worth more than double to $8.9 billion, while Samolet Group's Pavel Golubkov and Mikhail Kenin have each gained over $1 billion. The housing market has surged 14.4% in Russia, with mortgage originations rising to $7.5 billion in June, despite concerns about the sustainability of the boom and potential risks of a housing bubble.

site_title: SIA Engineering signs new maintenance agreement with Hawaiian Airlines
summary: SIA Engineering Company signed a new 12-year airframe maintenance agreement with Hawaiian Airlines for its Airbus A330-200 fleet, commencing in March 2022. The agreement expands existing services, covering 12-year checks, at SIAEC's Singapore facility. The deal is seen as a testament to the successful relationship between the two companies and demonstrates Hawaiian Airlines' confidence in SIAEC's airframe maintenance services. The transaction is not expected to significantly impact SIAEC's earnings or net tangible assets for the current financial year.

site_title: Brokers' take: Bharti rights issue may lessen Singtel's chances of special dividends
summary: Singtel plans to fully subscribe to Bharti Airtel's 21,000 crore rupees (S$3.8 billion) rights issue at 535 rupees per share, exercising its full rights entitlement for its 14% stake. Analysts from CGS-CIMB view this as a sensible move, considering Bharti's improving prospects and easing mobile competition in India. The move may reduce the size of potential special dividends from asset monetization, but Singtel should be able to afford the rights issue with its S$755 million cash pile. The research team reiterates an "add" call on Singtel, with an unchanged target price of S$2.90.

site_title: Japan welcomes Taiwan bid to join trade pact, citing shared values
summary: Japan has welcomed Taiwan's application to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), citing shared democratic values. Economy Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura stated that Japan considers Taiwan a "very important partner" with fundamental values such as freedom, democracy, and rule of law. In contrast, Japan has been cautious about China's bid to join the pact, citing strict rules related to state-owned enterprises. The decision allows Taiwan to move forward with its application, which was met with anger from China.

site_title: As Hanoi eases strict lockdown rules, workers still stay away from the office
summary: Hanoi, Vietnam's capital, is easing strict lockdown rules, allowing offices to reopen at 50% capacity and construction projects to resume. However, many white-collar workers remain hesitant to return to the office, citing difficulties in remote work and stress at the office. Employers are adapting to a new workplace culture, with some companies opting for flexible office solutions and others prioritizing employee health and safety. The city's COVID-19 cases have decreased, with 94% of the adult population vaccinated, but the prolonged lockdown may impact long-term workplace dynamics.

site_title: Thai August exports rise 8.9% y-o-y, below forecast
summary: Thailand's exports rose 8.93% in August from a year earlier, below the forecasted 13.5% increase. This follows July's 20.27% increase. Commerce Minister Jurin Laksanawisit attributed the slowdown to coronavirus restrictions affecting manufacturing and logistics. The data contradicts earlier statements by the minister, who mentioned the restrictions as a reason for the previous month's increase. The August export growth rate is lower than expected, indicating a potential slowdown in the country's economy.

site_title: McDonald's restarts share buybacks as business recovers from pandemic hit
summary: McDonald's Corp has restarted its US$15 billion share buyback program as the company recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic. The world's largest fast-food chain increased its quarterly dividend by 7% to US$1.38 per share, taking the total dividend payout to over US$1 billion. Global sales are now above pre-pandemic levels, with McDonald's raising its guidance for fiscal 2021. The company's decision to restart share buybacks and increase dividends reflects its confidence in the recovery of the restaurant industry.

site_title: KTL Global says independent review may take 3-5 months; shares to remain suspended
summary: KTL Global expects an independent review of the company to take 3-5 months, with shares remaining suspended since August 17. The review follows queries from the Securities Investors Association (Singapore) regarding the company's FY2020 annual report. The main issue is related to the transactions of subsidiary Bluegas with four branding, operation and procurement (BOP) customers in China, including irregularities in accounting treatment of receipts. The company's board and management remain in possession of Bluegas's company seals and legal documents, and a new CEO is expected to bring business opportunities and connections to support growth.

site_title: Jobs Growth Incentive extended to March 2022 but support reduced: MOM
summary: Singapore's Jobs Growth Incentive (JGI) will be extended to March 2022 to support employers hiring locals, with reduced support of 15% for non-mature workers and 50% for mature workers, persons with disabilities, or ex-offenders. The scheme aims to encourage employers to hire locals during the extended period, as the labour market continues to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic. The reduced support is in line with improving economic conditions.

site_title: Japan's ruling party race puts legacy of Abenomics in focus
summary: Japan's ruling party is holding a leadership contest to decide the next prime minister, with a focus on addressing the country's widening wealth gap. The contest comes as a government survey shows that households hardly benefited from former premier Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" policies, despite a boom in share prices and corporate profits. Candidates, including Taro Kono and Fumio Kishida, have pledged to focus on boosting household wealth, with Kishida proposing targeted payouts to low-income households. The winner of the leadership vote, set for September 29, will become Japan's next prime minister.

site_title: Japan's Sept manufacturing activity growth slows: flash PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity growth slowed in September, with the manufacturing PMI index at 51.2, the slowest pace in eight months. Output and orders contracted, and the services sector remained in its downturn due to the coronavirus pandemic. The Delta variant and global semiconductor chip shortage contributed to the decline. Manufacturers' input prices rose at the fastest pace in 13 years, while the services sector contraction eased slightly. The economy's protracted impact on the pandemic continues to be a concern.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares dip at Friday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly lower on Friday morning, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.10% to 24,487.24, following gains in the previous two trading days. Investors are awaiting developments on Evergrande, a Chinese property giant. The Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.12% to 3,637.87 and the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.19% to 2,446.60.

site_title: 'We've been expecting you, Mr Bond...': 007 back after virus delay
summary: The James Bond film "No Time To Die" is set to have its world premiere in London's Royal Albert Hall next week, marking nearly six years since the last Bond film and an 18-month delay caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The film, directed by Cary Joji Fukunaga, stars Daniel Craig in his final appearance as 007, alongside Rami Malek and Lea Seydoux. The film's producers hope it will help bring movie-goers back to cinemas worldwide, with the film set to release globally on October 8.

site_title: Ex-head of Chinese liquor giant Moutai jailed for life for bribery
summary: A former head of Chinese liquor firm Kweichow Moutai, Yuan Renguo, has been jailed for life for taking over 112.9 million yuan (S$23.6 million) in bribes between 1994 and 2018. The court stripped him of his political rights and confiscated his personal property. Yuan, a former Communist Party cadre and local government advisory group member, was found guilty of accepting more in bribes than he earned during his time at the company.

site_title: Aspen clarifies timeline leading up to price surge in another response to SGX
summary: Aspen clarified its timeline regarding a price surge in its shares, stating it received a 510(k) clearance for its latex examination powder free gloves on Sept 22, despite claiming it was unaware of any explanation for the trading. The clearance was actually obtained on Sept 20, but Aspen's glove unit received it on Sept 22. This came in response to further questioning from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) about the unusual price movements on Sept 22.

site_title: Carlos Ghosn can't wait to sell Renault shares after Nissan exit
summary: Carlos Ghosn, former Nissan executive and international fugitive, is eager to sell his Renault shares after his exit from the company. He believes the Renault-Nissan alliance is "doomed" due to lingering power struggles and has no trust in the management. Ghosn has lost nearly $30 billion in market value for the two companies since his arrest in 2018. He denies charges against him and is working on a sequel to his memoir to defend his legacy. Ghosn remains optimistic about his appeal of a Dutch court's ruling and hopes to be cleared by another court.

site_title: China Evergrande bondholders in limbo over debt resolution
summary: China Evergrande is facing uncertainty as it struggles to pay its US$305 billion in debts, leaving investors worried about a potential default. Despite appointing financial advisers and resolving one coupon payment, the company has not addressed two imminent interest payments, leaving bondholders on edge. Global markets are watching for signs of default, which could pose systemic risks to China's financial system and reverberate worldwide. A restructuring agreement is likely, but the outcome remains uncertain, with investors expecting little recovery.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed with outlook upbeat but Evergrande crisis simmering
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Friday, with Tokyo leading gains and Hong Kong, Shanghai, and other cities also rising. Despite concerns over the Evergrande debt crisis, investors remained optimistic about the global recovery outlook, citing a potential tapering of the Federal Reserve's monetary easing program. The crisis has eased somewhat, with Evergrande agreeing to pay interest on a local bond payment and regulators urging the firm to avoid a near-term default. However, the situation remains uncertain, and fears of a "Lehman Moment" persist, with US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi promising to have a deal ready to raise the debt ceiling by the end of the month.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened flat on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.44 points to 1,539.78. A total of 306.61 million lots were traded worth RM149.99 million. The market saw a slight edge to gainers, with 231 stocks gaining and 155 losing.

site_title: Four of Trump's allies summoned by parliamentary committee proving Capitol riot
summary: Four members of Donald Trump's inner circle, including Mark Meadows, received subpoenas to appear before a congressional committee investigating the January 6 US Capitol riot. The committee aims to determine what Trump said and did on the day of the attack. The Democratic-controlled committee is scrutinizing Trump, whom Democrats accuse of being responsible for the deadly assault on the US democracy. The committee's focus on Trump's allies and associates is part of an effort to shed light on the events surrounding the riot.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, extending gains on Wall Street, following the Federal Reserve's indication it could soon unwind its easing. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.66% or 491.91 points to 30,131.31, while the Topix index advanced 1.57% or 32.08 points to 2,075.63. This follows similar gains on Wall Street, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff concerns.

site_title: Uber to roll out pension plans for UK drivers
summary: Uber plans to roll out pension plans to eligible drivers in the UK, following a Supreme Court ruling that reclassified its drivers as workers. The company will contribute 3% of drivers' earnings and offer a minimum 5% contribution option. Uber is also urging other ride-hailing companies to offer similar benefits, with plans to create a cross-industry pension scheme. The move comes after Uber granted workers' rights to its drivers in the UK in March.

site_title: Australia should do more to contain housing bubble, climate change: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned Australia to take action to contain the country's rapidly rising housing market and address climate change. The IMF advises tightening home loan standards to support the economy and reduce financial risks. It also calls for more action on climate change, urging Australia to set a "time-bound" target to reach net zero emissions by 2050. The IMF forecasts 3.5% economic growth in 2021 and 4.1% in 2022, despite near-term risks due to the COVID-19 Delta variant.

site_title: Tycoon Richard Li's insurer FWD files for long-awaited US IPO
summary: FWD, a Hong Kong-based insurer backed by billionaire Richard Li, filed for a US IPO, listing the offering size as $100 million, with potential to raise $2-3 billion. The company aims to sell shares in the fourth quarter, with Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs, and JPMorgan Chase leading the offering. FWD manages $62.5 billion in assets and has secured commitments from investors including Li Ka Shing Foundation, PCCW, and PCGI Holdings, with a strategic partnership with Athene Life Re and Apollo Global Management.

site_title: Stocks to watch: IReit Global, SIAEC, Hong Leong Asia, LHN, GS Holdings
summary: IReit Global acquired a Barcelona office building for $43.1 million, while SIA Engineering signed an agreement with Hawaiian Airlines for airframe maintenance services. Hong Leong Asia's US-listed subsidiary China Yuchai entered a joint venture to research new energy technologies. LHN Limited entered a 30-70 joint venture to purchase properties, and GS Holdings' subsidiary signed a franchise agreement to expand halal chicken rice in Qatar. TTJ Holdings reported a net profit of $1.6 million for the half-year ended July 31.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Friday's open tracking global rally; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.3% to 3,086.85 on Friday, driven by a global market rally. Gainers outnumbered losers 91 to 47, with heavily traded securities including Sembcorp Marine, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, and Rex International. Banking stocks also advanced, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC up 0.5%, 0.4%, and 0.7% respectively. The rally followed a positive session in US and European markets, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and pan-European Stoxx 600 index rising 1.5% and 0.9% respectively.

images.alt_text: Gainers outnumbered losers 91 to 47, or about two securities up for every one down, after 77.3 million securities worth S$80.1 million changed hands.

site_title: IReit Global acquires Grade A office building in Barcelona for 27.2m euros
summary: IReit Global's wholly-owned subsidiary has acquired a Grade A office building in Barcelona, Spain, for 27.2 million euros (S$43.1 million). The 15,510 sq m building has a committed occupancy of 64% and a weighted average lease expiry of 6.8 years. The acquisition brings the number of Spain properties in IReit's portfolio to five, with the building located in a sought-after area 20 minutes from Barcelona's financial district. The purchase represents a discount of about 4.5% to the building's independent valuation.

site_title: Twitter courts influencers with bitcoin tips and NFT craze
summary: Twitter has begun allowing high-profile users to receive bitcoin tips, as part of its efforts to attract and retain content creators and their audiences. The platform is also testing a system to verify non-fungible tokens (NFTs), which have seen a surge in popularity. Twitter aims to make its platform a more welcoming space for creators, with tools to filter out offensive comments and provide "heads up" prompts for potentially heated conversations. The move is part of Twitter's strategy to attract and retain creators, who have driven popularity among younger users on platforms like TikTok and Instagram.

site_title: UK consumer morale wilts under cost-of-living crisis: GfK
summary: UK consumer morale has plummeted to its lowest level since April due to growing concerns over energy bills, food costs, and tax hikes. The GfK Consumer Confidence Index fell to -13 in September, marking the largest monthly drop since October 2020. This comes as the Bank of England signaled a possible interest rate hike to combat inflation, which is expected to exceed 4% by the end of the year. Consumer confidence is now at its lowest since the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: US lawmakers weigh further crackdown on 'air rage' villains
summary: US lawmakers are considering a crackdown on "air rage" incidents, which have surged during the pandemic. Proposed measures include more criminal charges for violent passengers, a shared national no-fly list, and halting "to-go" alcohol sales at airports. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has made progress in addressing the issue since introducing a "zero tolerance" policy, but incidents remain a serious safety threat. Lawmakers are urging the Justice Department to criminally charge worst offenders and for airlines to implement stricter measures to prevent unruly behavior.

site_title: UK's Sunak set to tighten financial regulations after Greensill scandal
summary: British finance minister Rishi Sunak has ordered two reviews of UK financial regulation in response to the Greensill Capital scandal, which highlighted risks in the $1.3 trillion supply chain finance business. Sunak has accepted a parliamentary committee's call for reform of the "appointed representatives regime" and commissioned the UK treasury to review the regime, including legislative reforms to strengthen oversight. The move aims to reduce opportunities for abuse in the system.

site_title: Blinken says rebuilding France ties will take time
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken acknowledged that repairing ties with France will take time after a canceled mega-contract, following talks with French counterpart Emmanuel Macron. Blinken reiterated the White House statement on open consultations among allies, showing respect for French Foreign Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian. The US is committed to working closely with France on this effort, but acknowledges it will require time and hard work.

site_title: Oil prices rise, hit two-month highs on supply worries
summary: Oil prices rose to two-month highs, with Brent crude reaching $77.25 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude rising to $73.30 a barrel, driven by growing fuel demand and concerns over supply issues, particularly in the Gulf of Mexico. US crude inventories fell by 3.5 million barrels, and Opec+ production remains hampered by under-investment and maintenance delays. Supply concerns and the potential for higher interest rates from the Federal Reserve also supported prices.

site_title: MG 5 EV review: An electric car without the sticker shock
summary: The MG 5 EV, a Chinese-made electric station wagon, has been praised for its affordability, smooth ride, and instant electric acceleration, making it a standout in the market. Priced at around S$130,000, it offers a high level of features and space, with a 495-liter boot and ample legroom. The car's electric hardware has some drawbacks, such as a high seating position and less supportive seats, but overall, it excels as a car, with a long electric range of over 400km and fast charging capabilities. Its Chinese provenance may be a concern for some, but its value and performance make it a compelling option.

site_title: The CHIJ old girl now in charge at Rolls-Royce
summary: Irene Nikkein, a 41-year-old Singaporean, has been appointed as the new regional director of Rolls-Royce Motor Cars for the Asia-Pacific region. Nikkein, who was born in Indonesia, has an "exceptional track record" and extensive regional knowledge, according to Rolls-Royce. She joins the company after previously working at BMW Asia and Mini Japan, and takes over the position from Paul Harris. Nikkein's appointment comes as Rolls-Royce works on its first pure electric car and pursues a more understated design direction.

site_title: Facebook ordered to release anti-Rohingya posts for genocide case
summary: A US judge ordered Facebook to release posts the social network removed for inciting violence against the Rohingya people in Myanmar. The ruling comes after Facebook resisted releasing content due to US privacy law, but the judge ruled the deleted posts wouldn't be covered under protections. The decision is seen as a boost for The Gambia's case against Myanmar at the International Court of Justice, which accuses the country of breaching the 1948 UN genocide convention. Facebook has made voluntary disclosures to the UN Human Rights Council's Independent Investigative Mechanism for Myanmar.

site_title: Over 70% of Singapore consumers open to switching to digital banks: survey
summary: Over 70% of Singapore consumers are open to switching to digital banks, signaling strong competition for traditional banks. Despite many banks increasing their digital capabilities, only 20-30% of respondents in the Asia-Pacific region have purchased banking products through mobile apps or online. New digital-first players, such as Mox Bank and the Grab-Singtel consortium, are expected to capitalize on this trend. To stay relevant, incumbents must modernize technology and acquire new skills while managing the costs of legacy networks and systems.

site_title: US Democratic leader vows to avert government shutdown
summary: US Democratic leader Speaker Nancy Pelosi vowed to pass a government funding package by September 30, despite Republican opposition. The House passed a "continuing resolution" to keep federal agencies open until December 3, but Democrats also attached a debt ceiling suspension. Economists warn that failure to extend the debt limit could erase six million jobs and wipe out US$15 trillion in household wealth. Republicans are refusing to help due to protests over President Joe Biden's public works package and infrastructure spending bill. Pelosi claims Democrats can pass the necessary legislation without Republican backing.

site_title: Disabled people can now use Android phones with face gestures
summary: Google has introduced two new tools to make Android smartphones more accessible to people with speech and physical disabilities. The "Camera Switches" feature allows users to control their phones with facial gestures, such as raising an eyebrow or smiling, while the "Project Activate" app enables users to trigger actions like sending texts or making calls using customised eye movements and facial gestures. The free app is available in four countries, including the US, Britain, Canada, and Australia, and aims to make Android more accessible to the estimated 61 million adults in the US living with disabilities.

site_title: Recognise the Taliban? World powers face Afghan dilemma
summary: The international community is grappling with whether to recognize the Taliban as the rulers of Afghanistan, weighing concerns over their Islamist vision against the need for stability. Despite opening channels of communication, world powers have not made recognition official, and the Taliban have begun to show impatience. Western countries, including Germany and the US, are cautious due to the Taliban's brutal past, particularly regarding women's rights. The West is using economic pressure, including freezing Afghan bank accounts and suspending IMF disbursements, to influence the Taliban's actions.

site_title: Fed seems to have learned from infamous 2013 taper tantrum
summary: The US Federal Reserve signaled a shift in its monetary policy, indicating it may start tapering bond purchases as soon as its next meeting on November 2 and raising interest rates as soon as next year. This move is seen as a clear signal that the retreat from pandemic-era stimulus programs has begun, aiming to combat rising inflation. Unlike the infamous "taper tantrum" of 2013, the Fed has carefully foreshadowed its decision, striking a positive tone and acknowledging the US economy's strength. This move is expected to boost the stock market and ease investor anxiety.

site_title: Emerging markets cheer as Evergrande dodges bullet
summary: Emerging market stocks rose 0.6% on Thursday, driven by relief over Evergrande's coupon payment and interest payments on offshore bonds. MSCI's index of EM shares extended gains for a third straight session. The US Federal Reserve hinted at tapering monetary policy, weakening the dollar. Turkey's central bank is expected to hold rates, while South Africa's rate is expected to remain low. Central banks in Brazil, Russia, and Hungary also made interest rate decisions, with Brazil's central bank hiking rates by 100 basis points.

site_title: US: Stocks extend post-Federal Reserve rally, Dow + 1.5%
summary: US stocks rose for a second consecutive session, driven by improved sentiment over China's Evergrande and US monetary policy. Despite disappointing labor data, investors are optimistic about the Federal Reserve's intentions to taper asset purchases, with Chair Jerome Powell indicating near-term action. The Dow Jones surged 1.5% as investors await November's announcement. This rally follows recent rallies in Europe and Asia, with key stocks such as Singtel and Sinarmas Land also making gains.

site_title: Nike cuts sales forecast, citing worsening supply chain woes
summary: Nike cut its sales forecast for fiscal 2022 due to worsening supply chain problems, citing a doubling of shipping times from Asian manufacturing centers to North America and factory closures in Vietnam and Indonesia. The company reported profits of $1.9 billion and revenues of $12.2 billion in the quarter ending August 31, but fell short of analyst expectations. Nike attributed the decline to increased wages, digital marketing, and higher shipping costs, resulting in a "lack of available supply." Shares fell 3.2% in after-hours trading.

site_title: China's policy changes amid broader demographic shifts present investment opportunities
summary: China's recent policy changes, aimed at increasing childbirths and alleviating demographic pressures, present investment opportunities in sectors such as maternity and children businesses, pet-related products, and the "silver hair economy". The government's efforts to encourage more births may not be enough to reverse the decline, but could mitigate the decrease by 0.5 to 0.6 million babies per annum. Other sectors, such as education and beauty, are also poised for growth due to shifting consumer preferences. Investors should consider the long-term implications of these trends and have a deep understanding of the strategies and capabilities required to succeed in these markets.

site_title: Impossible Foods to roll out meatless pork in HK, Singapore, US
summary: Impossible Foods is set to roll out its meatless pork product in Hong Kong and Singapore, starting with 120 restaurants in Hong Kong on October 4. The product, made from soya, will also be sold in grocery stores and debuted at New York's Momofuku Ssam Bar. The company aims to continually drive down prices as it does with its Impossible Beef products. A public listing is also in the works, potentially valuing the company at over $10 billion.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rally for third day, FTSE 100 struggles after Bank of England comments
summary: European stocks rose 0.9% for a third day, driven by easing concerns over China Evergrande, while the UK's FTSE 100 fell 0.1% after the Bank of England increased inflation forecasts, citing a strengthened case for higher interest rates. European banks led gains, but UK shares lagged.

site_title: Australia's APA Group complains against AusNet Services in takeover dispute
summary: APA Group has approached the Takeovers Panel to scrap AusNet Services' exclusive deal with Brookfield Asset Management in a takeover battle. APA had raised its offer to A$9.96 billion for AusNet, which owns the Victorian electricity transmission network. AusNet rejected APA's previously undisclosed bid and granted exclusive due diligence to Brookfield. Analysts warn Brookfield's bid may face scrutiny on national security grounds due to its potential 100% foreign ownership of the network. The matter is currently under investigation by the Takeovers Panel.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hong Leong Asia's US-listed subsidiary China Yuchai signed an agreement with the Government of Nanning Municipality to research, develop, and construct new production capacity for new energy technologies, including fuel cell systems and hybrid power systems. Dutech Holdings announced it will delist on Oct 4 due to a low free float. GS Holdings signed a franchise agreement to expand its Sing Swee Kee brand to Qatar. LHN Group entered a joint venture to purchase properties in Singapore, with 70% control.

site_title: Covid-19 hastens a new era in philanthropy: Seven key trends
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated a new era in philanthropy, characterized by a sense of immediacy and responsible participation in a fast-changing world. Seven key trends define the future of philanthropy in Asia, including increased collaborations and collectives, addressing sustainable food systems, and combating climate change. Philanthropists are shifting their priorities to create impact now, with a focus on mega donations, time-limited foundations, and responsible investing. This trend is driven by a younger, more tech-savvy generation and a growing desire to leverage wealth and assets to drive social and environmental impact.

site_title: Taiwan applies to join Pacific trade deal days after China
summary: Taiwan has applied to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), a major trade deal signed by 11 Asian countries in 2018. The move comes days after China expressed interest in joining the pact, which aims to keep China isolated. The US-led deal would be a significant development for Taiwan, which has sought to strengthen its economic ties with the US and other like-minded countries. Japan has welcomed the move, while China's inclusion could complicate its efforts to isolate Taiwan internationally.

site_title: Hedge fund to offer crypto- investing that cuts volatility
summary: Cambrian Asset Management, a US$200 million hedge fund, is launching two active crypto-investing trusts tied to Bitcoin and Ethereum, offering exposure to the virtual-money boom with reduced volatility. The trusts will charge a 4% management fee and are open to accredited investors. The firm's systematic model dials exposures up and down based on market signals, cutting downside volatility by over 70% compared to a passive bet. The launch comes as crypto demand has cooled, with Bitcoin down 33% from its peak in April, and regulatory crackdowns have increased.

site_title: Korean bar treats at Anju
summary: The article reviews Anju, a Korean restaurant in Singapore, describing it as a stylish eatery serving crowd-pleasing, familiar Korean dishes. The menu, crafted by head chef Kim Gi Deok, offers a mix of traditional and modern Korean flavors, with dishes like Bori prawns, Domi carpaccio, and Hogan Jeon. While the food is not complex, it is well-tuned to the local palate and appealing to non-Koreans. The restaurant's friendly pricing and good food make it a great option, earning a rating of 7 out of 10.

site_title: European businesses urge China to open up, avoid 'inward' turn
summary: European businesses in China are urging the country to open up and avoid an "inward" turn of the economy, citing increased control and restrictions on foreign firms' technology and components. The European Union Chamber of Commerce in China reported that Beijing's focus on building core technologies domestically could lead to massive mis-allocation of resources and slower innovation. The chamber has laid out 930 recommendations for the government, highlighting contradictions between China's self-reliance and openness.

site_title: VTL has created sustained interest in Germany tours: travel agencies
summary: Travel agencies in Singapore see increased interest in leisure trips to Germany, following the Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) arrangement. However, many are waiting for similar arrangements with other destinations and a stabilised Covid-19 situation before reviving leisure travel.

site_title: Temasek-backed Oxford Nanopore prices IPO that may yield valuation of up to £3.8b
summary: Oxford Nanopore Technologies, a DNA-sequencing company backed by Oracle and Temasek, is pricing its IPO at £476 million, valuing it as high as £3.8 billion. The company plans to use the funds to fund future growth, capitalizing on its success in pandemic work.

site_title: Norway's crown leads charge vs US dollar after rate hike
summary: Norway's central bank raised interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point to 0.25%, leading to a rally in the Norwegian crown against the US dollar, which climbed 0.7% to its highest levels since mid-June. The decision overshadowed the US Federal Reserve's decision to start tapering bond purchases by November, causing the dollar to weaken broadly against its rivals. The crown reached 10.07 crowns per euro, while the dollar fell 0.4% against a basket of rivals, with the euro reaching a month high at $1.1721.

site_title: Egon Zehnder's boss takes more human-centric approach to leadership
summary: Egon Zehnder's first female chair, Jill Ader, is leading a human-centric approach to leadership, valuing qualities like curiosity, modesty, empathy, vulnerability, and inclusion. This approach complements traditional business acumen, emphasizing emotional intelligence and compassion to build productive and inspiring workplaces. Ader's approach has gained traction, with 90% of CEOs surveyed agreeing that the CEO has moved into the centre of louder, more diverse voices. To develop desired traits, Egon Zehnder has developed a scientifically-based model, assessing individuals on curiosity, insight, engagement, and determination.

site_title: Bank of England nudges up inflation outlook, split over quantitative easing widens
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) has revised its inflation outlook, predicting it will rise above 4% later this year, and two policymakers called for an early end to quantitative easing due to rising price pressures. The MPC voted to stick with its £895 billion asset purchase target and kept interest rates at 0.1%. The BOE also downgraded its GDP growth expectations and expects inflation to temporarily rise above 4% in the final quarter of the year.

site_title: Eurozone business activity slowed in Sept, input costs hit over two-decade high
summary: The Eurozone's business activity slowed in September, with the Flash Composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to a five-month low of 56.1, down from 59.0 in August. Input costs hit a two-decade high, with the input costs sub-index reaching 70.5. Growth is expected to weaken further if supply headwinds persist, and optimism about future output fell to an eight-month low.

site_title: Putting the debate on prize money to bed
summary: Singaporean athletes received significantly lower prize money for Paralympic medals compared to Olympic medals, sparking debate on equality and inclusiveness. Paralympians receive only one-fifth of the prize money awarded to Olympians, despite both events promoting inclusivity. Companies and governments are urged to address this inequality, with proponents arguing that the Olympics' competitiveness justifies higher prize money for medal-winning Olympians.

site_title: Facebook chief technology officer Mike Schroepfer to step down
summary: Facebook's chief technology officer Mike Schroepfer will step down next year after a 13-year tenure. He will be replaced by Andrew Bosworth, another longtime Facebook executive. This move comes as Facebook continues to evolve and expand into new technologies such as AI, virtual reality, and the blockchain.

site_title: Industrial S-Reits' return on assets most resilient: IREUS
summary: Singapore-listed industrial real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) experienced the smallest decline in their return on average assets (ROAA) during the COVID-19 crisis, averaging a 0.5 percentage point drop in FY2020. In contrast, retail, hospitality, and healthcare players saw their ROAAs decline, with hospitality S-Reits recording negative numbers in FY2020. Despite the challenges, industrial S-Reits' average ROAA remained robust, easing by a mild 1.3 percentage points to 2.1% from FY2019, with data centre-focused Keppel DC Reit enjoying the biggest upside, exceeding the sector average of 2.9%.

site_title: Nestle, Swatch among companies exposed to physical climate risks: major investors
summary: Major investors with $10 trillion in assets have identified 50 companies worldwide, including Nestle, Swatch, and Galp Energia, as being highly exposed to physical climate risks such as flooding, droughts, and extreme heat. The companies are in various sectors, including energy, mining, food, pharmaceuticals, and transport. The Institutional Investors Group On Climate Change (IIGCC) has published expectations for companies to build resilience to physical climate change risks, including scenario testing and reporting against risk metrics. The move comes ahead of global climate talks in Scotland in November, where governments are being urged to accelerate efforts to reach net zero emissions by 2050.

site_title: Airbus leads the way as aviation industry sets out green goals
summary: Airbus and the aviation industry set a goal to reach net-zero carbon emissions by 2050, calling for cooperation among airports, airlines, and air traffic systems. The planemaker emphasized the need for alternative fuels, lightweight materials, and a revised air traffic system. However, critics argue that the transition could lead to increased fares. Industry leaders agreed on the need for public and private investment to reduce carbon emissions, with some executives expressing concerns about the feasibility of low-emission bio-based fuels.

site_title: 1,504 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore; two unvaccinated women die
summary: Singapore reported 1,504 new Covid-19 cases, the highest daily total since the pandemic began, with 1,218 in the community and 273 among dormitory residents. Two unvaccinated women, aged 71 and 93, have died, raising the death toll to 70. The majority of new cases are seniors above 60 years old. Large clusters were also announced at a pre-school and two dormitories.

site_title: Singtel commits US$405m to Bharti Airtel's 21,000 crore rupees rights issue
summary: Singtel commits US$405 million to Bharti Airtel's 21,000 crore rupees rights issue, signaling confidence in India and Airtel's growth prospects. The move, valued at 535 rupees per share, translates to a total consideration of up to 29.4 billion rupees. Singtel believes the funds raised will enable Airtel to invest in 5G capabilities and ride India's digital growth momentum.

site_title: Worsening chip woes to cost automakers US$210 billion in sales
summary: The global semiconductor shortage has worsened, with automakers facing a US$210 billion hit in sales in 2021, according to AlixPartners. The shortage, which began late last year, has led to a 90% increase in costs and a 7.7 million vehicle production shortfall this year, nearly double the previous estimate. Supply chain efforts have been insufficient, with inventory exhausted and factory shutdowns in key supply centers in South-east Asia. The shortage is expected to last for years, with car prices reaching a record US$43,355 in the US and dealers resorting to renting cars to display in their showrooms.

site_title: Thailand to start shipping line to boost status as logistics hub
summary: Thailand plans to launch a national shipping company, dubbed Thai National Shipping Line, to bolster its trade capabilities and become a bigger player in global logistics. The company will be a private entity, with the government owning 49% through the Port Authority of Thailand. Its first services will be domestic freight routes in 2022, with plans to expand regional and international routes. The move aims to reduce reliance on foreign ships, increase tonnage, and handle strategic goods and energy products for national security. The launch is expected to boost exports, which have expanded 16.2% in the first seven months of 2021.

site_title: JPMorgan agrees to pay US$15.7m to settle spoofing lawsuit
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co agreed to pay US$15.7 million to settle a class action lawsuit alleging intentional manipulation of US Treasury futures and options prices. The lawsuit, stemming from US government investigations into spoofing, was settled without admitting wrongdoing. This payment recovers less than one-third of estimated classwide damages, with lawyers seeking up to US$5.2 million in legal fees. The settlement follows JPMorgan's prior agreement to pay US$920 million to settle US government probes into spoofing in Treasuries and precious metals.

site_title: Jaguar's F-Pace SVR could be a future classic - but not for the reasons you think
summary: Jaguar's F-Pace SVR, a high-performance variant of the F-Pace SUV, has been unveiled in Singapore. The F-Pace SVR boasts a 5.0-liter supercharged V8 engine producing 550 horsepower, accelerating from 0-100km/h in just four seconds and reaching a top speed of 286km/h. The car is part of Jaguar Land Rover's Special Vehicle Operations (SVO) division, which creates bespoke, high-performance models for demanding customers. SVO's business model is focused on delivering high margins, with the F-Pace SVR priced at S$442,999. The division's success has been attributed to its ability to create cars that command high prices, making them profitable for Jaguar Land Rover.

site_title: Art Basel fair breathes life back into moribund market
summary: Art Basel, the world's top contemporary art fair, has returned to Basel, Switzerland, after a year's gap due to COVID-19 curbs, drawing wealthy buyers and reviving the moribund market. Despite the absence of US collectors, galleries showcased emerging artists and major figures, with several large galleries already reporting seven-figure sales. The fair has exceeded expectations, with three-quarters of works sold by mid-afternoon, and is seen as a barometer for art market trends. The event's return is a significant boost to the art market, which fell 22% in 2020, and highlights the importance of art fairs in meeting new clients.

site_title: Seoul warns of debt hangover as apartment price growth hits new highs
summary: South Korea's vice finance minister, Lee Eog-weon, warned of a potential debt hangover due to excessive borrowing, citing China Evergrande's struggles as a cautionary example. Home prices in the capital region jumped 13.11% this year, the fastest increase in 15 years, with the average price of a Seoul apartment doubling in the past five years to 1.18 billion won. Policymakers are concerned the debt pile could become unsustainable as rates rise, hurting people's purchasing power and long-term growth.

site_title: Shopping for shophouses
summary: Singapore shophouses have become a sought-after asset, with a surge in transactions and prices over the last year. This trend is driven by the unique characteristics of these heritage properties and improving returns as investments. The appeal is also fueled by the growing demand for sustainable and environmentally-friendly assets, as highlighted by ENGIE's shift to green energy. As investors increasingly prioritize Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) engagement, shophouses are becoming an attractive option, particularly in a market where traditional power companies are transitioning to green energy.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher as taper fears ease
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.11% to 34,296.30, the S&P 500 gaining 0.25% to 4,406.75, and the Nasdaq Composite increasing 0.42% to 14,960.00. Investors largely dismissed concerns over the Federal Reserve's tapering plans, while positive forecast raises from Accenture and Salesforce contributed to the positive mood.

site_title: Royal Navy makes Daniel Craig honorary commander
summary: The Royal Navy has made James Bond actor Daniel Craig an honorary commander, matching his on-screen rank. The honor comes as Craig's final Bond film, No Time To Die, premieres in London. First Sea Lord Admiral Tony Radakin praised Craig for his portrayal of a naval officer, saying the real Royal Navy does the same work with technology and skill. Craig expressed his privilege and honor to join the oldest British armed force, vowing to support personnel and their families.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Thursday, up 10.32 points to 1,539.34. The index saw a gain of 624 to 419 gainers-to-losers ratio, with 4.742 billion lots worth RM3.539 billion traded.

site_title: Fitch cuts China growth forecast on property woes
summary: Fitch Ratings cut China's economic growth forecast to 8.1% for 2021, citing a slowdown in the property sector and concerns over Evergrande's financial stability. The slowdown is attributed to regulatory tightening and excessive borrowing by developers. The impact is expected to extend to emerging markets and global commodity demand. Despite efforts by Chinese Premier Li Keqiang to promote consumption and maintain growth, investors remain anxious about Evergrande's debt repayment obligations.

site_title: Yum China CEO says to focus store expansion on smaller cities
summary: Yum China Holdings, the owner of KFC, Pizza Hut, and Taco Bell in China, is focusing store expansion efforts on smaller cities where demand has recovered faster than in major centers. The company aims to reach 20,000 outlets across 2,700 cities, with a focus on lower-tier cities where residents have larger disposable incomes. This shift comes as the pandemic has impacted business, with adjusted operating profit expected to take a 50-60% hit in the third quarter.

site_title: Tensions ease across Asian markets on Fed's no-surprise tapering signal
summary: Asian equity gauges rallied after the US Federal Reserve's Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting, with Hong Kong posting the biggest 1.2% gain. The Fed left monetary policy unchanged, delaying tapering of bond buying until November. Markets welcomed the "hawkish" signals from Chairman Jerome Powell, indicating a strong US economic recovery. Key gauges in the region, including Australia, Singapore, Taiwan, Malaysia, and Indonesia, also rose, while China inched up 0.4%.

site_title: UK's slow growth and rising inflation gives BOE headache
summary: The UK economy lost momentum in September, with the "flash" PMI dropping to 54.1, its lowest reading since February, as businesses grappled with rising costs. This marks the fourth consecutive month of slowdown, affecting both services and manufacturing sectors. The Bank of England faces a difficult backdrop ahead of its interest rate decision, as inflation rises and the economy shows signs of slowing down.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims unexpectedly rise; labour market gradually healing
summary: US weekly jobless claims unexpectedly rose to 351,000 for the week ended Sept 18, despite a steady labor market recovery. A surge in California filings offset a decrease in Louisiana, which was impacted by Hurricane Ida. The four-week moving average of claims fell to 335,750, still above the 200,000-250,000 range for a healthy labor market. The Federal Reserve signaled interest rate increases may follow, citing rapid employment gains expected as pandemic-related factors diminish.

site_title: EU plans one mobile charging port for all, in setback for Apple
summary: The European Union plans to adopt a single USB-C charging port for all mobile devices, including smartphones, tablets, and headphones, in a bid to reduce electronic waste and increase convenience. The proposal, which has been over a decade in the making, is expected to save users 250 million euros annually. Apple has pushed back against the plan, citing concerns that it will stifle innovation and harm consumers. The EU executive argues that the move is a step towards its green and digital ambitions, and companies will have two years to adapt their devices to the new standard.

images.alt_text: The EU Commission proposes to legislate a common charger for mobile phones and other electronic devices in its member countries.

site_title: Taiwan says 'risk' to its Trans-Pacific trade pact bid if China joins first
summary: Taiwan has applied to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), but there's a "risk" if China joins first, according to Taiwan's chief trade negotiator John Deng. China, the world's second-largest economy, has expressed opposition to Taiwan's participation, citing its insistence that Taiwan is part of "one-China." Despite this, Taiwan's democracy, rule of law, and transparent laws differ from China's, making its membership case "quite risky." The CPTPP application was made to New Zealand's government, which handles the paperwork, and Taiwan has applied under its WTO name.

site_title: Frasers Property issues S$200m sustainability notes at 3%
summary: Frasers Property AHL, a subsidiary of Frasers Property's Australia unit, has issued S$200 million worth of sustainability notes due October 2028 at a 3% coupon rate. The notes are expected to list on the Singapore Exchange on September 24. The issuance is intended to finance sustainable portfolios in Australia and marks Frasers Property's second SGD bond market sustainability note issuance. The group has secured over S$6 billion in green financing since 2018 and aims to finance its new sustainable asset portfolios with green financing by 2024.

site_title: TTJ Holdings swings into the black with S$1.6m in H2
summary: TTJ Holdings reported a net profit of S$1.6 million for the second half of the year, reversing a loss of S$14.1 million in the same period last year. Revenue grew 48% to S$52.3 million, driven by growth in structural steel operations. The company attributed a 3% decline in full-year revenue to the slow restart of project sites in the construction industry. Despite this, gross profit increased 42% to S$11.3 million, and the gross profit margin improved to 15%.

site_title: Panasonic retrenches 700 as it shuts Singapore manufacturing operations
summary: Panasonic is laying off 700 workers in Singapore as it shuts down its refrigeration compressor manufacturing operations by the end of 2022. The move is due to a "challenging" global business outlook and comes after a strategic review of its refrigeration compressor business portfolio. While research and development operations will remain in Singapore, the company will consolidate its compressor manufacturing operations with existing facilities in Malaysia and China. Affected employees will receive higher retrenchment benefits and job placement assistance from the United Workers of Electronics & Electrical Industries (UWEEI) and government agencies.

site_title: India merger of Sony, Zee to create TV powerhouse challenging Disney
summary: A merger between India's Zee and Japan's Sony Group Corp will create a TV powerhouse, challenging Disney's market share in the country. The Sony-Zee alliance will have a 27% market share, surpassing Disney's 24%. Sony will pump $1.6 billion into Zee, taking a majority stake, to enhance its digital platforms and bid for broadcasting rights. The deal aims to unite networks, digital assets, and production operations, posing a significant challenge to Disney in the fast-growing Indian television entertainment industry worth $10.5 billion.

site_title: GS Holdings to expand chicken rice brand in Qatar
summary: GS Holdings' indirect wholly-owned subsidiary, Hao Kou Wei Food Group, signed a franchise agreement to expand Rasa Chicken by Sing Swee Kee brand to Qatar. Tan Yan Shan and Lim Yee Min, experienced F&B entrepreneurs, will develop and operate chicken rice outlets under the brand name "Sing Swee Kee". The company believes there are strong opportunities for expansion in Qatar, with over 280 million Muslim consumers. The agreement is expected to have minimal impact on GS Holdings' earnings per share and net tangible assets.

site_title: STI jumps 0.93% on US Fed tapering news; Evergrande fears ease
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.93% on Thursday, driven by Wall Street's overnight gains after the US Federal Reserve's slightly hawkish stance at its September meeting. The US Fed may begin cutting bond purchases as early as November, with the process completed by mid-2022. China Evergrande Group's default fears eased after a cash injection from the People's Bank of China. Despite the rebound, sentiment remains cautious, with debt woes of Evergrande expected to linger.

site_title: Myanmar faces 'alarming' risk of escalating civil war: UN
summary: Myanmar faces an "alarming" risk of escalating civil war as an uprising against the military junta widens, according to UN human rights chief Michelle Bachelet. Since Aung San Suu Kyi's government was ousted, the country has been in turmoil, with attacks on troops increasing and a nationwide uprising sparked. The human rights situation has deteriorated, and the UN urges countries to support a political process that would engage all parties to reverse the military coup and prevent wider conflict. Over 1,100 people have reportedly died, and 8,000 others are arrested and in detention.

site_title: China's cosmetics market projected to grow 8.3% CAGR through 2025: GlobalData
summary: China's cosmetics market is projected to grow 8.3% CAGR through 2025, driven by the face make-up category, reaching 60.8 billion yuan. E-retailers account for 36.7% of the market, with prestige brands expected to focus on digital engagement to dilute geographic and distribution risk. Luxury brands are shifting focus to premium skincare and home-based beauty treatments. Multinational players like Shiseido and L'Oréal reported stronger H1 2021 results, with 40% of Chinese respondents with high household income purchasing beauty products online directly from brands.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rally for third day, business surveys awaited
