The Indian government hopes the project will help the country's $488 billion farm sector and compete with global exporters.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start day on back foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with losses, falling 0.32% to 24,589.17, following four days of heavy selling due to concerns over China's regulatory clampdown, geopolitical tensions, and the spread of the Delta variant. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also declined, with the Shanghai Index falling 0.33% to 3,595.27. The losses come amid global market uncertainty, with US-EU trade talks and tariff threats also weighing on investors' minds.

site_title: Ex-Goldman, Morgan Stanley execs join Hong Kong-based crypto unicorn Amber
summary: Former Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley executives Dimitrios Kavvathas and Todd Miller have joined Hong Kong-based crypto unicorn Amber Group as chief strategy officer and chief operating officer for the Americas, respectively. The firm, founded by five Morgan Stanley traders, has raised $100 million and expects revenue to surge tenfold to $500 million this year, managing $1.5 billion of trading capital. The new hires bring Amber's global headcount to nearly 450 employees and will help formulate its global strategy and engage with regulators and institutional clients.

site_title: Over S$200m in rent support to be doled out to 35,800 tenants, owner-occupiers
summary: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) and Ministry of Finance (MOF) announced the second round of Rental Support Scheme (RSS) payouts, totaling over S$200 million, to be disbursed to 35,800 tenants and owner-occupiers starting from Sept 22. Eligible SMEs and NPOs with annual revenue not exceeding S$100 million will receive half a month's rent support for the July 22 to Aug 18 period. The total government support for businesses' rental costs now exceeds S$400 million, with the first round of payouts disbursed on Aug 6.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise as travel shares jump on Ryanair forecast
summary: European stocks rose 0.4% on Thursday, snapping a four-day losing streak, after Ryanair lifted its long-term traffic forecast, boosting travel shares. The Stoxx 600 index bounced off a six-week closing low. Travel stocks rose 3.4%, while miners fell due to concerns over China's economy. Strong US data reinforced optimism about a US recovery, while Asia stocks came under pressure.

site_title: China's Evergrande to let angry investors bid on discounted properties: sources
summary: China Evergrande Group plans to allow consumers and staff to bid on discounted properties to repay billions in overdue investment products. The company will organize an online property event by Sept 30, offering discounted real estate as an alternative to cash repayments. This move aims to preserve cash as the embattled developer seeks to repay investors. The discounted real estate is the preferred option among angry investors seeking repayments, with three options available.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS says PropNex is positively priced in; initiates with 'hold'
summary: DBS Group Research has initiated coverage on PropNex with a "hold" call and target price of S$1.83, citing that the real estate agency is "priced to perfection" due to the strong residential property market in Singapore. Despite a high risk of government intervention to cool the market, DBS expects PropNex to continue riding the property market due to its expanding share of various market segments. The brokerage team also expects the company to pay dividends of S$0.10 per share for FY2021 and FY2022.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares edge higher at Friday open
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.86 point or 0.06% to 1,556.12 at the Friday open, with 211 gainers and 105 losers. Volume reached 154.3 million lots worth RM67 million.

site_title: Asia: Shares stabilise but global growth fears nag
summary: Asian shares stabilized in early trading on Friday, but global growth concerns and China jitters weighed on investors. The MSCI's Asia-Pacific index traded flat, down 2.7% for the week. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 0.5% despite China Evergrande Group's shares dropping 5% amid uncertainty over the property developer's fate. US stock futures fell 0.6% amid concerns about global growth and the spread of the Delta coronavirus variant, with economists expecting a slowdown in the US economy.

site_title: Gold set for second weekly loss as firmer dollar dents appeal
summary: Gold prices are set for a second weekly loss due to a firmer dollar, which deters investors from the metal. Spot gold remains flat at $1,754.86 per ounce, while US gold futures fell 0.1%. The dollar's strength is attributed to strong US economic data, potentially leading to earlier policy tightening by the US Federal Reserve. Economists now expect the Fed to start tapering stimulus in November, reducing central bank stimulus and boosting bond yields.

site_title: Australia to trial home quarantine for vaccinated arrivals
summary: Australia is set to trial a home quarantine program for fully vaccinated arrivals, starting in New South Wales, with a 7-day period. The program, which will include a mobile phone app and random police checks, aims to ease the country's strict border controls. The trial will involve around 175 people, including Australians, non-residents, and Qantas crew members, and could pave the way for a gradual reopening of international borders. This marks a significant shift from the 14-day hotel quarantine currently in place.

site_title: US: S&P ends modestly lower as rising Treasury yields offset robust retail data
summary: The S&P 500 ended slightly down, paring losses, after unexpectedly strong retail sales data highlighted the US economic recovery's strength. Rising Treasury yields pressured tech stocks, and the rising dollar weighed on exporters. Despite this, Amazon.com's solid online sales boosted the Nasdaq into positive territory. Economically sensitive sectors like transports and microchips outperformed, with the Dow Jones falling 0.18% and the Nasdaq adding 0.13%.

site_title: Singapore export growth cools to 2.7% in August despite support from electronics boom
summary: Singapore's export growth slowed to 2.7% in August, missing analysts' forecasts of 8.5% expansion, according to data from Enterprise Singapore. Non-electronics shipments declined year-on-year, but electronics exports grew 16.7% due to strong demand for integrated circuits. Total trade grew 19.8% year-on-year, driven by increases in both exports and imports. Despite the slowdown, economists maintain their 2021 GDP growth forecast at 7.1% and expect external-facing industries to benefit from the global trade recovery.

site_title: Hong Kong tests boosters for Sinovac users as protection wanes
summary: Hong Kong is testing whether Sinovac vaccine recipients will benefit from a BioNTech mRNA booster, as protection from the Chinese-made vaccine appears to wane. The study aims to determine the effectiveness of different boosters in maintaining immunity. Sinovac shots account for about one-third of Hong Kong's immunizations, and recent research shows that protection from all available vaccines decreases over time. The investigation will help officials understand the importance of booster shots and inform future vaccination strategies.

site_title: Biden expects Congress to approve spending, infrastructure bills
summary: US President Joe Biden expressed confidence that Congress will pass a $3.5 trillion spending bill and a $1 trillion infrastructure bill, despite Republican opposition. The spending bill funds social programs with increased taxes on companies and the wealthy, while the infrastructure bill has bipartisan support. Biden had a positive discussion with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer, and plans to pass a continuing resolution to fund government operations. Senate Democrats are using budget reconciliation to pass the spending bill, which faces challenges from moderate members like Senators Joe Manchin and Kyrsten Sinema.

site_title: Frasers Property prices S$200m notes due 2028 at 3%
summary: Frasers Property priced S$200 million of fixed-rate notes due 2028 at 3% interest, with net proceeds to be used for green or sustainable projects. The notes, issued under a A$2 billion multicurrency debt program, are guaranteed by Frasers Property and will mature on Oct 9, 2029. The sole lead manager is OCBC. The issue is expected to be completed on Sept 23.

site_title: Constituents of the iEdge S-Reit Index
summary: The iEdge S-Reit Index constituents include NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer, which received 9.8 times oversubscription. Meanwhile, US stocks fell amid tariff threats, with Wall Street opening lower. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO.

site_title: Oil prices steady as US storm threat wanes
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Thursday as Hurricane Nicholas receded, allowing US Gulf energy companies to restore pipeline service and electricity. Brent crude ended up 0.3% at $75.67 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) remained unchanged at $72.61 a barrel. Analysts attribute the stability to profit taking and the ongoing recovery of oil production capacity after Hurricane Ida. Oil prices are expected to continue rising due to supply cuts by Opec and the pandemic-related collapse in demand, with global oil use forecast to rise above 100 million barrels per day next year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singapore Airlines, QAF, UOB, DBS
summary: Singapore Airlines exhausted its S$8.8 billion rights issue proceeds, using the last S$0.6 billion for aircraft payments. QAF shares halted trading due to concerns over JBS' acquisition of Rivalea Holdings. UOB launched an integrated green financing solution for electric vehicles, while DBS' private bank assets under management more than doubled to S$10 billion over the past year. These developments may impact trading of these companies' securities.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Australia's competition regulator, the ACCC, has raised concerns over JBS' proposed acquisition of Rivalea Holdings, a subsidiary of QAF, due to potential anti-competitive effects. JBS would control three of seven export accredited abattoirs and have significant pork processing capacity, giving it leverage to raise costs of downstream rivals. The ACCC is inviting submissions on the issues and will announce its final view by Dec 9.

site_title: Women are a powerful asset in business
summary: A study by the Harvard Business Review found that companies with a substantial influence of women in the C-suite are more profitable, socially responsible, and provide safer, higher-quality customer experiences. Women bring a unique ability to combine short-term and long-term perspectives, making them valuable assets in strategy development. Contrary to the notion of a competitive advantage, women collaborate with men, supplementing their assets and contributing to a more knowledge-building company. By embracing diversity and collaboration, businesses can reap benefits and achieve success.

site_title: Reliefs for telco sector in India a boon for Airtel: Singtel CFO
summary: Bharti Airtel, a joint-venture company between Singtel, will benefit from a telecoms sector relief package in India, which reduces the amount of Adjusted Gross Revenue (AGR) payments to the government. The package includes a four-year deferral of AGR payments and a redefinition of AGR to only count telecoms revenue. This frees up "tremendous" free cash flow for Airtel to invest in its 5G network and fibre broadband, making it a stronger player in the market.

site_title: Renault plans 2,000 job cuts in France as it moves to electric cars
summary: Renault plans to cut up to 2,000 engineering and support jobs in France as it shifts towards electric cars, while hiring 2,500 people in other functions. The move is part of a broader restructuring, with the company aiming to build nine new car models in France. Renault aims to create 500 net new jobs and strengthen its electric car offering, with new hires in areas such as data sciences and chemistry specialists. The company has already announced around 4,600 job cuts in France.

images.alt_text: French carmaker Renault said on Thursday it would cut up to 2,000 engineering and support jobs in France as it shifts into electric cars and hires in different positions.

site_title: Evergrande's local bonds face more pressure after downgrade
summary: Evergrande Group's local bonds face increased pressure after a downgrade to A from AA, prompting trading platform changes that limit the pool of investors. The downgrade, by China Chengxin International Credit Rating Co, has led to the suspension of onshore bond trading. Evergrande's dollar notes, however, saw a 1.6-cent increase in price to 28.6 cents. The firm is scheduled to make interest payments, and Chinese authorities have begun laying groundwork for possible debt restructuring.

site_title: Japan PM contender Kono wants stimulus to focus on energy, 5G
summary: Japan's vaccine minister Taro Kono, running to replace Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga, has proposed prioritizing economic stimulus spending on renewable energy and expanding 5G networks nationwide. This move comes as the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) campaigns for Suga's successor. Kono's plan aims to boost the economy while focusing on key sectors, but the exact details of his proposal remain unclear.

site_title: Silver lining for some S-Reits that missed out on FTSE global Reit index
summary: A quarter of Singapore's 40 actively traded S-Reits and property trusts remain excluded from the FTSE EPRA Nareit Global Developed Index, despite a lowered market cap threshold. Half of the 10 S-Reits that missed out on the index have outperformed it year to date, suggesting some still have potential to grow and join the index later. Analysts weigh the possibility of these S-Reits making the cut, while others face a bleaker future.

site_title: Temasek, MAS, EDB, SGX in multi-billion dollar charge to list tech firms in Singapore
summary: Singapore has launched a multi-billion dollar initiative to boost listings of high-growth technology startups on the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The government, along with Temasek, MAS, and EDB, has established a co-investment fund, the Anchor Fund @ 65, to support promising high-growth enterprises in their initial public offerings (IPOs) and provide pre-IPO financing to catalyze their growth. The fund's first tranche of S$1.5 billion will support high-growth companies, while the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will expand its Grant for Equity Market Singapore (GEMS) scheme to provide more support to companies.

site_title: France says Biden acted like Trump to sink Australia defence deal
summary: France accused US President Joe Biden of acting like his predecessor Donald Trump after Paris was pushed aside from a historic defense export contract to supply Australia with nuclear-powered submarines. The US, Britain, and Australia announced a new security partnership, which will help Australia acquire US submarines and scrap the $40 billion French-designed submarine deal. French Foreign Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian called the decision "unilateral and unpredictable" and "a stab in the back," straining transatlantic ties and potentially complicating EU cooperation in the Indo-Pacific region.

site_title: Europe's uninspiring car sales turn ugly amid chip crunch
summary: Europe's car sales plummeted in July and August, with new registrations falling 18% and 24% from last year's levels. Auto production is being suppressed by the global semiconductor shortage, leading to higher prices and prioritization of lucrative models. Traditional combustion vehicles have been hit the hardest, while plug-in hybrids and electric cars continue to see growth. The decline is the worst since the Eurozone economic crisis in 2013, with major markets such as Germany, France, and Spain experiencing double-digit drops.

site_title: Dollar edges higher with focus on Fed for taper clues
summary: The US dollar rose 0.3% to 92.743 on Thursday, reaching a two-week high, as traders await the Federal Reserve's policy meeting next week for clues on tapering stimulus. The dollar index is expected to provide clarity on tapering and interest rate hikes. The euro fell 0.4% to US$1.1770, while the Swiss franc hit a two-month low against the dollar. The dollar also strengthened against the yen and Norway's crown, while the Australian dollar slipped back to its lowest this month due to falling iron ore prices.

site_title: New Japan PM unlikely to set off BOJ shift, survey shows
summary: A new Japanese prime minister is unlikely to change fiscal or monetary policies, according to a Bloomberg survey of 47 economists. The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is expected to keep its yield-curve control and asset-purchase programs unchanged at a meeting ending September 22. Only 14% of economists predict significant changes in monetary policy, with most citing the BOJ's limited ability to influence inflation. The BOJ will assess the economic impact of a surge in Covid cases and consider bolstering stimulus if necessary, but economists expect low inflation to remain a challenge.

site_title: Cream of the design crop
summary: Singapore's top interior designers under 45 have been recognized for their outstanding work through the Society of Interior Designers Singapore's (SIDS) inaugural 20 UNDER 45 Awards. Winners include Cherin Tan, Dennis Cheok, and Pan Yi Cheng, who have made significant impacts through their biophilic design and sustainable projects. The awards aim to empower young designers to push boundaries and showcase the industry's best work. Experts in the field, such as Patricia Ho Douven and Matilda Sung, highlight the evolving nature of interior design, with a focus on user experience, employee well-being, and sustainable practices. The awards celebrate the contributions of these talented individuals, who are redefining the interior design industry in Singapore.

site_title: Chinese smartphone giant Oppo cuts jobs after going up against Apple
summary: Chinese smartphone giant Oppo is cutting around 20% of its staff in key software and device teams after merging with affiliate OnePlus. The cuts come as the company expands too rapidly and competes with Apple in the premium segment. The affected units include a team customizing Android for Oppo's ColorOS and an Internet of Things division developing wearables. Oppo's R&D team for phones and overseas sales positions remain unaffected. The move is part of a consolidation in the Chinese mobile industry struggling with chip shortages and economic shocks.

site_title: Malaysia says KPMG to pay US$80.1m in 1MDB settlement
summary: Malaysia has reached a settlement with audit firm KPMG, agreeing to a $80.11 million payment to resolve claims related to their fiduciary duties on 1MDB accounts from 2010 to 2012. The settlement concludes a lawsuit filed in July and marks one of the largest 1MDB-related settlements by an audit firm in South-east Asia. The agreement was reached collectively by all parties, including the Malaysian government, and will enable KPMG to focus on rebuilding public trust.

site_title: Race for the watch Oscars begins
summary: The 2021 Grand Prix d'Horlogerie de Geneve (GPHG) watch awards ceremony is set to announce its winners on November 4, marking the 20th anniversary of the event. A jury of 30 members and 500 academy members will select the best timepieces in 14 categories, including the Aiguille d'Or grand prize. The ceremony will showcase a range of watches, including those from Vacheron Constantin, Franck Muller, Hublot, and Jaeger-LeCoultre, among others, which are competing for the prestigious awards.

site_title: Are you vaccinated, Mr President? New York wants proof, but UN chief cannot enforce
summary: The United Nations chief, Antonio Guterres, cannot enforce proof of vaccination for world leaders entering the UN General Assembly Hall, despite New York City officials' request. The UN headquarters is not subject to US laws, and officials have discussed vaccination with local authorities. Guterres has warned about the risk of more dangerous variants if the virus circulates among unvaccinated people, and is pushing for a global plan to vaccinate 70% of the world's population by mid-2022.

site_title: Pizza flair at La Bottega
summary: La Bottega Enoteca, a new trattoria in Joo Chiat, Singapore, serves authentic Italian cuisine, particularly pizzas, that rival traditional Neapolitan-style pizzas. Chef Antonio Miscellaneo's menu features house-made pasta, cured meats, and unique toppings, such as burrata and pickled sardines. The restaurant's retro ambiance and cozy atmosphere make it a standout dining experience. Prices are reasonable, with a multi-course set menu starting at S$139. Overall, La Bottega Enoteca offers a delightful and authentic Italian dining experience that is worth trying.

site_title: Asia supercharges vaccination efforts after slow start
summary: Asian countries, including Japan, South Korea, and Australia, are rapidly increasing vaccination efforts to combat growing Covid-19 infections. Japan and South Korea have surpassed the US in first-dose vaccination rates, while Australia has given 56% of its population at least one shot. Experts attribute the surge to pent-up demand for vaccines to ease lockdowns and reopen borders. While momentum is building, experts warn that vaccinations will plateau globally, as seen in the US and Britain, where inoculation rates have stagnated due to low trust in vaccines.

images.alt_text: Several Asian nations are quickly ramping up vaccination campaigns from shaky starts to combat growing Covid-19 infections, as supply shipments roll in and people overcome hesitancy in hopes of easing curbs and freeing up travel.

site_title: Community spaces in mixed-use projects are great, but who pays?
summary: Singapore developers incorporate greenery and community spaces in upcoming mixed-use projects, but who ultimately pays for these features? Analysts say the cost is partly 'paid' by the state through lower land cost and partly by buyers and tenants. The proposed Jalan Anak Bukit development will feature community events, gardens, and a transport hub, with prices expected to surpass $2,000 psf, according to analysts. The development could benefit all stakeholders, including buyers, tenants, and the wider community, if developers do a good job with the space.

site_title: Design studios big and small
summary: Design studio website Studio SML launched by Kelley Cheng, a President's Designer of the Year recipient, aims to showcase the personal stories of designers through mini-biographies and interviews. The website features a diverse group of designers, including Randy Chan and Chang Architects, and highlights the challenges and triumphs of each. Cheng hopes to educate the public about the work of designers and promote a comprehensive design history in Singapore, which she believes is lacking due to the lack of documentation.

site_title: Environmental, social issues still not main priority for global CEOs: Egon Zehnder
summary: Global CEOs prioritize traditional financial metrics over environmental and social issues, with 2/3 saying decision drivers remain consistent. Financials, growth, talent management, health and safety, and innovation top the list, with ESG ranking 6th. CEOs are re-evaluating their role, team engagement, and accountability amid heightened demand for ESG awareness and hybrid work pressures. Many CEOs are considering personal development and self-reflection, with 78% agreeing they need to transform themselves to transform their organizations.

site_title: Obscure Taiwan company's rise shows profit, pain of chip crunch
summary: A global semiconductor shortage, exacerbated by a lack of Ajinomoto build-up film (ABF) substrates, is hindering production for major companies such as Intel, Nvidia, and AMD. The obscure Taiwanese company Nan Ya Printed Circuit Board has seen its shares soar due to its rise in supplying the critical component. Supplies are expected to remain constrained until at least 2025, with a compound annual growth rate of 16% for substrate supply and 18-19% for demand. This bottleneck adds to the series of disruptions in the chip industry, affecting giants like Toyota Motor and Apple.

site_title: NTUC LearningHub launches agri-tech training space to groom workforce
summary: NTUC LearningHub has launched its first agri-tech training space, the Agritech Lab @ Benoi, to train workers in high-tech farming solutions and equip them with skills in Internet of Things and machine-learning. The space aims to address the pressing issue of employability in the sector and contribute to Singapore's goal of producing 30% of nutritional needs locally by 2030. The six-month programme is expected to create and upskill about 4,700 jobs in the agri- and aqua-tech food industry by 2030, with 119 trainees already enrolled in the pioneer cohort.

site_title: Temasek-backed Covid-19 test provider Oxford Nanopore seeks £300m in IPO
summary: Oxford Nanopore Technologies, a DNA-sequencing company, is seeking £300 million in a London IPO, valuing the company at £2.5 billion. The company's technology is used to detect Covid-19 variants and has also been used during Ebola and Zika outbreaks. Oracle has agreed to subscribe for £150 million of new shares, and existing shareholders, including IP Group and Temasek, will also participate in the offering. The company's shares will be listed on the standard segment of the London Stock Exchange, excluding major FTSE benchmarks.

site_title: The next unicorn could emerge from Indonesia's thriving e-logistics sector
summary: Investor interest in Indonesia's e-logistics sector is growing, driven by the sector's estimated $300 billion value by 2024. Successful fund-raising by startups has fueled the interest, but weak logistics infrastructure remains a challenge, leading to high transportation costs. The sector's growth is part of Indonesia's thriving e-commerce sector, which continues to drive the country's digital economy.

site_title: China's biotech sector comes of age with big licensing deals, global ambitions
summary: China's biotech sector has gained significant momentum with major licensing deals, marking its emergence as a major player in the global biopharma industry. Notable deals include a $2.4 billion agreement with Seattle-based Seagen and a $2.2 billion deal with Novartis AG. This growth is attributed to supportive government policies, increased funding, and the return of overseas-trained Chinese scientists. China's biotechs are now valued at $180 billion, with many expecting to secure more licensing deals, further solidifying their position in the global market.

site_title: Art galleries bounce back from the brink
summary: Art galleries worldwide have recovered from the pandemic, with over half of the surveyed dealers seeing an increase in sales in the first half of 2021. Asian dealers saw the most improvement, with an 18% increase in sales, while European dealers saw a 7% decline. Wealthy millennials are leading the charge, spending an average of $378,000 on art and antiques, with women collectors increasing their spending by a third to $410,000. Digital sales rose, with online channels accounting for 33% of sales, and digital artworks like NFTs gaining attention.

site_title: Love wine? Here are 10 ways to appreciate it even more
summary: Wine enthusiasts can appreciate it more by exploring new options, finding value for the price, and pairing it with food. Consumers can also learn from mass-market wines, examine their biases, defy conventional wisdom, consider the place of origin, value simplicity, and appreciate the beauty of nuance. Returning to classic wines can also provide a deeper understanding of the craft. By adopting an open-minded approach, wine lovers can discover new favorites and enhance their appreciation for the beverage.

site_title: Malaysians enjoy taste of travel after lockdown in tourism restart
summary: Malaysia has restarted its tourism sector after a four-month lockdown, with the first batch of 159 vaccinated domestic tourists arriving on the island of Langkawi. The program aims to revive the travel industry with agreed health protocols, targeting 400,000 visitors by the end of the year. With over half of its population vaccinated against Covid-19, Malaysia has recorded over two million cases and 20,000 deaths. The move is part of a regional trend, with Thailand, Indonesia, and Vietnam also opening their borders to vaccinated tourists.

site_title: SpaceX sends four US civilians into space on first private flight
summary: SpaceX launched the Inspiration4 mission, the first private flight to space, on September 15, 2021. The mission carried four US civilians, including technology billionaire Jared Isaacman, into an orbital height of 585km. The crew, which includes a childhood-cancer survivor, flew aboard a privately built SpaceX Dragon spacecraft, marking a new era in human spaceflight. The mission aimed to raise $200 million in charity for childhood-cancer research and set a new altitude record for SpaceX's Dragon spacecraft.

site_title: CEO behind Philippines' biggest Reit IPO eyes earnings rebound in 2022
summary: Philippines' second-largest mall builder, Robinsons Land Corp, is optimistic about returning to pre-pandemic earnings levels in the second half of 2022, according to CEO Frederick Go. The company's Reit IPO raised $472 million, with plans to build up rental assets and accelerate office construction. Go expects a significant increase in gross leasable space to over 500,000 square meters by the end of 2022, driven by resilient demand from BPOs and call centers. The company is also open to acquiring third-party assets to drive growth.

site_title: Central banks still in no rush to raise rates as inflation takes back seat
summary: Central banks in Asean-6 economies are unlikely to raise interest rates soon, despite recent producer price spikes in the US fueling concerns about inflation. Analysts expect policymakers to adopt a wait-and-see approach for at least another six months, citing low inflation and a focus on maintaining accommodative monetary settings. Some analysts, however, warn that persistent inflation could weigh on company earnings and impact equity markets if central banks react too late or hike rates too quickly. Regional policymakers are expected to prioritize growth over inflation concerns, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore likely to stand pat at its October meeting.

images.alt_text: THE 30-year Singapore Government Securities (SGS) (Infrastructure) bonds, expected to be issued on Oct 1, will likely see decent demand, said DBS Group Research in a note.

site_title: Australian competition watchdog flags concerns over QAF's proposed Rivalea sale
summary: Australia's competition regulator, the ACCC, has raised concerns over JBS' proposed acquisition of Rivalea Holdings, a pork-processing plant owned by Singapore-listed food company QAF. The ACCC expressed concerns that the deal could reduce competition in the Australian market. QAF agreed to sell Rivalea to JBS for A$107.9 million, citing a desire to focus on its bakery and distribution segments. The ACCC has yet to make a final decision on the deal.

site_title: Unesco adds 20 new biospheres in 21 countries
summary: UNESCO added 20 new biosphere reserves in 21 countries, bringing the total to 727 in 131 countries. The new sites include Lesotho, Libya, and Saudi Arabia, and cover areas such as dry woodlands, steppe grasslands, and hyper-arid desert zones. The International Coordinating Council approved the additions, which include transborder reserves and sites with threatened species like the Striped hyena and red mangrove. The move aims to promote sustainable development and conservation, with 25 sites approved last year, and a total zone covering nearly 5% of the planet.

images.alt_text: Unesco chief Audrey Azoulay visiting the Oban Biosphere Reserve in Nigeria on Sunday.

site_title: As Merkel exits, Germans debate famed budget discipline
summary: Germany's post-Merkel era has sparked debate on budget discipline, as Chancellor Angela Merkel's government smashed its debt taboo to weather the pandemic crisis. The centre-left Social Democrats (SPD), led by Finance Minister Olaf Scholz, promise higher taxes and public spending, while the conservatives warn of "free beer" policies. Total public debt is expected to exceed 70% of GDP, forcing a difficult choice between changing budgetary rules or sharply reducing the public deficit. A change to the debt brake, a constitutional rule limiting borrowing, may be necessary to address the crisis, but any change would require a two-thirds super majority in parliament.

site_title: Mercedes to go all-electric in Singapore by 2030
summary: Mercedes-Benz Singapore has announced plans to go all-electric by 2030, becoming the first car brand in the country to set a deadline to stop selling combustion cars. The company aims to reach full carbon neutrality by 2039 and has already launched its second electric model, the EQA 250. Mercedes-Benz Singapore's CEO is confident that the market conditions will allow the company to achieve 100% electrification by 2030, with the goal of having an electric vehicle in every segment it currently serves by 2022 and an electric model for every car line by 2025.

site_title: Can California governor do anything about its housing crisis?
summary: California Governor Gavin Newsom has won a decisive victory in the recall election, but the state's housing crisis remains a pressing issue. Despite efforts to pass Senate Bills 9 and 50, which would allow duplexes and apartment buildings in neighborhoods, the state's supply-demand imbalance persists. Newsom's administration has gained more power to enforce housing policies, but critics argue that the executive branch's ability to enforce laws is key to addressing the crisis. The governor plans to focus on enforcing existing laws, including a new "housing accountability unit" to monitor local governments' housing decisions.

site_title: US initial jobless claims rise last week
summary: US initial jobless claims rose to 332,000 in the week ended Sept 11, exceeding economists' median estimate of 322,000. The increase is attributed to Hurricane Ida's impact on the labor market, particularly in Louisiana, where unadjusted claims jumped 4,058. Continuing claims fell to 2.7 million, a pandemic low. The rise in claims may reflect the labor market's broad recovery, while economic growth is expected to slow in the third quarter amid reduced stimulus spending.

site_title: ING cuts dirty energy loans as banks purge books to meet CO2 goals
summary: ING, a Dutch bank, plans to reduce financing for upstream oil and gas projects by 12% from its 2019 loans of $6.3 billion, aiming to meet its goal of net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. The bank will also set tougher carbon policies for sectors like automotive, real estate, and shipping. ING's head of sustainability, Anne-Sophie Castelnau, stated that clients with big carbon footprints should expect higher loan costs. The move is part of the finance industry's efforts to slash its carbon footprint and meet the Paris Agreement's climate goals.

site_title: Many of South Korea's small crypto exchanges set to disappear
summary: South Korean regulators plan to shut down 35 out of 63 cryptocurrency exchanges by September 24 due to lack of certification. The shutdowns will primarily affect smaller, less liquid exchanges that trade "Kimchi coins," which lack intrinsic value. The impact is expected to be limited given the low trading volumes involved, with the four largest exchanges accounting for 97% of trading volume in the country. The shutdowns could cause up to 3 trillion won (S$3.4 billion) in damage to investors in "Kimchi coins."

site_title: Ride on national momentum to tackle climate change
summary: The National University of Singapore (NUS) has set an ambitious goal to achieve carbon neutrality by 2030, aligning with Singapore's decarbonisation priorities and plans. To achieve this, NUS has developed a Sustainability and Climate Action Plan 2030, which includes five key strategies: deploying renewable energy, electrifying its fleet, enhancing energy efficiency, planting trees, and investing in green innovation. The university's efforts serve as a model for other organizations to follow, and its approach highlights the importance of data collection, emission assessments, and proactive planning in tackling climate change.

site_title: Singapore Airlines spends last S$600m of 2020 rights issue
summary: Singapore Airlines has exhausted its S$8.8 billion rights issue, with the last S$600 million used for aircraft and aircraft-related payments between July 1 and Sept 1. The airline has raised S$21.6 billion in fresh liquidity since April 2020, retaining access to S$2.1 billion of committed lines of credit. Proceeds from the rights issue were used for various purposes, including debt service, operating expenses, and aircraft payments. The airline will remain prudent in managing its liquidity amid ongoing international air travel disruptions caused by the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Online purchases boost US retail sales
summary: US retail sales unexpectedly increased 0.7% in August, driven by a surge in online and furniture store purchases, despite a decline in car dealership sales. The rebound is attributed to back-to-school shopping and child tax credit payments. Economists have downgraded their GDP estimates for the third quarter, citing plunging motor vehicle sales. Despite this, consumer spending is expected to continue leading the economic recovery, with core retail sales rising 2.5% in August.

site_title: 1.5 C warming limit 'impossible' without major action: UN chief
summary: The United Nations has released a report stating that limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius is "impossible" without immediate and large-scale emissions cuts. The report, released just weeks before the COP26 climate summit, found that climate change and its impacts are accelerating, despite a temporary reduction in carbon emissions caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. The report's findings were described as "an alarming appraisal" by UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres, who warned that catastrophic consequences for people and the planet will occur if warming is not limited.

site_title: Crypto fraudster gets 7½ years for Ponzi scheme
summary: A US federal judge sentenced Stefan Qin, a 24-year-old crypto fraudster, to 7½ years in prison for running a Ponzi scheme that defrauded over 100 people out of approximately $90 million. Qin used investors' money to fund a lavish lifestyle, including a Manhattan penthouse apartment, and lied to clients about his investment strategies. Prosecutors said Qin's actions were "brazen" and intended to discourage others from committing similar crimes. Qin, who had no prior criminal record, pleaded guilty to securities fraud and showed no genuine remorse.

site_title: How would China liberalise its capital account?
summary: China is not prioritizing capital account liberalization, focusing instead on a strong and stable domestic economy. The country aims to promote a domestic consumption-driven growth model, shifting away from its export-led growth strategy. China's controlled approach to capital account liberalization involves gradual steps, a managed floating exchange rate, and maintaining an independent monetary policy. The country seeks to assert financial sovereignty and curb the global hegemony of the US dollar, while also developing its financial markets and managing cross-border financial risks. China's domestic orientation outweighs international considerations, with the goal of delivering a better life for its 1.4 billion people.

site_title: Performance review tool OnLoop raises US$5.5m ahead of its launch
summary: Startup OnLoop raises US$5.5m ahead of its launch, with investors including MassMutual Ventures, Square Peg, and Hustle Fund, to create a performance review tool that enables regular daily feedback loops for team development. The platform, founded by former Uber executive Projjal Ghatak, has been in private beta since January 2021, with over 25 companies and 650 users testing its auto-generating performance reviews. The tool aims to shake up outdated performance review cycles, which are time-consuming and inefficient.

site_title: We need to talk about tuition
summary: Singapore's education system fuels a $1 billion tuition industry, with households spending thousands monthly on private tuition, causing stress and inequality. The article explores the consequences of this trend and draws parallels with China's crackdown on excessive tuition spending. It also touches on various other topics, including ESG investing, corporate purpose, and the importance of finding a balance for success.

site_title: Flagship Wall St conference sees record attendance
summary: A flagship Wall Street conference, SALT, returned this year with a record attendance of 2,300 in-person attendees and 700 remote viewers. The event, hosted by Anthony Scaramucci, featured prominent investors discussing cryptocurrency investments and the impact of the pandemic on society. Despite initial nervousness, attendees quickly relaxed and engaged in conversations, with many praising the event as worth the price paid to attend. The conference marked the first time SALT was held in New York, a change from its previous location in Las Vegas.

site_title: Providing feedback to drive change
summary: Effective feedback is crucial for improving individual and team performance, but it must be delivered in a timely and constructive manner. The best time to give feedback is in real-time, rather than during six-monthly appraisals. Feedback should be provided in a positive and helpful manner, and it's essential to be sincere and calm when delivering it. It's also crucial to ask questions to clarify and provide practical suggestions for improvement. Additionally, being aware of cultural differences in receiving feedback is vital, and the approach should be tailored to the individual and organization. Ultimately, a culture that encourages open and honest feedback without malice or politics is key to achieving long-term success.

site_title: Reliefs for telco sector in India a boon for Airtel, says Singtel CFO
summary: Bharti Airtel, a joint-venture company with Singtel, is expected to benefit from India's telecoms sector relief package, which redefines adjusted gross revenue (AGR) to exclude non-telecoms revenue. The package reduces AGR payments to the government, freeing up cash flow for Airtel to invest in its 5G and fibre broadband networks. Airtel will still pay a significant amount, but with a four-year deferral and reduced upfront burden, analysts see it as a "game-changer" for the company's growth prospects.

site_title: WEF eyes return to Davos in 2022
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) has announced its annual gathering, set to take place in Davos, Switzerland from January 17-21, 2022, after repeatedly shifting due to the coronavirus pandemic. The meeting will focus on "Working Together, Restoring Trust" and will be the first global leadership event to set the agenda for a sustainable recovery. The WEF emphasized the importance of in-person dialogue among leaders to address the world's pressing economic and societal challenges amid the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Asian edition of Milan Furniture Fair in 2022
summary: The DesignSingapore Council and Singapore Tourism Board, along with Fiera Milano and dmg events, have signed a Memorandum of Understanding to launch the inaugural Furniture, Interiors and Design (FIND): Design Fair Asia, the Asian edition of Salone del Mobile. The show, set to take place from September 22 to 24, 2022, will feature a hybrid format with a mix of country pavilions and digital platforms, and is expected to attract 500 brands and 15,000 visitors from 15 countries. The event aims to provide a platform for Singapore design brands and designers to showcase alongside global brands and manufacturers.

site_title: US: Wall Street falls as oil, tech losses outweigh retail cheer
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday, with the Dow Jones down due to losses in technology and oil stocks, despite strong retail sales data showing economic resilience. The data showed retail sales unexpectedly rose in August, boosting consumer-exposed stocks like Home Depot and Nike. Economically sensitive sectors like financials and transport stocks also gained. The losses in tech and oil outweighed the retail sales cheer, leading to a decline in the US market.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: Tencent Holdings is set to lose its place among the world's 10 largest companies by market value, leaving no Chinese names in the global top 10 due to Beijing's regulatory crackdown. Oxford Nanopore, a Covid-19 test provider, is seeking £300m in a London IPO. A conservation shophouse in Clarke Quay is up for sale for S$15-18m. UOB launched an integrated green financing solution for electric vehicles, while DBS Private Bank's in-house managed investment products saw a 200% increase in AUM to S$10b. Singapore stocks resisted a rout, edging up 0.2% on the Straits Times Index.

site_title: Credit Suisse shuffles Asia-Pacific investment banking team: memo
summary: Credit Suisse has shuffled its Asia-Pacific investment banking team, appointing Christian Deiss as head of mergers and acquisitions (M&A) and Sanjeev Chaurasia as head of industrials and renewable investment banking coverage. The changes come after the bank made 200 net hires in APAC in the first half of 2021, following staff departures due to the Archegos and Greensill Capital scandals. Other key appointments include Aaron Tan as co-head of energy and infrastructure banking, and Kuan-Ern Tan as co-head of investment banking and capital markets for the region.

site_title: Singapore stocks resist rout in most Asia markets on Thursday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks resisted a decline in most Asian markets, closing 0.2% higher on Thursday with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,064.54 points. Advancers outnumbered decliners 237 to 233, with City Developments Limited leading gains and Genting Singapore falling 3.3%. The decline in Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index and South Korea's Kospi, and the fall of Jakarta's Jakarta Composite Index, were attributed to cautiousness over China's retail sales data and potential regulatory tightening.

site_title: Singapore Airlines uses up last S$600m of S$8.8b from 2020 rights issue
summary: Singapore Airlines has exhausted its S$8.8 billion rights issue, with the last S$600 million used for aircraft and aircraft-related payments between July 1 and Sept 1. The airline has also raised S$21.6 billion in fresh liquidity since April 2020. SIA will retain access to S$2.1 billion of committed lines of credit and will continue to manage its liquidity prudently amid ongoing air travel disruptions due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Malaysia says auditor KPMG to pay US$80.1m in 1MDB settlement
summary: Malaysia's finance ministry announced that audit firm KPMG has agreed to pay a US$80.11 million settlement to resolve claims related to its fiduciary duties on 1MDB accounts from 2010 to 2012. The settlement concludes a lawsuit filed against KPMG in July and is valued at over 800 times the audit fees earned by the firm. The agreement allows all parties to move forward, including the Malaysian government, and enables KPMG to focus on building public trust.

site_title: Beleaguered Singapore retailer Naiise makes comeback as online platform after 5 months
summary: Singapore retailer Naiise, known for local designers and artisans, is making a comeback as an online platform after 5 months. The company was acquired by Weststar Group, an investment firm founded by Ong Lay Ann, and its website will launch on Thursday. Naiise promises to pay vendors instantly upon successful order fulfillment and will introduce over 500 merchants and debut new brands. The company is also working on a new incubator model for up-and-coming designers and "buy now pay later" concepts. Naiise's comeback comes after it stopped operations in April due to payment delays and liquidation.

site_title: Industrial-tech startup Ackcio raises S$4m in Series A funding
summary: Singapore startup Ackcio has raised S$4 million in Series A funding led by Atlas Ventures. The company, founded in 2016, develops wireless data-acquisition tech for industrial monitoring, aiming to provide real-time solutions for harsh environments. Ackcio's goal is to address the issue of lack of visibility in industries such as construction, rail, and mining, resulting in improved worker safety. The startup plans to expand into asset-heavy industries like oil and gas, energy, and power infrastructure.

site_title: Japan's Noda, former gender equality minister, joins PM race
summary: Seiko Noda, Japan's former gender equality minister, has announced her candidacy to replace Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga, becoming the nation's first female leader. Noda, 61, has been a vocal advocate for addressing Japan's declining birthrate and fast-ageing population, as well as women's empowerment. She cleared the registration line to run for the ruling Liberal Democratic Party's leadership, joining other contenders including former foreign minister Fumio Kishida and former internal affairs minister Sanae Takaichi. The LDP president will become Japan's prime minister due to the party's majority in the Lower House of Parliament.

site_title: Indonesia court finds Widodo negligent in air pollution lawsuit
summary: An Indonesian court ordered President Joko Widodo and other senior government officials to improve Jakarta's hazardous air quality, finding them guilty of environmental negligence in a civil lawsuit. The 32 plaintiffs, who filed the lawsuit in 2019, alleged that authorities had failed to protect citizens from severe air pollution in the capital. The court's ruling obliges the president to establish national air quality standards and requires the health minister and Jakarta governor to devise strategies to control air pollution.

images.alt_text: An Indonesian court on Thursday ordered President Joko Widodo and other senior government officials to improve the hazardous air quality of the capital Jakarta after finding them guilty of environmental negligence in a civil lawsuit.

site_title: Indonesia's Telkom to pursue IPO of unit in Q4; US$1b target
summary: Indonesia's Telkom plans to launch an initial public offering (IPO) for its infrastructure and data tower unit Mitratel by the fourth quarter of 2021, with a potential valuation of around US$1 billion. CEO Ririek Adriansyah stated that the company is exploring other potential spin-offs and is building out its digital businesses, including data centers and cloud services. The IPO is part of Telkom's broader restructuring plans, which aim to expand its growth opportunities in the digital sector.

site_title: Many of South Korea's small crypto exchanges set to disappear
summary: South Korea's regulators plan to shut down 35 out of 63 cryptocurrency exchanges by September 24 due to lack of certification. The shutdown will primarily affect smaller, less liquid exchanges, and "Kimchi coins" traded on these platforms, potentially causing 3 trillion won (S$3.44 billion) in damage to investors. The country's four largest exchanges, which account for 97% of trading volume, have already registered as legal platforms, minimizing the impact on the overall industry.

site_title: DBS Private Bank posts S$10b AUM for in-house managed investment products
summary: DBS Private Bank has reported a significant surge in assets under management (AUM) for its in-house managed investment products, more than doubling to S$10 billion over the past year. The bank's growing suite of managed investment products, including the DBS I.D.E.A Fund and DBS ESG Focus Note, reflects its focus on sustainability and ESG investing, with all products rated 'BBB' and above by MSCI ESG Ratings. The bank aims to play a larger role in constructing portfolios for clients seeking long-term capital appreciation and income generation.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise most in over six weeks as virus curbs ease
summary: Australian shares rose 0.58% to close at 7,460.2, the biggest jump in over six weeks, as the New South Wales government eased restrictions for vaccinated citizens, lifting a night curfew in Sydney and easing curbs on travel and outdoor exercise in Melbourne. Energy stocks led the gains, driven by strong oil price rises, while employment data showed a surprise 146,000 drop in August. Despite disappointing job numbers, analysts attributed the gains to the easing of restrictions and a modest improvement in the unemployment rate to 4.5%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend losses to fourth day
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell for a fourth consecutive day on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index dropping 1.46% to 24,667.85. The decline was driven by casino stocks and concerns over China's regulatory clampdown and the Delta virus variant. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell, with declines of 1.34% and 1.95%, respectively.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise on travel rebound, gains in Wall Street
summary: European stocks rose 0.6% on Thursday, rebounding from a six-week low, driven by gains in travel and leisure stocks, and overnight strength on Wall Street. Travel and leisure added 1.6%, while automakers rose 1.2%. Miners, including Rio Tinto and Anglo American, fell due to metal price declines after China released more metals from its reserves. Utilities inched up 0.2% amid concerns over energy bill measures in Spain.

site_title: NTUC LearningHub launches agri-tech training space to groom workforce
summary: NTUC LearningHub launched its first agri-tech training space, The Agritech Lab @ Benoi, to train workers in high-tech farming solutions and equip them with skills in Internet of Things and machine-learning. The six-month programme aims to train 180 trainees by 2022 and address Singapore's goal of producing 30% of nutritional needs locally by 2030. The programme has seen an "overwhelming response" with 119 trainees enrolling in the pioneer cohort, and is targeting middle-aged workers from various sectors to expand their job prospects in "sunrise industries" like agri-tech.

site_title: Temasek-backed Covid-19 test provider Oxford Nanopore seeks £300m in IPO
summary: Oxford Nanopore Technologies, a UK-based DNA-sequencing company, is seeking £300 million in an initial public offering (IPO) on the London Stock Exchange. The company, backed by Temasek, uses its technology to detect Covid-19 variants and has been valued at £2.5 billion. Oracle has agreed to subscribe for £150 million of new shares, and the company's CEO will hold a special class of shares to block hostile takeovers. The IPO is part of London's efforts to attract more businesses to its stock exchange.

site_title: Far East Consortium close to selling 21 Anderson to Kheng Leong Group
summary: Far East Consortium International Limited is close to selling 21 Anderson, a 10-storey freehold block in Singapore's prime district 10, for approximately S$213 million to Singapore-based Kheng Leong Group. The sale marks a significant transaction in the Singapore property market.

site_title: Putin says he will be in Covid-19 self-isolation 'a few days'
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin will spend "a few days" in self-isolation after dozens of people in his entourage fell ill with Covid-19. Putin, 68, has had two shots of Russia's Sputnik V vaccine and was initially planning to attend a summit in Tajikistan. The Kremlin confirmed Putin's health and said his self-isolation could last at least a week, with no reports of severe illness. Putin's attendance at upcoming summits, including the G20 in Rome, remains uncertain.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end four-day rally as tech heavyweights slide
summary: South Korean stocks ended a four-day rally, with the Kospi index closing down 23.31 points or 0.74% at 3,130.09. Major tech heavyweights like Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix led the decline, with chip giant SK Innovation's shares falling 4.44% after separating its battery business. The won weakened, while the benchmark bond yield rose, amid concerns over China Evergrande Group's financial woes. Investors await the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting for clues on tapering its bond-buying programs.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOBKH upgrades Ascott Residence Trust to 'buy' with higher S$1.16 target price
summary: UOB Kay Hian has upgraded Ascott Residence Trust to "buy" with a higher target price of S$1.16, from S$1.09 previously. Analyst Jonathan Koh expects the stapled group's Europe portfolio to benefit from a recovery in the region's hospitality industry, driven by vaccination rates and pent-up demand. The analyst also views the group's expansion into student accommodation as an attractive asset class. The group trades at a discount to its peer CDL Hospitality Trusts, with a price-to-net-asset value of 0.82 times.

site_title: Prenetics to merge with Hong Kong Tycoon Adrian Cheng's Spac; to list on Nasdaq
summary: Prenetics, a Hong Kong-based Covid-19 testing laboratory, has agreed to merge with US-listed blank-check company Artisan Acquisition, backed by tycoon Adrian Cheng. The deal values Prenetics at $1.25 billion, with the combined company expected to trade on the Nasdaq. Prenetics will receive up to $459 million in cash and will prioritize acquisitions, particularly in the US and Southeast Asia. The transaction is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter or first quarter of 2022.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower, giving up early gains
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Thursday, erasing early gains, after investors locked in profits following a recent surge. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.62% to 30,323.34, while the Topix index lost 0.30% to 2,090.16. Profit-taking emerged after a Wall Street rebound on Wednesday, but sentiment remained intact with hopes for stimulus under the next government. A decline in coronavirus cases in Japan also boosted the market. Key players such as Nintendo and Panasonic experienced profit-taking, while Sony gained 0.82% to 12,270 yen.

site_title: VW's Skoda to stop production at Czech plants for a week due to chip shortage
summary: Skoda Auto, a Czech car maker part of the Volkswagen group, will halt production at its domestic plants for a week at the end of September due to a chip shortage. This is the latest in a global shortage affecting businesses and consumers worldwide. The shortage has resulted in thousands of unfinished cars in Skoda's production lines, impacting the Czech economy. The decision is part of efforts to manage the supply chain and address the shortage.

site_title: 500 Startups rebrands to 500 Global; closes largest fund to date at US$140m
summary: Venture capital firm 500 Startups rebranded to 500 Global, closing its largest fund at US$140 million and bringing assets under management to US$1.8 billion. The firm will continue to invest at all stages, including seed and later-stage growth. 500 Global's portfolio includes companies like Grab, Canva, and Talkdesk, with 33 companies valued over US$1 billion and backing over 6,000 entrepreneurs across 77 countries. The rebrand reflects the firm's expanded scope to back founders globally.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks snap four-day rally as tech heavyweights slump
summary: South Korean stocks snapped a four-day rally due to a slump in major tech heavyweights, including Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix. The benchmark Kospi fell 0.66% to 3,132.59, while the won gained and the bond yield rose. Foreigners were net sellers of 156.7 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: Analysts see hope for some S-Reits excluded from FTSE EPRA Nareit index series
summary: Analysts believe some Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) excluded from the FTSE EPRA Nareit Global Developed Index series may still have growth potential. However, others may not recover due to poor liquidity and limited avenues for growth. Experts note that inclusion in the index series is not a guarantee of success and that factors such as quality of sponsors, assets, and growth strategy are more important. Some analysts, like RHB, see potential in excluded S-Reits, while others, like veteran Reit investor Gabriel Yap, advise investors to be cautious and focus on holistic evaluations of Reit performance.

images.alt_text: IReit Global, among the Reits liked by analysts, earlier this year entered into a conditional sale agreement to acquire Decathlon's properties in France.

site_title: SK Innovation shareholders approve plan to split off battery business
summary: SK Innovation's shareholders have approved the separation of its battery business into a new company, SK Battery Co Ltd. The move, set to take effect on October 1, aims to raise funds and finance production capacity expansion. Over 80% of shareholders voted in favor, despite the National Pension Service voting against the plan due to concerns about shareholder value. The new company will be a wholly-owned subsidiary of SK Innovation.

site_title: CEOs need to draw on EQ, not just IQ, in tough times: Egon Zehnder
summary: CEOs are increasingly relying on their emotional quotient (EQ) to navigate social and economic challenges, rather than just their intelligence (IQ). A study by Egon Zehnder found that 9 in 10 CEOs are prioritizing self-reflection and personal development, and 78% believe they need to continue their self-transformation. However, many CEOs struggle to balance traditional business acumen with empathy and compassion, and only 46% are aligned with their executive teams. The study suggests that CEOs must shift their focus inward to develop new leadership skills, such as listening, trusting, and communicating authentically.

site_title: Clarke Quay conservation shophouse put on the market for S$15-18m
summary: A four-storey conservation shophouse in Clarke Quay, Singapore, has been put on the market via expression of interest with a guide price of S$15 million for its existing condition and S$18 million with a six-storey rear extension. The property has a 99-year tenure and is located near Clarke Quay MRT station. The sale comes as there is a lesser supply of well-located shophouses in the central business district, with many owners holding out for better prices. The EOI closes on October 14.

images.alt_text: The refurbished shophouse is tenanted to a restaurant on the ground floor and offices on the upper levels.

site_title: 'Many will follow': SpaceX sends all-civilian crew into orbit
summary: SpaceX successfully launched its all-civilian crew, Inspiration4, into orbit on a Falcon 9 rocket from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The crew of four Americans, including Jared Isaacman, Hayley Arceneaux, Chris Sembroski, and Sian Proctor, spent three days in space, reaching an altitude of 357 miles. The mission aims to raise $200 million for St Jude's Children's Research Hospital and marks a significant step towards commercializing space travel, with SpaceX's founder Elon Musk envisioning a multi-planetary humanity.

images.alt_text: A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket carrying four space tourists blasted off Wednesday night from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida for the first mission to orbit the globe with an all-civilian crew.

site_title: Philippines says won't cooperate with ICC probe of 'war on drugs'
summary: The Philippines will not cooperate with the International Criminal Court's (ICC) formal investigation into possible crimes against humanity committed during President Rodrigo Duterte's "war on drugs". Judges at the ICC approved a probe, citing the campaign as a systematic attack on civilians. The ICC has jurisdiction for crimes committed between 2016 and 2019, and the investigation will not be permitted to enter the country. Human rights groups welcome the ICC's decision, calling for Duterte and his cohorts to be made accountable for alleged crimes. Duterte denies any wrongdoing.

site_title: China Evergrande bond trading suspended after downgrade
summary: China Evergrande Group's Hengda Real Estate Group applied to suspend trading of its onshore corporate bonds following a downgrade by rating agency China Chengxin International to A from AA. The bonds' ratings and issuer rating were put on a watchlist for further downgrades. Trading of the bonds will be suspended for one day and resumed on September 17, with only negotiated transactions allowed. This move is seen as a measure to limit participation and curb volatility amid a liquidity crisis, which has raised concerns of contagion to other Chinese high-yield issuers.

site_title: Chinese smartphone giant Oppo cuts jobs after going up against Apple
summary: Oppo, China's top-selling smartphone brand, is cutting around 20% of staff in key software and device teams after merging with OnePlus. The move comes after expanding too rapidly and competing with Apple in the premium segment. Cuts affect units such as Android customization and Internet-of-Things development, but research and development teams remain unaffected. The company's efforts to expand into new markets have not paid off as expected, and it now faces a Chinese retail slowdown due to Covid-19 resurgence.

site_title: Climate change may halve sugar and coffee output by 2099
summary: Climate change may significantly impact global food production, with key crops like sugar and coffee output potentially dropping by 59% by 2099. The Stockholm Environment Institute report highlights the US, China, and Brazil as major sources of climate risk, while Russia and Canada may see slight increases in wheat and corn production. The report emphasizes the need for policymakers to address climate change globally, rather than focusing on national borders.

site_title: Tencent's slide leaves China with no stocks in global top 10
summary: Tencent Holdings is set to lose its place among the world's 10 largest companies by market value, leaving China without any names in the global top 10. Tencent's shares fell 1.9% before paring some of the loss, with its market capitalization at around $552 billion. This marks the first time a Chinese company is not among the world's 10 largest since 2017, following Alibaba Group Holding's unseating earlier this year. China's tech behemoths face regulatory crackdowns on monopolistic practices, data security, and gaming hours, further depleting market value.

site_title: UOB launches integrated green financing solution for EVs
summary: UOB launched U-Drive, an integrated green financing solution for electric vehicles (EVs), to promote the development of the EV sector and simplify the transition to green vehicles. The solution provides green banking facilities, including trade financing and loans, for automotive brand owners and car dealers. UOB will pioneer the solution with Hong Seh Evolution, a distributor of commercial EVs in Singapore, to provide greater working capital flexibility and drive the adoption of commercial EVs. This move follows other banks, such as OCBC and DBS, introducing their own green financing offerings for EVs.

site_title: Auditor issues disclaimer of opinion on Best World's FY2020 statements
summary: Ernst & Young (EY) has issued a disclaimer of opinion on Best World International's FY2020 financial statements due to insufficient audit evidence on the group's business model in China, its relationship with import agents and marketing agents, and the classification of payments made to promotional companies. The auditor noted uncertain evaluations on the franchise business model's compliance with China's laws and regulations. This is similar to its previous disclaimer for FY2019. Best World's shares have been suspended from trading since 2019 due to accounting issues.

site_title: Gold steady as investors eye Fed policy meet
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,792.86 per ounce, awaiting the Federal Reserve's policy meeting next week, which may signal the start of stimulus tapering. Softer-than-expected US inflation data sparked uncertainty, while US Treasury yields ticked higher. Manufacturing in the US remained strong despite production slowdowns due to Hurricane Ida and a microchip shortage. The Fed's tapering could diminish gold's appeal as a hedge against inflation and currency debasement.

site_title: Chevron would rather pay dividends than invest in wind and solar: CEO
summary: Chevron CEO Mike Wirth stated the company prefers paying dividends to investing in solar and wind power projects, citing low financial returns for shareholders. Instead, investors can use dividend payments to invest directly in renewable projects. Wirth's comment suggests Chevron prioritizes shareholder returns over environmental concerns, sparking criticism.

site_title: Malaysia: Markets closed for public holiday
summary: Malaysia's financial markets are closed on September 16, 2021, for a public holiday. Trading will resume on September 17. Meanwhile, global markets experienced fluctuations, with stocks down in Europe due to bank and healthcare sector concerns, and US stocks edging down despite reaching fresh records amid US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Indonesia in talks with WHO to become global vaccine hub: minister
summary: Indonesia is in talks with the World Health Organization (WHO) and six pharmaceutical companies to become a global hub for manufacturing Covid-19 vaccines. The country aims to prioritize purchases of vaccines from companies sharing technology and set up facilities in Indonesia. This initiative is part of a WHO strategy to distribute vaccine production globally and build capacity in developing countries. Indonesia is well-placed to export vaccines due to its large population and the fact that its vaccines would be halal, making it an attractive option for Muslim-majority countries.

site_title: Australia: Energy, mining stocks lift shares as markets cheer easing of virus curbs
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by gains in energy and mining sectors, as the government eased restrictions for vaccinated citizens in New South Wales. Energy stocks led the gain, with Whitehaven Coal rising 4.3% after the government approved its coal mine extension project. Mining stocks added 1% on strong copper prices, while banks rose 0.3%. Despite a rise in Covid-19 cases in Victoria, the market took comfort in the easing of restrictions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks flat at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks remained flat at the opening of Thursday, September 16, 2021, following a three-day sell-off. The Hang Seng Index rose 8.82 points to 25,042.03. Casino operators stabilized after a previous day's collapse. Meanwhile, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index edged up, with the Shanghai Composite Index increasing 0.24% to 3,664.84.

site_title: Obscure Taiwan firm's 1,219% rise shows profit, pain of chip crunch
summary: A Taiwanese company, Nan Ya Printed Circuit Board, has seen its stock rise 1,219% in three years due to the semiconductor industry's chip crunch. The company produces Ajinomoto build-up film (ABF) substrates, a crucial component for chipmaking that's in high demand. Supply constraints are expected to last until 2025, affecting companies like Intel, Nvidia, and AMD, with Broadcom warning of longer lead times for its router chips. Analysts predict further growth for Nan Ya and other ABF substrate makers, with profits expected to soar in the coming years.

site_title: GIC-backed Thoughtworks rises with others in flurry of high-performing US IPOs
summary: Technology consulting firm Thoughtworks Holding rose 40% in its trading debut after raising $773 million, making it one of four large US IPOs priced above their ranges. The company, backed by GIC and Apax Partners, has a market value of nearly $9 billion. Thoughtworks' shares closed at $29.39, following a 40% gain on its first day. The company's digital transformation services are expected to drive growth, with CEO Guo Xiao predicting a constant state of change in the next 10-20 years.

site_title: India announces measures to shore up telecoms sector; respite for Vodafone Idea
summary: India's federal cabinet approved a relief package for its cash-strapped telecom sector, including a four-year moratorium on airwaves payments and measures to boost growth. The package includes waiving usage charges for future auctions, free spectrum sharing, and raising airwave tenure to 30 years. The measures aim to ease the cash crunch at debt-ridden Vodafone Idea, which runs the risk of a shutdown without government help. The government also announced changes to the definition of adjusted gross revenue, allowing Indian carriers to settle outstanding payments forward.

site_title: US: Stocks rebound, Asia buffeted by weak China data, Macau crackdown
summary: US stocks rebounded 0.9% as the S&P 500 led major indices, despite losses in Europe and Asia. The positive session followed weak Chinese economic data, including a 12-month low in retail sales and a contracting services sector. Macau's crackdown on the gambling industry also impacted Hong Kong-listed operators, with stocks plummeting 20-30% in response. Analysts attributed the US gains to underlying confidence in an economic rebound despite ongoing Covid-19 concerns and potential Federal Reserve policy tightening.

site_title: World leaders will hold closed-door climate meet at UN
summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres and British Prime Minister Boris Johnson will host a closed-door meeting of world leaders on the sidelines of the General Assembly in New York to boost climate commitments ahead of COP26 in Glasgow. The meeting comes as the UK prioritizes climate change, with Britain's UN ambassador stating it will be the country's top priority. The roundtable aims to ensure the world meets its goal of holding century-end warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius.

site_title: Medline marketing US$7b of loans to fund jumbo buyout by group including GIC: source
summary: Medline Industries, a US medical supply company, is being acquired by a group of private equity firms, including Blackstone Group, Carlyle Group, and Hellman & Friedman LLC, in a leveraged buyout worth up to $34 billion. The deal is being funded with a $7 billion loan sale led by Bank of America, with a $7.8 billion high-yield bond offering expected to launch in the coming weeks. The acquisition marks a return of large-scale leveraged buyouts amid historically low borrowing costs.

site_title: UK natural gas prices hit record after fire
summary: UK natural gas prices hit a record high after a fire at a vital power grid connection to France, exacerbating concerns about inflation. The fire, reported by National Grid, knocked out the IFA interconnector at Sellindge in Kent, southeast England. This outage compounded price fears, contributing to the UK's inflation hitting a nine-year peak in August.

site_title: Top carbon emitters fall short on climate risk disclosure: report
summary: A report by Carbon Tracker and the Climate Accounting Project found that top carbon emitters, such as oil and gas companies, did not disclose the full risks associated with climate change in their 2020 accounts, reducing the chances of meeting global emissions targets. Over 70% of the 107 assessed companies failed to reflect climate change risks, with eight out of 10 audits showing no evidence of assessing climate risk. The report raises concerns about the lack of consistency between climate pledges and financial accounts, and calls for better disclosure and analysis of climate risks.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall as utilities drag, luxury slides after China data
summary: European stocks fell on Wednesday as utilities dropped 2.9% due to Spain's energy bill cap measures and luxury stocks weakened amid concerns about China's slowing economy. China's factory and retail sectors reported one-year lows, while French luxury goods makers LVMH and Kering fell 4% each. The Stoxx 600 index lost 0.8% and is on course to end its seven-month winning streak in September.

site_title: Hot stock: Hatten Land sees heavy trading after crypto mining, solar energy tie-ups
summary: Hatten Land, a Malaysia property developer, saw its shares surge 40% after announcing partnerships to install cryptocurrency mining rigs and solar panels on its properties in Melaka. The company plans to raise S$1.8 million through a share placement and has partnered with SMI to install 2,000 crypto mining rigs. Hatten Land also partnered with Nestcon Berhad to install solar panels, with plans to generate up to 100 MWp of solar energy. The company's shares were the most heavily traded on the Singapore bourse by volume, with 35.7 million shares changing hands.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Thursday's open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% at Thursday's open, tracking overnight Wall Street rallies. The Straits Times Index (STI) reached 3,063.38, with Hatten Land surging 28% on its strategic initiatives involving cryptocurrency mining and solar energy. Index stocks ComfortDelGro and Singtel also saw brisk trading. In contrast, US stocks finished solidly higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.7% and the S&P 500 advancing 0.9%. European shares slipped, while Tokyo stocks opened higher on hopes for Japan's stimulus package.

site_title: OCBC hires DBS veteran as head of global wholesale banking
summary: OCBC has appointed Tan Teck Long, a 51-year-old veteran from DBS, as its head of global wholesale banking, effective March 15, 2022. Tan, who is currently DBS' chief risk officer, will oversee all of OCBC's wholesale banking businesses. His appointment is part of OCBC's efforts to ensure its top executives remain relevant to its strategic objectives. Tan brings extensive experience in global corporate banking, risk management, and investment banking, having held various positions at DBS since 2011.

site_title: US regulators wary of Big Tech swallowing startups
summary: US regulators are increasing scrutiny of Big Tech giants' smaller acquisitions, citing concerns over their collective impact on monopolistic dominance. The Federal Trade Commission has reviewed hundreds of acquisitions by tech titans from 2010-19, finding that individual deals may not seem significant but collectively can lead to a monopolistic behemoth. FTC Commissioner Rebecca Slaughter said reviewing acquisitions individually is insufficient, and regulators need a broader perspective. The move follows increased anti-trust enforcement under President Joe Biden's administration, which has filed suits against Facebook and is reviewing guidelines on "harmful mergers".

site_title: GIC-backed fintech Pagaya to go public via US$8.5b SPAC deal
