summary: Pagaya, a US-Israeli fintech backed by Singapore's GIC, is set to go public through a US$8.5 billion SPAC deal with EJF Acquisition Corp. The deal, expected to close early next year, will result in Pagaya retaining a 94% ownership stake. Founded in 2016, Pagaya uses artificial intelligence to manage assets for banks and institutional investors. The deal comes as the blank-cheque space experiences slowing activity due to growing investor caution and regulatory scrutiny. UBS Investment Bank and Barclays advised EJF Acquisition, while JP Morgan Securities advised Pagaya.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on US rebound
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by a US rebound, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index up 0.25% or 75.28 points at 30,586.99. The broader Topix index also rallied 0.24% or 5.00 points to 2,101.39. Investors remain optimistic about stimulus under Japan's next government, supporting the market.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Hatten Land, Singapore Myanmar Investco, Keppel Reit, Keppel Corp, Top Glove
summary: Hatten Land announced strategic initiatives involving cryptocurrency mining and solar energy, raising up to S$1.8 million from a proposed share placement. The company lifted its trading halt and shares last traded at 2.5 Singapore cents. Meanwhile, Singapore Myanmar Investco also saw developments, but no specific information is provided in the article.

site_title: Moderna says Covid-19 vaccine protection wanes, makes case for booster
summary: Moderna's large Covid-19 vaccine trial data shows protection wanes over time, supporting the need for booster doses. The company estimates 600,000 additional Covid-19 cases in the fall and winter, with some requiring hospitalization. Moderna President Stephen Hoge stated this estimate, but did not project the severity of cases. The news supports the case for booster doses, as protection wanes over time.

site_title: Oil prices jump over US$2/barrel after drawdown in US stocks
summary: Oil prices surged over US$2 a barrel on Wednesday, driven by a larger-than-expected drawdown in US crude inventories and expectations of rising demand as vaccination roll-outs widen. US crude inventories fell to the lowest since September 2019, while petrol stocks also declined. Brent crude rose 2.5% to US$75.46 a barrel and WTI crude climbed 3.1% to US$72.61 a barrel. The drawdown and rising demand are expected to continue, with analysts attributing the increase to the ongoing impact of Hurricane Ida on the Gulf of Mexico.

site_title: Temasek and its subsidiaries jump in on US biotech firm Allay Therapeutics' US$60m Series C round
summary: Temasek and its subsidiaries invested in US biotech firm Allay Therapeutics' $60 million Series C round. The biotech startup aims to develop therapies for long-lasting pain management and plans to advance its lead product ATX-101 into Phase 2B clinical trials. With the funding, Allay Therapeutics will focus on expanding its manufacturing capabilities and developing new clinical candidates. The investment is seen as a response to the growing demand for non-opioid pain relief solutions, with Arboretum Ventures' managing partner noting the "unprecedented potential breadth" of Allay's technology platform.

site_title: Australia to get nuclear submarines in new US, British partnership
summary: The US, Australia, and Britain announced a new partnership to strengthen naval capabilities in the Indo-Pacific with a new Australian nuclear submarine fleet. The move aims to counter growing rivalry from China, following a deal that was set to include a multi-billion-dollar sale of conventional submarines to Australia from France. The French company, Naval Group, expressed "deep disappointment" at the announcement, which appears to pull the rug out from under the French-Australian deal. The partnership is expected to enhance Australia's naval capabilities and deter potential threats in the region.

site_title: Flying-taxi hubs planned for 65 cities spanning London to South-east Asia
summary: Urban-Air Port and Hyundai Motor have partnered to establish a network of flying-taxi hubs in 65 cities worldwide, including the UK, US, France, and South-east Asia. The first site, in Coventry, England, is set to open in early 2022. This partnership aims to provide a dedicated infrastructure for flying taxis and cargo drones, with Urban-Air Port being the only company focused solely on this type of network. The project is expected to be a significant investment, with $150 million spent on physical infrastructure in 2021.

site_title: The enduring charm of landed homes
summary: Singapore's landed home market has seen a surge in sales, with 1,779 homes sold in the first seven months of 2021, exceeding 2020's total. The segment's popularity is driven by limited availability, enduring charm, and growing demand from bigger households and multi-generational families. Prices have risen 9.7% for terrace houses and 9.6% for detached houses, with semi-detached houses seeing the biggest gain of 10.5%. The top six districts, including District 20, have seen a healthy compound annual growth rate, driven by established housing estates and connectivity.

site_title: Good Class Bungalows - major value uplift in the works?
summary: Singapore's Good Class Bungalow (GCB) market has seen record-breaking prices since early 2021, with average prices rising in tandem with per-square-foot prices based on land area. However, the number of transactions remains below pre-2010 levels. Analysts believe a new trend may be emerging, driven by the growth of the new economy and the increasing wealth of its entrepreneurs. As the new economy grows, fresh records are expected to be set in the GCB market, with limited supply and high demand expected to drive prices upwards. The trend may expand in scale as Singapore attracts more talent and businesses.

site_title: Spackman shares in play on news of sale of Zip Cinema
summary: Spackman Entertainment's shares rose 50% on Wednesday after announcing the sale of its Zip Cinema business to South Korea's Kakao Corp for S$19.8 million. The stock closed the day unchanged at 0.4 cent after a day of trading. The sale is expected to result in higher group net tangible assets, reduce loss per share, and enhance liquidity. Proceeds from the sale will be used to diversify and expand the company's business into US films and other ventures.

site_title: Microsoft names Smith vice-chair, starts US$60b buyback
summary: Microsoft has appointed president and chief legal officer Brad Smith as vice-chair, a new role that does not require a seat on the board. Smith, who joined Microsoft in 1993, will oversee policy, government, and legal issues, including sustainability and data privacy. The company also unveiled a $60 billion stock-repurchase program, bringing its total cash pile to over $130 billion. The repurchase authorization has no expiration date and may be terminated at any time, following a 35% stock rise in 2021, making Microsoft the second-most valuable publicly traded company.

site_title: Law firm poised to steer client businesses through uncertain times
summary: Clyde & Co Clasis Singapore, a 30-year-old law firm, continues to navigate complex regulatory, transactional, and litigation issues for clients worldwide amidst the pandemic. The firm, which has grown to almost 100 staff, provides seamless integrated offshore and onshore services to local and international clients. Its core sectors include insurance, aviation, marine, construction, and litigation. The firm's partners see a significant growth area in corporate and commercial disputes in the next five to 10 years, driven by Singapore's rise as an arbitration hub.

site_title: Mercedes sees sales stabilising at year-end amid chip turmoil
summary: Mercedes-Benz expects sales to stabilize in the fourth quarter, despite disruptions from the global semiconductor shortage. The division aims to generate double-digit returns for 2021, targeting an operating profit margin of 10-12%. Despite factory shutdowns in Malaysia, demand remains strong in China, Europe, and North America. The company prioritized profitable cars, leading to higher margins, and is focused on maintaining cost discipline to sustain current profitability levels. This could positively impact Daimler shares, which may see a re-rating after the planned separation of Daimler Truck later this year.

site_title: New or resale homes? Unravelling the property investment conundrum
summary: In Singapore, median resale prices of private homes in the secondary market rose 15.6% in the OCR and 13.8% in the RCR from 2017, while the CCR saw a modest 3.8% growth. The strong recovery in suburban regions is linked to the previous collective-sale boom.

site_title: China's cooling measures curb new home price growth, investment
summary: China's average new home prices rose 0.2% in August, the slowest pace since December, as authorities tightened measures to curb the property market. New home prices grew 4.2% from last year, down from 4.6% in July. Authorities have restricted purchases and tightened credit policies, leading to a slowdown in price growth. Property investment increased 0.3% year-on-year, its smallest growth in 18 months. Experts predict further slowdown in housing price growth, with 46 out of 70 cities reporting month-on-month gains.

site_title: Meet the creme de la creme of interior designers
summary: The Society of Interior Designers Singapore has introduced the "20 under 45" awards, recognizing the best local talent in the field. Winners include Cherin Tan from LAANK, Dennis Cheok from UPSTRS_, and Pan Yi Cheng from Produce Workshop. Meanwhile, art galleries are seeing a steady increase in sales, led by millennials and female collectors. A Sotheby's auction features rare collectibles from Wong Kar Wai's films. The article also highlights various dining and lifestyle news, including a review of La Bottega's pizza and a discussion on corporate purpose and financial literacy for women.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Top Glove withdraws US$1 billion listing application on the Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing due to delay. The company will re-submit its application after resubmitting to the Malaysian bourse. Keppel Electric signed an agreement with Laos state-owned electricity company to import up to 100 MW of renewable hydropower into Singapore. OKP Holdings clinched a S$57.2 million contract for the Deep Tunnel Sewerage System project from PUB.

site_title: UK traders are betting on two BOE rate hikes in 2022
summary: UK traders are predicting two interest rate hikes by the Bank of England (BOE) in 2022, with a quarter-of-a-percentage-point increase in December 2022, bringing the key rate to 0.5% by the end of next year. This is in response to building inflationary pressures in the economy.

site_title: Private residential hotspots: A housing renaissance emerges
summary: A housing renaissance is emerging in Singapore, driven by HDB upgraders and new wealth from pandemic-driven growth industries. Recent new condominium projects, such as Pasir Ris 8, Bukit Merah's The Reef at King's Dock, and Downtown Core's Midtown Modern, have set fresh benchmarks for their respective localities, leading to price increases. However, not all projects have seen significant price re-rating, with some areas, like Queenstown, still lagging behind. The trend is expected to persist, with demand for homes remaining high and developers re-evaluating pricing amid projected higher costs.

site_title: Singapore industrial real estate: Going strong
summary: Singapore's industrial real estate market continues to show strong growth, driven by healthy demand and strong manufacturing output. Occupancy rates have improved, with the JTC All Industrial Rental Index rising for the third consecutive quarter, and ground-floor factory and warehouse rents increasing in Q2 2021. Demand is expected to come from sectors such as semiconductor manufacturing, pharmaceuticals, and e-commerce, leading to increased space requirements and rental growth. CBRE Research forecasts a 5-6% increase in prime logistics rents in 2021, driving investment in the sector.

site_title: Asia's wealthy find favour in digital approach for discretionary mandates: UBS
summary: UBS's hybrid digital wealth management tool My Way has amassed $4.2 billion in assets under management (AUM) nine months after its launch, with $1 billion in Asia. The platform allows clients to co-create and personalize their portfolios with managers, choosing from over 50 "building blocks" across various investment types. UBS sees a steady increase in client adoption of discretionary portfolio management in Asia, with a 20% annual growth rate over the last five years. The bank's sustainable investing advisory also reports a surge in popularity among Asian clients, with over 70% selecting sustainability building blocks for their portfolios.

site_title: Touch 'n Go cards and their stored value remain valid for 10 years
summary: Touch 'n Go smart cards, used by thousands of Singaporean motorists, remain valid for 10 years despite the land crossings between Singapore and Malaysia being shut since March 2021. Users can check the expiry date on the card and get a refund of the balance through the company's online portal if the card is less than 10 years old. Once borders reopen, drivers will be able to use their cards as usual, but it's unclear if any additional steps will be required to re-activate the cards.

site_title: Evergrande tries to pay bills with parking spots
summary: Evergrande, a Chinese property developer, is facing financial struggles after failing to meet cash repayments. The company has offered property, parking spaces, and store units to investors instead, sparking protests. Evergrande's debts total over $300 billion, causing panic among investors and contractors. Experts warn of a potential default, but Beijing is likely to intervene, preventing a disorderly collapse. Protests have been ongoing for a third day, with demonstrators demanding their money back.

site_title: Investor group sets tough climate blueprint for Big Oil
summary: An investor group managing over $10 trillion has set a blueprint for Big Oil to tackle climate change, requiring companies to reach net zero carbon emissions by 2050 and wind down oil and gas production. The Net Zero Standard for Oil and Gas includes 10 required standards to help investors compare companies' strategies and ensure they align with UN-backed efforts to reduce global carbon emissions. Companies such as BP and Royal Dutch Shell have published targets, but the huge variation in scope and ambition makes analysis difficult. The initiative aims to provide a level playing field for investors to compare and contrast across the sector.

site_title: 'Ghost kitchens' boom in Asia as pandemic sparks huge demand
summary: Ghost kitchens in Asia are experiencing rapid growth due to lower operating costs and the increased demand for food delivery from tech-savvy younger generations. The "Amazonification" of commercial kitchens, which started before the pandemic, has been accelerated by lockdowns and restrictions. Analysts predict continued growth for these kitchens, driven by their lower costs and adaptability to changing consumer habits. This trend is expected to continue in Asia, with the potential for further expansion into other regions.

site_title: After War on Terror, US foreign policy will remain a work in progress
summary: The US is seeking a new foreign policy narrative after the end of the War on Terror and the decline of the global adversary. Following the collapse of the Soviet Union, the US installed a liberal international order, but with the shift in global power, its role is now uncertain. The country's dominance, once marked by the unipolar moment, is being challenged, and its ability to dictate global rules is diminishing. This shift has significant implications for US foreign policy, and the country is still searching for a new narrative to define its role in the world.

site_title: Governance is the foundation of ESG
summary: SGX Regco released two consultation papers on enhanced climate and diversity rules, as well as a common set of ESG metrics for companies to disclose. The new rules will make certain board diversity disclosures mandatory, building on existing 2018 Code of Corporate Governance. The move aims to improve ESG governance and transform companies from 'brown' to 'green'. The consultation papers will help shape the regulatory framework for ESG reporting in Singapore.

site_title: Singapore O&G stocks ride oil rally; industry consolidation, manpower among challenges
summary: Singapore-listed oil and gas companies reported positive results for the first half of 2021, driven by a recovery in crude oil prices. However, merger negotiations between Keppel and Sembmarine could lead to increased competition and margin erosion for smaller companies. Industry consolidation and manpower challenges are also concerns.

site_title: North and South Korea conduct duelling missile tests as arms race heats up
summary: North Korea and South Korea conducted dueling missile tests, with North Korea firing two ballistic missiles that landed in the sea off its east coast, and South Korea testing a submarine-launched ballistic missile (SLBM), its first of its kind. The tests come amid an escalating arms race and stalled denuclearization negotiations. The US, Japan, and China condemned North Korea's launch, while South Korea's President Moon cited the need for deterrence against North's provocations.

site_title: Reeling from the impact of Covid-19
summary: BT Infographics reports on various economic updates. Vietnam reacts to US President Trump's tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate. In Malaysia, an agency plans to seize approximately RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. Industrial production in Malaysia rose 0.3% in May, below forecast. Indonesian GoTo shares are expected to rebound after a US$2.2 billion sell-off. Foreign investors are returning to Vietnam's stock market due to sweetened US trade terms, causing stocks to surge. Additionally, SMCCI and Maybank have signed a MOU to support Malay or Muslim-owned enterprises in Singapore and Malaysia.

site_title: Homes within integrated developments retain their popularity
summary: Integrated developments, which combine residential and commercial components linked to an MRT station, remain popular in Singapore. Despite the Covid-19 pandemic and potential threats from technological innovations, demand for homes within these developments has increased due to their convenience and accessibility. Prices in these developments can command a premium of 4-30% compared to nearby condominiums, driven by factors such as limited supply and a bullish market. As the MRT network continues to improve and the cost of car ownership rises, integrated developments are expected to remain attractive to owner-occupiers and investors.

site_title: EU chief executive lays out plan to make bloc more independent
summary: European Union chief executive Ursula von der Leyen outlined plans to increase the bloc's independence in defense, global trade, and climate action. She proposed a "Chips Act" to ensure semiconductor self-sufficiency and counter China's global infrastructure push. Von der Leyen also called for the EU to establish a "defence union" and increase military intervention abroad without US support. Additionally, she pledged an additional 4 billion euros to help poorer countries fight climate change and announced a donation of 200 million vaccine doses for third countries by mid-2022.

site_title: Rental market for private homes maintains buoyancy
summary: Singapore's private residential leasing market is expected to maintain its recovery momentum, driven by the global economic outlook and vaccination roll-outs. Leasing demand for private homes has bounced back to pre-pandemic levels, with 47,515 transactions recorded in the first half of 2021. Occupancy rates remain high, and demand is expected to be boosted by the resumption of air travel and employment prospects in Singapore. Rental prices are projected to rise 5-8% in 2021 due to limited supply and declining housing stock.

site_title: Dollar near one-week low after soft US inflation
summary: The US dollar traded near a one-week low against peers on Wednesday after softer-than-expected US inflation figures tempered expectations of Federal Reserve tapering. The dollar index fell 0.2% to 92.536, despite recovering from earlier losses on haven demand. Disappointing Chinese data also weighed on the yuan and Aussie.

site_title: 807 new Covid-19 cases; new clusters at two nursing homes
summary: Singapore reported 807 new Covid-19 cases, a new high in over a year, with two new clusters at nursing homes in Simei and West Coast Drive. The clusters have 13 cases each, with residents and staff affected. The total number of infections in Singapore stands at 73,938, with 58 deaths, and 822 patients in the hospital.

site_title: Tears, joy and surprise guests as Broadway's big musicals return
summary: Broadway's top musicals, including Hamilton, The Lion King, and Wicked, reopened in New York on Tuesday after 18 months of the pandemic shutdown. The shows were met with tears, joy, and standing ovations from packed audiences. Surprise guests, including Lin-Manuel Miranda and Kristin Chenoweth, added to the emotional moments. The return of live theatre is seen as a boost for the city's tourism and economy, with over a dozen more shows set to reopen in September.

site_title: Some O&G plays see light after oil's 2020 shock
summary: Some smaller oil and gas (O&G) companies are experiencing recoveries after being heavily impacted by the 2020 oil price shock. Marco Polo Marine, a marine logistics company, has displayed resilience and achieved profitability, while Rex International, a mid-sized oil producer, has expanded its operations in Oman, Norway, and Malaysia. RH Petrogas posted a record first-quarter showing, and CSE Global has secured a healthy order book. Analysts attribute these recoveries to the recent oil price rally, which has boosted free cash flows for industry players.

site_title: Apple's new iPhone 13 touts faster 5G, sharper cameras to spur trade-ins
summary: Apple has unveiled its new iPhone 13 and updated iPad Mini, featuring faster chips, sharper cameras, and 5G connectivity. The iPhone 13 starts at $699 and will be available on September 24, with participating wireless carriers offering up to $700 off for trade-ins. The iPad Mini starts at $499 and will also be available on September 24. The company's focus on incremental upgrades and trade-in incentives is expected to encourage customers to upgrade, despite no major new features.

images.alt_text: The price of the iPhone 13 starts at US$699 and it comes in five colours. It will be available on Sept 24.
The iPad Mini's price starts at US$499 and it will be available next week.

site_title: Can Malaysia stabilise both politics and pandemic?
summary: Malaysia's newly installed Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob and the main opposition bloc, Pakatan Harapan, have signed a bipartisan pact dubbed "Transformation and Political Stability". The agreement aims to bring reforms and political certainty to the country, which has been plagued by turmoil for over a year. Despite this, Malaysia's pandemic situation remains dire, with rising infections and deaths. The memorandum of understanding marks a historic attempt to stabilize both politics and the pandemic, but its effectiveness remains to be seen.

site_title: Priciest food since 1970s is a big challenge for governments
summary: Global food prices rose 33% in August from a year earlier, driven by extreme weather, freight, and fertilizer costs. Governments worldwide are intervening to mitigate the impact, with aid, price cuts, and trade rule changes. The issue is more acute in emerging markets, where food accounts for a larger share of household spending. Riots and protests have already occurred in Asia, Africa, and the Middle East, and food inflation is now higher than at any point in the past six decades, according to FAO data.

site_title: China tells banks Evergrande won't pay interest next week
summary: China's Ministry of Housing and Urban-Rural Development has told major lenders to Evergrande Group not to expect interest payments next week, citing the developer's inability to meet its debt obligations due on Sept 20. Evergrande is sitting on over $300 billion of liabilities and is discussing possible extensions and loan rollovers. The move is seen as a sign of liquidity stress, and bondholders have priced in slim odds of a rescue, with senior leaders in Beijing remaining silent on whether to allow creditors to suffer major losses.

images.alt_text: The company's complex web of obligations has become one of the biggest sources of financial risk in China's economy.

site_title: MBS reaffirms commitment to giving with S$275,000 donation
summary: Marina Bay Sands (MBS) has donated S$275,000 to support its community engagement programme, Sands Cares, through a six-month food programme for 1,000 vulnerable families. The programme aims to improve nutrition using fresh produce. MBS also engaged its 10,000-strong workforce in an Impact Conversation series to celebrate community partners, including organisations such as the Singapore Red Cross and Care Corner Singapore. The initiative is part of MBS' commitment to providing shelter, food, and services to vulnerable communities and supporting education and employment in the hospitality industry.

site_title: Data from platform operators key to unravelling gig worker issues
summary: Singapore's newly-formed advisory committee on platform workers will review protections for gig workers, including delivery riders, ride-hailing drivers, and cabbies. The committee will focus on three areas: housing and retirement adequacy, financial protection for work injuries, and bargaining power. Data from platform operators will be key to understanding the demographics, work patterns, and accident rates of gig workers. The committee aims to plug gaps in the current understanding of gig workers and provide insights for policymakers to ensure fair protection measures.

site_title: 'Supernormal' returns traditional banks enjoy to erode as challengers emerge: JPMorgan
summary: Traditional banks' stronghold in the industry is eroding due to the emergence of challenger banks in Asia, which can manage interest rates, credit, and cross-sell well. Fintechs are also gaining ground, with some companies preparing for listing via SPACs or standalone. JPMorgan's report notes that banks must address customer needs and adopt regulations to outperform, and that embracing technology is crucial. The report predicts that market share will shift in favor of innovators with banking licenses, and that traditional banks with weak digital offerings will lose ground at an accelerated pace.

site_title: Next few weeks critical as Singapore faces unprecedented Covid-19 situation: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore faces an unprecedented COVID-19 situation, with the current wave of infections expected to be critical in the next few weeks. Health Minister Ong Ye Kung emphasized the need for the country to hold its position while deciding on next steps, citing Denmark's experience of managing multiple waves of illness and deaths. Singapore has been riding the current wave with vaccine-generated immunity, but its relatively naive state makes it vulnerable to severe illness and deaths. The country is closely watching for more cases and is considering its options, with mandatory vaccinations unlikely and masks likely to remain in place.

site_title: Redefining retail
summary: Singapore's retail industry is evolving, with a shift towards F&B and co-working spaces. Data from major Reits shows a 8% increase in F&B tenants, while sports and fitness retailers' concentration has grown by 2%. In contrast, department stores' footprint has fallen 6.1%, and the leisure and entertainment category's proportion has dropped 5%. To future-proof malls, landlords and occupiers must innovate, embracing technological solutions and forming symbiotic relationships. The push towards F&B and co-working spaces will likely continue, with online deliveries and self-pick-ups also becoming more prevalent.

site_title: China's oil sale is a clear message to Opec+
summary: China has announced the sale of crude oil from its strategic petroleum reserve, marking the first time the country has made such a move public. The sale is aimed at stabilizing domestic market supply and demand, and effectively guaranteeing the country's energy security, amid rising oil prices over $70 per barrel. The move is seen as a message to Opec+, which has decided to keep adding production at rates agreed earlier despite calls to add more supply to the market. China's decision is part of its efforts to temper domestic prices and mitigate the effects of inflation, which has become a cause for anxiety in the country.

site_title: Dwindling options for EC buyers in H2 2021, 2022
summary: Singapore's executive condominium (EC) market is experiencing dwindling options for buyers, with demand remaining robust. As of Q2 2021, the supply of completed EC units was nearly depleted, and uncompleted units remained unsold. With only one EC launch expected every six months, buyers face limited choices in the Outside Central Region (OCR). The top EC districts, District 19, District 23, and District 18, accounted for 61.1% of completed EC units. The scarcity of ECs is expected to continue, with a Q3 wave of condo launches potentially testing demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf.

images.alt_text: Parc Greenwich, along Fernvale Lane, was launched on Sept 11, 2021. It was the first EC launch in District 28 in eight years and the only EC launch in the second half of 2021.

site_title: Zara owner Inditex's sales rebound to top pre-pandemic levels
summary: Inditex, the owner of Zara, reported a second-quarter profit of €850 million, surpassing pre-pandemic sales levels and outshining rival H&M. Sales rebounded as most stores reopened, and consumers rushed to renew their wardrobes. The company's sales accelerated in the May-July period, with shop and online sales 22% higher than a year ago. Inditex expects online sales to exceed 25% of total sales this year, and plans to launch a men's sports collection.

site_title: Househunt August 2021
summary: US mortgage rates have climbed after five consecutive weeks of declines. A Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore is expected to test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 per square foot. Manhattan rents have hit a record, with more increases anticipated. Goldman Sachs has acquired 262 billion won worth of hotel and retail assets in Seoul. UK homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high, according to an index. New World Development is selling its China property assets after securing a loan deal. WeWork has secured new tenants and filled more space at its Singapore location.

site_title: Banks in Singapore waive S$500,000 stolen via fraudulent card payments
summary: Banks in Singapore have waived S$500,000 stolen from 75 customers due to fraudulent card payments. Malicious actors gained access to overseas telecommunications operators' systems, diverting SMS one-time passwords meant for verifying credit card transactions. The compromised networks have been identified and notified, with investigations ongoing to identify the perpetrators. Local telecommunication networks are secure, and banks have implemented additional safeguards, including specialized firewalls and system monitoring. As a result, banks will provide a goodwill waiver to affected customers who had taken care to protect their credentials.

site_title: What's behind the resilience of Singapore real estate?
summary: The Singapore real estate market has shown resilience despite a global pandemic, with homebuyers and investors picking up residential properties across various segments. Recent private residential project launches have broken price records, and HDB flat owners are enjoying a seller's market with resale prices climbing. The landed housing segment continues to shine, with some districts seeing bigger price gains than others. The rental market for private homes is also changing, with tenant profiles shifting and rents expected to support a recovery. The industrial, retail, and office sectors are also performing well, with new developments and changes in demand drivers.

images.alt_text: A semi-detached house at the highest point of Bright Hill Drive, sold within the last three months. It comes with a roof terrace overlooking the neighbourhood, and is near the new Upper Thomson MRT station.

Allianz Real Estate's S$634 million purchase of a half stake in Grade A office asset OUE Bayfront (above), OUE Tower and OUE Link was one of the top three acquisitions by institutional investors in 2021 year to date.

site_title: Is the double-digit growth of HDB resale flat prices sustainable?
summary: Singapore's HDB resale flat prices experienced a remarkable 11% year-on-year growth in the second quarter of 2021, defying pandemic and economic downturn expectations. The double-digit growth rate is unsustainable in the long run, as it exceeds the recommended 2-3% above inflation. Rising demand, improved economic recovery, and generous resale grants fueled the market. However, prices are expected to surpass $1 million by 2030, making them unaffordable for many homebuyers, and may lead to a shrinking gap between mature and non-mature estates' price premiums.

site_title: British tennis darling Raducanu set for big bucks on and off court
summary: British tennis star Emma Raducanu, 18, is projected to earn up to £20m from endorsements and branding over the next two years. Her US Open win and rising tennis career have increased her market value, making her a "brand gold" opportunity. To reach $100-200m in off-court earnings, analysts say she needs to become a consistent Grand Slam winner. Raducanu's diverse background and likeable personality have drawn attention from top brands, including Nike, and she has already been featured on British Vogue's cover and at the Met Gala.

images.alt_text: Emma Raducanu poses with the 2021 US Open championship trophy after defeating Leylah Fernandez of Canada during the women's singles final on Sept 11.

site_title: CBD Grade A and B office rental gap to widen further
summary: Singapore's office market has shown resilience in the first half of 2021, with Grade A office rents declining 0.5% to S$9.52 per square foot and Grade B rents falling 0.9% to S$7.79 per square foot. The rental gap between Grade A and B offices has widened to 18.2%, driven by the growth of the flexible-workspace sector and technology companies expanding their presence in the CBD. Despite increased vacancies, selective landlords are still seeking higher rents for Grade A offices, leading to a forecast of 2% rent growth for the year.

images.alt_text: Talent recruitment is a key consideration for tech companies, driving their preference for either well-located Grade A buildings or high-quality business parks in fringe locations. For example, at Razer's new headquarters at one-north (above), the gaming hardware firm would hire about 1,000 positions.

site_title: Time to end chasm between vaccine-rich and vaccine-poor
summary: US President Joe Biden will urge world leaders at the UN to vaccinate 70% of the world's population within a year, but this goal remains unattainable due to low inoculation rates in developing countries. The contrast between the West's high vaccination rates (70%) and Africa's 2% highlights the issue. Many vaccine doses remain unused in Europe and North America, exacerbating the problem. Former UK Prime Minister Gordon Brown emphasizes that vaccine scarcity in poor countries is not only a moral failure but also a potential threat to global health, as new mutant variants of the virus could emerge.

site_title: US manufacturing output slows sharply in August
summary: US manufacturing output slowed sharply in August, increasing 0.2% amid disruptions from Hurricane Ida and ongoing shortages of raw materials and labor. The slowdown was more than expected, with economists forecasting a 0.4% gain. The sector, accounting for 11.9% of the US economy, is being driven by businesses restocking inventories after sharp declines in the first half of the year, despite a shift towards services due to Covid-19 vaccinations. General Motors and Ford are also reducing production due to microchip shortages and congestion at ports in China.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 0.25 points lower at 1555.26 on Wednesday, with a trading volume of 4.495 billion lots worth RM3.06 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 519-492.

site_title: US: Wall St opens slightly higher; economic uncertainty weighs
summary: US stocks opened slightly higher on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite rising 3.4, 4.4, and 33.6 points respectively. Cooling inflation eased concerns about reduced monetary stimulus, but a slowing economic recovery and uncertainty over higher taxes limited gains. The US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, with the US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Reshaping the office market: De-densification and decentralisation
summary: Singapore's office market is shifting towards de-densification and decentralization, driven by hybrid work arrangements and employees' preferences for flexibility. To support new ways of working, offices will need to be revamped with more collaborative and shared spaces, potentially at the expense of individual workspaces. Some occupiers are adopting decentralized grade A offices near employees' homes, which offer cost-effectiveness and a desired destination for employee experience. The demand for decentralized offices is expected to rise, with rents anticipated to grow 2-3% per annum, driven by limited new supply and increasing demand.

site_title: OKP wins S$57.2 million PUB contract
summary: OKP Holdings, an infrastructure and civil engineering company, has secured a S$57.2 million contract from PUB for the Deep Tunnel Sewerage System (DTSS) project. The contract, valued at S$320.9 million, includes the construction of link sewers and manholes in Singapore. The project is expected to be completed by June 20, 2025. This win brings OKP's current net construction order book to S$320.9 million, with contracts extending up to 2025.

site_title: Goldman to buy GreenSky for US$2.24b for payment plans
summary: Goldman Sachs has agreed to purchase GreenSky, a payment plan company, for approximately US$2.24 billion. The deal, valued at about US$12.11 per share, is a significant move by Goldman to expand its Marcus consumer-banking platform. GreenSky offers payment options to over 10,000 merchants, and the acquisition aims to bring in new customers through its mobile app and core offerings. The deal is expected to close in the fourth quarter of 2021 or first quarter of 2022.

site_title: London property rents decline at the sharpest pace in 11 years
summary: London property rents declined at the sharpest annual pace in 11 years, falling 0.4% in August, according to the Office for National Statistics. This drop is attributed to a decrease in demand, partly due to the shift to remote working, and an increase in supply, including an excess of rental properties. Excluding London, rents rose 2% in the rest of the UK. This trend reflects a shift away from urban areas during the pandemic, with consumers opting for larger houses with outside space and room for an office.

site_title: Johnson begins Cabinet reshuffle to bolster standing
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson began a Cabinet reshuffle, removing education secretary Gavin Williamson and justice secretary Robert Buckland. Dominic Raab, who will remain foreign secretary, took over as justice secretary. Trade Secretary Liz Truss is expected to replace Raab. The move aims to revitalize the government, which has seen a decline in popularity, and prepare for a post-Covid policy agenda. Johnson's government is bracing for a possible surge in hospitalizations this fall and winter, and has announced plans for vaccine booster shots and mask mandates if necessary.

site_title: India seeks up to 10t rupees in valuation for insurer's mega IPO
summary: India is seeking a valuation of 8-10 trillion rupees for the state-backed Life Insurance Corp's initial public offering, the nation's largest. The government plans to sell a 5-10% stake, potentially raising 400-1 trillion rupees. This IPO is crucial for the government to raise 1.75 trillion rupees by March through divestments. The sale is expected to be formalized by banks, including Kotak Mahindra Bank and Goldman Sachs, with a listing between January and March 2022. The move aims to diversify investors and raise funds to plug a widening budget gap.

site_title: Bluesheets raises US$1.5m led by Investible
summary: Bluesheets, a Singapore-based data analytics platform, has raised US$1.5 million in funding led by Investible, with participation from several other investors. The startup automates and simplifies financial data flow between company systems, connecting tools like WhatsApp and email inboxes with accounting platforms like Xero. Founded in 2021, Bluesheets has over 100 paying clients in 10 countries, including Pizza Express and Guzman y Gomez. The platform aims to simplify data processing, allowing companies to access valuable data with ease.

site_title: Singapore property investment sales could return to pre-Covid levels
summary: Singapore's property investment sales are expected to return to pre-pandemic levels, with the year-to-date total of S$17.4 billion, just 1.6% shy of 2020's figure. The residential sector dominated the market, with landed homes and GCB sales exceeding S$5 billion and S$1.9 billion respectively. Institutional investors, such as funds and REITs, poured S$3.4 billion into the market, mainly into office and industrial assets. With several GLS sites and en-bloc deals expected to conclude, sales could potentially reach S$31 billion, close to the pre-pandemic average of 2010-2019.

site_title: Private equity firm Bridgepoint's assets jump in first results since IPO
summary: Bridgepoint Group, a private equity firm, reported a 54% year-on-year increase in assets to €28.5 billion (S$45.18 billion) in the first half of 2021. Fee-paying assets rose 41% to €17.7 billion, driving a 55% increase in revenues to £122.2 million (S$226.8 million). The company deployed €2.1 billion in investments and raised €2.1 billion from stake sales. Bridgepoint sees strong demand for its funds and plans to raise €7 billion for its Bridgepoint Europe VII fund, with shares up over 20% since listing.

site_title: Myanmar anti-coup protesters attack more cell towers
summary: Anti-coup protesters in Myanmar have destroyed four military-owned communications towers in western Chin state, targeting the junta's money source. The attacks, carried out by the "Zoland People's Defence Force," are part of a broader effort to disrupt government infrastructure. The violence has pushed civilians to form defense forces, and over 1,000 civilians have been killed and nearly 8,000 arrested since the coup in February. The junta seeks to install its own representative at the UN General Assembly, amid diplomatic tensions over who should represent Myanmar.

site_title: Singapore stocks close lower on Wednesday on weak China, US data; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.7% on Wednesday, tracking losses on Wall Street due to weak US consumer inflation data and China's industrial production and retail sales data missing expectations. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,058.61 points. Local lenders DBS, UOB, and OCBC also fell, while Hongkong Land and SGX were the top and second-best performers, respectively. The decline was attributed to concerns about China's economic outlook, with analysts warning that the downward repricing of China equities could be far from over.

site_title: Japan's streetwear veteran Nigo takes over at Kenzo
summary: Nigo, a renowned Japanese streetwear designer, has been named the new artistic director of luxury brand Kenzo, succeeding Felipe Oliveira Baptista. Nigo, known for his celebrity collaborations and label A Bathing Ape, takes over the role after just two years under Baptista. He aims to revive the spirit of Kenzo founder Kenzo Takada, with whom he shares a connection due to their shared Tokyo fashion school background. LVMH's CEO welcomed Nigo as "an extremely talented Japanese talent" who will open a new chapter in Kenzo's history.

site_title: Buy-now-pay-later startup Fundiin raises US$1.8m in seed round
summary: Fundiin, a Vietnamese "buy now, pay later" startup, has raised US$1.8 million in a seed round led by Japanese funds Genesia Ventures and JAFCO Asia, along with former Affirm executives and existing investors. The funds will be used to expand operations and strengthen the executive team. Fundiin was founded by fintech executives to provide BNPL options to Vietnam's rising middle class, working with over 100 merchants. The company aims to increase sales for retailers with its credit-based service, charging merchants instead of consumers.

site_title: Malaysia could hit 70% full vaccination by Oct, Vietnam remains laggard in Asean: Citi
summary: Malaysia is expected to reach 70% full vaccination by October, surpassing other Asean countries, according to a Citi report. The country has eased restrictions in major cities since September 10 and is set to treat COVID-19 as an endemic disease by the end of the month. This comes as vaccination coverage improves, with mobility picking up in the capital since June.

site_title: StanChart to add bankers in sustainable finance, capital markets in Saudi Arabia
summary: Standard Chartered plans to add bankers in sustainable finance, project finance, and capital markets in Saudi Arabia, a market it views as a "front-runner" for its regional business. The bank, which has a team of 25 people in Saudi Arabia, aims to double its current staff numbers. Its strategy in the country includes working with global corporates and financial institutions, and participating in transactions that contribute to the country's economic development. Standard Chartered has also been involved in significant transactions in Saudi Arabia, including a $6 billion sukuk issue by Saudi Aramco.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: MBS has extended its deadline to deliver expansion plan details to March 31, 2022. New private home sales dropped 24% in August due to tightened restrictions and fewer launches. Job vacancies reached a record 92,100 in June, with labor market indicators expected to improve in the third quarter. Banks waived S$500,000 stolen from 75 customers via fraudulent card payments. Carousell raised US$100m, entering the unicorn club at a US$1.1b valuation. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.7% lower on Wednesday due to weak China and US data.

site_title: Digital doggies: pet influencers on the rise in Singapore
summary: In Singapore, a growing trend of pet influencers on social media has emerged, fueled by the rise in online shopping and pet ownership during the pandemic. Sasha and Piper, two fluffy white terriers, have gained tens of thousands of followers on Instagram, endorsing products such as vacuum cleaners and shoes for thousands of dollars. Their owner, Carrie Er, stumbled into the business by posting photos of her dogs online, and now works with an agency to promote products. The pet influencer boom has created opportunities for pet owners to monetize their pets' online presence.

site_title: Asean wraps up meeting with commitments to further digital economy, sustainability
summary: The Association of South-east Asian Nations (Asean) has agreed to collaborate with external partners to spur recovery from the pandemic and promote longer-term growth. Key commitments include working on the digital economy, including exchanging electronic customs information, and conducting a study on a region-wide digital economy pact by 2023. Asean also agreed to collaborate with Japan on innovation and sustainability and will start negotiations on the Asean Digital Economy Framework Agreement by 2025. The group will enhance existing free-trade agreements and work towards ratifying the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement in early 2022.

site_title: Top Glove withdraws application for Hong Kong listing; will resubmit at later date
summary: Top Glove withdraws its application for a US$1 billion dual primary listing on the Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX), citing a delay in plans due to unresolved issues with the US Customs and Border Protection (CBP) over forced-labour practices in its production process. The company had previously delayed its listing plans in June and had its import ban lifted on September 10 after addressing all indicators of forced labour. Top Glove will resubmit its listing application to the Malaysian bourse at a later date.

site_title: North Korea ratches up regional tensions with ballistic missiles test
summary: North Korea fired two ballistic missiles off its east coast on September 15, 2021, amid regional tensions and stalled denuclearization talks with the US. The launches follow a cruise missile test with nuclear capabilities, and come as South Korea and China hold diplomatic talks. Analysts say the missiles are designed to evade defenses and target South Korea and Japan in the event of war. The US and its allies condemn the launches, with the US saying they do not pose an immediate threat but highlight the destabilizing impact of North Korea's illicit weapons program.

site_title: Keppel unit, Laos state-owned power company to look into importing renewable energy into Singapore
summary: Keppel Electric, a subsidiary of Keppel Infrastructure Holdings, has signed an agreement with Laos' state-owned electricity company Électricité Du Laos (EDL) to import up to 100 MW of renewable hydropower from Laos to Singapore. The trial electricity supply is expected to commence once technical, commercial, and regulatory arrangements are finalized. This project aims to promote energy sustainability and connectivity in the Asean region, with potential collaboration opportunities for long-term renewable energy development and tracking.

site_title: No worrying signs of rising indebtedness among young adults: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has reported no worrying signs of rising indebtedness among young adults, with average monthly default rates below 0.7% and a 23% decrease in credit card rollover balances from 2020 to 2021. Unsecured personal loan balances fell by 21% and mortgages by 12% over the same period. These findings come despite a reported increase in personal debt among young adults amid the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dive, dragged by Macau casinos
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.84% on Wednesday, dragged down by casino operators following Macau officials' plans to tighten regulations. Retail sales data showed China's economic recovery slowed further in August. The Shanghai Composite Index also declined 0.17%. The market's decline was partly attributed to concerns over the US-EU trade talks, which may impact global trade.

site_title: Carousell raises US$100m, enters unicorn club at US$1.1b valuation
summary: Carousell, a Singapore-based online classifieds startup, has raised US$100 million in fresh funds, valuing it at US$1.1 billion, entering the unicorn club. The fund-raise was led by South Korean private equity firm STIC, and the company plans to spend the money on deepening investments across more categories of pre-owned goods and markets. Carousell also explores acquisitions to scale up the business and aims to provide investors with an exit by 2024 at a valuation of at least US$1.13 billion.

site_title: Keppel Reit prices S$150 million 2.07% notes due 2028
summary: Keppel Reit has priced S$150 million notes with a 2.07% coupon rate due 2028. The notes will be issued under the Reit's S$1 billion debt issuance programme and are expected to mature on Sept 24, 2028. The net proceeds will be used for financing or refinancing acquisitions, investments, and asset enhancement works. DBS, OCBC, and UOB have been appointed as joint lead managers and bookrunners. The issue price is 100% of the principal amount, and interest will be payable semi-annually.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Wednesday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index falling 0.52% to 30,511.71, and the Topix index losing 1.06% to 2,096.39, as investors sought to lock in profits after recent rallies. The declines were also influenced by falls on Wall Street and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Evergrande's teeter may clear path for Singapore players in China
summary: Evergrande Group, a Chinese real estate giant, is facing over US$300 billion in liabilities and potential collapse, which could impact the global property market and economy. Singapore property players, such as CapitaLand, Keppel Corporation, and GuocoLand, may benefit from the situation as Chinese developers become more conservative in debt. With scale, debt can be a friend, but Evergrande's debt woes highlight the risks of debt servicing. Singapore property groups may find opportunities to acquire assets at lower prices, but the situation will be closely watched and may present challenges for the entire economy.

site_title: Gig workers: Committee to focus on savings, injury protection; may involve legislative change
summary: A newly-formed advisory committee on platform workers will focus on retirement and housing adequacy, work injury financial protection, and bargaining power. The committee aims to complete its work by the second-half of 2022. Its efforts may lead to legislative changes to address the needs of gig workers, who often lack comprehensive financial protection and benefits.

site_title: Europe: Stocks under pressure from weak China data
summary: European shares fell 0.1% due to concerns over China's slowing economy, declining travel and leisure stocks, and soaring UK inflation. Asian stocks also tumbled after China's factory and retail sectors faltered. Travel and leisure stocks declined 1.1%, with gaming companies hit by Macau casino regulations. Meanwhile, H&M fell 3% due to lower-than-expected quarterly sales, while Zara's sales approached pre-pandemic levels. UK inflation reached a 9-year high, and US-EU trade talks are in focus.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher as foreign-buying outweighs global growth worries
summary: South Korean stocks closed higher on Wednesday, with foreign buying outweighing concerns about global economic growth. The Kospi index rose 0.15% to 3,153.40, extending a fourth consecutive gain. The benchmark bond yield fell, while the won remained unchanged. Investors avoided making big bets ahead of a holiday next week, with the market focusing on US-EU trade talks and global economic trends.

site_title: MBS seeks deadline extension to deliver details on expansion plan
summary: Marina Bay Sands (MBS) has extended its deadline to deliver details on the expansion of its integrated resort to March 31, 2022, from June 30, 2021. The extension is part of a waiver agreement with lenders, allowing MBS to delay compliance with financial covenant provisions until December 31, 2022. The expansion plan, valued at S$4.5 billion, includes a new 1,000-room hotel tower and a live entertainment arena. The deadline extension comes as MBS's parent company, Las Vegas Sands, faces challenges due to the COVID-19 pandemic, including a net loss of US$192 million in the first quarter of this year.

site_title: OCBC hires DBS veteran as head of global wholesale banking
summary: OCBC has hired DBS veteran Tan Teck Long, 51, as its head of global wholesale banking, effective March 15, 2022. Tan will oversee OCBC's global corporate banking, commercial banking, and other wholesale businesses. He previously served as chief risk officer at DBS, where he will relinquish the role on March 12, 2022. The appointment is part of OCBC's efforts to ensure its top executives remain relevant to its strategic objectives. Tan's experience and knowledge were identified through an independent search firm and assessed by OCBC's board of directors.

site_title: Watten Estate Condominium up for sale at minimum price of S$500m
summary: The Watten Estate Condominium in Singapore has been put up for collective sale with a minimum price of S$500 million. The 220,241 square foot freehold site can be redeveloped into 286 units, with over 80% of owners consenting to the sale. The site is zoned residential with a gross plot ratio of 1.4 and an allowable height of up to five storeys. The minimum price translates to about S$1,622 per square foot per plot ratio, or S$1,570 psf after a 8% bonus gross floor area and development charge.

site_title: Indonesia's August exports hit record high on resources boom
summary: Indonesia's exports reached a record high of $21.42 billion in August, a 64.1% increase from the previous year, driven by a surge in mining products and a surplus of $4.74 billion. This surpassed analysts' forecasts of a 36.90% rise. High prices for coal, copper, palm oil, steel, and tin contributed to the growth. Imports also rose 55.26% to $16.68 billion, beating the forecast of a 45.10% increase.

site_title: New private home sales down nearly 24% in August on the back of tighter restrictions, fewer launches
summary: Singapore's private home sales declined nearly 24% in August due to tightened restrictions and fewer launches. Despite this, sales remained above the 10-year monthly average, with 1,215 units sold. The market is expected to maintain its positive momentum for the rest of the year, driven by demand for larger spaces and attractive pricing. Analysts predict a strong buying power, with demand potentially spilling over to ongoing launches or the secondary market, and expect private home prices to rise 6% for the full year.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars weighed down by disappointing Chinese data
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell against the US dollar on Wednesday after disappointing Chinese data showed factory and retail sales growth cooled more sharply than expected in August. The Aussie was steady at US$0.7326, while the Kiwi dropped to US$0.7097, touching a two-week low. Investors are concerned about slowing global growth due to the pandemic and central banks' tapering of stimulus. The Reserve Bank of Australia is not expected to hike interest rates next year, contrasting with the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's expected rate hike next month.

site_title: Heartland shophouses in Little India, Bedok and Toa Payoh for sale
summary: Three heartland shophouses in Little India, Bedok, and Toa Payoh are up for sale via expressions of interest. A three-storey freehold conservation shophouse in Little India is priced at S$4.8 million, while two HDB shophouses in Bedok and Toa Payoh are sold collectively at S$7.5 million. The properties offer immediate rental income and are eligible for foreign buyers, with potential for capital appreciation and change-of-use options. The sale of these shophouses is expected to benefit from the growing vibrancy of the Little India and Farrer Park enclaves.

site_title: Singapore, Thailand launch depository receipts linkage
summary: Singapore and Thailand have launched a depository receipts (DRs) linkage, the first exchange-level DR cooperation in South-east Asia. The partnership allows investors to buy and sell securities in both markets via DRs, with the goal of advancing securities market cooperation in the Asean region and offering investors enhanced access with unmatched efficiency. The first DR under the linkage is expected to be introduced in the next 12 months, improving connectivity across borders and asset classes, and meeting rising demand for more choice in investments.

site_title: BT's Top Stories from Last Week
summary: Temasek CEO Ho Ching advocates for continuing to report unlinked Covid-19 cases despite Singapore's decision to stop publishing the number. Meanwhile, CapitaLand shares will cease trading on September 10. The Asian garment industry is bracing for higher US tariffs, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Additionally, Citigroup sets a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index, and Thaksin Shinawatra is confident his daughter's suspension as Thai PM will be cleared by the court. UK economy shrinks for the second month in a row.

site_title: Macau casino stocks tumble as city proposes gambling industry crackdown
summary: Macau casino stocks plummeted over 13-24% as the Macau government proposed a crackdown on the gambling industry, including increased supervision and criminalizing underground banking. The move comes amid concerns over the city's reliance on the industry, which accounts for 80% of government revenue and 55% of GDP. The proposals, set to expire in June 2022, will require licensed operators to submit to direct supervision and bid to renew their licenses. The crackdown is seen as a significant threat to the industry's future, with Macau's economy heavily reliant on gambling revenue.

site_title: Asia: Markets slip again as US data fails to temper recovery worries
summary: Asian markets slipped on Wednesday, tracking a US sell-off, despite data showing US consumer inflation slowed last month. The Delta variant's impact on the global recovery outlook and concerns about monetary policy, regulatory crackdowns, and a possible Evergrande default continue to weigh on investors. Despite a slight dip in inflation figures, analysts believe inflation remains strong and may not ease significantly. Markets in Hong Kong, Macau, and other Asian cities fell, with casino operators plummeting after China tightened control over the industry.

site_title: US startup aims to transform pet food with lab-made chow
summary: A US startup, Bond Pet Foods, is developing lab-made pet food by growing nutritional chow using biotech processes. The company aims to reduce animal slaughter and greenhouse gas emissions. Unlike traditional pet food, which relies on animal protein, Bond Pet Foods' lab-made chow avoids these issues, offering a more sustainable alternative.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.65% and the Topix index down 0.81%. Investors sought to lock in profits after recent rallies, with falls on Wall Street also weighing on the market. The benchmark indices fell to 30,469.80 and 2,101.69 respectively.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at open, tracking Wall Street losses; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks fell at the open, tracking Wall Street losses, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.4% to 3,065.87. The decline follows US stocks' losses, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.8% and the S&P 500 down 0.6%. Asian markets also fell, with Tokyo stocks down 0.7% and European shares closing 0.1% lower. Banking stocks led the decline, with OCBC down 0.5% and DBSD05 down 0.7%.

site_title: China's industrial output rose 5.3% y-o-y in August, retail sales up 2.5%
summary: China's industrial output rose 5.3% year-over-year in August, narrowly missing expectations for a 5.8% increase. Retail sales growth slowed to 2.5% year-over-year, the slowest pace since August 2020. This marks a decrease from the 7.0% growth analysts had expected in August. The data suggests China's economic growth is slowing, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: UOB prices Sonia benchmark covered bonds due 2026 in £850m issuance
summary: UOB priced £850m of floating-rate covered bonds due 2026, the largest-ever Sterling covered bond offering from an Asian issuer. The bonds use the Compounded Daily Sterling Overnight Interest Rate Average (Sonia) as their interest basis, marking UOB's first Sonia benchmark covered bond offering. The offering was priced above par at 103.52% and has a coupon rate of compounded daily Sonia plus 100 basis points. The bank expects the bonds to be rated Aaa by Moody's and AAA by S&P Global Ratings.

site_title: Hong Kong: Equities open lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.73% at the open, following a retreat across Asian markets driven by Wall Street losses. The Hang Seng Index dropped 186.27 points to 25,315.96. Asian markets were influenced by concerns over the global economic recovery, with investors fretting about the recovery.

site_title: Apple supplier Foxconn halts electric vehicle project with China's Byton: Nikkei
summary: Foxconn, an Apple supplier, has halted its electric vehicle project with Chinese startup Byton due to Byton's worsening financial situation. The project, initially set to start in 2022, is now uncertain. Foxconn has maintained plans to build factories in the US and Thailand to assemble vehicles in 2023. Byton has seen some employees leave, and a few Foxconn employees remain at the factory, wrapping up the project when necessary.

site_title: Japan'a July core machinery orders rise 0.9% m-o-m
summary: Japan's core machinery orders rose 0.9% in July from the previous month, exceeding a 3.1% rise forecast by economists. This growth compares to a 11.1% advance year-over-year, beating the 15.7% expectation. The data suggests a positive outlook for Japan's economy, potentially indicating increased capital spending in the coming months.

site_title: UOL completes integrated development in London with hotel, heritage building
summary: UOL has completed One Bishopsgate Plaza in London, a 43-storey tower and the conservation of the 144-year-old heritage building Devonshire Row. The project features Pan Pacific London, a hotel with five levels of amenities, and The Sky Residences, 160 luxury apartments. The development is located near Liverpool Street station, offering easy access to various London landmarks and transportation hubs. The project is part of UOL's vision to establish a strong presence in the UK, with 43 units of The Sky Residences already sold at an average price of £2,000 per sq ft.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.57 points, or 0.10%, to 1,557.08, with 177 gainers and 156 losers. The market opened higher on Wednesday, with a trading volume of 210.26 million lots worth RM98.95 million.

site_title: Job vacancies hit record high of 92,100 in June: MOM
summary: Singapore's job vacancies reached a record high of 92,100 in June, driven by sustained demand in growth sectors despite ongoing border restrictions. Manufacturing and construction saw the greatest rise in job vacancies, while industries such as information and communications, administrative and support services, and professional services also experienced growth. Unemployment rates declined, with the resident long-term unemployment rate improving to 0.9% in June. Total employment fell by 16,200 in the second quarter, with resident employment rising by 4,800.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit names Ooi Eng Peng as non-executive director
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) has appointed Ooi Eng Peng as a non-executive director, effective immediately. Ooi brings over 35 years of real estate experience to the role, having previously held non-executive directorships at various companies across Asia Pacific. His appointment is seen as beneficial for the Reit's strategy and governance, with the current board expecting to deliver sustainable and growing returns to unitholders. Michael Wilde, the Reit sponsor's acting CEO, will resign from his non-executive directorship role on the same date and resume his role as CFO on October 5.

site_title: Instagram seeks to curb mental harm to teenagers
summary: Instagram plans to address concerns about its impact on teenagers' mental health, particularly in regards to body image and negative social comparison. The social network's head of public policy, Karina Newton, defended the platform against a Wall Street Journal report, citing mixed research on the effects of social media on well-being. Instagram is exploring ways to "nudge" users towards more uplifting content and has worked to address issues like bullying and eating disorders. The platform is also developing a version of Instagram for children aged 13 and under, despite opposition from child safety advocates.

site_title: 'Ghost kitchens' boom in Asia as pandemic sparks huge demand
summary: A boom in "ghost kitchens" has emerged in Asia, driven by the pandemic's huge demand for food delivery. These commercial kitchens, also known as "dark kitchens," produce meals that are then delivered to customers through food delivery apps, bypassing traditional restaurants. The trend has been fueled by coronavirus lockdowns and the growth of food delivery apps, allowing customers to have high-quality meals quickly delivered to their homes. This shift is seen as a significant development in the food industry, with many Asian countries embracing the concept.

site_title: China's Miniso to double US stores, add New York 'flagship' as pandemic slashes mall rents
summary: China's Miniso Group plans to nearly double its US stores to 54 by the end of the year, with a flagship store in New York's Flushing district. The retailer is betting on post-pandemic shoppers seeking affordable, fun goods for homes and work. Lower mall rents due to the pandemic have made it easier to secure locations, and Miniso sees the US as a strategic market. The company aims to expand further, with Vincent Huang estimating "thousands" of US stores in the future.

site_title: Malaysian holiday hotspot readies for reopening with tourism bubble
summary: Langkawi, Malaysia, a popular holiday destination, is reopening to fully vaccinated domestic tourists starting September 16, as part of a domestic tourism bubble. The move aims to boost the country's tourism industry after a devastating coronavirus crisis. With strict protocols in place, the plan targets 400,000 visitors by the end of the year, generating estimated revenues of RM165 million. The reopening is seen as a relief for local businesses, which rely heavily on tourism, and follows a similar approach taken by Thailand with its Phuket reopening.

site_title: Livingstone Health appointed by MOH to procure, deliver Sinovac vaccines to Singapore
summary: Livingstone Health International, a subsidiary of Livingstone Health Holdings, has been appointed by the Ministry of Health (MOH) to procure and deliver Sinovac vaccines to private healthcare institutions in Singapore. The vaccines will be available from September 24 at designated clinics, with the company's non-executive chairman and CEO committing to purchase and donate 500 doses. Sinovac will deliver 101,000 doses, with MOH allocating 170,000 doses for free distribution to approved institutions.

site_title: Australian consumers cheered by reopening plans as vaccinations surge
summary: Australian consumer sentiment rebounded in early September, rising 2.0% after the state government of New South Wales flagged a loosening of restrictions for those fully vaccinated by mid-October. The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index of consumer sentiment reached 106.2, with optimists outnumbering pessimists. Confidence in the economy and finances improved, while expectations for house prices rose to an eight-year peak. The improvement in sentiment is attributed to the surge in vaccinations, with 57% of respondents who have had at least one dose showing confidence in the economy.

site_title: Evergrande warns of growing default risks as pressures mount
summary: China Evergrande Group, a cash-strapped property developer, warned of growing default risks as it engages financial advisers to examine financial options amid plummeting property sales. The company's stock and bond prices plummeted, with shares falling to a six-year low in Hong Kong and Shanghai trading halted. Evergrande has appointed two firms to assess its capital structure, evaluate liquidity, and explore restructuring options, which may involve interest payment delays or haircuts. The company is also talking to potential investors to sell assets, but progress is slow, amid growing concerns about the potential contagion of a crisis to China's banking system.

site_title: Europe: Shares close lower, dragged by mining, banks, luxury stocks
summary: European shares closed 0.1% lower, driven by declines in mining, banking, and luxury stocks. The US Labor Department reported a 0.1% increase in the Consumer Price Index, the smallest gain in six months, indicating inflation may have peaked. However, concerns about prolonged inflation pressure stocks, and the US Federal Reserve's upcoming meeting may delay tapering its bond-buying program, adding to market uncertainty.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam, Livingstone Health, Spackman, OUE, Low Keng Huat
summary: Several Singaporean companies reported new developments on Wednesday, September 15, 2021. Olam International confirmed plans to develop a new dairy processing facility in New Zealand, while Livingstone Health Holdings received approval to import and supply Sinovac vaccines to Singapore. Spackman Entertainment Group agreed to sell its Zip Cinema business for S$19.8 million, and OUE proposed issuing S$150 million notes with a fixed interest rate of 3.5% per annum. Meanwhile, Low Keng Huat reported a 52% decline in net profit for the first half of the fiscal year.

site_title: Audience Analytics to raise S$5.5m in IPO for overseas expansion, business segment growth
summary: Audience Analytics, a publisher and awards organiser, plans to raise S$5.5 million in an initial public offering (IPO) to expand its business in overseas markets and grow its product team. The company, which organises awards and exhibitions, will sell 26 million shares at S$0.30 each. The IPO aims to leverage the company's collected data and analytics capabilities.

site_title: Gold steady above US$1,800 as US inflation raises doubts on Fed taper timeline
summary: Gold prices remained steady above $1,800 due to a lower-than-expected US inflation rate, which raised doubts about the Federal Reserve's taper timeline. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) rose 0.1% last month, contradicting expectations of a 0.3% increase. This led to a decline in the dollar index and benchmark US 10-year yield, making gold more attractive. The Fed will hold a meeting next week, and the data's impact on the taper timeline is uncertain.

images.alt_text: Gold prices held above the key psychological level of US$1,800 as the dollar and bond yields came under pressure after a tamer-than-expected rise in US inflation led to uncertainty on when the US central bank will begin tapering its asset purchases.

site_title: Bank of England urges banks to wait out EU pressure over euro clearing
summary: The Bank of England's Governor Andrew Bailey has urged banks to wait out EU pressure to shift euro clearing from London to Frankfurt, rather than relocating positions, citing the significant costs of moving and fragmenting markets. The deadline for London clearers to serve EU customers ends in June 2022, and Bailey believes banks are waiting rather than shifting positions to avoid these costs. However, Bailey also emphasized the need for EU regulators to sort out the issue, warning that fragmentation could pose risks to financial stability, potentially leading to clearing of euro instruments switching to New York.

site_title: South Korea's jobless rate falls to record low in August
summary: South Korea's unemployment rate plummeted to a record low of 2.8% in August, down from 3.3% in July, according to Statistics Korea. This marks the lowest rate since data release began in 1999. The country added 518,000 jobs last month, a decrease from 542,000 the previous month, indicating a continued economic recovery from the pandemic.

site_title: Macau kicks off public gaming consultation ahead of casino rebidding
summary: Macau's government begins a 45-day public gaming consultation ahead of casino rebidding in 2022. The consultation aims to gauge public consensus on nine areas, including increased regulation, employee welfare, and government supervision. Macau has tightened scrutiny of casinos, clamping down on illicit capital flows and targeting underground lending. Casino operators, including Sands China and Wynn Macau, will rebid for licenses when they expire in June 2022, amid heightened scrutiny on capital management and daily operations. The consultation's outcome may impact the industry's long-term sustainable growth.

site_title: Hot stock: Spackman jumps 50% in early trade on cinema divestment news
summary: Spackman Entertainment 40E shares rose 50% in early trade after announcing the sale of Zip Cinema to Kakao Corp for S$19.8 million. The counter reached 0.6 cent, its highest point, before easing to 0.5 cent. The move came after the group's announcement, with 35.9 million shares changing hands, making it the top traded by volume at the market open.

site_title: Spackman to sell Zip Cinema for S$19.8m to South Korea's Kakao Corp
summary: SPACKMAN Entertainment Group has agreed to sell its Zip Cinema business to Kakao Entertainment for S$19.8 million, approximately 18 billion won in cash. The sale, subject to shareholder approval, was first disclosed in July 2020. Zip Cinema, also known as Zip Korea, is a production house and major asset of Spackman. The deal will be announced through an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: UK Parliament bars China envoy after MPs sanctioned
summary: The UK Parliament has barred China's new ambassador, Zheng Zeguang, from addressing a group of MPs due to Beijing's sanctions against them for opposing Communist Party policies. The sanctions were imposed after the UK, US, Canada, and EU placed sanctions on Chinese officials responsible for human rights abuses in Xinjiang. The Speaker of the House of Commons and House of Lords expressed concerns, saying the meeting would be "inappropriate" while sanctions remain in place, and instead, the UK all-party parliamentary group on China will make new arrangements to hear from the ambassador.

site_title: Apple's new iPhone 13 touts faster 5G, sharper cameras to spur trade-ins
summary: Apple unveiled the iPhone 13 and a new iPad mini, featuring faster 5G connectivity, sharper cameras, and improved chips without a price increase. To encourage trade-ins, participating wireless carriers are offering incentives, making the new phones free to some customers ahead of the year-end holiday season. This move is expected to entice customers to upgrade from older models like the iPhone X.

site_title: For Tesla probe, US regulators seek data from 12 automakers
summary: The US National Highway Traffic and Safety Administration (NHTSA) has sent letters to 12 automakers, including BMW, Ford, and Tesla, seeking data on their driver assistance systems.
