The probe began after 11 Tesla accidents involving emergency vehicles since 2018, including one fatal crash and seven injuries. The NHTSA wants to conduct a benchmark analysis of vehicles with advanced driver assistance systems. Safety officials are asking for details on how these systems were developed and tested, and how they detect the presence of first responder vehicles.

site_title: FDI inflows across Asia remain resilient despite the prolonged pandemic
summary: Global foreign direct investment (FDI) flows dropped 33% in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with Asia being a resilient region. FDI inflows to Asia rose 4% to $535 billion, driven by China's $149 billion investment. Intra-ASEAN FDI flows saw 5.4% growth, with Singapore and Thailand being the largest investors. Despite economic challenges, Asia's FDI growth is expected to continue, driven by regional and global linkages. The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) is expected to boost growth, and energy infrastructure projects in Asia grew, defying global trends.

site_title: Hongkong Land signs crypto firm as tenant for the first time
summary: Hongkong Land Holdings has signed a lease with HashKey Group, a crypto asset firm, for the first time, marking a shift towards embracing the emerging sector. The lease is for a floor in Three Exchange Square, a prestigious office building in Hong Kong's Central district. This move follows a decline in demand from foreign banks in the area, and Hongkong Land expects to see more virtual asset companies expanding in the finance district.

site_title: As PM Suga exits, weary Japan must avoid return to revolving-door era
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga has announced his resignation, effective in a few weeks. His departure marks the end of a tumultuous 12 months, during which he faced criticism over the Summer Olympics and his handling of the pandemic. Suga's approval ratings have plummeted to 27%, the lowest since the LDP's return to power in 2012. The ruling Liberal Democratic Party is set to choose a new leader, with Taro Kano emerging as the early favorite. The next prime minister will face the challenge of lifting the country's disenchantment and dealing with the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Oil settles unchanged as latest storm spares US energy sector
summary: Oil prices ended largely unchanged on Tuesday as tropical storm Nicholas brought heavy rain and power outages in Texas, sparing the US energy sector from significant damage. Despite over 39% of US Gulf of Mexico production shut, oil prices remained stable, with Brent crude settling up 9 cents to $73.60 a barrel. The International Energy Agency expects global oil demand to rebound in October, with a demand growth forecast of 1.6 million barrels per day.

images.alt_text: Oil prices ended largely unchanged on Tuesday as tropical storm Nicholas brought heavy rain and power outages in Texas but caused less damage to US energy infrastructure than Hurricane Ida caused earlier this month.

site_title: Microsoft names Smith vice-chair, starts US$60b share buyback
summary: Microsoft has appointed president and chief legal officer Brad Smith as vice-chair, with no board membership, and introduced a new $60 billion share buyback program. Smith, who has led policy and legal efforts, will continue to report to CEO Satya Nadella. This move follows the company's resurgence under Nadella's leadership, resulting in a market value over $2.2 trillion and a cash pile of over $130 billion. The repurchase program has no expiration date and may be terminated at any time.

site_title: Lamborghini fans bid S$2m farewell to the brand's pure combustion era
summary: Lamborghini has bid farewell to its pure combustion era with the launch of the Aventador Ultimae in Singapore, priced at S$2 million. The limited-edition car, with 350 examples produced, marks the end of the V12-powered Aventador. The company plans to hybridize its full product line, with the first hybrid car set to debut in 2023, followed by an all-electric Lamborghini in 2027. Despite the shift towards electric vehicles, Lamborghini's region director, Francesco Scadaoni, aims to ensure the new electric model excites drivers like its combustion cars.

site_title: In first, Indonesia to buy back some global bonds after raising US$1.84b
summary: Indonesia has raised US$1.84 billion from bond sales, with part of the proceeds to be used for repurchasing outstanding dollar bonds. The move is seen as a move to manage liquidity ahead of US tapering, a move that could impact global markets. This is Indonesia's first dollar bond buyback, a strategy used by other countries to manage risk and maintain liquidity.

site_title: 'Broadway is back': New York celebrates return of hit shows
summary: New York's Broadway celebrated the return of hit shows, including Hamilton, Wicked, and The Lion King, after an 18-month coronavirus shutdown. The resumption of performances marks a landmark moment in the city's post-pandemic recovery. All audiences are required to be vaccinated, and spectators must wear masks throughout the show. The industry and theatre lovers are delighted by the return of live performances, with officials and theatres confident that New Yorkers are eager to watch live theatre again.

site_title: Republicans withhold support for US debt ceiling increase
summary: US Republicans withhold support for a debt ceiling increase, citing a "massive reckless tax and spending spree" by Democrats. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned of a government run out of money next month unless lawmakers act. Republican Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell says Democrats must resolve the issue on their own. Democrats plan to wrap a debt ceiling increase into a $3.5 trillion spending package, but want a separate, bipartisan vote. Industry groups warn of "irreparable harm" to the US economy if the debt ceiling is not raised.

images.alt_text: The country's debt and deficit have soared during the Covid-19 pandemic after Washington approved three massive spending bills aimed at lessening the damage to the economy.

site_title: China's Foreign Minister, PM Lee 'affirm excellent state of relations'
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong met with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, reaffirming the excellent state of relations between the two countries. They discussed international and regional developments, including their cooperation amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The two leaders also welcomed the 30th anniversary of Asean-China Dialogue Relations. Wang Yi's two-day visit to Singapore concluded on Tuesday, with him also visiting Vietnam and Cambodia before heading to South Korea.

images.alt_text: Mr Wang (left) with PM Lee at The Istana on Tuesday. In a Facebook post later, Mr Lee said that they had a productive and candid discussion on international and regional developments.

site_title: US: Wall Street retreats after early boost, closing lower on Tuesday
summary: US stocks closed lower on Tuesday, reversing an early boost, as the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.8% to 34,577.57. The S&P 500 fell 0.6% to 4,443.05, and the Nasdaq Composite Index lost 0.5% to 15,037.76. The decline was attributed to "caution" over the Delta variant of Covid-19 and expectations of the Federal Reserve's stimulus removal. Despite inflation data showing a 0.3% rise in August, below forecasts, the market paused and consolidated.

site_title: Solar-powered 4x4s are totally transforming safaris
summary: Electric safari vehicles, powered by solar energy, are transforming the traditional safari experience. Companies in South Africa and Kenya are adopting eco-friendly vehicles, reducing noise pollution and carbon footprint. The vehicles, rebuilt from diesel-driven Land Rovers and Toyota Land Cruisers, offer significant benefits, including lower maintenance costs and reduced logistical needs. While the initial investment is substantial, operators are seeing significant economic advantages, with some lodges recouping their costs in as little as three years. The trend is gaining traction, with more safari outfitters expected to adopt electric vehicles in the future.

site_title: UK grocery prices up 1.3% as promotions hit record low
summary: UK grocery prices rose 1.3% year-on-year in the four weeks to Sept 5, with supermarket promotions hitting record lows, according to Kantar. Sales fell 1.9% year-on-year, but remain 8.7% higher than pre-pandemic levels. Fastest-rising prices are in savoury snacks, cat food, and ambient cakes, while falling in fresh bacon, vegetables, and cooking sauces. Only 27.5% of spending was done on deals, the lowest level recorded in 15 years.

site_title: Apple issues emergency security updates to close a critical flaw
summary: Apple has issued emergency security updates to address a critical vulnerability in its products, allowing invasive spyware from Israel's NSO Group to infect iPhones, iPads, Apple Watches, and Mac computers without user interaction. The zero-click remote exploit, known as Pegasus, can access user data, camera, and microphone, and send it to NSO's clients worldwide. The discovery affects over 1.65 billion Apple products, prompting Apple to urge customers to update their software immediately. The incident highlights the escalating cybersecurity arms race and the lucrative market for hacking tools, with governments willing to pay millions to spy on digital communications.

site_title: Dutch announce 'Covid pass', end to social distancing
summary: The Netherlands has announced plans to further ease COVID-19 restrictions, including an end to social distancing, starting September 25. The country will introduce a 'Covid pass' for bars, restaurants, and festivals, requiring proof of vaccination, recovery, or a negative test for those aged 13 and over. This decision comes as infection rates in the Netherlands have been falling, following the tightening of restrictions during a brutal second wave.

images.alt_text: The Netherlands said on Tuesday it would further ease Covid-19 restrictions including an end to social distancing, but will introduce a pass for bars, restaurants and festivals.

site_title: Temasek-backed Taiwanese startup Gogoro in merger talks with Poema SPAC: sources
summary: Gogoro, a Taiwanese startup backed by Temasek Holdings, is in talks to merge with Poema Global Holdings, a blank-cheque firm, valuing the combined company at $1 billion or more. The deal, if finalized, could see Gogoro go public. The company, known for its battery-swapping technology, has saved 300 million kilogrammes of carbon dioxide and has over 400,000 monthly subscribers. Poema, which raised $345 million in a January IPO, is seeking a company in Asia or Europe with validated technologies and attractive unit economics.

site_title: Struggles facing China's Evergrande not panicking markets - yet
summary: China's debt-crippled real estate giant Evergrande, with a US$300 billion debt load, may default on creditors, but foreign investors are not panicking the markets. Analysts expect a government-led restructuring to pay off debts while maintaining certain business activities. The exposure of foreign clients, totaling US$7 billion, is considered manageable. While the company's struggles could have repercussions beyond China, the risk of a major contagion remains low. Evergrande's collapse could create a buying opportunity for asset managers, and the Chinese government's emphasis on social and economic stability may limit the impact of a possible default.

site_title: Asean's DEFA: An engine for pandemic recovery
summary: Asean's Digital Economic Framework Agreement (DEFA) aims to standardize digital trade rules and facilitate cross-border data flows, enabling businesses to operate efficiently across partner economies. The agreement builds on Singapore's experience with digital economy agreements, with the Asia Competitiveness Institute finding that Asean-6 economies are roughly on par with external partners in terms of digital payments and AI capabilities. However, significant gaps remain, particularly in e-payment adoption among Asean members. A regional DEFA will require equitable standards, interoperable standards, and careful consideration of data privacy laws to ensure its success.

site_title: UK employee numbers exceed pre-pandemic levels
summary: UK employers added a record 241,000 staff in August, surpassing pre-pandemic levels, according to official data. The total number of employees on company payrolls is now just above the level before the COVID-19 lockdown last year. The unemployment rate fell to 4.6% in July, while businesses reported 1.034 million vacancies, the highest since 2001, with sectors like accommodation and food services experiencing a boom in demand. The government's furlough program ends on September 30, which supported around 700,000 workers.

site_title: Why state of Europe's union is stronger
summary: European Union President Ursula von der Leyen is set to deliver her annual 'state-of-the-union' address, outlining her vision for the EU post-pandemic. With the worst of the coronavirus crisis potentially over, Brussels faces a 'window of opportunity' to build back better. The EU has made significant progress, including a Brexit trade and cooperation deal with the UK and the distribution of vaccines. However, von der Leyen also warns of growing populism and the fragility of the political situation across the continent, with potential challenges including Brexit, the rise of anti-EU sentiment, and the impact of external factors such as Russia's assertiveness and the US withdrawal from international agreements.

site_title: Gig workers: CPF, injury risk expected to be in focus amid review
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower is reviewing gig worker protections, focusing on ensuring a "more balanced relationship" between platforms and workers. Key issues include strengthening CPF contributions and work injury compensation for delivery riders, private-hire car drivers, and taxi drivers. Observers expect the review to review existing legislation to provide protections akin to those for employees. The review comes as a Dutch court ruled Uber drivers are employees, not contractors, and similar developments have occurred in the UK and US.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Olam International's unit Olam Food Ingredients is set to develop a new dairy processing facility in Tokoroa, New Zealand, with the first stage expected to be completed in the third quarter of 2023. The facility will create 50-60 full-time jobs and become part of Olam's global network spanning 20 major milk consumption markets. Meanwhile, Low Keng Huat reported a 52% decline in net profit for the first half of the fiscal year due to higher costs. King Wan Corporation and Evercomm Singapore have entered into a joint venture agreement to support Singapore's Green Plan 2030.

site_title: 10 lessons from (relentlessly) owning Amazon shares for 10 years
summary: Amazon's rise from an online bookstore to a $1.8 trillion US company can be attributed to 10 key lessons learned by a shareholder since 2010. These include focusing on customer experience, embracing a relentless flywheel strategy, prioritizing customer focus, and focusing on things that remain constant despite disruption. The company's innovative culture, exemplified by its two-pizza rule and emphasis on experimentation, has led to numerous successful products and services. Despite not every venture turning into gold, Amazon's "Day 1" mentality, which emphasizes remaining curious and nimble, has driven long-term success and rewards patient investors.

site_title: Putting monetary values on beaches and coral reefs
summary: The CFA Society Singapore emphasizes the importance of assigning monetary values to natural capital, such as beaches and coral reefs, to inform policy decisions. This can strengthen the economic viability of environmental infrastructure, like mangrove forests and barrier reefs, which provide essential ecosystem services. A study by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) highlights the need for more green and blue finance to support conservation efforts, with an estimated US$700 billion needed annually to reverse biodiversity loss by 2030. ADB has launched initiatives, including blue bonds, to mobilize financial resources for biodiversity and ecosystem restoration.

site_title: Asia in the long aftermath of Afghanistan
summary: The US withdrawal from Afghanistan has led Asia to reevaluate its reliance on American power, as China's resurgence as a global rival to the US becomes more apparent. Many Asian states want Washington to act as a counterweight to Beijing, but they are also courting a powerful China in case America withdraws from its forward military presence. China's peaceful rise, lack of democratic claims, and state-driven economic initiatives, such as the Belt and Road Initiative, have eroded the US's hegemonic attractiveness. The US's limitations in staying power are highlighted by its inability to prevent the Taliban's recapture of power in Afghanistan, and China's deeper roots in Asian history and its ability to choose when and how to intervene globally.

site_title: US dollar holds as investors await inflation data
summary: The US dollar remained stable despite reaching a 2½-week high, as investors awaited inflation data to gauge the Federal Reserve's policy tightening plans. Global growth expectations have decreased, increasing the dollar's safe-haven appeal. A Bank of America survey found growth expectations at their lowest since May 2020, further boosting the dollar.

site_title: German banks look beyond lost decade as Merkel era ends
summary: Germany's banking sector, once a dominant force, has declined over the past decade under the leadership of Chancellor Angela Merkel. Her era ends this month, and the next chancellor, Olaf Scholz, faces the challenge of reviving the industry. Despite efforts to create a banking union, the project remains unfinished due to disagreements over risk management. German banks have strengthened their capital and liquidity buffers but struggle with competitiveness, with the sector seen as a "servant to the industrial sector" rather than a driving force.

site_title: As Covid curbs ease, Bali eyes tourism uptick
summary: Indonesia is easing restrictions on Bali to allow international tourists, with stricter protocols in place to curb the spread of new variants. The country has reported a significant decrease in Covid-19 cases, with 2,577 new cases on Monday, the lowest since May 16. Tourism Minister Sandiaga Uno expects vaccination rates of 70% in tourism areas before reopening, and is considering a "Phuket Sandbox" approach to Bali. Indonesia lost US$13 billion due to the ban on foreign tourism since the pandemic began, with the creative economy sector taking a US$5 billion hit.

site_title: Cutting foreign worker numbers won't save jobs for Singaporeans
summary: Finance Minister Lawrence Wong stated that reducing foreign worker numbers won't prevent Singaporeans from being displaced from jobs. He reiterated the need to stay open to foreign talent while managing their inflow and ensuring fair employment. Wong rejected the Progress Singapore Party's motion to reduce foreign manpower, citing the need for a balanced approach to address the downsides of globalization. He emphasized that the government will continually upgrade manpower policies to manage the flow and quality of work pass holders, and help displaced workers through upskilling and finding good jobs.

site_title: Malaysia to lift government debt ceiling to 65% of GDP
summary: Malaysia's Cabinet has proposed raising the government's debt ceiling to 65% of gross domestic product (GDP) to deal with economic fallout from the Covid-19 pandemic. This is the second time in two years the debt ceiling has been raised, following a 60% increase in 2020. The government also plans to boost the Covid-19 fund to RM110 billion and waive interest payments for low-income borrowers. The proposals will be tabled to Parliament in October for approval, aiming to strengthen the public health system and support businesses.

site_title: Dubious of Trump's sanity, US general secretly called China: book
summary: US Joint Chiefs Chair General Mark Milley secretly called Chinese officials to reassure Beijing in early January 2021, amid concerns about President Donald Trump's sanity and potential escalation of tensions with China. Milley ordered aides to delay any US nuclear force move and worked with the intelligence community to resist Trump's aggressive actions, according to a new book. The move aimed to prevent a war with China after Trump lost the 2020 presidential election.

images.alt_text: Joint Chiefs Chair General Mark Milley ordered aides to not act immediately on any move by Mr Trump to use US nuclear forces, and he called a Chinese general to reassure Beijing, presidential chronicler Bob Woodward and co-author Robert Costa wrote in their soon-to-be-released book.

site_title: Indonesia's SEZs set to attract 92.3t rupiah in investments in 2021
summary: Indonesia's special economic zones (SEZs) are expected to attract 92.3 trillion rupiah (S$8.7 billion) in investments by the end of 2021, with nearly 32.8 trillion rupiah already secured. As of July, 166 investors have invested in SEZs, creating over 26,700 jobs and exporting 3.66 trillion rupiah worth of goods. The Indonesian government aims to boost industrial activity and create jobs, offering tax holidays and fiscal incentives to investors.

site_title: S Korea slaps 207b-won fine on Google
summary: South Korea's antitrust regulator fined Alphabet Inc's Google 207 billion won (S$237.22 million) for blocking customized versions of its Android operating system, citing an abuse of its dominant market position. The Korea Fair Trade Commission ruled that Google's contract terms restricted competition in the mobile OS market. Google plans to appeal the ruling, stating it undermines consumer advantages. The fine, the second in less than a month, is the ninth-biggest the regulator has ever imposed, banning Google from forcing device makers to sign anti-fragmentation agreements.

site_title: Sustainable investing: An unstoppable trend
summary: Sustainable investing has surged in recent years as asset owners and investors increasingly consider environmental and social impacts. The Paris Agreement's 1.5-degree Celsius temperature goal and COVID-19's social issues have driven the trend, with $35 trillion in sustainable assets now under management. Large institutions and mutual funds are adopting Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) criteria, while individuals are investing sustainably to align with their values and manage risk. Regulatory bodies are also implementing stricter sustainability reporting requirements, creating opportunities for investors to distinguish between genuine ESG strategies and greenwashing.

site_title: US consumer price growth cools to smallest gain in seven months
summary: US consumer price growth cooled in August, with the consumer price index (CPI) rising 0.3% from July, the smallest gain in seven months. Core inflation, excluding food and energy, climbed 0.1% from the prior month, the smallest gain since February. The data suggests some of the upward pressure on inflation is waning, but tenuous supply chains could keep inflation elevated. The CPI data precedes the Federal Open Market Committee meeting, where Fed officials will debate tapering asset purchases.

site_title: German finance minister favourite to take Merkel's difficult legacy
summary: Germany's Finance Minister Olaf Scholz is now the favorite to succeed Angela Merkel as chancellor after the September 26 election, following a surprising turnaround in polls. Scholz's Social Democratic Party (SPD) is ahead in opinion polls, despite being behind the Greens and Merkel's Christian Democratic Union/Christian Social Union grouping earlier in the summer. Scholz's leadership style is being compared to that of Helmut Schmidt, but his ability to navigate the country's post-Covid and post-Merkel transition will be crucial in addressing the country's legacy of budget and economic issues, as well as energy and climate change.

site_title: How scepticism tempered with bravery helps in investment decisions
summary: A balanced approach to investing is crucial, as excessive risk aversion can lead to missed opportunities and excessive caution can result in significant losses. In Singapore, investment scam victims lost S$66.2 million in the first half of 2021, a 3x increase from the same period last year. This highlights the importance of a moderate approach to investing.

site_title: Investors watch strategies of Harvard and Yale endowments
summary: Investors are closely following the endowment strategies of Harvard and Yale universities, particularly Yale's, as they publish their latest reports. Yale's endowment, valued at $31.2 billion in 2020, returned 9.9% per annum, outperforming US stocks and bonds. Harvard's endowment, valued at $41.9 billion, underperformed the S&P 500 index, returning 4.8% per annum. Yale's strategy focuses on diversification, with a target allocation of 41% in private equity funds, 23.5% in venture capital, and 17.5% in leveraged buyouts. The endowments' performance reflects their long-term approach, with Yale's stewardship under the late David Swensen credited for its success.

site_title: OUE unit proposes to issue S$150 million 3.5% notes due 2026
summary: OUE Limited is proposing to issue S$150 million 3.5% notes due 2026 under its S$3 billion multi-currency debt issuance programme. The notes will be issued at 100% of their principal amount in denominations of S$250,000 and will mature on Sept 21, 2026. The net proceeds will be used for general working capital, corporate funding, and refinancing existing borrowings. CIMB Bank Berhad and HSBC, Singapore Branch have been appointed as joint lead managers and bookrunners for the issue.

site_title: Asean investors more focused on financial well-being following Covid-19 pandemic: survey
summary: Southeast Asian investors have become more focused on their financial well-being since the Covid-19 pandemic, with 91% of Thai investors, 88% of Indonesian investors, and 85% of Malaysian investors strongly prioritizing it. The survey of 24,000 individuals in 33 economies found that over half of these investors plan to save more once the pandemic normalizes, compared to 46% globally. Investor confidence is at its highest level since 2016, with expected annual returns averaging 11.3% and 12.8% over the next five years.

site_title: Phoney Walmart news release signals crypto pump-and-dump scheme
summary: A fake news release from GlobeNewswire, a communication services company, claimed Walmart would start accepting Litecoin as payment, causing Litecoin's value to jump 30% before being debunked by Walmart. The release, likely a pump-and-dump scheme, led to an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and raised concerns about the need for greater regulation of the cryptocurrency industry. The perpetrators are unknown, but securities lawyers say charges are likely.

site_title: Stars dazzle in defiant fashion at 'surreal' Met Gala
summary: The Met Gala, a prestigious black-tie event, returned with a splashy display of fashion, defying the ongoing pandemic. Over 400 vaccinated or Covid-tested guests, including celebrities and athletes, attended the event, largely maskless. The night featured bold outfits, including a sword-wielding Canadian musician, a glittering silver dress that required assistance to lift, and a patchwork quilt that revealed a sharp black suit underneath. The event aimed to raise funds for the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Costume Institute, which had suffered financially due to the pandemic.

site_title: New York transport body withholds death benefit from its unvaccinated workers
summary: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA) in New York will extend its $500,000 death benefit to vaccinated employees who die of Covid-related causes through the end of 2021. However, the benefit will remain unavailable to unvaccinated employees. This change comes as vaccines became widely available in April, with the authority initially reserving the benefit for vaccinated employees.

site_title: Philippines' RL Commercial Reit's IPO raises 23.5b pesos
summary: Philippines' RL Commercial REIT Inc successfully raised 23.5 billion pesos (S$632.5 million) through its initial public offering (IPO), becoming the country's largest share sale of the real estate investment trust (REIT) asset class. The company sold 3.6 billion shares at 6.45 pesos each, with its shares closing flat at 6.46 pesos. The IPO drew strong interest from institutional investors, showcasing the potential of the Philippines as a vibrant REIT market. RL Commercial's portfolio includes 425,315 square meters of office buildings and plans to add 40,000 to 100,000 square meters of gross leasable area in the next 18 months.

site_title: Malaysia, Thailand set rules for bank entry under Asean accord
summary: Malaysia and Thailand have set rules for banks to operate in each other's countries under the Asean accord. Malaysian banks can open up to 40 branches in Thailand, requiring at least 15 billion baht (S$611.5 million) in capital. Similarly, Thai banks can operate in Malaysia with prior approval. The rules aim to facilitate intra-Asean trade and investment, promoting an integrated regional economy. The designation of Qualified Asean Banks (QABs) will enable lenders to expand their networks and services in the region, boosting market access among Asean members.

site_title: A Vermeer restoration reveals a god of desire
summary: In a nearly three-century-long restoration project, a naked Cupid was uncovered in Johannes Vermeer's "Girl Reading a Letter at an Open Window" in Dresden, Germany. The discovery, led by Stephan Koja, director of the Old Masters Picture Gallery, revealed a previously hidden god of desire in the artwork. The restoration, described as a "detective story and an adventure," drastically altered the background of the quiet interior scene, shedding new light on Vermeer's masterpiece.

site_title: Trade or scrap, win either way
summary: Shipping industry experiences a surge in scrapping numbers, with 275 cargo vessels sold for scrap in the first half of 2021, a 40% increase from 2020 and 33% from 2019. High steel prices and costly new environmental regulations have driven up scrapping prices, reaching $600 per lightweight ton in June 2021, a level not seen in nearly 13 years. Despite this, many shipowners are choosing to build new ships to meet demand, with container ship owners capitalizing on high charter and sale prices.

site_title: Debunking conventional wisdom
summary: A CIO at Standard Chartered Bank debunks conventional wisdom that investing against the consensus is the best approach for generating decent returns. Instead, for investors seeking long-term, low-effort returns, following the consensus is acceptable, as equities have historically outperformed bonds 60-70% of the time. The key to success lies in diversification and capturing market "beta" returns, rather than trying to generate "alpha" through outperforming the consensus.

site_title: Mandatory climate disclosures, diversity targets: get on board or risk getting left behind
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has proposed enhancements to its sustainability reporting regime, including mandatory climate reporting and diversity targets for listed companies. The proposals aim to align with global best practices and investor expectations. Companies that fail to comply risk limiting access to financing and facing reputational damage. The SGX RegCo's diversity proposals focus on board diversity, requiring companies to consider the combination of talents and skills among directors to serve the issuer's needs. The proposals aim to improve corporate governance and governance practices, but their effectiveness depends on stakeholder engagement and education.

site_title: Boeing sees full commercial air recovery by 2024
summary: Boeing predicts the commercial aviation market will fully recover by 2024 from the pandemic slump, with a US$9 trillion aerospace market forecast for the next decade, up from US$8.5 trillion. The company expects increased orders for commercial planes and aviation services, with demand for defence and space remaining steady. Domestic travel has recovered more quickly than international travel, with 84% of domestic travel returning to 2019 levels in July, compared to only 25% of international travel. Boeing projects 32,500 new single-aisle planes and 7,500 new wide-body jets through 2040.

site_title: Promote foreign-local skills transfers by tracking outcomes, having fixed-term employment pass: Workers' Party
summary: Singapore's Workers' Party proposes five suggestions to promote foreign-local skills transfers and address job issues. These include publicly tracking skills transfers, introducing a fixed-term employment pass that requires companies to prove benefits for Singaporean workers, and setting up a parliamentary standing select committee on jobs and foreign employment. The party also calls for the government to release factual information and track underemployment.

site_title: Temasek, GIC urged to juice up Singapore bourse via SPACs: sources
summary: Singapore is planning new measures to boost its domestic stock market, with state investment giant Temasek Holdings being encouraged to facilitate the listing of tech firms in its portfolios through Special Purpose Acquisition Companies (SPACs). This move aims to increase the market presence of mid-cap firms in Singapore, with at least S$1 billion in investments expected. The goal is to enhance the country's stock market, although specific details and timelines have not been released.

site_title: Amazon to hire 125,000 more ground workers in the US
summary: Amazon plans to hire 125,000 ground workers in the US, primarily in transportation and e-commerce fulfillment roles, offering starting wages over $18/hour and a $3,000 signing bonus. The new hires will also receive health benefits and other perks. The move comes as the company expands its logistical footprint amid strong e-commerce growth during the pandemic.

site_title: Myanmar's Suu Kyi back in court after absence, still 'somewhat dizzy': lawyer
summary: Myanmar's Aung San Suu Kyi returned to court on Tuesday after a day's absence due to dizziness, stating she was "somewhat dizzy" but relieved to be present. Her lawyer attributed the dizziness to motion sickness while being driven to court. Suu Kyi, 76, is on trial over multiple charges since the February 1 military coup.

site_title: Malaysia to ease more virus curbs as pandemic fatigue worsens
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob plans to announce the easing of more virus curbs, amid growing concerns over pandemic fatigue and mental health. The government aims to provide "low-risk" concessions for the population, including allowing tourist activity, reopening gyms, and easing travel restrictions. This move comes after a surge in suicides in the first seven months of the year, with 638 reported cases, and follows Malaysia's swift vaccine rollout, which has led to over half of the population being fully vaccinated. The goal is to reopen all economic and social sectors by the end of the year.

site_title: US consumer inflation slows to 5.3% annually in August
summary: US consumer price inflation slowed to 5.3% annually in August, down from 5.5% in July, according to government data. Core CPI, excluding volatile food and energy prices, rose 0.1%, its smallest increase since February. Gasoline prices remain a key driver of inflation. This slowdown in inflation rate is a relief for policymakers, but rising core CPI indicates ongoing pressure on prices.

site_title: Philippines to test localised lockdowns in capital region
summary: The Philippines' capital region, Metro Manila, will exit wide-scale coronavirus restrictions starting Thursday, as the government launches a pilot test of localized lockdowns. The local lockdown will have five alert levels, allowing outdoor dining and indoor gatherings with restrictions. If successful, the approach could be applied nationwide to balance reopening the economy and containing the spread of the coronavirus. The move comes after a surge in cases and calls for tighter curbs to give stretched hospitals a breathing space, with 13 million people in the region fully vaccinated.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong stated that job displacement due to globalization is a reality, not a problem with foreigners, but rather about Singaporeans being displaced. The country is exploring non-mRNA vaccine boosters for its national Covid-19 vaccination program. Despite the Hungry Ghost month, condo resale prices and volumes continued to rise in August. Singapore and India plan to link real-time payment systems by 2022. A study by BNP Paribas found that brand reputation is the top reason for Singapore investors to consider ESG factors in their decision-making.

site_title: Singapore stocks end slightly higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended slightly higher on Tuesday, rising 0.2% to 3,080.37 points, driven by overnight gains on Wall Street ahead of US August inflation data. Asian markets were mixed, with the Nikkei 225 and Kospi indices also up 0.7%, while the Hang Seng Index fell 1.2%. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC closed higher, with Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) being the top advancer.

site_title: PSP's foreigner-related discourse hurts perceptions of Singapore's openness: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore's Progress Singapore Party (PSP) has sparked controversy with its foreigner-related discourse, hurting perceptions of the country's openness to free trade agreements and foreign talent. Manpower Minister Tan See Leng stated that the PSP's views have negatively impacted business and investor sentiment, contributing to Singapore's decline in the Institute for Management Development's 2021 World Competitiveness Ranking. Tan rejected the PSP's proposed levy and quotas, citing concerns that they would harm the local workforce and deter foreign investments.

site_title: Memiontec says unaware of reason for unusual stock price movements
summary: Memiontec Holdings, a water-treatment company listed on the Singapore Exchange, stated it is unaware of reasons for unusual price movements in its shares, which rose 14.1% to 53.5 cents on Tuesday, following a query from regulator SGX RegCo. The stock opened at 50 cents and briefly touched 57 cents before experiencing swings in the second half of the trading day. Memiontec confirmed its compliance with listing rules and said it was unaware of any material, price-sensitive information not previously announced that could explain the trading.

site_title: Two-week rental waiver framework passed in Parliament
summary: Singapore's Parliament has passed a two-week rental waiver framework for private commercial landlords, aiming to support small and medium enterprises and non-profit organizations during the COVID-19 pandemic. The framework requires tenants to provide evidence of a 20% drop in average monthly revenue during Phase 2 (Heightened Alert) periods. Landlords can offset any direct monetary assistance or rental waivers provided to tenants from May 16. The Ministry of Law has introduced provisions for assessors to consider exceptional circumstances and provide flexibility to tenants.

site_title: Bali tourism industry looking for uptick after Covid-19 curbs are eased
summary: Bali's tourism industry is poised for an uptick after COVID-19 restrictions were eased, with hotels and restaurants reopening and cinemas operating at 50% capacity. The island has seen a decline in cases in the past month, and vaccination rates have reached 66% of the population. Tourism Minister Sandiaga Uno is drafting plans for reopening to foreign tourists, with the possibility of implementing a "Phuket Sandbox" approach. The goal is to reach an 80-90% vaccination rate before opening to international tourists, with regional collaboration also being considered.

site_title: EU says has no option but to talk to Taleban
summary: The European Union has acknowledged it must engage with the Taliban in Afghanistan to influence events, according to EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell. Borrell stated that talking to the Taliban is necessary to have any chance of shaping the crisis, and the EU will stress the importance of human rights. The EU plans to coordinate with its governments to establish a diplomatic presence in Kabul, despite potential contradictions between human rights and the Taliban's regime.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with losses on Tuesday, dropping 1.21% as traders awaited US inflation data and concerns over Evergrande's debt and a new virus flare-up in China. The Hang Seng Index fell to 25,502.23, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined.

site_title: Global corporate issuer upgrades exceeds downgrades as pandemic troubles ease: Fitch
summary: Fitch Ratings reported that global corporate issuers have experienced more upgrades than downgrades from January to July 2021, marking the first time since 2017. The credit ratings agency attributed this improvement to issuers' resilient financial performance during the pandemic and their more conservative approach to funding. Most upgrades were not reversals of rating actions taken in 2020, with 22% of upgrades being reversals. This trend is expected to continue as the easing of pandemic-related restrictions and economic growth in many countries alleviate severe credit pressures.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Tuesday, down 14.62 points to 1,555.51, with losers outnumbering gainers 715 to 339. The index saw a decline in volume of 4.653 billion lots worth RM3.010 billion.

site_title: Olam's food ingredients unit to develop dairy processing facility in New Zealand
summary: Olam International's food ingredients unit, Olam Food Ingredients (OFI), plans to develop a new dairy processing facility in Tokoroa, New Zealand. The facility, expected to be commissioned in the third quarter of 2023, will produce high-value dairy ingredients and create 50-60 full-time jobs. The Tokoroa plant will be part of a global network spanning 20 major milk consumption markets, supporting Olam's customers and meeting growing consumer demand for natural and nutritious products.

site_title: In first, Indonesia to buy back some global bonds after raising US$1.84b
summary: Indonesia has raised $1.84 billion from bond sales, including $600 million in 10-year US dollar bonds and $625 million in 40-year euro bonds. The funds will be used to repurchase existing dollar bonds and finance a tender offer. Analysts believe the move is aimed at managing liquidity ahead of US interest rate hikes. The government's strategy may also involve reducing refinancing risks and reprofiling its debts to lower yields. This is Indonesia's first move to buy back dollar bonds and its maiden sale of euro-denominated bonds.

site_title: IMDA suspends The Online Citizen's class licence; website told to stop posting content by Sept 16
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) in Singapore has suspended the class licence of The Online Citizen (TOC) website and its social media channels due to repeated non-compliance with its legal obligation to declare all sources of funding. TOC must stop posting content by September 16, with its class licence potentially being cancelled by September 28 if it continues to breach the requirements. The suspension is aimed at preventing foreign influence in domestic politics.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.42% and the Topix index advancing 0.39%. Investors remained optimistic about a new Japanese government ahead of a ruling party leadership vote this month.

site_title: Biden to host Indo-Pacific leaders for first White House summit
summary: US President Joe Biden will host the leaders of Australia, India, and Japan at the White House for a summit on September 24, marking the first in-person meeting for the "Quad" group. The discussions will focus on countering China's influence in the Asia-Pacific region, with topics including COVID-19, climate change, and emerging technologies. The leaders aim to promote a free and open Indo-Pacific, while Chinese officials emphasize the need for regional cooperation and mutual trust. The meeting aims to strengthen US alliances and demonstrate the region's importance in US foreign policy.

site_title: Introduce fair employment compliance requirements for tenders, license HR managers: PSP
summary: The Progress Singapore Party (PSP) has proposed strengthening fair employment compliance in tenders and licensing HR managers for large employers. PSP Non-Constituency Member of Parliament (NCMP) Hazel Poa suggested imposing a duty of care on purchasing companies for large contracts and introducing licensing for HR managers to ensure compliance with manpower regulations. She questioned the government about the creation of local PMET jobs, citing a potential reclassification of foreign workers to Permanent Residents. The PSP aims to balance the benefits of foreign manpower with reduced levels and wage growth monitoring.

site_title: Universal Music Group publishes prospectus for planned 33b euro listing
summary: Universal Music Group, the world's largest music company, published a prospectus for a 33 billion euro stock market flotation, set to separate from Vivendi. The listing will see 60% of its shares distributed to Vivendi shareholders, including Vincent Bollore. Universal's shares will trade on Euronext's Amsterdam stock exchange on September 21, following a technical reference price on September 20. The music group benefits from a music industry rebound, driven by streaming revenues and sales of vinyl records and CDs.

site_title: PSP's suggestion to 'get rid of foreigners' will not stop Singaporean workers from being displaced: Lawrence Wong
summary: Finance Minister Lawrence Wong says Singaporeans being displaced from jobs due to globalization and technological advancements will not be stopped by reducing foreign workers. Despite the Progress Singapore Party's suggestion to "get rid of foreigners," Wong argues that locals will still be displaced due to these factors. He emphasizes the need for reskilling workers and protecting every worker, rather than impeding progress by holding on to every job. Wong cites the government's strategies, including median income growth and employment rate, as evidence that an open economy brings benefits, but also acknowledges the need to address the downsides of globalization.

site_title: Singapore weighing non-mRNA vaccine boosters, pauses endemic roadmap: Janil
summary: Singapore is exploring non-mRNA vaccine boosters for its national Covid-19 vaccination program, with Senior Minister of State Janil Puthucheary stating that a mix-and-match approach is being considered. The country's four-stage roadmap towards living with endemic Covid-19 has been paused due to rising case numbers, but the government remains committed to vaccination, testing, and safe-management measures. Non-mRNA vaccines are being procured from various suppliers, and the expert committee is studying issues such as booster shots for healthcare and transport workers.

site_title: PSP proposes raising EP, S-Pass qualifying salaries, introducing levies and quotas
summary: The Progress Singapore Party (PSP) has proposed increasing the qualifying salaries for Employment Pass (EP) and S-Pass holders, introducing levies and quotas, and nationality-based caps. The proposals aim to address concerns about the "quality, number, and concentration" of foreign workers in Singapore, with a focus on preventing displacement of local workers. The PSP also seeks to reduce the number of Permanent Residents (PRs) and new citizenships awarded to work pass holders.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS expects Econ Healthcare to gain from ageing population; initiates with 'buy'
summary: DBS Group Research has initiated coverage on Econ Healthcare with a "buy" call and target price of S$0.40, citing the company's potential to benefit from an ageing population and growing demand for private nursing home beds. The brokerage expects the industry to grow at a 13.6% compound annual growth rate in Singapore, 11.5% in Malaysia, and 16.6% in China from 2020 to 2024. Econ Healthcare operates nursing homes in Singapore and Malaysia and has a presence in China, with a strong occupancy rate of 95% in 2021.

site_title: Brand reputation the top reason for Singapore investors to include ESG in decision making: BNP Paribas study
summary: A BNP Paribas study found that brand reputation is the top reason for Singapore investors to incorporate environmental, social, and governance (ESG) considerations into their investment decisions, surpassing the Asia Pacific average. 76% of Singapore investors cited protecting their brand and reputation as their key ESG driver, followed by improved long-term returns and external stakeholder requirements. The study also revealed that ESG is becoming increasingly integral to Singapore institutional investors, with 42% of respondents expecting it to be central to their investment strategy in two years.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher ahead of US inflation data
summary: South Korean stocks ended higher on Tuesday, driven by foreign buying after overnight gains on Wall Street. The benchmark Kospi rose 0.67% to 3,148.83, extending its third consecutive gain. Chip giants Samsung and SK Hynix led the gains, while platform companies Naver and Kakao fell. The won strengthened and the benchmark bond yield rose ahead of US August inflation data due later in the day.

site_title: Taleban deny their deputy premier is dead
summary: The Taliban have denied rumors that Abdul Ghani Baradar, their deputy premier, was killed in a shootout with rivals. Baradar, who was named deputy prime minister last week, released a voice message on Twitter stating that the claims are "lies and totally baseless." The denial comes after internal splits within the Taliban movement were reported nearly a month after their victory over the Western-backed government in Kabul.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on hopes for new government
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Tuesday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index reaching a 31-year high, driven by progress in Japan's vaccine drive and hopes for economic stimulus under a new government. The Nikkei 225 index ended up 0.73% or 222.73 points at 30,670.10, while the Topix index gained 1.01% or 21.16 points to close at 2,118.87. The gains were seen as encouraging investors, despite ongoing concerns over US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Popular Netflix series sparks new debate over South Korea's military conscription
summary: A Netflix series, "DP," is reigniting a debate in South Korea over its military conscription system, which has been criticized for its history of abuse scandals and harsh treatment of conscripts. The show, which follows military police assigned to capture deserters, has sparked a heated debate over the country's mandatory conscription, with some former conscripts sharing their traumatic experiences and others calling for an end to the system. The military has responded by announcing plans to eliminate the system of rank-and-file soldiers tracking down AWOL comrades, with the change set to take effect in July 2022.

site_title: Indonesia's central bank pledges to keep rates low ahead of policy meet
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, has pledged to keep interest rates low until signs of rising price pressures appear, supporting the country's economic recovery. The bank's senior deputy governor, Destry Damayanti, made the statement during a parliamentary commission. Indonesia's inflation rate in August was 1.59%, below the central bank's target range of 2-4%. The next monetary policy review is scheduled for September 20-21.

site_title: Singapore, India to link real-time payment systems PayNow and UPI by 2022
summary: Singapore and India plan to link their real-time payment systems, PayNow and Unified Payments Interface (UPI), by July 2022, enabling instant and low-cost fund transfers between the two countries. The linkage is expected to increase remittance volumes, reduce costs, and enhance financial inclusion, aligning with G-20's financial inclusion priorities. This is the latest step in cross-border payment infrastructure development, following the recent linkage with Thailand's PromptPay, and is expected to benefit individuals and businesses reliant on remittances between the two countries.

site_title: British American Tobacco made dubious payments to Africa : watchdog
summary: British American Tobacco (BAT) is accused of making hundreds of "questionable payments" in 10 African countries between 2008 and 2013 to influence health policies and sabotage competitors. The watchdog STOP claims the company doled out over $600,000 in cash, cars, and campaign donations to dozens of politicians and staff at rival companies. BAT denies the allegations, but evidence from whistleblower testimonies and court records suggests a widespread pattern of corrupt practices.

images.alt_text: Tobacco giant British American Tobacco (BAT) allegedly made hundreds of "questionable payments" in 10 African countries over five years to influence health policies and sabotage competitors, a watchdog claimed Tuesday.

site_title: Some 77% of 103,000 workers to earn at least S$1,400 with new Local Qualifying Salary rules
summary: The Singapore government will require firms hiring foreigners to pay a Local Qualifying Salary (LQS) of S$1,400 to all local employees starting September 2022. This affects 77% of 103,000 lower-wage workers, who will see their wages rise to at least S$1,400. The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) will focus on implementing the new rules and sectoral occupational progressive wages to establish wage benchmarks, aiming to raise wages of lower-wage workers beyond the LQS.

site_title: Thailand, Malaysia set rules for banks entry under Asean accord
summary: Thailand and Malaysia have set rules for banks to enter each other's markets under the Asean accord. Malaysian banks seeking to operate in Thailand can open up to 40 branches and have at least 15 billion baht (S$611.5 million) in capital. Similarly, Thai banks can operate in Malaysia with approved applications. The designation of Qualified Asean Banks (QABs) aims to boost intra-regional trade and investment, facilitating an integrated economy. Both countries have already launched QR code payment linkages to enable instant financial transactions.

site_title: Reserve Bank of Australia optimistic on economy, but rates to stay low until 2024
summary: Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe expressed optimism about the economy, despite coronavirus lockdowns expected to cause a sharp contraction in the September quarter. The economy is expected to rebound in the December quarter, with wages growth needed to sustainably return to the 2-3% inflation target band by 2024. Lowe criticized market pricing for rate hikes in 2022 and 2023, citing the country's unique wage and inflation experience. The economy is forecast to contract by at least 2% and unemployment to reach "high fives" before recovering in the December quarter.

site_title: MOM to set up advisory committee on gig worker protection
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Manpower will convene an advisory committee to strengthen protections for platform workers, including delivery riders, private-hire car drivers, and taxi drivers. The committee will focus on ensuring a "more balanced relationship" between platforms and workers, addressing concerns over modest incomes, lack of job protections, and health risks. This move tracks developments in other countries regulating the gig economy, following recent court rulings in the Netherlands and the UK that classified Uber drivers as employees.

images.alt_text: The Ministry of Manpower will convene an advisory committee to look into strengthening protections for platform workers, namely delivery riders, private-hire car drivers and taxi drivers.

site_title: Temasek-backed Taiwanese startup Gogoro in merger talks with Poema SPAC: sources
summary: Gogoro, a Taiwanese battery-swapping technology startup, is in merger talks with Poema Global Holdings Corp, a US$1 billion or more blank-cheque firm. The deal aims to value the combined company. Gogoro, backed by Temasek Holdings and other investors, has seen 400,000 monthly subscribers and 200 million battery swaps. The proposed merger could introduce a better electric refuelling system, reducing consumer anxiety and carbon footprint. An announcement is expected soon, pending final terms.

site_title: US and India in talks over timeline for restarting Covid-19 vaccine exports
summary: The US is in talks with India to discuss the timeline for restarting Covid-19 vaccine exports. The Biden administration has been in close communication with India, a key vaccine producer, to address the global vaccine supply bottleneck. The talks come ahead of the US-India Quad summit on September 24, where the pandemic will be a key topic. The US has diverted raw materials to India for vaccine production and commended the country's contributions to global vaccine supply. Discussions are ongoing to ensure the necessary actions are taken to end the pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares begin with gains
summary: Hong Kong shares began Tuesday with gains, following a positive lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.05% to 25,826.86, while the Shanghai Composite slipped 0.13% to 3,710.64. The Shenzhen Composite Index edged up 0.20 point to 2,501.03. This marks a rebound from the previous day's sell-off.

site_title: Europe: Luxury, mining stocks slip ahead of US inflation data
summary: European stocks slipped 0.2% on Tuesday ahead of US inflation data, with luxury and mining shares falling 1.6-2% and 0.3% respectively. Despite a 3.7% gain for jewellery maker Pandora, mining stocks dragged the FTSE 100 lower. Data showed a record 241,000 staff additions to British payrolls, but Danish brewer Carlsberg fell 2.6% after a double downgrade to "sell". The Stoxx 600 index partially recovered from last week's slump, but remains down for the week.

site_title: Gold eases as investors eye US inflation data
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,790.74 per ounce ahead of US inflation data, as a stronger dollar made gold more expensive for holders of other currencies. The dollar index hit a two-week high, while US consumer price data is expected to show a 0.3% rise in core CPI in August. Expectations of future inflation have risen to the highest levels since 2013, prompting the European Central Bank to prepare for potential action if inflation in the euro area does not ease.

site_title: Singapore business sentiment improves further in Q4: SCCB
summary: Singapore's business sentiment improved further in Q4 2021, with a Business Optimism Index (BOI) of +5.78 percentage points, up from +4.07 percentage points in the previous quarter. The manufacturing and financial services sectors saw the most improvement, with all six indicators in positive territory for both. However, the construction and transportation sectors were downbeat, with significant downside risks remaining due to lingering domestic and global uncertainties, including the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic and regulatory developments in China.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel DC Reit, SGX, Sri Trang Gloves
summary: Keppel DC Reit secured two six-year revolving credit facilities totaling approximately $130 million. Singapore Exchange (SGX) is seeking shareholder approval for a scrip dividend scheme, which will allow shareholders to acquire new equity without brokerage fees. Sri Trang Gloves commissioned a new facility worth $65.3 million in Thailand to meet increasing global demand for gloves, enabling the production of three billion gloves annually.

site_title: Australia business conditions show promising improvement in August: survey
summary: Australia's business conditions showed a promising improvement in August, with a 4-point rise to +14 in the National Australia Bank survey. The conditions index recovered from a 14-point drop in July, and confidence edged up 2 points to -5. Businesses fared well, with sales and profits rebounding, and the conditions index remaining above the long-run average. The Reserve Bank of Australia expects the economy to recover quickly once lockdowns ease, and a separate survey showed a 10.6% jump in consumer confidence in New South Wales.

site_title: Buyers unfazed by Hungry Ghost month as condo resale volumes, prices rise
summary: Singapore resale condominium prices and volumes rose in August, defying expectations of a slowdown during Hungry Ghost month. Resale prices increased 0.5% month-on-month and 7.9% year-on-year, with suburban areas seeing the highest growth. Estimated resale volumes reached 1,860 units, 40.5% higher than the previous year, with demand driven by the need for space and support from the HDB resale market. The median capital gain stood at S$193,000, with District 20 posting the highest median gain at S$375,912.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 2.12 points, or 0.14%, lower at 1,568.01 on Tuesday, with 187.33 million lots traded worth RM101.14 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 198 to 166.

site_title: Grab posts higher revenue but wider losses in Q2, faces speedbumps
summary: Grab reported a net loss of $815 million for Q2, exceeding the $718 million loss in the same period last year, despite revenue rising to $180 million. The company cut its full-year forecast, citing uncertainty due to lockdowns in South-east Asia and potential regulations for gig workers. Grab's cash and cash equivalents rose to $5.3 billion, but total outstanding debt was $2.1 billion. Analysts say Grab needs to invest in emerging technologies and improve user experience to differentiate itself from competitors, while also addressing potential regulations for gig workers.

site_title: Asia: Markets struggle for traction ahead of US inflation data
summary: Asian markets struggled to gain traction on Tuesday ahead of US inflation data, which could influence the Federal Reserve's monetary policy. Tokyo was on track for its highest finish in over 30 years due to hopes for fresh stimulus, while China's tech sector tightened under a regulatory crackdown. European stocks also fell, with bank and healthcare shares weighing down the market. US stocks edged down from records despite a strong S&P 500 and Nasdaq performance. The uncertainty surrounding US-EU tariffs also added to market volatility.

site_title: China tea chain Heytea taps UBS for US$500 million Hong Kong IPO
summary: Heytea, a Chinese teahouse chain, has tapped UBS Group AG for a potential Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) as early as next year, with plans to raise at least US$500 million. The company, famous for its cheese-foam teas, is considering an IPO following Nayuki Holdings Ltd's successful US$654 million share sale in June. Heytea's valuation is over 60 billion yuan (S$12.48 billion) after its latest funding round, with backers including IDG Capital and Sequoia Capital China. Details of the IPO remain preliminary, with other banks potentially added to the lineup.

site_title: US, EU pursuing global deal to slash planet-warming methane emissions: documents
summary: The US and EU are jointly pushing for a global deal to cut methane emissions by nearly a third by 2030, in an effort to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius. The methane pledge, to be launched this week, targets over two dozen countries, including major emitters China, Russia, and Saudi Arabia, with the aim of reducing human-caused emissions by 30% from 2020 levels. The move comes ahead of the COP26 climate change summit in November, where countries will discuss solutions to mitigate climate change.

site_title: Stop funding coal overseas, NGO group tells top investor Bank of China
summary: Bank of China, a top investor in coal power plants, is urged by 35 NGOs to end overseas coal financing and support renewable energy instead. The letter, signed by groups from 13 countries, criticizes China's Belt and Road Initiative for financing coal-fired power stations abroad. Bank of China has financed over $35 billion in coal projects since 2015, contradicting China's climate change ambitions. The NGOs, including Market Forces, call for the bank to follow other financial institutions that have restricted fossil fuel investments, with dozens of coal-fired power plants dependent on the bank's support.

site_title: Embattled China Evergrande warns of cross-default, liquidity crunch
summary: China Evergrande Group warned of a risk of cross-default due to a liquidity crunch, as property sales continue to plummet. The developer has been struggling to raise funds to pay its lenders and suppliers. Two of its subsidiaries failed to discharge guarantee obligations for 934 million yuan worth of wealth management products. Regulators and financial markets are concerned that any crisis could ripple through China's banking system, intensifying pressure on the embattled company.

site_title: Cyber arms dealer exploits new iPhone software vulnerability, affecting most versions, say researchers
summary: A cyber surveillance company, NSO Group, developed a tool to exploit a previously unknown vulnerability in Apple iPhones, affecting all versions except the latest update. The vulnerability allows attackers to break into devices without user interaction, and can be used to target specific individuals. Apple confirmed the vulnerability and released a fix in the latest software update. The discovery highlights the critical nature of device security and the need for constant protection against sophisticated attacks, with experts warning of a growing threat landscape.

site_title: Malaysia plans to lift government debt ceiling to 65% of GDP
summary: Malaysia's cabinet has proposed raising the government's statutory debt ceiling to 65% of gross domestic product to address the economic fallout of the Covid-19 pandemic. This is the second increase in two years, following a 60% increase in 2020. The government also plans to boost the size of its Covid-19 fund to RM110 billion from RM65 billion. The moves aim to support the country's economic recovery and mitigate the impact of the pandemic.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at open, tracking Wall Street rebound; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% to 3,085.35, driven by a Wall Street rebound. Banking stocks led gains, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC up 0.1%, 0.6%, and 0.3% respectively. The STI was also influenced by gains in Ascendas Reit and the Singapore Exchange. The bourse operator is seeking approval for a new share issuance scheme. This follows a rebound in US stocks, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 gaining 0.8% and 0.2% respectively.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) plans to issue new shares under a scrip dividend scheme at its annual general meeting on Oct 7, allowing eligible shareholders to acquire equity without brokerage fees. Prime US Reit's manager is in talks with WeWork to resolve the latter's lease obligations at a California office property. Sri Trang Gloves has commissioned a new facility in Thailand worth 1.6 billion baht to meet global demand for latex and nitrile gloves.

site_title: Private securities marketplace Forge Global to go public via US$2b SPAC deal; Temasek among investors
summary: Forge Global, a private securities marketplace, will go public through a US$2 billion merger with Motive Capital Corp. The deal includes funding from Temasek, ION Group, and Adit Ventures. Forge's platform has 400,000 users and traded over US$10 billion in private company shares. The merger is expected to close in the fourth quarter of 2021 or first quarter of 2022, providing gross proceeds of US$532.5 million to the combined company.

site_title: Facebook shields VIPs from some of its rules: report
summary: Facebook shields high-profile users from some of its own rules as part of a quality-control program called "XCheck." The program, which affects around 5.8 million users, allows certain celebrities, politicians, and other elite users to post content without being held to the same standards as others. This has raised concerns about a double standard in content moderation, contradicting Facebook's assurances to an independent board set up to oversee disputes. Facebook defends the program as an attempt to prevent mistakes, but critics argue it undermines trust in the platform.

site_title: UK readies infrastructure plan to boost labour market
summary: The UK government has launched a £200 billion infrastructure plan to boost the pandemic-hit labour market. The plan aims to support 425,000 jobs annually over the next four years, with funding from both public and private sectors. The initiative is part of a broader effort to revitalize the economy, following the UK's second consecutive month of economic contraction.

site_title: Heavy industry must be decarbonised to reach emission goals
summary: Heavy industry, accounting for 40% of global CO2 emissions, must undergo radical innovation to decarbonize. Companies like Solugen, H2 Green Steel, and Boston Metal are developing solutions to reduce carbon emissions from steel, chemicals, and cement production. Investments in these startups, such as Solugen's $350 million Series C funding, signal a shift towards green industry leaders. However, significant funding and innovation are still needed to meet the growing demand for steel, cement, and chemicals, with the global market size expected to reach $5.7 trillion by 2025.

site_title: Rolls-Royce, Babcock sell air-refuelling stakes for £315 million
summary: Rolls-Royce Holdings and Babcock International Group sold their combined 39% stake in AirTanker Holdings for £315 million, with Equitix Investment Management purchasing Rolls-Royce's 23.1% and Babcock's 15.4%. The sale aims to shore up depleted balance sheets, with both companies focusing on core operations. The deal is conditional on regulatory approvals and expected to complete by the end of 2021, with the majority of the business remaining under Airbus SE and Thales SA control.

site_title: UK to vaccinate over 12s against Covid-19
summary: The UK has announced plans to vaccinate all children aged 12-15 against Covid-19, following the advice of four top medical officers. This move comes as the country struggles with stubbornly high case rates due to the Delta variant, despite a successful vaccination programme. The decision aims to protect the young population and prevent further rises in cases now that schools have reopened.

site_title: Litecoin spikes briefly on bogus announcement
summary: Litecoin's price surged around 30% on Monday after a fake press release claiming Walmart had agreed to a partnership with the cryptocurrency. The digital currency briefly reached $230 before reversing to around $179 after the hoax was exposed. A Walmart spokesman confirmed the information was false, and the Litecoin Foundation also denied any partnership. GlobalNewswire, the platform that published the fake news, did not respond to a request for comment. The fake announcement caused significant market volatility, but ultimately, the price correction was swift and decisive.

site_title: Australian home prices jump record 6.7% in Q2
summary: Australian home prices surged a record 6.7% in the June quarter, driven by low borrowing costs and strong demand for work-at-home properties. Prices rose 16.8% compared to the same quarter last year, with major cities like Canberra (8.2%), Sydney (8.1%), and Melbourne (6.1%) leading the gains. The total value of residential dwellings increased by A$596.4 billion, reaching A$8.9 trillion.

images.alt_text: Prices for Australian residential properties in the major cities climbed a record 6.7 per cent in the June quarter versus the previous quarter amid super-low borrowing costs and strong demand for work-at-home property.

site_title: China 'should curb tech monopolies to ensure growth'
summary: China's central bank adviser, Cai Fang, suggests that the country should curb tech monopolies to ensure growth, citing the "winner takes all" dynamic that increases inequality and slows economic growth. He argues that anti-monopoly regulation will increase productivity and help long-term growth, as China transitions from investment-driven growth to productivity gains. Cai calls for government action to increase competition and prevent monopolies, rather than relying on markets, and emphasizes the need for a social security system to protect consumer rights.

site_title: Canada's Trudeau sought an election he risks losing with only a week to go
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has called a snap election with just a week to go, despite low public support and opposition from his own party. Trudeau hopes to capitalize on his government's pandemic response, but his Liberals are trailing the Conservatives in polls. Trudeau's campaign has been marred by low energy, fatigue, and ethics scandals, including a recent accusation of lying to the public. With only a 38% public support needed for a majority, Trudeau's chances of winning are uncertain, and he risks losing to the Conservatives led by Erin O'Toole.

site_title: Shang-Chi triumphs again at US box office as Malignant misfires
summary: Marvel's Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings dominated the US box office for the second consecutive weekend, earning $35.8 million. This marks a 53% decline in ticket sales from its debut, comparable to many Marvel films in pre-pandemic times. In contrast, Black Widow plummeted 70% in its sophomore outing. Meanwhile, Disney's Malignant, a horror film, underperformed, debuting with $5.57 million from 3,485 locations, despite a solid track record from director James Wan.

site_title: Oil rises to six-week high as US supply concerns dominate
summary: Oil prices rose to a six-week high, with Brent futures reaching $73.51 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude reaching $70.45 a barrel. The increase was driven by concerns over US supply, following Hurricane Ida's impact on the Gulf Coast two weeks ago, and potential disruptions in Texas. Despite OPEC's trimmed forecast for world oil demand due to the Delta variant, prices rose due to supply worries.

site_title: Biden to host India, Japan, Australia leaders on Sept 24: White House
summary: US President Joe Biden will host the prime ministers of India, Japan, and Australia on September 24 for an in-person summit, marking the first-ever White House gathering of the "Quad" grouping. The summit aims to deepen ties and cooperation on Covid-19, climate change, emerging technologies, and cyberspace. India's Narendra Modi, Japan's Yoshihide Suga, and Australia's Scott Morrison will attend, with discussions expected to include the situation in Afghanistan and a united front before a G-20 meeting in October. The Quad grouping seeks to counterbalance China's growing influence in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Evergrande haircut of 75% now a base case for bond analysts
summary: Evergrande Group, a Chinese developer with over $300 billion in liabilities, may undergo a debt restructuring amid distressed-level bond prices. Analysts predict a government-supervised deal ensuring the delivery of homes and payment to suppliers, with dollar debt investors recovering 25% of their funds. Other scenarios include a partial takeover by a state-owned enterprise, sale of listed assets, or a nightmare liquidation scenario where bondholders may get close to nothing, posing a threat to China's financial system. Regulators have signed off on a proposal to renegotiate payment deadlines with banks and other creditors.

site_title: Are we willing to pay for ecosystem services provided by others?
summary: Singapore residents are willing to pay for ecosystem services, including clean air, with a willingness-to-pay (WTP) of around 1% of their annual income. Studies suggest that a national WTP for reduced land burning lies between S$400 million and S$700 million, similar to the estimated losses during the 2015 haze episode. A transboundary public response to protect South-east Asia's forests and peatlands could be more effective, with PES potentially supporting sustainable supply chains, fire mitigation strategies, and green finance investments.

site_title: Sydney Airport sale a step closer after improved A$23.6b offer
summary: Sydney Airport's sale is moving forward after a consortium of infrastructure investors, Sydney Aviation Alliance, improved its takeover offer to A$23.6 billion, a 3.6% increase from its previous proposal. The bid has won the airport's board permission to conduct due diligence, and analysts predict a high probability of a deal succeeding due to the board's commitment to recommending the offer. The deal would be a long-term bet on the travel sector, which is expected to recover once Australia opens its borders and 80% of adults are fully vaccinated.

site_title: US: Wall Street bounces back as key data loom
summary: US stocks rebounded after a negative week, closing higher as investors await key economic data and a Federal Reserve meeting. Markets have been volatile due to signs of slowing recovery, rising inflation, and COVID-19 infection rates. Investors are also monitoring debates in Congress, including a proposed corporate tax rate increase. Despite US-EU tariff threats, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records, and investors await the outcome of the Fed meeting.

site_title: Goldman Sachs loses top South-east Asia banker to Citi
summary: Goldman Sachs has lost its top South-east Asia banker, Harry Naysmith, to Citigroup, where he will take on a top role as vice-chairman of banking, capital markets and advisory. Naysmith's departure follows a tumultuous period for Goldman, which had to pay a record foreign bribery penalty in the US over its involvement in the 1MDB investment fund scandal. Goldman is trying to bolster its presence in the region, where its revenue lags behind other markets, and has added to its headcount in Singapore.

site_title: With economies on the brink, South-east Asia chooses to reopen
summary: South-east Asia, struggling with one of the world's worst Covid-19 outbreaks, is reopening its economies despite low vaccination rates and the risk of the Delta variant. Nations such as Vietnam, Malaysia, and Singapore are implementing experiments to balance containing the virus with keeping people and money moving. The region's low vaccination rates and dwindling monetary policy firepower have made lockdowns less tenable, leading to a shift towards treating Covid-19 as endemic.
