summary: US private equity firm Carlyle is reviving plans to sell Netherlands-based lingerie chain Hunkemoller, which operates 850 stores across Europe, in a deal potentially worth over $1.58 billion. The sale was delayed due to the pandemic, but sales and earnings are expected to rebound strongly this year, driven by the chain's hybrid model and increasing online sales. Hunkemoller reported earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) of 40.6 million euros in the year ended January 31.

site_title: PCF Sparkletots centre in Serangoon closed till Sept 21 after Covid-19 cluster emerges
summary: A PCF Sparkletots centre in Serangoon, Singapore, has been closed until September 21 after a Covid-19 cluster emerged. The centre underwent deep cleaning and disinfection before the closure. After further cleaning, it is expected to reopen on September 21, barring further developments.

site_title: CBD offices filling back up, but hybrid work may be here to stay
summary: Singapore's central business district is showing signs of life as companies return to work after easing work-from-home regulations. Many companies, such as HSBC and OCBC, are adopting hybrid working arrangements, allowing employees to split their time between working from home and in-office. However, some companies, like Dasin Retail Trust, are only allowing fully vaccinated employees back into the office. The government's Vaccinate or Regular Test (VoRT) regime and vaccination rates are key considerations for companies as they weigh their back-to-the-office strategies, with 81% of the population having completed both doses of Covid-19 vaccines.

images.alt_text: Since the easing of work-from-home rules from Aug 19, a majority of companies BT spoke to said they were implementing split team or staggered arrangements.

site_title: Visits to residential care homes to be suspended from Sept 13 to Oct 11: MOH
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health has announced that all in-person visits to residential care homes will be suspended from September 13 to October 11 to reduce the spread of Covid-19. The suspension aims to encourage unvaccinated seniors to get vaccinated and roll out a vaccine booster program. The ministry will also strengthen testing for staff and residents, using Antigen Rapid Tests more frequently.

site_title: Food-delivery apps sue New York City over fee limits
summary: Three major food-delivery platforms, Grubhub, DoorDash, and Uber Eats, have filed a lawsuit against New York City, seeking to overturn a cap on fees charged by the companies. The cap, set at 15% for online orders and 5% per order for other fees, was implemented to help restaurants survive during the pandemic. The companies claim the cap is unconstitutional and interferes with their contracts with restaurants, while the city argues it brings fairness to the industry and protects consumers and workers.

site_title: El Salvador's bitcoin digital wallet beset by technical glitches
summary: El Salvador's bitcoin digital wallet Chivo has faced technical glitches for a fourth consecutive day, causing problems with accessing the wallet, withdrawing money from ATMs, and data verification. Users have reported issues with the app, including being unable to log in and recognize their pin or face ID. President Nayib Bukele's administration had promised a US$30 bonus to all Chivo users, but the government has yet to deposit the funds. The glitches have raised concerns about the adoption of bitcoin as a payment method in El Salvador.

site_title: Stripe is discussing public listing for 2022 with bankers
summary: Stripe Inc, a digital payments company valued at nearly $100 billion, is in early discussions with investment bankers about a potential public listing as early as 2022. The 11-year-old company is considering a direct listing or initial public offering, which would be one of the biggest private companies to ever go public. If successful, Stripe would be the latest in a growing list of companies to go the less conventional route pioneered by Spotify in 2018. The company's investors include prominent firms such as Allianz and Sequoia Capital.

site_title: Designer Michael Kors holds first live fashion show since pandemic
summary: Designer Michael Kors held his first live fashion show since the pandemic at New York City's Tavern on the Green in Central Park, showcasing a collection that celebrates romance and everyday moments. The show featured models including Gigi Hadid and Kendall Jenner, and Broadway star Ariana DeBose performed live. The event followed strict COVID-19 protocols, with guests required to be double vaccinated and staff and crew undergoing on-site testing. Kors described the show as "intimate" and "thrilling," marking a return to live fashion after a prolonged hiatus.

site_title: Fifa backs down on threat to fine Premier League clubs who field South American players
summary: Fifa has waived its threat to fine Premier League clubs for fielding South American players due to travel restrictions. The four countries - Brazil, Chile, Mexico, and Paraguay - agreed to waive the five-day travel restriction period, allowing players to compete without sanctions. This deal comes after extensive talks between Fifa, the English FA, and the Premier League to find a solution with the UK government over red-list quarantine restrictions. The waiver will allow players to participate in this weekend's games, resolving a potential issue that had sparked concern over potential sanctions.

site_title: CDL sells Sincere stake for US$1; raises stake in Shenzhen tech park
summary: CDL sells its 63.75% stake in HCP Chongqing Property Development (HCP Cayman), which holds an 80.01% equity interest in Sincere Property Group, for US$1. The sale is part of CDL's efforts to reduce its exposure to Sincere, which has faced liquidity issues and potential bankruptcy. The transaction also involves CDL increasing its stake in Shenzhen Longgang Tusincere Tech Park, a technology park in Shenzhen, China.

site_title: Twitch sues unnamed pair linked to 'hate raids'
summary: Twitch is suing two users, identified as a Netherlands resident and a Vienna resident, for orchestrating "hate raids" targeting video game streamers from marginalized groups. The pair allegedly used bots to flood chat with racist, sexist, and homophobic language, with Twitch suspending and banning offending accounts but allowing them to create new ones to continue the attacks. Twitch is seeking unspecified cash damages and will amend the complaint with the culprits' real names once identified.

images.alt_text: Twitch is suing two users in US federal court, accusing them of orchestrating 'hate raids' spewing abuse at video game play streamers who are not white or straight.

site_title: Indonesia ends deforestation pact with Norway, citing non-payment
summary: Indonesia has terminated its pact with Norway on reducing carbon emissions from deforestation due to non-payment. The agreement, which included a $56 million contribution from Norway, was aimed at curbing greenhouse gas emissions. Indonesia met its commitment to cut 11.2 million tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions in the 2016-2017 period, but the Norwegian International Climate and Forest Initiative stated that discussions on payments were "constructive and progressing well." The decision will not affect Indonesia's commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: Disney to debut rest of 2021 films exclusively in theatres
summary: Disney will release the remaining 2021 films exclusively in theaters before sending them to streaming, a move indicating confidence in moviegoing's recovery. Films like "Eternals," "West Side Story," and "Encanto" will debut in theaters for at least 45 days before streaming. This strategy follows Disney's experiment with simultaneous releases during the pandemic. The company's decision aims to boost box office sales, which remain below pre-pandemic levels, as theater chains rely on big fall and winter titles to attract customers.

site_title: Insurance via bite-sized premiums: tasty appetiser, but not a full meal
summary: Singapore's microinsurance market has gained traction, with NTUC Income and Prudential offering bite-sized premium options for low-income individuals. These plans, such as NTUC Income's Snack and Prudential's Pulse, allow users to gradually accumulate coverage through daily activities, with premiums ranging from 30-70 Singapore cents. While convenient and accessible, microinsurance may not be sufficient for those with immediate protection gaps or dependents, and users should consider traditional insurance options to supplement their coverage. Experts advise customers to assess their specific protection needs and mix and match traditional and microinsurance plans.

images.alt_text: From left: DBS's head of financial planning literacy Lorna Tan says microinsurance lowers barriers of entry; UOB's head of group personal financial services Jacquelyn Tan says one should complement it with more holistic coverage; and NTUC Income's chief digital officer Peter Tay says there are products which give customers flexibility to upsize and downsize their coverage using a digital dashboard.

site_title: Oil rallies to US$73 on tight US supplies, Biden-Xi call
summary: Oil prices surged to a session high of nearly US$73 a barrel on Friday, driven by tight US supplies due to Hurricane Ida and rising demand hopes. US crude rose 2.3% to US$69.72, while Brent crude rose 2.3% to US$72.92. A call between US President Joe Biden and Chinese leader Xi Jinping also boosted oil markets. The US added rigs in the latest week, suggesting production may rise in coming weeks, and Opec is expected to revise down its 2022 oil demand forecast.

site_title: 20 years after 9/11, fight against terrorism is far from over
summary: Twenty years after the 9/11 attacks, the fight against terrorism remains far from over. Extremist terrorism has metastasized, with digital media amplifying its poison. Al-Qaeda was succeeded by ISIS, which continues to operate online, while lone-wolf attackers self-radicalize on the internet. Singapore, which successfully navigated the aftermath of 9/11, remains a prime target, with terrorists planning attacks on the country. The country's racial harmony is still work in progress, and eternal vigilance is necessary to maintain security and unity.

site_title: Toyota will again slash production of vehicles
summary: Toyota plans to produce 40% fewer cars and trucks globally in October due to chip shortages and COVID-19 restrictions in South-east Asia. This is the second consecutive month of production cuts, and the company now expects to produce 330,000 fewer vehicles in October, with North American operations likely to be reduced by 60,000 to 80,000 vehicles. Toyota's global output in September fell 70,000 vehicles short of its previous targets, and the company now expects to produce 9 million cars and trucks for the fiscal year ending March 31, down from an earlier estimate of 9.3 million.

site_title: Bank of America revamps leadership, but CEO plans to stick around
summary: Bank of America has made significant leadership changes, promoting Alastair Borthwick to CFO, Dean Athanasia to consumer-banking division head, and Lauren Mogensen to general counsel. The moves are seen as a sign that CEO Brian Moynihan, 61, plans to remain at the helm for years to come, despite being groomed for succession. Moynihan has stated his intention to stick with the bank's growth strategy, which he implemented in 2010, for its second decade. Analysts praise the changes, but note that the "number of chefs in the kitchen" could create issues, as Moynihan's planned long tenure as CEO.

site_title: Epic ruling invites future efforts to paint Apple as monopolist: experts
summary: A US judge stopped short of labeling Apple an "illegal monopolist," but ruled that the company's rules on its App Store business violated California state competition laws. The ruling, in a closely-watched antitrust case brought by Epic Games, found that Apple enjoys considerable market share and high profit margins, but did not demonstrate unlawful monopoly power. Experts say the decision provides a roadmap for future claims against Apple, with some predicting that the company could be accused of abusing monopoly power in the future.

site_title: Australia's Queensland state warns of possible Covid-19 lockdown
summary: Queensland, Australia's third most populous state, may order a snap lockdown due to a cluster of Covid-19 cases. Five new infections were detected after a family tested positive in Brisbane. The state's Premier, Annastacia Palaszczuk, stated that the situation is currently contained but warned that if seeding occurs, a lockdown would be necessary. This comes as Australia reports a record one-day rise in daily infections, with the country's total cases nearing 73,000. A lockdown in Queensland would be another blow to Australia's economy, which is already at risk of a second recession.

site_title: Fit to heal: Sports surgeon Alan Cheung's take
summary: Orthopaedic surgeon Alan Cheung, a consultant at Mount Elizabeth Novena Hospital, emphasizes the importance of understanding an athlete's struggles and sport to treat them properly. Cheung, a martial arts enthusiast, draws parallels between his experiences in sports and surgery, citing improved physical and mental strength, discipline, and concentration. As a team doctor for various sports organizations, including the Singapore Cycling Federation and Wrestling Federation of Singapore, Cheung applies his knowledge to assess and treat injured athletes, ultimately aiming to help them "fit to lead" in their respective sports.

site_title: UPS adds gig delivery with Roadie acquisition
summary: UPS has announced plans to acquire Roadie, a crowd-sourced same-day delivery company, in a deal expected to close in the fourth quarter. The acquisition will add new UPS services just in time for the peak holiday shipping season. Roadie will continue to operate with its existing name and goods transported by Roadie will not cross into the UPS network, while packages transported by UPS will not cross into the Roadie network. The deal comes as key UPS retail customers have built or bought gig delivery services to provide speedy local delivery of items.

site_title: Hong Kong plans to limit retail investor access to SPACs
summary: Hong Kong plans to limit retail investor access to SPACs, allowing only professional investors with assets of over HK$8 million (S$1.4 million) to participate in both primary and secondary markets. This move comes as regulators prepare to roll out a framework this month. The proposal aims to curb speculative trading in blank-cheque companies, which have been criticized for their volatility and lack of transparency. The move is part of efforts to enhance market stability and protect investors.

site_title: Hackers possibly stole personal data of 79,400 MyRepublic customers, including copies of NRICs
summary: Hackers potentially accessed the personal data of nearly 79,400 MyRepublic customers, including scanned copies of National Registration Identity Cards (NRICs) and other identity verification documents. No evidence of personal data misuse has been found, but MyRepublic is offering complimentary credit monitoring services to affected customers. The incident is the latest in a string of cyber attacks in Singapore, with other mobile operators and companies experiencing data breaches in recent months. MyRepublic is reviewing its systems and processes to prevent similar incidents in the future.

site_title: Smart glasses made Google look dumb. Now Facebook is giving them a try
summary: Facebook has teamed up with Ray-Ban to release a line of smart glasses called Ray-Ban Stories, which can take photos, record video, answer phone calls, and play music and podcasts. The glasses start at $299 and come in over 20 styles, with features such as audio activation, a charging case, and a smartphone app for uploading content. Despite concerns over privacy, Facebook has implemented measures such as a notification light and prompts to ask users if it's okay to take photos or videos. The glasses are part of Facebook's goal to create a future where technology seamlessly integrates into everyday life.

site_title: Del Monte mulls US subsidiary IPO; eyes higher FY22 net profit
summary: Del Monte Pacific Limited, a canned food brand, is considering an initial public offering (IPO) of its US subsidiary Del Monte Foods Inc (DMFI) to improve its capital structure and business performance. The IPO, which could take 18-24 months, aims to ease the company's high debt levels and capitalize on market opportunities. Despite a recent surge in Covid-19 cases, Del Monte is expecting higher net profits in FY2022, driven by higher sales in the US and exports of pineapple products.

site_title: Truths and myths about heart disease
summary: A recent article examines the common myths and truths about heart disease. Contrary to popular belief, heart attacks are not always accompanied by chest pain, and women are not immune to heart disease. In fact, women are more likely to die from heart disease due to a lack of symptoms. The article aims to dispel these myths and provide accurate information to promote a healthier heart.

site_title: Kakao empire loses US$16b as South Korea steps up crackdown
summary: South Korea's tech giant Kakao has lost over $16 billion in market value this month due to a crackdown by regulators, who are focusing on fintech and online platforms. Shares dropped 17% over two sessions, with KakaoBank and Kakao Games also tumbling. Despite concerns, analysts remain optimistic on the long-term growth outlook, citing Korea's more mature regulatory environment. Proposed legislation to promote an equitable relationship between platforms and users has been expressed support by the Fair Trade Commission, but sell-off is seen as short-term, offering buying opportunities.

site_title: Apple must ease App Store rules, US judge orders
summary: A US federal judge has ordered Apple to ease App Store rules, allowing developers to send users to other payment systems. The ruling, made by Judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers, requires Apple to allow buttons or links in apps that direct customers to outside payment methods. However, the judge did not force Apple to allow developers to use their own in-app payment systems. Epic Games, the creator of "Fortnite," had sought this change, but the judge's ruling is seen as a partial win for developers. Apple shares were down 3.2% following the ruling, but analysts expect the impact to be manageable.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end ECB week lower after stimulus slows as expected
summary: European stocks ended the week lower, down over 1% as investors weighed risks from the European Central Bank's slowdown of pandemic-era bond purchases. Despite this, defensive sectors like healthcare and real estate declined the most, while tech stocks rose 0.7% and luxury stocks got a boost. The ECB stressed it's not closing the money taps, but analysts predict a "real" tapering next year if economic conditions remain good. Data showed Britain's economy slowed in July, and stocks like Fresenius Medical Care and Rubis fell.

images.alt_text: European stocks closed lower on Friday, down more than 1 per cent this week as investors weighed risks from tighter monetary policies after the European Central Bank signalled a slowdown of pandemic-era bond purchases.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare's CFO resigns to 'pursue other career opportunities'
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare's CFO, Vincent Yik Yen Shan, resigned effective November 30, citing a desire to pursue other career opportunities. He joined the company in July 2019. The company has begun searching for a replacement and stated there were no material reasons for his departure, including no concerns over financial reporting or disagreements with the board. His resignation was announced on September 10, 2021.

site_title: Gold gains on US dollar dip, but hinges on Fed taper cues
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,800.47 per ounce as the US dollar eased slightly, but uncertainty over the Federal Reserve's next moves on unwinding economic support measures kept gold in a tight range. The Fed is scheduled to meet on September 21 to 22, and investors closely follow its cues. Despite a weak dollar, gold is set for a weekly decline of 1.3%, and investors remain cautious due to the Fed's potential impact on interest rates and inflation.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Tee International received a letter from DBS Bank, exercising its rights to take possession of a mortgaged property in one month. The company is reviewing the letter with its advisors and will take action accordingly. Meanwhile, SGX RegCo ordered Darco Water Technologies to disclose details about its proposed investment in the Gaoyi domestic wastewater treatment project by September 17, including the current ownership structure and relationships between parties.

site_title: Getting your finances in order
summary: A family's financial well-being after a loved one's passing can be significantly affected by lack of planning. The author shares their personal experience of their grandfather's death, where a decade-long probate process and unpaid debts caused immense stress to the family. To avoid such situations, experts emphasize the importance of having a will in every jurisdiction, appointing suitable executors, being aware of applicable estate duties, and completing advanced medical directives and lasting power of attorneys. A well-planned succession plan can also help maintain family harmony and prevent conflicts over inheritances.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends week lower after latest inflation spike
summary: US shares closed lower for the fourth straight day, with major indices posting losses for the week due to concerns over a slowing recovery and rising inflation. The producer price index (PPI) jumped 8.3% in August, its largest increase since 2010, amid worries about the Delta variant's impact on economic activity and supply chains. The Dow Jones, S&P 500, and Nasdaq composite Index all fell, with the Dow closing at 34,607.72, down 0.8%.

site_title: Singapore SPACs need to go hunting in bigger markets
summary: Singapore's SPACs face a challenge in attracting high-quality startups to sustain the asset class. With a small population, the city-state cannot produce enough local champions to support SPACs. Sponsors will need to look to bigger markets, such as Indonesia and India, to find suitable targets. To succeed, Singapore's blank-cheque vehicles must appeal to a more risk-tolerant investor class, unlike traditional real estate investment trusts, which have a steady stream of rents. The Singapore Exchange has introduced listing rules for SPACs, including a 24-month timeline to find a private target, and detachable warrants to incentivize investors to stay.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust's private placement priced at S$0.983 each; units end 4.8% lower
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) closed its private placement priced at S$0.983 per new stapled security, 4.8% lower than its initial price range. The placement saw participation from new and existing institutional and accredited investors, and 152,594,100 new stapled securities will be issued. The funds will partially fund the acquisition of Wildwood Lubbock, a US$70 million student accommodation asset, and for future potential acquisitions. Trading of new units on the Singapore Exchange is expected to commence on September 20.

site_title: Biden's new vaccine push is a fight for the US economy
summary: US President Joe Biden is pushing for expanded vaccination efforts to combat the Delta variant and its impact on the economy. A surge in deaths has led to a decline in consumer confidence, with people opting for limited in-person commerce. The plan would mandate vaccinations for federal employees, healthcare workers, and require weekly tests for employees at companies with over 100 employees. The goal is to counter the economic threat posed by the virus and revive the recovery. The president faces backlash from conservative lawmakers, but administration officials argue that vaccinating more Americans is key to economic health.

site_title: DBS/POSB cardholders to get real-time control over security access to protect against fraud
summary: DBS has introduced new features to give its 3.6 million debit and credit card holders real-time control over their card accounts, aiming to curb fraudulent transactions amid rising cases. Customers can manage access, stipulate spend limits, receive instant alerts, and lock or unlock their cards instantly through the digital banking app. The bank is also partnering with industry partners to develop new payments security protocols, such as 3D Secure 2.0, to stay ahead of fraudsters.

site_title: Talented teens steal show at Flushing Meadows
summary: Three teenagers, Leylah Fernandez, Emma Raducanu, and Carlos Alcaraz, have made a significant impact at the US Open tennis tournament, overshadowing top superstars who withdrew due to various reasons. Fernandez and Raducanu will contest the final, marking the first time two teenagers have done so since 1999. Fernandez has won four straight three-setters, while Raducanu defied odds to become the first qualifier to reach a Grand Slam final. Alcaraz, 18, has been touted as "The Next Rafa" but has vowed to establish his own identity.

site_title: Why 9/11 matters to Singapore
summary: Singapore's response to the 9/11 terrorist attacks led to increased focus on inter-faith engagement and understanding, as the government sought to counter the threat of terrorism. In 2001, 13 Jemaah Islamiyah members were arrested, foiling plans to attack American targets. The government's initial response, however, sparked concerns about Muslim exclusion and self-segregation. Recognizing the need for a more holistic approach, Singapore shifted to a "whole-of-society" approach, promoting inter-ethnic understanding and religious freedom. This included the formation of Inter-Racial and Religious Confidence Circles and the launch of initiatives such as the Commitment to Safeguard Religious Harmony.

site_title: Be careful whose China investment advice you take
summary: George Soros criticizes BlackRock for investing in China, citing the country's communist system, capital controls, and strict crackdowns, which pose a risk to clients' money and US security interests. However, other prominent investors, such as Mark Mobius and Ray Dalio, defend the idea of investing in China, citing its massive demographic potential and increasing weightings in major index providers. Soros' advice to be cautious and prioritize return of capital over potential gains is advised, but both perspectives have valid points, highlighting the need for thorough due diligence and local intelligence.

site_title: Malaysian PM proposes political reforms to woo opposition
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob proposed political reforms, including new laws to prevent defections and a 10-year term limit for the premier, to win opposition support. The offers come ahead of a Parliament session, where King Al-Sultan Abdullah plans to hold a confidence vote. Sabri's proposals include bipartisan agreements on bills, opposition input on a national recovery council, and lowering the minimum voting age to 18. The moves aim to address Malaysia's prolonged political instability since 2018.

site_title: Japan's top egg producer invests S$100m to build Singapore's fourth egg farm
summary: Japan's top egg producer, ISE Foods Holdings, is investing S$100m to build Singapore's fourth egg farm, which will produce 360 million eggs and 5 million day-old chicks annually by 2026.

site_title: Revealing more of the math behind Covid-19 action plans can help allay public fear, uncertainty
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 taskforce has revealed its calculations for the country's future cases, indicating four or five 10-day "doubling cycles" before the wave peaks, with daily cases potentially rising to 2,000 by the end of the month. Health Minister Ong Ye Kung and Finance Minister Lawrence Wong have emphasized the need for transparency and predictability, aiming to alleviate public fear and speculation while also addressing concerns about reopening. The taskforce's focus is on intensive care unit (ICU) cases, and it will continue to provide updates on its latest thinking to ensure clarity for the public.

site_title: Asean, China will benefit from closer economic links: DPM Heng
summary: Singapore Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat said Asean and China will benefit from closer economic links, despite the Covid-19 pandemic. Trade volume between the two grew 6.7% last year to US$684.6 billion. The China-Singapore Chongqing Connectivity Initiative saw a 30% year-on-year increase in trade volume, and Heng emphasized the need for closer economic integration and a rules-based multilateral framework for trade and investments.

images.alt_text: Trade between Asean and China grew last year in spite of the Covid-19 pandemic, and both sides would benefit from building closer economic links, Singapore Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat said on Friday.

site_title: Singapore's new Covid-19 wave 'happening faster than expected': Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore is experiencing a new wave of COVID-19 cases, with infection rates doubling twice in 18 days, and is expected to peak at 2,000 new cases per day within weeks. Despite this, the government has decided not to return to a "heightened alert" or "circuit breaker" and instead plans to adjust healthcare protocols, including automatic quarantine orders and shortened quarantine periods. The government aims to balance the need to control the spread of the virus with the need to minimize disruptions to daily life.

site_title: Economists downgrade US growth prospects for rest of the year
summary: US economists have downgraded growth prospects for the remainder of 2021 due to the spread of the Covid-19 Delta variant, higher inflation, and supply challenges. Forecasts for the third quarter have been lowered to 5% from 6.8%, while fourth-quarter estimates are trimmed to 5.3% from 5.6%. Consumer spending is expected to contract in the third quarter, with annualized growth of 2.1%, down from 4.5% previously. The median estimates for gross domestic product growth in 2022 have been revised up to 4.1% and 3.3%.

site_title: Making the historical case for talent
summary: Adrian Wooldridge's book "The Aristocracy of Talent: How Meritocracy Made the Modern World" defends meritocracy as a progressive idea that has created the modern world. The book argues that meritocracy, defined as the idea that an individual's position in society should depend on their ability and effort, has been instrumental in promoting social mobility and equality of opportunity. Wooldridge traces the history of meritocracy from ancient Greece to the modern West, highlighting its role in the French, American, and British liberal revolutions. However, he acknowledges the challenges and criticisms of meritocracy, including its potential for inequality and elitism. Wooldridge concludes that meritocracy is a progressive force that must be improved to ensure that it benefits all members of society, not just the elite.

site_title: Thai Parliament passes election changes favouring ruling party
summary: Thailand's Parliament passed major electoral changes favouring larger parties, including increasing constituency representatives to 400 and reinstating a two-ballot system. The changes, which require King Maha Vajiralongkorn's endorsement, are expected to benefit Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha's military-backed organisation. The amendments were passed with 472 lawmakers voting in favour, 187 abstaining, and 33 voting against.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finish week with flourish
summary: Hong Kong stocks rebounded on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index climbing 1.91% to 26,205.91. The gains followed phone talks between US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping, who urged a way forward away from conflict. Asian markets also rose, with the Shanghai Composite Index adding 0.27% and the Shenzhen Composite Index increasing 0.31%. The rebounds came as traders brushed off new US threats to extend the rally.

site_title: US producer prices up by more than forecast in August
summary: US producer prices increased by 0.7% in August, exceeding forecasts, driven by supply chain disruptions and rising production costs. The core PPI advanced 0.6%, and prices for goods rose 1%, with costs for meats, residential natural gas, and motor vehicles increasing. The report also showed a 7.8% gain in margins for health, beauty, and optical goods retailing. The data comes ahead of the consumer price index report, which is forecast to show a 0.4% advance in the CPI.

site_title: Rebuilding ground zero was a mess. Lower Manhattan bloomed anyway
summary: Two decades after the 9/11 attacks, Lower Manhattan has largely recovered, with many areas improved upon their pre-attack state. Despite the challenges of rebuilding Ground Zero, the community came together to cope and reimagine the city. However, the reconstruction process was marred by mistakes, and the area remains a work in progress. Neighborhoods have adapted, with residents and businesses finding ways to thrive in the area, transforming it into a vibrant and resilient community.

images.alt_text: Since Sept 11, City Hall has failed to add much-needed affordable housing in the neighbourhood. And in an old waterfront district with few protections against rising seas, climate change presents an existential challenge that dwarfs the rebuilding at ground zero.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after Biden-Xi call
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 70.21 points, or 0.20%, to 34,949.59, after signs of easing tensions between the US and China. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with gains of 13.64 and 84.66 points, respectively. The recent call between President Biden and Chinese leader Xi Jinping is believed to have contributed to the positive market sentiment. The gains come despite ongoing trade tensions and concerns about a slowdown in the economic recovery.

site_title: All jokes aside, scientists find talking duck
summary: A Dutch scientist, Carel Ten Cate, has discovered recordings of a musk duck mimicking human speech, including the phrase "You bloody fool!" The duck, nicknamed "Ripper," was raised by humans in an Australian bird park and was found to have a unique ability to imitate human voices. Ten Cate's findings, published in the Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society journal, suggest that Ripper's vocal learning is an independent evolutionary occurrence, making it an extraordinary case. The discovery highlights the remarkable vocal learning abilities of some animal species.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's multi-ministry taskforce on Covid-19 is changing protocols due to rising cases, shortening quarantine periods, and making home recovery the default for more fully vaccinated cases. The country is also set to start Covid-19 vaccine boosters in mid-September for at-risk groups. Meanwhile, SPH shareholders approved a historic vote to hive off its media business, and Reebonz, a luxury marketplace, has entered creditors' voluntary liquidation. Hackers may have accessed data of 79,400 MyRepublic customers, and DBS/POSB cardholders can now lock or unlock their cards instantly through the digital banking app.

site_title: Japan's power industry needs nuclear power, will discuss it with next PM
summary: Japan's power industry needs nuclear power, with the head of an electricity sector federation stating that the industry will have a serious debate with the next prime minister on energy policy. The upcoming prime minister, Taro Kono, previously criticized nuclear energy but has since taken a more cautious stance. Discussions will focus on restarting dormant nuclear plants deemed safe to achieve a goal of carbon neutrality by 2050, rather than building new plants. The nuclear target remains unchanged at 20-22% of the electricity mix for 2030.

site_title: DBS named world's best bank, world's best digital bank by Euromoney
summary: DBS has been named the world's best bank and the world's best digital bank by Euromoney for the fourth consecutive year. The Singapore-headquartered bank received the accolades, making it the first to hold both titles concurrently. DBS demonstrated its ability to innovate and support customers during the pandemic, growing its business through strategic acquisitions. CEO Piyush Gupta attributed the bank's success to its focus on digital leadership and key trends shaping the post-pandemic world.

site_title: Chinese regulator tells businesses to set commodity prices 'reasonably'
summary: China's market regulator has told businesses to set commodity prices "reasonably" as the country grapples with a 13-year high factory gate inflation. The regulator accused hoarders and speculators of driving up prices, which have led to increased costs for manufacturers. The State Administration of Market Regulation vowed to crack down on such actions, which it said disrupt market order and harm small and medium-sized businesses. The regulator also reminded companies that prices should be based on production and operating costs, as well as market supply and demand.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks snap three-day losses on tech rebound, Biden-Xi call
summary: South Korean stocks rebounded, snapping a three-day losing streak, after tech heavyweights SK Hynix, Naver, and Kakao rose. The Kospi index closed up 0.36% at 3,125.76, driven by relief from a call between US President Joe Biden and Chinese leader Xi Jinping, who discussed avoiding competition conflict. Foreigners sold US$445.14 million worth of shares, but domestic investors helped offset the loss.

site_title: Kakao empire loses US$16b as South Korea steps up crackdown
summary: South Korea's tech crackdown has led to a significant loss of market value for Kakao Corp, with the company's shares dropping 17% over the past two sessions. Kakao Corp has lost nearly US$10 billion in value this month, following calls from prominent lawmakers labeling the company a "symbol of greed." The crackdown is part of South Korea's efforts to regulate the tech industry and address concerns over monopolies and unfair business practices.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Friday, down 2.92 points to 1,575.97. The index saw 4.395 billion lots traded worth RM2.753 billion, with 498 gainers and 467 losers.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher with eyes on politics
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 1.25% to 30,381.84, driven by Asian share gains and anticipation of a ruling party leadership vote in Japan this month. The Topix index rose 1.29% to 2,091.65. Investors are focusing on Japanese politics ahead of the leadership vote.

site_title: DBS/POSB cardholders to get real-time control over security access to protect against fraud
summary: DBS Bank has introduced new features to give its 3.6 million debit and credit card holders real-time control over security access to protect against fraud. Principal cardholders can manage access, stipulate spend limits, and receive instant alerts for blocked transactions. The bank also allows customers to lock or unlock their cards instantly, set monthly spend limits, and disable online e-commerce transactions. These measures aim to provide an additional layer of protection against unauthorised transactions and are part of DBS's efforts to curb fraudulent activities.

site_title: Sinovac in talks about setting up South Africa vaccine production
summary: Sinovac Biotech is in talks to set up a vaccine production facility in South Africa, partnering with Numolux Group to supply the African continent with Covid-19 and other vaccines. The facility aims to produce vaccines for the entire spectrum of vaccinations, with the first phase focusing on bottling and labelling. The move follows a global Phase III trial of Sinovac's CoronaVac vaccine in children and adolescents, with South Africa enrolling 2,000 participants. The South African government is considering using the vaccine in its immunisation programme, alongside other vaccines developed by Pfizer-BioNTech and Johnson & Johnson.

site_title: SPH shareholders say aye in historic vote to hive off media business
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) shareholders overwhelmingly approved a restructuring plan, transferring the media business to a company limited by guarantee (CLG) with 97.6% of votes in favor. The restructuring is expected to be completed by December, paving the way for the proposed privatization of SPH by Keppel Corporation. The CLG structure will allow profits from the media business to be reinvested, rather than distributed to shareholders, and will provide greater flexibility for the company to pursue strategic options.

site_title: US lifts import ban on Malaysia's Top Glove over forced labour concerns
summary: The US has lifted its one-year import ban on Malaysia's Top Glove Corp, allowing imports after a thorough review of evidence showing the company has addressed forced labour concerns. The ban, imposed in 2020, was sparked by allegations of debt bondage, excessive overtime, and abusive working conditions. Top Glove has taken steps to improve conditions for its migrant workers, including upgrading hostel facilities and compensating them for fees paid to employment agents. The company's shares jumped 10% on the news, while its production in Malaysia has dropped since the ban.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rise at open
summary: European stocks rose at the open on Friday, ending a week of struggles, as concerns over rising virus cases offset economic recovery hopes. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.2% to 7,035.75 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices rose 0.1% and 0.3%, respectively.

site_title: Shorter quarantine, home recovery as default for more as Singapore changes protocols in face of rising Covid-19 cases
summary: Singapore is adjusting its Covid-19 protocols amid rising case numbers, focusing on TraceTogether data for contact tracing and shortening quarantine periods to 10 days, down from 14 days. For fully vaccinated cases, discharge dates are being brought forward and home recovery is being made the default care management protocol, starting from September 15. The multi-ministry taskforce aims to allocate hospital beds to those who need medical attention, while prioritizing contact tracing resources for high-risk settings.

site_title: Singer Phil Collins can barely hold a drum stick due to worsening health
summary: Phil Collins, a 70-year-old British musician, has expressed frustration over his deteriorating health, which affects his ability to play drums and sing live. Collins, an eight-time Grammy winner, underwent back surgery in 2009 and 2015 and has diabetes. His son Nic will play drums on the upcoming Genesis tour, the first in 14 years. Collins described the tour as "putting it to bed," indicating a possible retirement from touring.

site_title: Make more Covid-19 calculations public to allay fears, uncertainty
summary: Singapore's multi-ministry taskforce on Covid-19 has revealed its calculations, indicating the country may see four to five "doubling cycles" of cases before the wave peaks, with daily cases potentially reaching 2,000 by the end of the month. The taskforce's co-chair, Health Minister Ong Ye Kung, emphasized that the pace of cases is faster than expected and urged the public to remain calm, while Finance Minister Lawrence Wong warned of a possible surge in ICU cases if the situation deviates from the predicted trajectory.

site_title: Tee International receives notice from DBS to take possession of 33 Changi North Crescent
summary: Tee International has received a notice from DBS Bank to take possession of its mortgaged property at 33 Changi North Crescent, one month from the date of service. The company is reviewing the letter with its financial consultant and legal advisers, and will take appropriate action. Tee International had filed an application for a moratorium in August and has three outstanding claims totaling S$13.7 million. Trading in its shares has been suspended amid the development.

site_title: SGX RegCo issues notice of compliance to Darco for detailed report on Gaoyi project
summary: SGX RegCo ordered Darco Water Technologies to disclose a detailed report on the Gaoyi domestic waste water treatment project by Sept 17, including current ownership structure and relationships between parties. The report will cover the transfer of the water treatment asset, extension of deadline for transfer, and legal recourse available to the company. The regulator is also seeking the board's assessment on the proposed investment and key findings from Darco's independent due diligence consultant.

site_title: Hackers possibly stole personal data of 79,400 MyRepublic customers including copies of NRICs
summary: Hackers potentially accessed personal data of nearly 79,400 MyRepublic customers, including scanned copies of National Registration Identification Cards (NRICs) and other identity verification documents. The breach, discovered on August 29, was limited to a third-party data storage platform, and MyRepublic systems remain unaffected. The company is notifying affected customers and offering complimentary credit monitoring services, while reviewing its systems to prevent future incidents.

site_title: China vehicle sales slid 18% in August
summary: China's auto sales plummeted 17.8% in August to 1.8 million vehicles, according to industry data. Despite this, new energy vehicle sales surged 100% to 321,000, driven by the government's push for greener vehicles. This growth is attributed to manufacturers like Nio, Xpeng, and BYD expanding production in China to meet demand.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand dollars try for firmer finish to soggy week
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars saw a firmer finish to a soggy week, with the Aussie edging up 0.2% to US$0.7384 and the kiwi dollar off 0.4% at US$0.7118. The currencies were boosted by news of US President Joe Biden's call with Chinese President Xi Jinping, offering hope for improved relations. Vaccination progress in Australia and New Zealand is also seen as a positive factor for economic recovery, with Australia expected to surpass the US in vaccination rates soon.

site_title: Singapore shares advance with most regional peers, STI up 0.88%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index rose 0.88% to 3,098.80, following a phone call between US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping, which eased negative US sentiment and boosted regional stocks. The Hang Seng Index led the advance, gaining 1.91%, while other regional benchmarks also rose, with the exception of Kuala Lumpur's composite index. Advancers outpaced decliners 299 to 171, with real estate investment trusts Mapletree Commercial Trust and Singtel leading the gains.

site_title: Vietnam to reopen resort island to foreign tourists to boost economy
summary: Vietnam plans to reopen Phu Quoc, a beach-fringed island, to foreign tourists for a trial period of six months starting next month. Fully vaccinated tourists with a negative COVID-19 test will be eligible to visit, with chartered or commercial flights available. The move aims to boost Vietnam's economy, which suffered from extended lockdowns due to the pandemic. The country has seen a surge in infections driven by the Delta variant, but Phu Quoc has not reported community infections and has sufficient quarantine facilities.

site_title: Chinese women to drive US$5.3t consumer boom, UBS says
summary: Chinese women are expected to drive a US$5.3 trillion consumer boom over the next decade, accounting for 80% of growth in household consumption. Their rising incomes, improved social standing, and increasing education levels are key factors. This shift could benefit international companies in luxury, cosmetics, and leisure sectors, but may also lead to lower consumption growth as women tend to invest more of their incomes. By 2030, China is projected to contribute 27% of global consumption growth, surpassing the US.

site_title: Flynn Park sold en bloc for S$371m to Hoi Hup-Sunway joint venture
summary: Flynn Park in Pasir Panjang, Singapore, has been sold en bloc for S$371 million to a joint venture between Hoi Hup Realty and Sunway Developments. The sale price of approximately S$1,355 per plot ratio (ppr) exceeds the reserve price and is the largest collective sale site sold this year. The 72-apartment development sits on 208,443 square feet of freehold land, 350m from Pasir Panjang MRT station, and is zoned "residential" with a plot ratio of 1.4 under the Urban Redevelopment Authority's 2019 Master Plan.

site_title: Biden, Xi talk to avoid US-China 'conflict:' White House
summary: US President Joe Biden held a 90-minute phone call with Chinese President Xi Jinping, urging them to avoid "unintended conflict" and ensure "competition" remains dynamic. The call aimed to set "guardrails" for the relationship, with no concrete decisions expected on outstanding issues. Biden and Xi discussed areas of convergence and divergence, including trade, Taiwan, and the South China Sea. The White House signaled that the diplomatic impasse is unsustainable and potentially dangerous, requiring intervention by the leaders.

site_title: Del Monte mulls IPO of US subsidiary; eyes higher net profit for FY22
summary: Del Monte Pacific Limited, the parent company of canned food brand Del Monte, is considering an initial public offering (IPO) of its US subsidiary Del Monte Foods Inc to improve its capital structure and business performance. The IPO could take 18-24 months and aims to ease high levels of debt, which could make the company vulnerable to macroeconomic shocks. Despite high debt levels, Del Monte reported a net profit of $18.3 million in the first quarter of FY2022, up 11.9% year-over-year, and expects to generate a higher net profit in FY2022.

site_title: Super typhoon Chanthu threatens Philippines, Taiwan
summary: A super typhoon, Chanthu, is threatening both the Philippines and Taiwan with destructive winds and torrential rains over the coming days. The typhoon formed rapidly in 48 hours, packing gusts of up to 234km/h, and is expected to graze the northeastern tip of the Philippines and directly hit Taiwan over the weekend. The storm's rapid intensification has raised concerns about its unpredictability, with scientists attributing it to climate change.

site_title: Luxury marketplace Reebonz in creditors' voluntary liquidation
summary: Luxury marketplace Reebonz has appointed a provisional liquidator to wind up the company due to estimated liabilities of S$65 million. The company, founded in 2009, had failed to maintain a minimum share price on the US stock exchange and was delisted last year. Reebonz had previously owed over S$30,000 to 11 sellers on its platform, and its website stated it would not accept new orders. A creditors' meeting is scheduled for October 1, with notices to be issued to creditors on September 17.

site_title: Hot stock: Ascott Residence Trust down 5.8%; private placement closes at 98.3 S cents
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) units fell 5.8% to 98.3 Singapore cents after closing its S$150 million private placement at the bottom end of its price range. The placement, which raised S$150 million, will partially fund the acquisition of a US student accommodation asset for US$70 million. About S$58.7 million will go towards the Wildwood Lubbock acquisition, while S$89 million will fund future potential acquisitions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 2.07 points, or 0.13%, to 1,576.82 on Friday. Volume was 393.34 million lots worth RM1139.76 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 203 to 173. The lower opening is attributed to the lack of significant market-moving news.

site_title: Asia: Hong Kong rallies as markets bounce back from sell-off
summary: Asian markets rebounded on Friday, with Hong Kong leading the gains as investors cautiously assessed the impact of the Delta variant on the global outlook. Tech firms, which were severely impacted by China's gaming crackdown, saw significant buying, while the European Central Bank's monetary stimulus tweak boosted eurozone equities. However, concerns about the pandemic's pace of recovery and potential tapering of monetary policies by the Federal Reserve remain.

site_title: SIRCLO, the Shopify of Indonesia, raises US$36m in Series B round
summary: Indonesian e-commerce startup SIRCLO has raised US$36 million in a Series B round led by East Ventures' growth fund and Saratoga. Traveloka and Sinar Mas Land also participated in the round. The funds will be used to develop technology infrastructure and expand services for businesses. SIRCLO has over 100,000 brands on its platform and recorded a five-fold increase in transactions during the pandemic. The company aims to provide real-time data analytics and financing solutions for micro, small-and-medium enterprises. This investment is seen as a way to strengthen Indonesia's economic recovery.

site_title: Councillors swear new Hong Kong loyalty oath after hundreds quit
summary: Councillors in Hong Kong have sworn a new loyalty oath to China after hundreds of their colleagues quit in protest. The oath is part of authorities' efforts to purge the city of "unpatriotic" elements. District councillors, who are the only fully elected officials in Hong Kong, have become a symbol of residents' desire for greater control over their city. The move has sparked controversy and raised concerns about the erosion of democratic freedoms in the city.

site_title: Singapore's new wave of Covid-19 infections 'happening faster than expected': Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore is experiencing a new wave of COVID-19 infections at a faster rate than expected, with daily cases projected to reach 1,000 and then 2,000 within weeks. The government's multi-ministry taskforce has adjusted protocols to include shorter quarantine periods, home recovery for young, healthy, fully-vaccinated individuals, and automatic quarantine orders for household members of infected patients. Despite the rising case numbers, there is no need to return to a "heightened alert" or "circuit breaker" and the government is ramping up healthcare facilities to handle the surge.

images.alt_text: Singapore is likely to see 1,000 new cases a day soon, while hitting 2,000 new cases a day in a few weeks time, said Finance Minister and Covid-19 taskforce co-chair Lawrence Wong.

site_title: Uber Eats, DoorDash, Grubhub sue New York City over legislation on commission caps
summary: Food-delivery companies DoorDash, Grubhub, and Uber Eats sued New York City over a legislation capping commissions at 15% for delivery services and 5% for advertising services. The companies claim the law is unconstitutional as it interferes with freely negotiated contracts between platforms and restaurants. The legislation, approved in August, aims to limit the amount food delivery companies can charge restaurants to use their platforms. The companies are seeking an injunction and unspecified monetary damages, arguing the law will harm local restaurants and the industry as a whole.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Friday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened higher on Friday, gaining 0.4% or 11.22 points to 3,082.92. The most active counter, VCPlus, saw a 12.5% gain. Meanwhile, the US stock market closed lower, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.4% and the S&P 500 declining 0.2%. European stocks were largely unchanged after the ECB signaled a slight reduction in emergency bond purchases.

site_title: Japan vaccine czar Kono enters race to become PM
summary: Japan's vaccine czar Taro Kono has entered the race to become the country's Prime Minister, becoming the third candidate in the ruling Liberal Democratic Party's leadership vote. Kono aims to create a country where no one is left behind and has pledged to restart nuclear power if safety can be confirmed. He is currently the most popular option among the general public, with polls showing he will face a general election by the end of November. Kono's main rivals are former Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida and former Internal Affairs Minister Sanae Takaichi.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.60% to 25,870.71, following a previous day's sell-off. Investors remain cautious due to China's crackdown on private industries, particularly tech firms. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite and Shenzhen Composite Indexes fell 0.05% and 0.15%, respectively.

site_title: 450 new locally transmitted Covid-19 cases in Singapore; unvaccinated 62-year-old man dies of Covid-19
summary: Singapore reported 450 new locally transmitted COVID-19 cases, the highest number since August last year, with 108 cases among seniors above 60. The total infections stand at 70,039. An unvaccinated 62-year-old man died from COVID-19 complications, bringing the death toll to 57. New clusters were identified, including Hu Lee Impex and Sembcorp Marine Tuas Boulevard Yard, with most cases linked to workplace transmission.

site_title: Harvard University to end investment in fossil fuels
summary: Harvard University has announced it will end its investments in fossil fuels, with President Lawrence Bacow stating that the school's endowment has no direct investments in fossil fuel companies and will not make such investments in the future. The indirect investments, which make up less than 2% of the endowment, are in "runoff mode." The move comes after years of pressure from students, alumni, and activists to divest from fossil fuels to slow climate change. The university's decision is seen as a significant victory for the climate movement.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ascott Residence Trust, Del Monte, SPH
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) closed its private placement at 98.3 Singapore cents per new stapled security, surpassing its price range. Del Monte Pacific Limited posted a net profit of US$18.3 million for the first quarter, reversing a loss a year ago. Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) requested a trading halt pending a shareholder vote on restructuring its media business and forming a new constitution, citing potentially heavy financial costs.

site_title: Hong Kong plans to limit retail investor access to SPACs
summary: Hong Kong plans to limit retail investor access to Special Purpose Acquisition Companies (SPACs) to professional investors with assets of over HK$8 million (S$1.4 million), citing the need to mitigate risks and ensure a smooth start. The city's financial secretary had announced a timeline for the framework's public consultation, which is set to roll out this month. The decision is a compromise, with market participants agreeing to the limit to allow for potential expansion later.

site_title: The changing profile of the Good Class Bungalow market
summary: The Good Class Bungalow (GCB) market in Singapore has seen a surge in transactions and record prices this year, driven by a shift in buyer demographics. The new generation of ultra-high net worth (UHNW) individuals, many of whom have made their fortunes in the digital economy, are purchasing GCBs, often with a focus on legacy planning and wealth preservation. These buyers are willing to pay premium prices, with some transactions exceeding S$100 million. The limited supply of GCBs and strong demand from UHNW individuals are expected to continue driving up prices, with some predicting a widening price gap in the coming months.

site_title: Singapore to start Covid-19 vaccine boosters in mid-September for at-risk groups
summary: Singapore plans to start Covid-19 vaccine boosters for seniors and immunocompromised individuals in mid-September, with around 200,000 eligible seniors receiving their third shots starting September 14. The Ministry of Health recommends the booster shots for those aged 60 and above, aged-care facility residents, and moderately to severely immunocompromised individuals, such as cancer patients. The decision follows recommendations from Singapore's expert committee on Covid-19 vaccination and comes as other countries like Germany and the US also announce plans for booster shots.

images.alt_text: In early September, Singapore's expert committee on Covid-19 vaccination recommended booster shots for the elderly and immunocompromised.

site_title: Lung cancer patients in England to receive Amgen drug that targets a gene mutation
summary: Lung cancer patients in England are set to become the first in Europe to receive a US-made drug, sotorasib, targeting a specific gene mutation. The drug, approved for patients with the KRAS G12C mutation, has shown to stop lung cancer progression for seven months. 600 patients a year will receive the tablet through the NHS, with the treatment available as early as possible. The drug's accelerated approval follows its US approval in May for patients whose disease has worsened after chemotherapy or other medicines.

site_title: Hot stock: Top Glove up 9.8% after group announces lifting of US import ban
summary: Top Glove, a Malaysian glove maker, saw its shares rise 9.8% after the US Customs and Border Protection lifted its import ban on the company's products, effective Sept 10, 2021. The ban was previously in place due to forced labor allegations, but the CBP determined that the company had satisfied "satisfactory evidence" that its products were not produced with forced labor. Top Glove thanked the CBP and Malaysian government for their responsiveness and commitment to its workers' health and well-being.

site_title: New 'Life is Strange' debuts as LGBTQ video games take off
summary: The new "Life is Strange" game, "Life is Strange: True Colors", has debuted, featuring a bisexual protagonist and allowing players to pursue same-sex relationships. The game follows Alex Chen, a young Asian-American woman with the power to sense other people's emotions, as she investigates her brother's death. The game's sensitivity and portrayal of LGBTQ characters have received critical acclaim, with the series winning over three million copies since its inception in 2015. The game's success marks a growing trend of LGBTQ representation in video games, with larger studios now eager to depict a wider diversity of characters.

site_title: Apple rebuffs Epic's request to restore Fortnite developer account in South Korea
summary: Apple has rejected Epic Games' request to restore its Fortnite developer account in South Korea, which would allow the game to offer its own payment option. This decision comes as South Korea's parliament approved a bill banning major app store operators from forcing developers to use their payment systems. The move is part of a larger battle between Apple and Epic over app development fees, with the lawsuit alleging Apple has abused its market dominance.

site_title: UN says Taleban-led Afghanistan needs funds to avoid collapse
summary: The UN is urging the world to provide financial aid to the Taliban-led government in Afghanistan to prevent a total breakdown of the economy and social order. Secretary-General's special representative Deborah Lyons warned that without aid, the country could suffer a severe economic downturn, leading to widespread poverty, hunger, and a massive refugee crisis. The US has frozen $9.5 billion in Afghan central bank assets, and China has accused the US of worsening Afghans' plight, while the UN Development Programme estimates that 72% of Afghans live on less than $1 a day.

site_title: Malaysia's Khazanah raises RM664.5m from CIMB Group share placement
summary: Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund Khazanah Nasional completed a share placement of 1.4% stake in CIMB Group Holdings Bhd, raising RM664.5 million (S$215.3 million). This is part of Khazanah's efforts to rebalance its portfolio and recycle investments. The placement is aimed at recycling investments into new assets in Malaysia and globally.

site_title: Biden administration targets 20% drop in aviation emissions
summary: US President Joe Biden's administration unveiled measures to reduce aviation emissions by 20% by 2030, aiming to combat climate change. The White House proposed a tax credit for fuels with at least 50% lifecycle emissions drop, $4.3 billion in funding for new fuel development, and a sustainable fuel "grand challenge" to boost its use by 2030. Aviation emissions account for 11% of US transportation-related emissions, and addressing this pollution source is essential to achieve net-zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050.

site_title: Facebook and Ray-Ban debut 'smart' shades
summary: Facebook and Ray-Ban have launched the "Ray-Ban Stories" smart glasses, priced at $299, which can take pictures and video using voice commands and connect wirelessly to Facebook's platform. The glasses have cameras in the front and directional speakers, and a white light to alert others when recording. Users can share captured images or video through the Facebook View app, with only necessary data collected. This marks Facebook's entry into a market previously dominated by Google Glass and Snapchat's Spectacles, with the goal of creating futuristic eyewear that adds real-world views with internet data.

site_title: Biden slams 'minority' preventing US from overcoming Covid-19
summary: US President Joe Biden blamed a "distinct minority" of Americans who refuse COVID-19 vaccines for preventing the country from overcoming the pandemic. He announced a new vaccination plan requiring private companies with 100+ employees to ensure workers are vaccinated or tested weekly, impacting 80 million people. The plan aims to reduce COVID-19 spread by increasing vaccination rates in businesses nationwide. Republican lawmakers criticized the administration's overreach, calling it a "dictatorship."

site_title: Australia appoints former Macquarie boss to supervise financial regulators
summary: Australia has appointed Nicolas Moore, former Macquarie Group boss, to chair a new regulator review board to assess the effectiveness of the country's banking and corporate regulators. The Financial Regulator Assessment Authority (FRAA) will evaluate the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) and the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) over the next year. The move comes after a 2018 inquiry criticized regulators for their "light touch" on enforcement, citing funding cuts and an increasing mandate as obstacles to preventing wrongdoing in the financial sector.

images.alt_text: Australia's government has appointed Nicolas Moore, who led Macquarie Group for a decade until 2018, to chair a new regulator review board to report on the effectiveness of the country's banking and corporate regulators.

site_title: Kobe Bryant designed and signed Hublot watch hits the auction block
summary: A limited edition 18K rose gold Hublot watch designed and signed by Kobe Bryant is up for auction, valued at a minimum of $10 million. Only three of the 250 "Black Mamba" Tourbillon watches were made in rose gold. The package also includes a purple Nike Zoom 8 sneaker and digital art by artist Moshé Douglas, to be sold as a non-fungible token. The proceeds will benefit the Greater Los Angeles Make-a-Wish Foundation, with $50,000 donated.

site_title: Tencent leads US$60b loss as game crackdown expands
summary: Chinese regulators have summoned industry executives, instructing them to break their focus on profit and prevent minors from becoming addicted to games. The government will slow down approvals for new online games, a move that could hit developers' wallets directly. Tencent Holdings and Netease have lost over $60 billion in value as investor fears grow, with regulators also limiting the amount of time children can play video games to three hours a week. The gaming crackdown escalates concerns about Beijing's broader campaign to rein in its giant internet industry.

site_title: US Congress begins drafting historic US$3.5t spending package
summary: US Congress has begun drafting a historic $3.5 trillion spending package, a crucial part of President Joe Biden's legislative agenda. The package includes funding for climate measures, infrastructure investments, and education benefits, but faces opposition from Republicans who claim it would lead to inflation and government dependency. Senate Democrats are under pressure to trim the bill's cost, with centrist senators Joe Manchin and Kyrsten Sinema advocating for a lower total. A no vote from a single Democrat in the 50-50 Senate would effectively kill the bill.

site_title: Top chef shares secret to 're-ageing' steak at home
summary: Top chef Andrew Carmellini shares his "re-ageing" technique, a simpler alternative to dry-aging, to enhance the flavor of prime steak at home. The method involves refrigerating a pre-aged steak for a few days, allowing air to circulate and caramelizing sugars, resulting in a more intense flavor and better crust. Carmellini recommends pairing re-aged steak with Gorgonzola butter for a unique flavor combination.

site_title: US: Stocks fall again in 'exhausted' market
summary: US stocks declined for the second day in a row, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 0.4% to 34,879.38, the S&P 500 falling 0.2% to 4,493.28, and the Nasdaq Composite Index shedding 0.3% to 15,248.25. The decline was attributed to uncertainty over US monetary policy and President Biden's infrastructure package. Meanwhile, the European Central Bank announced a slowdown in its bond purchases, which may impact the Federal Reserve's plans to scale back asset purchases. Market analysts described the market as "exhausted" and seeking a catalyst.

site_title: Office air quality affects workers' cognitive function: study
summary: A new study by Harvard researchers found that poor office air quality, measured by fine particulate matter 2.5 micrometers and smaller (PM2.5) and carbon dioxide levels, can significantly impact employees' cognitive function, including response times and ability to focus. The study of 302 office workers across six countries found that increases in PM2.5 and CO2 levels led to noticeable reductions in cognitive performance, with a 1% decrease in response times and accuracy for every 10 micrograms per cubic meter of PM2.5 and 500 parts per million of CO2.

site_title: Historical interpretations
summary: A group of Singaporean creatives showcased their artworks at the Temenggong-SG-Creatives 2021 exhibition, titled Expressing Heritage: Art & Originality Unfold, at 28 Temenggong Road. The exhibition features works inspired by the history and surroundings of the colonial bungalow, including graphic artists, architect, designer, and art collective PHUNK. The event aims to support local artistic talent and inspire viewers with disparate narratives of true encounters. The exhibition is open until September 12 and can be visited by registration only.

site_title: Ford the latest automaker to exit car manufacturing in India
summary: Ford, the latest automaker, has exited car manufacturing in India due to accumulating operating losses of over $2 billion over 10 years. The company expects a $2 billion restructuring charge. This announcement is the latest blow to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's efforts to encourage foreign businesses to manufacture locally, following Harley-Davidson's withdrawal last year and General Motors' exit in 2017.

site_title: Europe: Stocks pare losses after ECB slows stimulus, as expected
summary: European stocks ended largely unchanged on Thursday after the European Central Bank signaled it will only slightly reduce its emergency bond purchases over the coming quarter, as expected. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.2% for rate-sensitive banking stocks and 1.0% for real estate stocks, while the UK's FTSE 100 dropped 1.0%. Analysts expect the ECB to outline plans for major policy changes by December and a gradual phasing out of the PEPP by March 2022.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, despite falls on Wall Street, with investors focusing on Japanese politics after Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's announcement that he will not seek re-election. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.35% to 30,113.97, while the Topix index edged up 0.29% to 2,070.89. The moves came as investors looked beyond the US market's recent record highs, which were impacted by US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust's private placement priced at bottom end of price range
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) closed its HMN private placement at 98.3 Singapore cents per new stapled security, priced at the bottom end of its range. The placement, which saw 2 times coverage, involved new and existing institutional and accredited investors. The managers of the Reit stated this in a bourse filing on Friday.

site_title: Warburg Pincus leads funding round for Advance.AI
summary: Warburg Pincus leads a US$200 million funding round for Singapore-headquartered Advance.AI, propelling the tech startup into the ranks of South-east Asia unicorns. Advance.AI, which uses AI-driven technology for digital identity verification, fraud detection, and credit scoring, has secured Warburg Pincus as lead investor. The funding is expected to help the company scale up its business significantly, with its valuation more than doubling from its last capital raising round. Advance.AI currently counts Chinese investment firm GSR Ventures and Temasek Holdings among its investors.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Bowman encouraged still by US recovery, taper likely this year
summary: US Federal Reserve bank Governor Michelle Bowman expressed optimism about the US recovery, despite a weak August jobs report. She stated that the central bank is close to its goal of maximum employment and may begin scaling back its $120 billion monthly bond purchases this year. Bowman's comments joined those of other Fed officials, signaling that the disappointing jobs report won't delay the taper. The Fed is considering a change in policy tied to economic variables, particularly job growth, amid a surge in coronavirus cases.

site_title: The changing profile of the GCB market
summary: The Good-Class Bungalow (GCB) market in Singapore has undergone a transformation, with its buyer profiles shifting to include a more diverse and affluent demographic. Gone are the days of business tycoons and "old money" owners, as the market now attracts high-net-worth individuals from various backgrounds. This shift has led to a surge in transactions and record prices being set this year, driven by the changing preferences of these buyers. The GCB market's evolution reflects the transformation of Singapore's economy and its growing economy.

site_title: Japan extends Covid emergency curbs in Tokyo, other areas, but govt eyeing reopening of borders
summary: Japan has extended emergency Covid-19 restrictions in Tokyo and other areas until the end of the month to curb rising infections and prevent hospital overloads. Despite a decline in new cases, the medical system remains stretched, prompting Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga to extend the curbs. The government is also eyeing the reopening of borders as vaccination rates rise.

site_title: Japan Airlines looking to raise 300b yen to ride out funding challenges: sources
summary: Japan Airlines Co Ltd is seeking to raise 300 billion yen (S$3.67 billion) by the end of the month to address funding challenges amid a slump in air traffic. The funds will be raised through subordinated loans and other financing methods. The airline reported a first-quarter operating loss of 82.65 billion yen, but expects its cash burn rate to fall in the second quarter. This move follows rival ANA Holdings Inc's previous funding, and JAL shares have declined 1.8% in morning trade.

site_title: HDB resale prices rise in August to just 0.1% below peak; record high of 26 million-dollar flats sold: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore rose 1.1% in August, their 14th consecutive month of gains, to 0.1% below the peak in April 2013. With strong demand outpacing flat supply, September prices are expected to hit a record high. This follows the completion of 26 million-dollar flats sold in August, the highest on record. Experts attribute the market confidence to the high vaccination rate and uncertainty in the BTO market, leading to more buyers opting for resale flats with certainty.

site_title: Oil dives late, hit by China supply plan, US bond auction
summary: Oil prices fell to a two-week low on Thursday, with Brent futures dropping 1.6% to $71.45 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude falling 1.7% to $68.14. The decline was driven by a China plan to release state oil reserves, a smaller-than-expected US crude draw, and a US 30-year bond auction. Oil prices rebounded after a ship was refloated in the Suez Canal, but were again pressured by strong demand and a surge in US 30-year bond yields, with investors seeking safer assets.

site_title: Mercedes EQE electrifies the scene on BMW's home ground
summary: Mercedes-Benz unveiled the EQE, a luxury electric sedan, at the Munich auto show, targeting electric car-minded buyers. The EQE is a battery-powered counterpart to its E-Class, a cornerstone model for the brand. This move aims to keep buyers within the Mercedes-Benz fold. The EQE's reveal comes ahead of IAA Mobility, a major European motor show currently taking place in Munich.

site_title: New York aims for zero-emissions cars and trucks by 2035
summary: New York Governor Kathy Hochul signed a bill aiming to make all new passenger cars and light-duty trucks zero-emission models by 2035, matching California's goal. The law sets a target of 100% in-state sales by 2035 and 100% for medium-duty and heavy-duty vehicles by 2045 if feasible. This move joins other states in efforts to phase out petrol-powered vehicles and reduce emissions, with several major automakers already investing in electric vehicle technology.

site_title: Japan's prime minister extends virus emergency for 19 areas to Sept 30
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga extended the virus emergency for 19 areas, including Tokyo, until September 30 to combat high levels of Delta variant infections. The move aims to ease restrictions if numbers start turning in the right direction, with plans to use vaccination certificates and test results to facilitate economic activities. The government also plans to shorten quarantine periods for vaccinated people entering Japan. The extension comes as the country faces a challenging task of balancing virus control with economic support under the new leadership.

site_title: Integrating sustainability into corporate governance
