The company, which provides packaging and testing services, will close Ipoh plants in Perak until September 15 to curb the spread of the disease. This disruption joins a global supply chain already struggling with inadequate capacity, particularly for low-end chips. The closure is projected to cut 2% from Unisem's annual production, with the company beginning an on-site vaccination program for staff.

site_title: Indonesia's Intudo Ventures closes US$115m fund for early-stage startups
summary: Indonesia's Intudo Ventures has closed a US$115 million fund to invest in early-stage startups in Southeast Asia. The firm's third fund will focus on Indonesian startups driven by rising private consumption and digitization. Intudo will prioritize Series A investments, with 70% of its capital coming from international investors. The firm's co-founders emphasize the importance of understanding local markets, rather than adopting a "one-size-fits-all" approach. Investors in the new fund include Wasson Enterprise, Black Kite Investments, and Uni-President Enterprises Corp.

site_title: Fragrance joins SGX delistings; Singapore's TDCX heads for NY listing
summary: Fragrance Group, a Singapore-based property developer, has applied to delist from the Singapore Stock Exchange following a successful privatization offer by JK Global Treasures at 13.8 Singapore cents per share. Meanwhile, TDCX, a digital customer experience services provider, has filed for an initial public offering on the New York Stock Exchange, aiming to raise funds to repay debt and expand its business into new markets.

site_title: Guarded reception for Taliban's new Afghan government in Asia, Europe
summary: The Taliban's provisional government in Afghanistan received a lukewarm reception from Germany, China, and Japan, with concerns over its composition and human rights record. German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas expressed little optimism about conditions in Afghanistan, citing the government's lack of inclusivity and violence against demonstrators. China urged an "open and inclusive" government, while Japan expressed concern over the safety of citizens. The international community is also worried about the humanitarian crisis in Afghanistan, with food and aid running out and over half a million people displaced internally.

site_title: Singapore's TDCX files for IPO on NYSE
summary: Singapore-headquartered TDCX, a digital customer experience services provider, has filed for an initial public offering (IPO) on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE), seeking to raise funds to repay debt and expand its business into new markets. Founded in 1995, TDCX has operations in 10 markets, a workforce of over 13,000, and revenue primarily from omnichannel CX solutions, with Facebook and Airbnb as its largest clients. The company aims to use a portion of the IPO proceeds to repay debt and invest in new markets, including Korea and China.

site_title: Chapter 11 isn't the end. It can mean a successful restructuring
summary: Singapore is redefining its perception of Chapter 11 insolvency, where companies can successfully restructure and emerge stronger. Examples include Marvel Entertainment, Apple, General Motors, and Chrysler, which have all successfully navigated bankruptcy proceedings. Pacific International Lines (PIL) recently completed a $3.3 billion debt restructuring, facilitated by a US$112 million investment, demonstrating that Singaporean companies can also benefit from insolvency protections. The key to success lies in having a sustainable underlying business or pivoting into new growth areas, allowing companies to shed dead weight and restart with a clean slate.

site_title: Deutsche Bank chief blames Europe for keeping banks small
summary: Deutsche Bank CEO Christian Sewing criticized Europe for regulating large banks too carefully, preventing them from consolidating and growing to compete with international peers. The fragmented regulation has led to a common deposit insurance system being lacking, hindering cross-border mergers. Europe's largest banks, including Deutsche Bank, have lower market valuations compared to US peers, with the German lender's stock price trading 88% below its peak. Sewing urged lawmakers to complete the banking union project to strengthen Europe's internal market and create a common deposit insurance system.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte accepts vice-presidential nomination for 2022
summary: Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte has accepted his party's nomination to run for vice-president in the 2022 election, despite criticism that it's an attempt to maintain power. Duterte, 76, is barred from running for president again, but wants to continue his efforts in a ceremonial role. Senator Panfilo Lacson has already declared his candidacy for president, with Senate speaker Vicente Sotto as his running mate. Duterte's daughter, Sara, is also considered a strong candidate for president, but has not yet confirmed her intentions.

site_title: Saudi Arabia lifts UAE travel ban weeks before Dubai Expo
summary: Saudi Arabia has lifted its travel ban on UAE, South Africa, and Argentina, allowing citizens to visit these countries starting Wednesday, weeks ahead of the Dubai Expo 2020. The move follows a phone call between Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman and UAE Crown Prince Mohammed bin Zayed, discussing strategic cooperation. The lifting of restrictions is seen as a boost for the delayed Expo, which aims to attract 25 million visitors and generate billions of dollars for the government.

site_title: CGS-CIMB's investment platform plugs gap in ageing client base
summary: CGS-CIMB launched ProsperUS, a digital investment platform targeting millennials and Gen Z, in March 2021. The platform offers access to eight asset classes across 30 exchanges and 25 markets, including equities, bonds, and ETFs. Founded by Saw Ping May, ProsperUS aims to educate and engage younger investors, with features such as curated stock picks, timely investment content, and perks like martini tasting and wood crafting. The platform has activation rates of 30-40%, higher than some competitors, and aims to be the entry point for new investors, with plans to offer additional products and services as they grow with the company.

site_title: Singapore stocks track Wall Street losses to end lower
summary: Singapore stocks ended in negative territory, closing 1.27% lower at 3,068.94 points, tracking Wall Street losses due to concerns over rising Covid-19 cases and a lacklustre US jobs report. The Straits Times Index (STI) saw Hongkong Land Holdings as the only gainer, up 2.3%, while other regional markets also declined, with the exception of Japan's Nikkei 225 and the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index. Losers outpaced gainers 351 to 147, with Jardine Matheson Holdings falling 3.9%.

site_title: Briton allegedly linked to Wirecard case in Singapore face 4 more charges of abetting to falsify document
summary: A Singaporean man, James Henry O'Sullivan, 46, linked to the Wirecard case, has been charged with four additional counts of abetting to falsify documents. O'Sullivan faces a total of five charges, with local accounting firm Citadelle Corporate Services' director R Shanmugaratnam also named in all charges. O'Sullivan allegedly instructed Shanmugaratnam to issue false documents to Wirecard and other firms, stating that Citadelle held large sums of money in escrow accounts. The charges carry a maximum jail term of up to 10 years and a fine.

site_title: Boeing board to face investors' suit over 737 Max crashes
summary: A Delaware Chancery Judge has allowed an investors' lawsuit against Boeing's board to proceed, accusing them of failing to properly monitor safety issues with the 737 Max jetliners. The lawsuit claims the board ignored "red flags" about the plane's safety after a fatal crash in 2018 and failed to implement adequate oversight until after a second crash in 2019. The judge's decision allows the case to move forward, with investors claiming Boeing's CEO made false public statements about the board's response to the first crash.

site_title: Digitalisation and new investors can help Singapore firms grow abroad
summary: Singapore companies can benefit from digitalisation and taking on capital from investors to expand abroad and capture new opportunities. Experts say companies must continually innovate and be willing to take calculated risks to stay ahead in the post-pandemic world. The need for diversification and expansion is driven by the need for growth and capturing new markets. Companies can leverage digital tools, talent, and capital to achieve this, but also face challenges such as talent and leadership shortages, and risk aversion. To overcome these, companies can send employees abroad for exposure and consider strategies such as humility and courage.

site_title: SGX RegCo orders Nutryfarm International to appoint independent reviewer to conduct investigation
summary: SGX RegCo has ordered Nutryfarm International to appoint an independent reviewer to investigate two issues: a HK$91.4 million refundable deposit made in relation to a tech acquisition and significant advances of 26.81 million yuan made to a customer's associate. This follows a notice of compliance issued by SGX RegCo. The investigation is expected to be conducted by a suitable independent reviewer.

site_title: Japan PM contender Kishida targets income disparity; rival Takaichi launches bid
summary: Japan's prime minister contender Fumio Kishida has proposed a new form of capitalism to reduce income disparity exacerbated by the Covid-19 pandemic. Kishida's economic policies aim to stimulate consumption and demand by distributing wealth. He also supports the Bank of Japan's 2% inflation target and a 10 trillion yen university fund to promote renewable energy. Rival Sanae Takaichi, a conservative candidate, has launched her bid on strengthening security and boosting the economy, but faces long odds due to low popularity ratings.

site_title: UK PM's tax hikes a risky political gamble
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has raised the country's tax burden to its highest level in 70 years, sparking a risky political gamble. The new taxes will increase the personal tax burden to 35.5% of GDP, with a 1.25% "health and care" levy for young workers and a rise in corporate national insurance contributions. The measures aim to finance a £12 billion annual support package for the National Health Service and social care reform. Markets have responded unfavorably, with sterling and equities down, amid concerns about the impact on businesses and the economy.

site_title: Home... as work space and play space
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a shift in how homes are designed and used, with property developers creating residences that prioritize quality of life over space efficiency. These new developments incorporate features like greenery, communal areas, and flexible spaces, reflecting the "new kampong spirit" that values wellbeing. This trend is catching on, as home buyers increasingly seek homes that balance work, play, and relaxation, blurring the lines between home and workspace.

site_title: Global vaccine programme Covax cuts 2021 supply forecast
summary: The Covax global vaccine programme has cut its 2021 supply forecast by more than a quarter, citing delays in acquiring life-saving vaccines and export bans. The programme now expects 1.4 billion doses by the end of the year, down from a previous forecast of 1.9 billion. Wealthy countries have prioritized bilateral deals, hindering equitable vaccine distribution. Only a fifth of people in lower-income countries have received a first dose, compared to 80% in higher-income nations. Covax aims to hit 2 billion doses in the first quarter of 2022.

site_title: Ford hires former Apple executive in push for electric cars
summary: Ford Motor Company has hired Doug Field, former senior executive at Apple, to transform its vehicles into software-driven products that interact with customers. Field, who led Apple's electric vehicle project, will report to CEO Jim Farley and oversee the development of new services. Ford aims to build 40% of its vehicles electric by 2030 and compete with startups and tech companies for talent. The move marks a significant shift for Ford, which plans to build a team around Field to drive innovation and adoption of electric vehicles.

site_title: Japan upgrades Q2 GDP on stronger business spending
summary: Japan's economy grew faster than initially estimated in Q2, with an annualized 1.9% expansion, beating economists' median forecast. The growth was driven by solid capital expenditure, but a resurgence in Covid-19 is expected to undermine service-sector consumption. The revised GDP data surpasses the initial estimate of 1.3% expansion.

site_title: Unvaccinated 93-year-old woman dies of Covid-19; death toll at 56
summary: A 93-year-old unvaccinated Singaporean woman has died from complications due to Covid-19, increasing the country's death toll to 56. The woman developed symptoms on September 2 and was admitted to the National Centre for Infectious Diseases, where she tested positive for the coronavirus. There are no new emerging large clusters, and 19 new cases were linked to staff at five bus interchanges. Singapore reported 349 new Covid-19 cases, with 664 patients still in hospital, including 6 in critical condition.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat on fears of slowing economic growth
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened flat on Wednesday due to concerns over the spread of the Delta coronavirus variant and uncertainty over the Federal Reserve's accommodative policies. The Dow Jones fell 12.55 points, the S&P 500 dropped 1.94 points, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 13.98 points. The economic slowdown fears and US-EU tariff uncertainty are causing market volatility, with stocks continuing to edge down from record highs.

site_title: South Korea's Internet giants come under fire in echo of China crackdown
summary: South Korea's internet giants, Kakao Corp and Naver Corp, plummeted in value after lawmakers warned against abusing market dominance for profits. Kakao dropped over 11% and Naver slid over 8%, their biggest declines in years. Regulators and politicians expressed concerns about the growing power of internet firms, mirroring a China crackdown that erased over $1 trillion in value. South Korean lawmakers have targeted tech companies for monopolistic behavior and corruption scandals, with a focus on platform operators in upcoming audits.

site_title: Evergrande slumps below 2009 IPO price after Fitch downgrade
summary: Evergrande Group shares dropped below their 2009 IPO price after Fitch Ratings downgraded the company to CC, citing a probable default due to worsening liquidity issues. The stock fell 2.8% to HK$3.47, while Evergrande's dollar bonds hovered below 30 cents. The company has over US$300 billion of liabilities, posing a risk to lenders, suppliers, and homebuyers if it collapses. Chinese authorities have kept quiet about their plans, and Evergrande itself warned of default risks if it fails to raise cash.

site_title: SGX RegCo orders Nutryfarm International to appoint independent reviewer to conduct investigation
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has ordered Nutryfarm International to appoint an independent reviewer to investigate two key issues, including a significant refundable deposit and advances made to a Chinese company. The issues relate to the proposed acquisitions of tech companies and the repayment of the deposit. The independent reviewer's findings will be directly reported to SGX RegCo. This move comes after Nutryfarm's shares fell 5.41% on Wednesday.

site_title: Aramco oil pipelines investors to sell at least US$4b in bonds in Q4
summary: A consortium led by EIG Global Energy Partners is set to issue at least $4 billion in bonds in the fourth quarter to refinance a $12.4 billion loan for a stake in Saudi Aramco's oil pipelines. The deal, which gave the consortium a 49% stake in Aramco Oil Pipelines Company, was backed by $10.5 billion financing from major banks. The bonds will be refinanced across two or three deals, with the first transaction likely to occur in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Miyoshi reports loss of major project in Philippines
summary: Miyoshi Limited, a components manufacturer, announced it will lose a major project in the Philippines due to a customer's decision to consolidate its production line. The registered activity in Manila will cease from November 30, 2021, affecting 18.4% of revenue from the subsidiary. This is expected to impact the group's consolidated net tangible assets and earnings per share by 1.2% and 48.5%, respectively. The company's shares dropped 2.63% to close at 3.7 Singapore cents.

site_title: 347 new locally transmitted Covid-19 cases in Singapore
summary: There were 347 new locally transmitted COVID-19 cases in Singapore as of Wednesday noon, September 8, 2021. Three of the cases were seniors aged above 70 who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated. Two of the new cases were imported, both of whom developed the illness while in isolation or serving a stay-home notice. The total number of cases in Singapore stands at 69,582.

site_title: US job openings rose to a record 10.9m in July
summary: US job openings reached a record 10.9 million in July, surpassing June's revised 10.2 million. This increase, more than economists expected, highlights staffing shortages as businesses struggle to meet demand. The gap between openings and hires was 4.3 million, the largest since 2000, with the quits rate remaining near a record 2.7%. The labor market's rapid recovery from pandemic-related factors is expected to ease hiring constraints as schools reopen, but the Delta variant's impact may delay significant improvement.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong urges companies and directors to restructure and innovate to avoid being left behind. He noted that the gap between leaders and laggards will continue to widen if firms do not continually innovate, as the business landscape continues to evolve.

site_title: China's regulatory reforms bring it closer to global best practices
summary: China's regulatory reforms have brought the country closer to global best practices, with notable improvements in its financial sector. The reforms have reduced debt levels, particularly in the property sector, from 78% of GDP in 2016 to 54% today. This reduction has alleviated concerns about credit defaults and contagion. While the crackdown on tech and other sectors has raised eyebrows, the regulatory reforms demonstrate China's commitment to addressing issues and aligning with international standards.

site_title: Gates' firm buys part of Saudi billionaire's Four Seasons stake
summary: Bill Gates' investment firm, Cascade Investment, agreed to purchase a 23.75% stake in Four Seasons Holding from Kingdom Holding for $2.2 billion, taking its total shareholding to 71.25%. The deal has a $10 billion enterprise value and is expected to close in January 2022. Kingdom Holding expects a $1.57 billion gain and plans to use the proceeds for investments and loan repayment. The relationship between Gates and Prince Alwaleed bin Talal dates back decades, with Gates calling him an "important partner" in their charitable work.

site_title: Yellen sees US debt-limit measures exhausted in October
summary: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned Congress that the US will likely exhaust its ability to avoid breaching the federal debt limit in October, prompting renewed calls to boost or suspend the ceiling. Yellen said cash and extraordinary measures will run out during the month, citing unpredictable spending and revenue flows linked to the pandemic. Democrats are expected to attach a debt limit measure to a stopgap spending bill, while almost all Republican senators oppose lifting or suspending the limit, citing opposition to a $3.5 trillion social spending package.

site_title: AirAsia reports smaller Q2 loss, lockdown slowed sales
summary: AirAsia Group reported a smaller loss in Q2, with net loss decreasing 41.6% to RM580 million, compared to RM992 million last year. Revenue jumped 160% to RM370 million, driven by cargo and logistics revenues. The airline carried 758,746 passengers, a 272% increase, and achieved a 68% load factor. AirAsia has sufficient liquidity and plans to raise up to RM1 billion through a rights issue by the end of the year, with the goal of completing lease restructuring by the end of 2021.

site_title: Ryanair says UK lagging Europe on post-Covid recovery
summary: Ryanair executives stated that the UK is lagging in Europe's post-Covid recovery due to confusing Covid-19 restrictions and airports will struggle in the winter. The airline's CEO, Eddie Wilson, cited Brexit border controls and Covid as major issues. The UK's abrupt changes in travel risk classifications this summer caused frustration among tourists, leading to lower bookings. Ryanair announced failed talks with Boeing over a MAX 737 plane order, with CEO Michael O'Leary waiting up to 10 years for a downturn in prices. British airports are expected to struggle over the winter period.

site_title: COE premiums end mostly higher, with more orders collected in 3-week break
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums ended mostly higher in the latest tender, with the COE for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp closing at S$47,000, a 13-basis-point increase from the previous three-week break. The higher premiums are attributed to increased demand for COEs during the break.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end the day lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day lower on profit-taking after a recent run-up, closing 0.12% down at 26,320.93. The decline followed a tepid Wall Street lead amid concerns over the spread of the Delta Covid variant.

site_title: UK's Smiths to sell medical division to ICU for US$2.4b, snubs TA
summary: UK-based industrial technology group Smiths has agreed to sell its medical division to ICU Medical for $2.4 billion, scrapping a previous deal with private equity firm TA Associates. The sale, expected to close in the first half of next year, will generate $1.85 billion in initial net proceeds for Smiths. The deal marks a strategic move for ICU Medical to create a leading infusion therapy company, and Smiths expects a 55% shareholder return via a share buyback. The move follows another bidding war for a British medical company, with shares in Smiths rising 4% in early trade.

site_title: Thai bus brings vaccines to Bangkok's vulnerable
summary: Thailand's capital, Bangkok, launched a pilot bus service to vaccinate the elderly and vulnerable groups against Covid-19. The mobile vaccination team, equipped with a bus, aims to reach those who struggle to travel far from their homes. The service, which can inoculate over 1,000 individuals a day, is part of Thailand's efforts to speed up its inoculation campaign amid a severe outbreak driven by the Delta variant. The pilot program is expected to expand to other locations once procedures are ironed out.

images.alt_text: Thailand's capital launched on Wednesday a pilot bus service to ensure that the elderly and other vulnerable groups in Bangkok are vaccinated against Covid-19, underscoring the country's push to speed up its inoculation campaign.

site_title: Singapore's TDCX files for IPO on NYSE
summary: Singapore-headquartered TDCX, a digital customer experience services provider, has filed for an initial public offering (IPO) on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) with an offering of American depositary shares. Founded in 1995, TDCX offers omnichannel CX solutions, sales, and digital marketing services, with operations in 10 markets and a workforce of over 13,000. The company aims to use IPO proceeds to repay debt and expand into new markets, including Korea and China.

site_title: World's largest plant capturing carbon from air starts in Iceland
summary: The world's largest plant capturing carbon from the air, the Orca plant, is set to start operating in Iceland. Developed by Climeworks and Carbfix, the plant can capture up to 4,000 tons of CO2 per year, equivalent to the annual emissions from about 790 cars. Direct air capture technology is seen as vital to limit global warming and is being scaled up by companies like Climeworks, with 15 plants operating worldwide, capturing over 9,000 tonnes of CO2 per year.

site_title: APRW partners NTU's Wee Kim Wee School to launch student fund to drive industry forward
summary: APRW, a Singapore public relations agency, has partnered with Nanyang Technological University's Wee Kim Wee School of Communication and Information (NTU WKWSCI) to launch a student development fund. The fund aims to nurture the next generation of communication professionals by supporting final-year projects and recognizing outstanding projects with the APRW Excellence Award. The agency plans to raise S$160,000 and encourages clients and partners to contribute to the fund. This collaboration marks APRW's 25th anniversary and aims to leave a lasting legacy for the next generation of communication professionals in Singapore.

site_title: Singapore stocks track Wall Street losses, STI down 1.27%
summary: Singapore stocks ended Wednesday in negative territory, tracking overnight losses on Wall Street. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,068.94 points, down 1.27% or 39.59 points. Investors are grappling with concerns over rising Covid-19 cases. This is the second consecutive day of losses for the STI.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall 1% on growth worries
summary: European stocks fell 1% on Wednesday, their biggest decline in three weeks, due to concerns over slowing global growth. Investors awaited the European Central Bank meeting for hints on tapering plans. Declines were seen in Swedish EQT (-5.9%), Stellantis (-2.5%), and French Sanofi (-1.4%), while British Smiths Group rose 3.8% after selling its medical unit. The Stoxx 600 index also faced losses after overnight declines on the S&P 500 and Asian stocks.

site_title: BT's Top Stories from Last Week
summary: Singapore is tightening its criteria for Employment Passes and S Passes, amid growing resentment towards foreign work pass holders. The country has also increased development charge rates for non-landed residential use by 10.9%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has banned Binance.com from unlicensed payment services and added it to its Investor Alert List. Meanwhile, a state tender for a commercial and residential site at Jalan Anak Bukit was awarded to Far East Organization and Sino Group with a joint bid of S$1.03 billion.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 14.15 points to 1,597.63 on Wednesday, driven by higher trading volume of 5.915 billion lots worth RM3.240 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 707 to 374.

site_title: Credit Suisse names compliance chief after twin scandals
summary: Credit Suisse named Rafael Lopez Lorenzo as its new chief compliance officer, effective October 1, replacing Lara Warner after the twin scandals involving Greensill Capital and Archegos Capital Management. This move follows the bank's efforts to rebuild its management ranks, including the hiring of David Wildermuth as chief risk officer. The bank has also taken steps to address concerns about controls, risk management, and corporate culture, including separating the roles of chief risk officer and chief compliance officer and recouping $70 million in pay.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end higher on stimulus hopes
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.89% to 30,181.21, driven by hopes for a new stimulus package from Japan's new prime minister. The cheap yen offset profit-taking. The broader Topix index also rose 0.79% to 2,079.61. The gains were seen as a positive sign for the market, despite ongoing concerns about the impact of US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Evergrande crisis means suppliers get paid in unbuilt properties
summary: China Evergrande Group is offering real estate projects to suppliers and contractors to offset missed payments, a practice known as commercial bills. Suppliers like Skshu Paint have signed agreements to receive unfinished projects, including three in 2022, 2023, and 2024. Evergrande's trade payables reached a record 951 billion yuan, accounting for almost half of its total liabilities, while its debt decreased to a five-year low. The company has paid 235 million yuan worth of overdue commercial bills, mostly in the form of unfinished properties, and is negotiating with suppliers to resume work on suspended projects.

site_title: Maersk joins Buffett to invest in startup promising green fuel
summary: AP Moller-Maersk has agreed to invest in WasteFuel, a California-based startup that converts trash into green fuels, backed by Warren Buffett. The investment aims to develop energy that doesn't pollute and meets Maersk's goal to be carbon neutral by 2050. Maersk plans to buy more green fuel startups, expecting the investment to help WasteFuel build bio-refineries, with the first fuel expected to be ready in 2024. The deal is part of Maersk's strategy to de-carbonize its fleet and stimulate the market for green technologies.

site_title: Steel demand, new investment from Hong Leong Asia give BRC Asia a boost
summary: BRC Asia, a steel products seller, has seen strong revenue and earnings growth despite the construction sector's turmoil. The company's revenue rose 68% to S$832.9 million in the nine months ended June 30, driven by a rebound in demand for steel products. BRC Asia has attracted the attention of conglomerate Hong Leong Asia, which has invested in the company and plans to expand overseas through collaboration. The company's growth outlook appears good, with the construction sector expected to improve, but its financial strength remains a concern.

site_title: ByteDance in talks with banks to borrow over US$3b: sources
summary: ByteDance, the owner of TikTok, is in talks with Wall Street banks to borrow over $3 billion to refinance its debt. The company plans to take advantage of low interest rates to repay its debt and fund overseas expansion. The loan size is expected to be between $4 billion and $5 billion, according to The Information. ByteDance had previously explored a public listing but now has no imminent plans for an initial public offering. The company's debt refinancing is part of its efforts to maintain financial stability amid growing competition and regulatory scrutiny.

site_title: PayPal heats up buy now, pay later race with US$2.7b Japan deal
summary: PayPal is acquiring Japanese buy now, pay later (BNPL) firm Paidy in a $2.7 billion deal, expanding its capabilities and presence in the domestic payments market in Japan. This move tracks rival Square's acquisition of Afterpay and is seen as a consolidation in the sector. PayPal's acquisition will not significantly impact its earnings, with the deal expected to close in the fourth quarter of 2021. Paidy will continue to operate independently, with its founder and chairman and president and CEO remaining in their roles.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end at one-week low as Kakao, Naver drop on regulatory risks
summary: South Korean stocks ended at a one-week low, closing 0.77% down at 3,162.99, due to regulatory risks and concerns over local Covid-19 cases. The Kospi benchmark fell 24.43 points, with technology heavyweights Kakao and Naver dropping 10.06% and 7.87% respectively. The won weakened, while the 10-year yield rose 4.2 basis points to 2.016%. The Korea Disease Control and Prevention Agency reported 2,050 new Covid-19 cases, contributing to the market's decline.

site_title: HSBC makes new Singapore-based appointments
summary: HSBC has appointed a new Singapore-based direct real estate team as part of its strategy to build out its alternatives businesses. Led by Victoria Sharpe, managing principal and head of real estate, Asia Pacific, the team will focus on strategic growth across the region. The appointment is part of HSBC's efforts to expand its insurance and wealth franchise in Asia.

site_title: UOBKH sees negative risk-reward payoff in Malaysia glove sector, advises minimal exposure
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) maintains its "underweight" recommendation on Malaysia's glove sector due to a negative risk-reward payoff. The analyst expects sector net profit to grow 62% in 2021 and decline 82% in 2022, with ASPs normalizing sooner than expected in mid-2022. The firm advises investors to minimize exposure to the sector, citing unfavourable reward-to-risk payoff.

site_title: Toshiba panel has evaluated privatisation, board undecided
summary: Toshiba Corp's board is undecided on whether to take the conglomerate private, despite exploring strategic alternatives. The panel has engaged with potential investors and is considering options to enhance corporate value and address issues related to potential privatization. This comes after Toshiba started weighing strategic options in May, following years of scandal and allegations of mismanagement. The company's share price has declined significantly since its heyday in the 1980s. Toshiba's board will continue to explore feasible strategic alternatives and will make a decision once they have a better understanding of investors' approaches.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index down 0.34% or 100.87 points at 29,815.27. Investors sought to lock in profits after recent rallies. The broader Topix index also edged down 0.2%. The market reaction was likely due to investors' caution ahead of the US Federal Reserve's upcoming decisions.

site_title: Japan PM contender Kishida says new form of capitalism needed to end disparity, recover from pandemic
summary: Former Japanese Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida has announced his candidacy to become the country's next prime minister, vowing to implement a new form of capitalism to address widening income disparity and stimulate economic growth. Kishida's economic proposals include a tens of trillions of yen stimulus package and a 10 trillion yen university fund to promote renewable energy. Rival Taro Kono and Sanae Takaichi, who is expected to announce her candidacy later, have also signaled their ambitions to run. The leadership election is set for September 29, with the winner all but assured to become Japan's next prime minister.

site_title: France's Sanofi to buy US biopharma firm Kadmon in US$1.9b deal
summary: French pharmaceutical company Sanofi has agreed to purchase US biopharma firm Kadmon Holdings Inc in a $1.9 billion deal. Sanofi offered $9.50 per share, representing a fully diluted value of $1.9 billion, and both companies' boards have unanimously approved the transaction. The acquisition is expected to expand Sanofi's pipeline of treatments for various diseases.

site_title: Indonesia-only Intudo Ventures closes US$115m fund for South-east Asia startups
summary: Indonesian venture capital firm Intudo Ventures has closed a $115 million fund to invest in early-stage startups in Southeast Asia. The third fund will focus on about a dozen Indonesian startups driven by rising private consumption and digitization. About 70% of the capital comes from investors outside Indonesia, with notable backers including Wasson Enterprise and Black Kite Investments. Intudo will maintain its focus on Series A investments, contrasting with other firms that have expanded regionally or launched growth-stage funds.

site_title: Private equity-backed firms shut out black directors, data show
summary: A new report by the Board Diversity Action Alliance found that private equity-backed companies have few minority directors, with black directors holding only 1% of board seats and women holding about 10%. The report analyzed data from companies that went public since 2000 and found slow progress for minorities. In contrast, women saw significant gains, with the number of female directors increasing from 19 to 189. The report calls for greater transparency and inclusivity in the venture capital and private equity industries, which are key drivers of US economic growth.

site_title: US to discuss way forward on Iran in Moscow, Paris talks
summary: US Special Envoy for Iran Robert Malley will visit Moscow and Paris for talks with Russian and European officials on Iran's nuclear program. The talks will focus on Iran's return to compliance with the 2015 Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action. The US is seeking a mutual return to compliance, but its approach remains uncertain. The visit comes as Iran's nuclear program advances and indirect talks on reviving the deal last took place on June 20. Washington is also exploring alternatives if Iran is not interested in a return to the deal.

site_title: China's long-term economic policy unchanged amid regulatory wave: People's Daily
summary: China's long-term economic policy remains unchanged despite recent regulatory measures. The country is imposing regulations to promote the healthy development of industries, particularly the private economy, and to curb "barbaric growth" of platform companies. Chinese authorities have pledged continued support for the private sector and aim to treat all companies equally, without targeting specific firms. The regulations, which have achieved "early results," are designed to guide companies to obey the Communist Party's leadership and promote fair competition. China will continue to open up to foreign capital and protect its rights and interests.

site_title: Ray Dalio says China, Singapore opportunities can't be neglected
summary: Billionaire investor Ray Dalio, founder of Bridgewater Associates, emphasizes the importance of investing in China and Singapore, citing his personal investments and philanthropic commitments. Despite market volatility and crackdowns, Dalio views China as an opportunity that cannot be neglected. His family office has expanded to Singapore, and he supports the reformation of capitalism to address the wealth gap. Dalio's comments come amid debate among Wall Street investors about the long-term viability of investing in China.

site_title: Four-storey hotel along Sims Avenue up for sale with S$23m guide price
summary: A four-storey hotel on Sims Avenue, Singapore, is up for sale with a guide price of S$23 million. The freehold hotel has 46 rooms and is located near Kallang MRT and major expressways. The sale is expected to benefit from Singapore's strong tourism and hospitality sector recovery, driven by high vaccination rates and easing border restrictions. The property is also situated between two growth centers, attracting high-net-worth individuals, corporate investors, and family offices. The sale will be conducted through an expression of interest exercise closing on October 14.

site_title: Kakao, Naver shares plunge after Korea lawmakers attack Internet giants
summary: South Korean lawmakers have criticized internet giants Kakao and Naver for pursuing profits and abusing market dominance. Kakao plummeted 11% and Naver slid 8% after lawmakers warned against ignoring fair competition and raising service prices. The comments sparked fears of policy reforms to rein in the influence of these companies, which dominate Korea's economy and have encroached on the market share of decades-old chaebol. The criticism marks a strong critique of the country's fast-expanding internet sector.

site_title: Gold steadies below US$1,800 as firm dollar, yields weigh
summary: Gold prices steadied at US$1,796.03 per ounce, after slipping 1.6% in the previous session due to a firm dollar and rising US Treasury yields. The benchmark 10-year Treasury note rose to 1.385%, increasing the opportunity cost of holding non-interest bearing bullion. Spot gold hovered near a one-week low of US$1,791.90, while silver, platinum, and palladium also saw slight gains.

site_title: Investors call for private firms to disclose more environmental data
summary: Investors managing $2.3 trillion in assets have called for over 1,000 private companies to disclose environmental data through the CDP platform to address transparency gaps with listed peers. The Private Markets Pilot aims to encourage private companies to measure and disclose their carbon impacts, enabling investors to make informed decisions and meet their net-zero emissions commitments by 2050. The move follows record capital flows into private equity and debt markets, and comes as investors risk investing in high-carbon assets from listed companies.

site_title: Fitch downgrades China Evergrande's ratings, sees 'probable' default
summary: Fitch Ratings downgraded China Evergrande Group and two of its subsidiaries to "very high credit risk" due to a probable default. The downgrade reflects the company's tight liquidity, declining contracted sales, and limited progress on asset disposals. This move follows recent downgrades by Moody's and China Chengxin International. Evergrande's shares fell 3.08% and its bond price dropped 0.57% on the day, with the bond's price falling nearly 50% since its rating downgrade. A default appears probable, increasing credit risk.

site_title: Nine in 10 Taiwanese executives expect business growth in Asean: survey
summary: Taiwanese executives are optimistic about business growth in ASEAN, with 9 out of 10 companies expecting an increase in revenue and production over the next 12 months. The top ASEAN markets for expansion are Singapore, the Philippines, and Malaysia, with 43%, 39%, and 34% of respondents respectively considering them the most promising markets. Key drivers for expansion include access to the large ASEAN consumer market, a mature supplier base, and global market access enabled by FTAs. Companies also identify risks such as the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic and geopolitical uncertainty, and are prioritizing sustainability, partnerships, and cybersecurity initiatives to mitigate these risks.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares fall at Wednesday's open
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 0.75 points or 0.1% to 1,582.73 at the open on Wednesday, with 189.3 million lots traded worth RM67.1 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 173 to 154.

site_title: E-commerce startup Rainforest raises US$20m in pre-Series A funds
summary: Rainforest, a Singapore-based e-commerce brand aggregator, has raised US$20 million in pre-Series A funding led by Monk's Hill Ventures. The funds will be used to "double down on aggressive growth strategy" and acquire more Asia-based e-commerce brands to scale up and expand globally. Since its launch in January 2021, Rainforest has acquired six brands, with its portfolio seeing over 50% improvement in post-acquisition growth rates. The company plans to grow its portfolio by three times by end-2021 and has named two vice-president hires for acquisitions and brands.

site_title: Motor insurer Marshmallow becomes first Black-founded UK unicorn
summary: Digital motor insurer Marshmallow has raised US$85 million, valuing it at over US$1.25 billion, becoming the first Black-founded UK unicorn. The company, founded in 2017, plans to expand into overseas markets and other insurance types, with a goal to hire 400 more employees. Marshmallow's Series B funding round follows a US$30 million Series A round in 2020, and the company has a diverse workforce, including a 50:50 male-female split and nearly 20% Black or ethnic minority employees.

site_title: AA Reit chief executive Koh Wee Lih resigns, to be replaced by investment head
summary: AIMS APAC Reit (AA Reit) announced the resignation of its CEO Koh Wee Lih, effective November 28, 2021, to pursue other professional interests. Koh will work with the board and new CEO-designate Russell Ng, 40, who assumes the role on November 29. Ng, previously head of investor relations and investments at AA Reit, has held senior roles at Lendlease and AEP Investment Management. The board expressed appreciation for Koh's contributions and wished him well in his future endeavors.

site_title: Oil slides on demand concerns, strong dollar
summary: Oil prices fell due to a strong US dollar and concerns about weak demand in the US and Asia. US West Texas Intermediate crude settled down 1.4% at $68.35 a barrel, while Brent crude futures fell 0.7% to $71.69 a barrel. Saudi Arabia's move to cut crude prices for Asia by at least $1 a barrel was seen as a sign of fading Asian demand, despite China's strong economic indicators, including a 8% increase in crude oil imports in August. Ongoing production outages on the US Gulf Coast also supported prices.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as commodities slump hits gold, miners
summary: Australian shares fell 0.4% as the country's mining and gold sectors were hit by a demand crunch and a strong US dollar. The benchmark ASX 200 index dropped to 7,497.40 points. Gold prices saw their biggest intraday drop in a month, while copper prices hit their lowest in five months. New Covid-19 cases in Sydney fell for a third straight day, and vaccination efforts continued.

site_title: SEC threatens to sue Coinbase over crypto lending programme
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has threatened to sue Coinbase Global if it proceeds with its planned "Lend" product, allowing users to earn interest by lending crypto assets. The SEC issued a Wells notice, which indicates an intention to sue, and Coinbase has delayed the product's launch until at least October. The move comes as regulators in the US raise concerns about crypto lending programmes and their compliance with existing securities laws.

site_title: Oxley offers to buy back 5.7% notes due 2022; reopens issue of 6.9% notes due 2024
summary: Oxley Holdings is offering to purchase 5.7% notes due 2022 in cash at 100% of principal amount, plus accrued interest, totaling S$150 million. The company also plans to issue new 6.9% notes due 2024, reopening the existing issue, to finance the purchase and for general corporate purposes. The move aims to reduce debt and enhance the company's debt structure. Noteholders can sell their notes and subscribe to the new issue, with priority allocation for those who tender their notes.

site_title: Ooredoo's Indonesian unit weighs sale of data centres: sources
summary: Indosat, the Indonesian wireless carrier unit of Qatar's Ooredoo, is considering the sale of its data centers business amid industry consolidation. The Jakarta-listed company is working with a financial adviser and could fetch US$150-200 million in a sale. Potential buyers include infrastructure investors and telecommunications companies, according to sources. The move is seen as a strategic shift in the company's business operations.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.16% to 26,396.11, following a recent rally. However, gains were tempered by weak leads from Wall Street and profit-taking. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite and Shenzhen Composite Index were down 0.09% and flat, respectively.

site_title: JetBlue names interim finance chief Hurley to job permanently
summary: JetBlue Airways Corp. named Ursula Hurley, a 17-year veteran, as its permanent chief financial officer, expanding the number of women in top positions. Hurley, who previously held roles including head of treasury and investor relations, led efforts to raise capital and cut costs during the pandemic. JetBlue CEO Robin Hayes also agreed to a contract extension through September 1, 2023.

site_title: Japan's PHC, formerly Panasonic Healthcare, announces 197.7b yen IPO
summary: Japan's Panasonic Healthcare, now PHC Holdings, is set to list on the Tokyo Stock Exchange on October 14 with an initial public offering (IPO) worth up to 197.7 billion yen. The company, which is 45.77% owned by US private equity firm KKR & Co, will offer up to 53.4 million shares at an indicative price of 3,700 yen per share, valuing the company at 452 billion yen. PHC reported revenue of $2.8 billion in the year ended in March and has a global workforce of over 9,700.

site_title: BlackRock sets up US$1b maiden China fund
summary: BlackRock has raised 6.7 billion yuan (S$1.39 billion) for its first China mutual fund, exceeding 111,000 investor participation. The fund starts onshore investments, following a successful fundraising campaign. Despite criticism from billionaire George Soros, BlackRock is tapping China's asset management industry, which has seen over 2 trillion yuan in new mutual fund launches this year. The company aims to provide long-term investment opportunities for Chinese investors.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Wednesday; STI down 0.9%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Wednesday, tracking losses on Wall Street, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.9% or 26.96 points at 3,081.57. Losers outnumbered gainers 90 to 42, with local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC down 1.3%, 1.4%, and 0.9% respectively. The decline follows a generally negative day on Wall Street, where the Dow Jones and S&P 500 declined 0.8% and 0.3% respectively, amid concerns over rising coronavirus cases.

site_title: New disclosure standards for Singapore retail ESG funds due early 2022: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to introduce new disclosure standards for retail ESG funds in early 2022. The standards will require funds to provide more detailed information on their investment process, risks, and ESG strategy, helping investors make more informed decisions. The move aims to address concerns over greenwashing and improve the quality and comparability of ESG data. MAS also announced the establishment of the Sustainable and Green Finance Institute, which will focus on developing a sustainability and impact measurement framework and providing training for companies to integrate sustainability considerations into their business strategies.

site_title: ESG asset managers need to ask the 'why'
summary: Asset managers with ESG ambitions must define their "why" from the outset, outlining what they mean by ESG and how it will benefit non-financial outcomes. Clients are increasingly discerning and can distinguish between authentic and greenwashed ESG strategies. To build credibility, asset managers must collaborate with industry players, NGOs, and regulators, and demonstrate expertise on specific issues. Effective use of data requires careful sourcing, integration, and disclosure, and asset managers must be transparent about their ESG goals and progress. Ultimately, ESG credibility and authenticity require a genuine commitment to positive, non-financial outcomes.

site_title: Asia eyes Australia blueprint as US$100b oil, gas clean-up looms
summary: Australia has passed legislation requiring former owners of oil and gas fields to pay for the costs of dismantling facilities, even if later owners go bankrupt. The US$100 billion estimated cost of decommissioning offshore facilities in the Asia-Pacific region by 2050 is expected to be a major challenge. The new law introduces "trailing liability," holding former owners liable for decommissioning if a current owner fails, potentially deterring the sale of mature fields to niche players with low overheads. This precedent could set a new standard for governments in Asia to scrutinize asset sales and ensure financial and technical capacity for decommissioning.

site_title: Lawrence Wong urges companies, directors to start thinking ahead, restructure
summary: Finance Minister Lawrence Wong urges companies and directors to start restructuring and transforming to stay ahead in the future. He notes that firms must continually innovate and optimise operations to improve productivity. Wong suggests companies can reconfigure their operations, pivot to adjacent emerging sectors, or consolidate and merge. The government has existing programmes to support companies adopting new digital solutions and upskilling workers. Wong encourages companies with good ideas to explore opportunities with the relevant agency, citing the need for creative destruction to ensure a continued renewal and rejuvenation of businesses.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Oxley, Keppel Corp, Frencken Group, SIA Engineering
summary: Oxley Holdings is offering to purchase a portion of its outstanding 5.7% notes due 2022 in cash. Keppel Corporation priced S$400 million in 2.90% subordinated perpetual securities. Frencken Group acquired Avimac for S$14 million to expand its business. SIA Engineering launched a training academy focused on Lean methodologies, investing S$10 million in the second phase of its Lean transformation program.

site_title: Energy geopolitics clouds Germany's post-Merkel election
summary: Germany prepares to elect a new chancellor on September 26, amid a complex energy geopolitics landscape. The Nord Stream 2 pipeline, which doubles Russia's natural gas supply to Europe, has sparked controversy, with US President Biden viewing it as a threat to EU security and Ukraine's interests. Germany's outgoing Chancellor Angela Merkel has promoted the pipeline to enhance energy security, despite opposition from Western allies. The winner of the election will face challenges in navigating this issue, as well as post-pandemic global challenges, and reconsolidating the Western alliance.

site_title: Bitcoin drops to lowest in month as El Salvador rollout falters
summary: Bitcoin dropped 17% to its lowest level in a month, falling to US$43,050, amid El Salvador's rollout of its cryptocurrency as legal tender. The selloff, accelerated by the liquidation of over 336,000 traders' accounts worth US$3.6 billion, was attributed to "mystery selloffs" and poor seasonality. Despite recouping some losses, Bitcoin remains down 9.9% at US$46,781, with other coins like Cardano and Dogecoin also experiencing significant declines.

site_title: Shareholders may pursue some 737 MAX claims against Boeing board, court rules
summary: A Delaware judge ruled that Boeing's board of directors must face a lawsuit from shareholders over two fatal 737 MAX crashes, which killed 346 people. The court found evidence that the board "knowingly fell short" of safety monitoring and "publicly lied" about its actions. The ruling allows shareholders to pursue some claims against the board, but dismissed others. Boeing has been charged with 737 MAX fraud conspiracy and agreed to a $2.5 billion settlement. The decision clears the way for additional discovery and potentially a trial, although a trial is considered unlikely.

site_title: China's e-sports powerhouse status undermined by tough new gaming rules
summary: China's e-sports industry is facing significant challenges due to new gaming rules limiting online games for under-18s to 3 hours a week, a drastic reduction from the current 1.5 hours on weekdays and 3 hours on weekends. The rules, aimed at curbing gaming addiction, are expected to undermine the industry's growth and make it harder for young players to become professional e-sports athletes, who typically start training in their teens and retire in their mid-20s. Experts warn that the rules will also harm the industry's massive fan base and the lucrative business of e-sports tournaments.

site_title: Microsoft rolls out personalised news feed
summary: Microsoft has rolled out a personalized news feed called Microsoft Start, available as a website and mobile app, to compete with news feeds from Apple, Google, and third-party apps. The feed aggregates content from news publishers and personalizes it based on user choices, according to a company blog post. This move aims to enhance user experience and provide a unique offering in the market.

site_title: Britney's father files to end conservatorship: US media
summary: Britney Spears' father, Jamie Spears, has filed a petition to end his daughter's 14-year conservatorship, citing changes in circumstances that render the arrangement no longer necessary. Britney, 39, has repeatedly expressed her desire to regain control over her life, finances, and medical decisions. The petition comes after Jamie Spears stated he was prepared to step back from his role as conservator and after Britney's supporters, including her lawyer Mathew Rosengart, called for his removal. The outcome of the petition is uncertain, but it marks a significant development in the highly publicized conservatorship saga.

site_title: US: Nasdaq edges to record on mostly down day for stocks
summary: US stocks ended the day with mixed results, with the Nasdaq edging out a record high despite a generally negative day for the market. Analysts cited concerns over the Delta variant and disappointing jobs data as factors in the session's lackluster performance. The Dow Jones fell 0.8% and the S&P 500 shed 0.3%, while the Nasdaq Composite Index added 0.1% to reach a fourth consecutive record. Markets are monitoring the expiration of federal aid programs for workers, which ended on September 6.

site_title: Qantas to test new overseas routes as countries reopen again
summary: Qantas plans to resume international flights from December, with a focus on new overseas routes as countries reopen. CEO Alan Joyce stated the airline will attempt multiple new international routes as borders open, including revisiting non-stop services to London and New York. Qantas has given away 220 million loyalty points to encourage vaccination. The airline will only carry inoculated passengers on international flights, with the main unresolved issue being quarantine for those returning to Australia. This will be addressed by allowing self-isolation at home before returning a negative test.

site_title: China's KE Holdings exploring Hong Kong listing: sources
summary: China's housing broker KE Holdings is exploring a Hong Kong stock market listing, backed by Tencent Holdings and SoftBank Group Corp. The company, which raised $2.1 billion in its New York IPO last year, is now considering a dual-primary listing in Hong Kong, potentially raising the same sum. Despite a regulatory crackdown, KE is still seeking fundraising opportunities, but a Hong Kong listing could be delayed due to its weighted voting rights structure, which may pose obstacles for listing.

site_title: Firmer US yields push dollar higher for second day
summary: The US dollar rose for a second consecutive day, moving away from its near one-month low, due to firming US Treasury yields. The dollar index rose 0.1% to 92.25, driven by rising 10-year yields near 1.36%. The euro remained supported ahead of the European Central Bank's policy meeting, while the Australian dollar was volatile due to the central bank's decision to extend the timeline of tapering its bond buying.

site_title: US unemployment benefits expire for millions without pushback from Biden
summary: US unemployment benefits for 7.5 million people expired on Monday without objection from President Joe Biden or his top economic advisers, as the delta variant affects the pandemic recovery. The $1.9 trillion economic aid package, signed in March, included extended and expanded benefits for unemployed workers, including a $300 federal supplement. Republicans and small-business owners argue the extension has hindered the economic recovery, while liberal Democrats push for additional aid. The administration believes the economy is transitioning to a labour market-driven recovery, with more Americans returning to work and drawing paychecks.

site_title: In world first, Bitcoin becomes legal tender in El Salvador
summary: El Salvador has become the world's first country to accept Bitcoin as legal tender, despite widespread domestic skepticism. The move is aimed at increasing access to banking services and saving $400 million in remittance fees. However, opinion polls show a majority of the population, 6.5 million people, reject the idea and will continue using the US dollar.

site_title: Snap 14-day WFH for firms if infected workers are in office in past week
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower (MOM) has updated guidelines requiring firms with employees who tested positive for Covid-19 to implement a 14-day work-from-home (WFH) period for all employees who were in the workplace within the past week. Employers must also monitor workers' health and ensure proper cleaning and disinfection of affected areas. The move aims to prevent potential outbreaks and protect workers.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip from recent highs, telecom deals in focus
summary: European stocks slipped 0.5% on Tuesday as caution ahead of the European Central Bank meeting drove down the Stoxx 600 index. Telecom deals, including a share-swap deal between Deutsche Telekom and SoftBank Group, led the market. Despite a 4.1% rise in KPN and a 0.1% increase in the telecoms index, the Stoxx 600 fell as investors anticipated tighter monetary policy and a potential slowdown in economic growth.

site_title: Afghan art activist defiant as Taliban erase Kabul murals
summary: Afghan art activist Omaid Sharifi's art collective, ArtLords, had created over 2,200 murals across the country since 2014, promoting peace, social justice, and accountability. However, after the Taliban took control of Kabul, many of the murals were painted over, replaced by propaganda slogans. Sharifi, who was forced to flee for his safety, vowed to continue his campaign, saying "We will never stay silent" and that the Taliban will be "shamed every single day." Despite being unable to express himself freely, Sharifi remains committed to his art and his message, determined to continue fighting for his country's rights.

site_title: Can shipping achieve zero carbon by 2050?
summary: US President Joe Biden aims to achieve zero carbon emissions from shipping by 2050, but industry experts see this as a massive challenge. Technologies to decarbonize shipping are known, but investment and scaling up are needed. Despite initial comments from outside the industry, achieving zero carbon by 2050 will require significant efforts and investment.

site_title: Freehold's premium may provide clue on valuing infrastructure spend
summary: Singapore property buyers are willing to pay a 15-20% premium for freehold tenures over 99-year leasehold condominiums, according to a study by the National University of Singapore. The study found low and declining long-run discount rates, suggesting buyers value long-term assets. The researchers believe this could inform policymakers in valuing infrastructure projects and mitigating climate change. The study's findings suggest buyers are patient and willing to pay a premium for long-term assets, similar to investing in environmental safeguards.

site_title: Australia's central bank sticks to tapering, but extends timeline
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has confirmed plans to trim its massive bond buying program by A$1 billion a week to A$4 billion, extending the timeline to at least mid-February. Despite speculation of delaying tapering, the RBA kept interest rates at a record low of 0.1% and remained optimistic on the economy's recovery, citing accelerating vaccination rates and easing restrictions. The central bank will continue to review the bond purchase program in light of economic conditions and the health situation.

site_title: Beyond Covid-19: Towards a net-zero world
summary: Temasek advocates for a 'net-zero world' by 2050, citing the need for a sustainable future amidst climate change. The pandemic has accelerated innovation, and Temasek sees this as an opportunity to develop solutions to global challenges. The organization has simulated long-term returns based on different climate change scenarios, concluding that a 'high ambition' approach is necessary to achieve a liveable planet and higher returns. Temasek emphasizes the role of corporations and private capital in driving climate change mitigation, and encourages boards to prioritize ESG issues, including climate change adaptation and cyber security.

site_title: Singapore Convention on Mediation more important amid Covid-19 pandemic: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore Law Minister K Shanmugam emphasizes the significance of the Singapore Convention on Mediation amid the Covid-19 pandemic, rising geopolitical tensions, and trade protectionism. The convention, which has been ratified by 7 countries, aims to make mediation more efficient and effective in resolving cross-border disputes. Shanmugam hopes more countries will join, as its effectiveness relies on ratification. He notes that the convention will provide greater certainty and confidence for parties, facilitating trade and commerce, and benefiting the global economy.

site_title: Park Hotel Farrer Park relaunches under Holiday Inn brand
summary: The 300-room Park Hotel Farrer Park in Singapore has been relaunched as Holiday Inn Singapore Little India under the management of IHG Hotels & Resorts. The hotel will undergo a renovation and introduction of a new dining and workspace concept, part of the "next-generation" Holiday Inn brand. This marks IHG's third management contract in Singapore, with the other two being Holiday Inn Express Clarke Quay and InterContinental Singapore Robertson Quay. The relaunch comes as the hospitality industry recovers, with IHG and RB Capital expressing confidence in Singapore's reopening.

site_title: Evergrande's heavy discounts fail to boost August property sales
summary: Evergrande Group's aggressive discounts failed to boost August property sales, with contracted sales dropping 26% year-over-year to 38.1 billion yuan. The company's average selling price slid 11.5% to its lowest since July 2016. Evergrande's debt woes continue to weigh on the company, with shares and bonds plummeting and the risk of default increasing. The company's profit for the first half slid 29%, and its gross margin almost halved to 12.9%. Regulatory tightening and the latest Covid-19 outbreak also cloud the sales outlook for Chinese residential property developers.

site_title: Allianz under investigation in Germany over investment funds
summary: Germany's financial regulator BaFin has launched an investigation into Allianz, the country's largest financial company, over its investment funds that lost billions of dollars last year. The probe, across multiple departments, examines Allianz executives' knowledge of events leading to the funds' losses. The investigation comes as the company faces investor lawsuits and US investigations by the DOJ and SEC. Allianz had previously reassessed the risks related to the funds, concluding they could significantly impact its future financial results, with investors claiming $6 billion in damages.

images.alt_text: The German insurer is one of the world's biggest money managers with 2.4 trillion euros in assets under management.

site_title: Buildings in S'pore have to meet higher standards to be certified green under refreshed scheme
summary: Singapore has updated its Green Mark scheme to make buildings meet higher sustainability standards, emphasizing the reduction of embodied carbon, integration of smart technologies, and creation of healthier environments. The revised scheme, launched at the International Built Environment Week 2021, aims to push towards the country's target of becoming a low-carbon built environment by 2030. New and existing buildings will need to meet higher minimum energy efficiency levels and score sufficient points in sustainability sections to be certified green, with residential buildings achieving at least 60% improvement in energy efficiency compared to 2005 levels recognized.

site_title: Accepting common prosperity: the latest in Chinese equity markets
summary: China's equity markets, hit by a regulatory crackdown, remain an attractive investment destination despite short-term challenges. The government aims to transition the economy to consumption-driven growth, increasing the "pie" through innovation and ensuring equitable distribution. Regulations target tech giants and monopolistic practices, while also addressing social issues like healthcare and housing. Despite uncertainty, fundamentals remain strong, and policy support in certain industries suggests a more sustainable economy. The Chinese tech giants will still play a major role in driving domestic consumption, and the crackdown is intended to prevent anti-competitive behavior and encourage innovation.

site_title: For American men, US Open hints at better days ahead
summary: The US Open tennis tournament has highlighted a promising future for American men's tennis, with 14 players from the US currently ranked in the top 100. The emergence of young players such as Frances Tiafoe, Jenson Brooksby, and Brandon Nakashima has sparked hope that the country's dominance in men's tennis may return. Although none of these players are yet ranked in the top 20, their depth and youth suggest that better days ahead are possible, potentially rivaling the success of the Sampras-Agassi era of the 1990s.

site_title: UK house prices defy ending of tax break for buyers
summary: UK house prices rose 0.7% in August to £262,954, defying the end of a tax break on purchases. The average annual pace of increase slowed to 7.1% due to low borrowing costs and supply shortages, according to Halifax. A stamp-duty holiday phased out in July and ends on September 30, but Halifax believes structural factors will continue to drive demand, including demand for larger homes due to remote work. Nationwide Building Society also reported a 2.1% gain in August, the second-largest in 15 years.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Frencken Group acquired Singapore-incorporated Avimac for S$14 million to expand its business, gaining access to new technologies and competencies in the aerospace and semiconductor sectors. Keppel Corporation priced S$400 million in subordinated perpetual securities with a 2.9% distribution rate. NutryFarm International secured a S$27 million sales order for durian exports to China. These deals aim to accelerate business expansion and diversification.

site_title: Hong Kong landlord sees robust demand for central offices
summary: Hong Kong Land Holdings, the largest landlord in the city's most expensive office market, expects robust demand for central offices despite concerns about political clampdowns and pandemic setbacks. Executives say leasing demand remains strong, with corporates elevating their focus on quality spaces. This contrasts with the overall performance of the rental industry in Central, where the vacancy rate rose to 9.6% and office rent prices fell 3.3% in the first seven months of the year.

site_title: Time to rethink pay norms, make equity ownership firm-wide
summary: US CEOs' pay packages are failing to satisfy shareholders and undermining their credibility as guardians of other stakeholders' interests. Despite the US Business Roundtable's stakeholder pledge, executives' incentives remain focused on shareholder outcomes, and investors are increasingly voting against CEO compensation packages. A rethink of compensation norms is needed, with incentives designed to produce outcomes that satisfy both shareholders and other stakeholders. This could involve tying CEO pay to stakeholder metrics, such as environmental and social goals, and extending equity ownership to other employees.

site_title: Hyundai to offer fuel cell versions of all commercial vehicles by 2028
summary: Hyundai Motor Group plans to offer fuel cell versions of all its commercial vehicles by 2028, with the goal of cutting prices to battery electric levels two years later. Currently, the company has one fuel cell bus and one fuel cell truck on the market, with plans to develop fuel cell vehicles for Kia and Genesis brands. The move aims to push ahead with hydrogen technology despite its niche status, with Hyundai also exploring autonomous container transport applications.

site_title: Integrating ESG risks into business strategy
summary: Companies must adopt transparent and effective ESG initiatives to avoid losing access to insurance or financing and to remain competitive. ESG priorities include environmental sustainability, social equity, and governance. The transition to a low-carbon economy requires significant investments in renewable energy, with Asia expected to lead the way. Companies can access sustainable financing by incorporating ESG considerations into their credit reviews and developing a climate risk strategy. Socially responsible practices, such as improving employee benefits and diversity, equity, and inclusion, can drive business performance and reputation. Effective governance and risk management are also crucial for building resilience and fostering competitive advantage.

site_title: Looking for September's market ledges
summary: The article warns that September is the worst month in the market, historically ending lower than it begins. The market has been on edge due to real and imagined problems, and with the Federal Reserve's lackluster Jackson Hole meeting, investors are searching for potential disasters. The article concludes that September may signal a dramatic market fall, making it a challenging time for investors to time their entry.

site_title: London takes aim at New York with 5-year financial plan
summary: London aims to regain its status as the world's top international financial centre within five years by easing taxes on banks and making it easier to hire staff from abroad. TheCityUK, a financial and professional services lobby, proposed the strategy in a blueprint to counter New York's dominance. The UK's departure from the EU has put pressure on London to catch up, and becoming a hub for financial data, sustainability investing, and investment risk management is crucial. The total tax rate for a London bank is 46.5%, 13% higher than a New York-based bank.

site_title: Singapore Convention on Mediation more important amid Covid-19 pandemic: Shanmugam
summary: Law and Home Affairs Minister K. Shanmugam emphasized the importance of the Singapore Convention on Mediation amid the Covid-19 pandemic and rising global tensions. The convention, which has been ratified by 7 countries, aims to make mediation more efficient and effective in resolving cross-border disputes. With the increasing number of disputes and trade protectionism, Shanmugam hopes more countries will ratify the convention to benefit the global economy.

site_title: UK PM Johnson raises taxes to tackle health, social care crisis
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has announced a tax hike to help rescue the National Health Service (NHS) and reform the social care system. National insurance and dividend taxes will rise by 1.25% from next year, generating £36 billion over the next three years. The move breaks a Conservative Party manifesto pledge and may spark backlash from colleagues, with concerns that the burden will fall more on younger and low-paid individuals.

site_title: How readable is the roadmap to endemic Covid-19?
summary: Singapore's multi-ministry taskforce on Covid-19 has faced criticism for its inconsistent messaging on living with the virus. Despite reiterating its commitment to a "new normal" with tighter curbs only needed as a last resort, taskforce co-chair Lawrence Wong called for a reduction in non-essential social activities over the next two weeks. The public reaction suggests a lack of clarity on what it means to live with endemic Covid-19 and how to react to high daily case numbers. The taskforce's reproduction rate is now above one, with cases doubling every week, but it's unclear whether this had changed since last Friday.

site_title: Sieving out the champions in this era of digital disruption
summary: Digital disruption is transforming traditional businesses, with 80% of executives believing existing business models are at risk. Innovation is crucial for future growth, with companies like Apple and those in emerging industries like blockchain and electric vehicles poised to thrive. A new stock selection framework, IDEA, identifies innovators, disruptors, enablers, and adapters that challenge the status quo and ride disruption waves successfully. By adopting this framework, investors can gain exposure to growth industries and companies that will survive in an ever-changing world.

site_title: China's Aug exports growth unexpectedly picks up speed in boost to economy
summary: China's exports unexpectedly grew 25.6% in August, surpassing forecasts, as solid global demand helped alleviate pressure on the world's second-largest economy. The recovery from a coronavirus-battered slump has been impressive, with exports of machineries and high-tech products remaining strong. Despite a higher base for comparison, analysts believe the ongoing global recovery will not be impeded, and the impact from the Delta variant remains limited.

site_title: Towards financial wellness: Set your priorities and commit to a plan
summary: Singaporeans must prioritize their financial needs and create a plan to achieve financial wellness, particularly as they age. A survey of 1200 individuals found that millennials are bracing for a financial squeeze, with only 30% expecting their children to care for them in retirement. Experts recommend prioritizing needs, setting clear financial goals, and allocating assets accordingly. Key steps include assessing current financial position, tracking cash flow, and creating a rainy-day fund. Regularly reviewing and adjusting the plan is also crucial, as well as considering estate and succession planning. By taking action and committing to a plan, individuals can make progress towards their financial objectives and achieve long-term financial wellness.

site_title: Taleban name new Afghan government amid protests in Kabul
summary: The Taliban has named Mullah Hassan Akhund as the head of Afghanistan's new government, with Mullah Abul Ghani Baradar as deputy. Mullah Mohammad Yaqoob, son of Mullah Omar, is the new defense minister, and Sarajuddin Haqqani, son of the founder of the Haqqani network, is designated as interior minister. The appointments are in an acting capacity.

site_title: SIA Engineering launches Lean Academy to upskill workforce
summary: SIA Engineering Company launched the Lean Academy to upskill its 4,000-strong workforce, aiming to boost competitiveness and productivity. The academy will focus on Lean methodologies to optimize resources and create value for customers. With a $10 million investment, the company expects to achieve 20-30% productivity improvements by 2023. The Lean Academy's courses will be made available to the wider maintenance, repair and overhaul community, and the Economic Development Board will provide $2.4 million in salary support. The goal is to establish SIAEC as a Lean enterprise by early 2023.

site_title: Singapore HR tech startup Veremark raises S$3.7m in seed money
summary: Singapore-based HR tech startup Veremark has raised S$3.7 million in seed funding, bringing total funding to S$5 million. The investments came from ACF Investors, Triple Point Ventures, and SOV Ventures, among others. Veremark offers an automated digital solution for pre-employment screening, aiming to reduce time wasted on repetitive checks and save clients up to 50% of traditional delays and costs.
