The company has grown 800% in the last 12 months, exceeding $1 million in annual recurring revenue, and plans to use the funding to expand in the pre-employment screening market valued at $16 billion annually.

site_title: US: Stocks lower after holiday weekend
summary: US stocks declined early Tuesday, opening a holiday-shortened week amid concerns over the Delta variant of the coronavirus and the expiration of federal aid programmes for Covid-19 unemployed workers. Despite this, strong North American movie box office performance over the Labour Day Weekend, with Disney's Shang-Chi And the Legend Of The Ten Rings earning a record $71.4 million, countered some of the market's downward momentum. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.5%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.3%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index slipped less than 0.1%.

site_title: Frencken Group acquires Joe Lau's Avimac for S$14m
summary: Frencken Group has acquired Singapore-incorporated Avimac for S$14 million, aiming to expand its business through high precision machining parts to the aerospace and semiconductor sectors. Avimac, founded by veteran Joe Lau in 2018, was a supplier to Frencken's subsidiary ETLA Limited. The acquisition will accelerate Frencken's capacity expansion, gain access to new technologies, and build a new business pillar in the aerospace industry, according to group president Dennis Au.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: Singapore's National Environment Agency (NEA) raised S$1.65 billion from a green bond issuance under its S$3 billion multicurrency medium-term note (MTN) programme. Shares of CapitaLand will cease trading on September 10. Investment manager Tikehau Capital SCA is planning to list a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) in Singapore. The STI rose 0.24% amid cautious trading as Covid-19 cases rise.

site_title: STI up 0.24% amid cautious trading as Covid-19 cases rise
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.24% on Tuesday, driven by a property group's share buyback plan, as the city-state faces a rising number of Covid-19 cases. The benchmark Straits Times Index ended at 3,108.53 points, with Hongkong Land Holdings and Dairy Farm International Holdings among top performers. The government urged Singaporeans to scale back non-essential social interactions amid a surge in cases, which prompted concerns about the impact on the economy.

site_title: Tikehau Capital joins race for Singapore's first SPAC: sources
summary: Tikehau Capital, a European alternative asset manager, is planning to raise up to S$300 million by listing a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) in Singapore, joining other firms seeking to take advantage of the city-state's new listing framework. The firm has not identified a specific target sector for its prospective SPAC firm and is in the advanced stages of its preparations. This move comes as Singapore becomes the first Asian financial hub to host blank-cheque companies, with several high-growth firms in the Asia-Pacific region preparing for public markets.

site_title: GIC star private equity investor leaving to start new fund
summary: Amit Kunal, managing director of private equity in South-east Asia for the Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC, is leaving to start his own private equity fund with assets under management of $500-1 billion. Kunal and GIC Vice-President of Private Equity in South-east Asia, Choo Koon Po, will join forces in their new venture, which will focus on growing companies in the region. Kunal's departure comes after he helped steer GIC's involvement in several record-breaking listings in Indonesia and the Philippines, including Monde Nissin Corp and PT Bukalapak.com.

site_title: Keppel Corp prices S$400m 2.9% subordinated perps
summary: Keppel Corp priced S$400m in 2.9% subordinated perpetual securities, with a 2.9% annual distribution rate from Sept 16, 2021. The securities, with a S$250,000 denomination, have no fixed redemption date and confer a right to receive distribution payments. Net proceeds will be used for general corporate and working capital purposes, including refinancing existing debts. DBS Bank, OCBC, and UOB have been appointed as joint bookrunners and lead managers for the issue, expected to be completed on or around Sept 16, 2021.

site_title: Lessons from Greatearth's bust: Integrated players best placed to tackle construction woes
summary: Construction companies in Singapore are facing significant headwinds due to the pandemic, with supply chains disrupted and costs increasing by 10-30% as a result. Affiliated companies of defunct contractor Greatearth are being wound up, causing delays in several projects. Integrated players, such as property developers with construction and engineering businesses, are better placed to navigate the challenges, as they have diversified revenue streams and can pass on increased costs to buyers. Analysts expect the construction sector to adapt to the new normal, with automation playing a key role in helping the industry overcome the shortage of foreign workers.

site_title: Johnson hands UK workers and firms annual health bill of US$17b
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has announced a 1.25% increase in National Insurance Contributions (NICs) for workers and businesses to help fund the National Health Service (NHS) and social care system. The tax hike, expected to generate £36 billion over three years, will be implemented in 2023. The move breaks a Conservative Party manifesto pledge and has sparked concerns about the impact on younger people and low-paid workers. Johnson aims to reform the NHS and social care system, but the decision risks alienating voters, particularly those who switched to the Conservatives in 2019.

site_title: Singapore buildings to have to meet higher standards to be certified green
summary: Singapore has updated its Green Mark scheme to require new and existing buildings to meet higher sustainability standards, including reduced embodied carbon, smart technologies, and healthier environments. The revised scheme aims to push the country towards its goal of becoming a low-carbon built environment by 2030. Buildings must achieve at least 60% improvement in energy efficiency compared to 2005 to be recognized. A one-stop digital platform, Corenet X, will streamline the submission process, and the scheme is aligned with the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals.

site_title: First SIA flight carrying vaccinated travellers from Germany to land on Wednesday
summary: Singapore Airlines' first Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) flight carrying vaccinated travellers from Germany will depart Frankfurt at 10pm on Tuesday and land at Changi Airport on Wednesday. Travellers will undergo up to four Covid-19 tests and adhere to designated VTL conditions. Demand for flights has increased, with travel booking platform Expedia seeing a 10-fold rise in bookings, but prices have remained stable. Experts, however, expect limited impact on Singapore's aviation and travel sectors due to factors such as Germany's more attractive tourism options and Brunei's closed borders.

site_title: MAS forms Sustainability Group and appoints chief sustainability officer
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has formed a Sustainability Group to steer sustainability efforts and develop a green finance ecosystem to support Asia's low-carbon transition. The group, led by chief sustainability officer Darian McBain, will coordinate MAS' green finance and sustainability agenda, aiming to strengthen the financial sector's resilience against environmental risks. MAS has taken steps to push the sustainability agenda, including the launch of its inaugural Sustainability Report in June, and will work on reducing its own carbon and environmental footprint.

site_title: Employers with at least 10 staff must notify MOM of all retrenchments from Nov 1
summary: Employers in Singapore with at least 10 staff must notify the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) of all layoffs from November 1, regardless of the number of employees affected. This change aims to provide earlier intervention for workers who may be retrenched, allowing for career counseling and support. Employers must file the notification within five working days after providing the notice to affected staff, with penalties of up to S$2,000 for non-compliance.

site_title: Alternative sub-sectors present diversification opportunities in Europe's industrial and logistics markets
summary: European industrial and logistics markets offer diversification opportunities for investors as prime net initial yields for big box logistics assets reach historically low levels of 3.5-4%. Emerging sub-sectors like cold storage and urban last mile logistics provide higher yielding alternatives, driven by strong demand and growth in e-commerce. Savills Investment Management urges caution, emphasizing the importance of yield-enhancing and risk diversification, and expects rental growth to be strongest in urban and city fringe locations.

site_title: Experts query move to study giving boosters to younger adults to lower infection rates
summary: Singapore's government plans to study giving Covid-19 vaccine boosters to younger adults to lower infection rates, but local infectious diseases experts have questioned the move, citing a lack of evidence that this group needs boosters. They argue that the primary goal of the vaccine is to prevent severe illness, not infection, and that more vaccinations may not be effective in slowing transmission due to the process taking months. Experts also suggest that booster shots for healthy, younger people may not provide an overall benefit to the individual or society compared to the regular two doses.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.89 points to 1,583.48 on Tuesday, driven by a higher volume of 4.748 billion lots worth RM2.888 billion. Gainers outpaced losers 633 to 439.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finish with more gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.73% on Tuesday, following an Asia-wide advance, driven by data showing Chinese trade growth exceeded expectations. The Hang Seng Index reached 26,353.63, while the Shanghai Composite Index jumped 1.51% and the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 1.11%. This comes as traders react to easing concerns about China's economy, the world's No. 2 economy.

site_title: Electricity retailers in Singapore hike rates amid surge in spot prices
summary: Electricity retailers in Singapore have raised prices of fixed-price plans amid a surge in spot electricity prices, which may undermine the country's energy sector liberalization. The top three players in the Open Electricity Market have increased prices between 10-15% for 24-month fixed-plan packages. Industry experts attribute the increase to a combination of factors, including higher wholesale prices set by generation companies and reduced liquidity in the futures market. The Energy Market Authority (EMA) is investigating the root cause of the surge in spot prices, which have reached a multi-year high of $167.04 per megawatt-hour in July.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall on tech sell-off, US tapering uncertainty
summary: South Korean stocks fell 0.50% on Tuesday, led by tech heavyweights Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix, amid uncertainty over US Federal Reserve's bond purchase program tapering. Foreign investors sold 327.2 billion won worth of shares, while China's exports unexpectedly grew in August, easing pressure on the world's second-largest economy. The won weakened to 1,157.8 per dollar, and the benchmark Kospi ended at 3,187.42.

site_title: Fall from grace: Evergrande's debt journey since China's 'three red lines' policy
summary: China Evergrande, the country's second-largest property developer, has experienced a rapid decline in fortunes over the past year due to its aggressive leverage and failure to meet China's "three red lines" policy. The company has raised billions of dollars through sales and debt restructuring but is now short on two of the policy's key metrics, limiting its access to new bank loans. Evergrande's debt has surged to a near-record 1.97 trillion yuan, and its cash reserves have plummeted to a six-year low, posing significant risks to the company's stability and future operations.

site_title: Greening Asia's economies will cost over US$12 trillion: ING report
summary: A report by ING estimates that greening Asia's economies, particularly China, Japan, and South Korea, will cost over $12.4 trillion. The costs are mainly focused on generating clean electricity for new fleets of electric vehicles, electrified rail, and sustainable aviation fuelled planes. China will bear the brunt of the investment, with $11 trillion expected, followed by Japan ($1 trillion) and South Korea ($400 billion). The report suggests that while the costs seem daunting, they are achievable if the transition process starts today, with annual costs dropping to manageable figures over the next 30 years.

site_title: Traveloka is said to halt talks with Thiel's Bridgetown SPAC
summary: Traveloka, an Indonesian online travel giant, has halted talks to go public through a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) deal with Bridgetown Holdings, backed by billionaires Richard Li and Peter Thiel. The company's board decided not to pursue a listing via a SPAC due to waning enthusiasm in the market. Traveloka is likely to explore a traditional initial public offering (IPO) in the US instead. The decision comes as the SPAC market has slowed, and the US Securities and Exchange Commission has increased scrutiny of these companies.

site_title: Australia's central bank sticks to tapering, but extends timeline
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), has confirmed plans to trim its massive bond buying program by $1 billion a week to $4 billion, extending the timeline to at least mid-February. Despite a slowdown in economic growth due to COVID-19 lockdowns, the RBA remains optimistic on the outlook, citing accelerating vaccination rates and easing restrictions. Interest rates remain at a record low of 0.1%. The RBA governor, Philip Lowe, expects the economy to recover once vaccination rates increase further and restrictions are eased.

site_title: Allianz under investigation in Germany over investment funds: sources
summary: German regulators are investigating Allianz, the country's largest financial company, over its US investment funds that lost billions of dollars last year. The investigation, led by BaFin, examines whether Allianz executives outside the fund division had knowledge of or were involved in the funds' losses. This is the latest in a series of investigations and lawsuits, including those by the US Department of Justice and Securities and Exchange Commission, and comes as Allianz faces 25 lawsuits claiming $6 billion in damages.

site_title: Hong Kong airport completes third runway as pandemic keeps city isolated
summary: Hong Kong's airport completed its third runway on Tuesday, marking a significant milestone despite the city remaining isolated due to the pandemic. The 3.9-km runway took five years to construct and is expected to start operations next year. The airport, once a thriving international travel hub, faces increasing competition from Singapore and mainland China's rapidly expanding airports. Hong Kong's strict quarantine measures have kept the city isolated, with mandatory hotel quarantine required for most arrivals, and it's unclear if travel restrictions will be eased by next year's runway operations.

images.alt_text: City leader Carrie Lam presided over the topping-off ceremony for the 3.9 km runway, which took five years to build on reclaimed land. Hong Kong's airport has long been one of the world's busiest, but it has felt the heat from regional rival, Singapore's Changi Airport. Hong Kong as a business hub has remained relatively inaccessible to most because of its strict Covid-19 quarantine measures.

site_title: Europe: Shares hover below record high, telecom stocks jump
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index slipped 0.1% on Tuesday, hovering below its record high, due to caution ahead of the European Central Bank meeting. However, telecom stocks gained 0.8% after Deutsche Telekom struck a share-swap deal with Softbank Group. Media and utilities fell, while Allianz slipped 0.5% after regulators launched an investigation into the company.

site_title: Healthway Medical Corporation to offer Sinopharm shots from Sept 8
summary: Healthway Medical Corporation (HMC) will begin administering Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccine at three clinics from Sept 8, with plans to expand to more clinics. The vaccine will be priced at S$99 per person, inclusive of GST, and will be offered for free to the first 1,000 seniors aged 60 and above who register. The vaccine has an estimated 79% efficacy against symptomatic infection and hospitalization, and has been approved by Singapore's Health Sciences Authority and the World Health Organization.

site_title: Japan's July household spending rises less than expected
summary: Japan's household spending rose 0.7% year-on-year in July, less than the 2.9% gain expected, due to a resurgence in Covid-19 cases hindering consumer activity. This modest rise was partly due to a sharp contraction in July last year, when spending slumped 7.6% year-on-year. The country's economy is struggling to recover from the pandemic, with the government imposing new state of emergency restrictions covering about 80% of the population. Economists warn that worsening infections and vaccination efforts will keep services spending volatile, raising concerns about the economy's recovery prospects.

site_title: Impossible Foods rolls out its 'chicken nuggets' in the US
summary: Impossible Foods has launched its faux-chicken nuggets in the US, with 150 restaurants selling the product, including David Chang's Fuku and Tal Ronnen's Crossroads Kitchen. The nuggets, made with textured soy protein and sunflower oil, will also be available at over 10,000 grocery stores by the end of the year. The product does not include heme, a genetically modified ingredient that has limited its sales in Europe and China. This marks a significant expansion of Impossible Foods' presence in the plant-based poultry market, which has seen increased competition from other companies.

site_title: Panic buying grips Yangon after shadow government in Myanmar declares 'people's defensive war'
summary: Panic buying grips Yangon, Myanmar, as the shadow government declares a "people's defensive war" against the junta. Long queues formed at supermarkets and petrol stations after the acting president, Duwa Lashi La, issued a warning to avoid unnecessary travel and stock up on essentials. The declaration calls for anti-junta armed resistance groups and ethnic armed organizations to attack junta forces. The move aims to restore a civilian government to power, but its impact and implications are yet to be seen.

site_title: NCID launches gallery on second anniversary to educate public on infectious diseases
summary: The National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID) in Singapore launched a gallery on its second anniversary, aiming to educate the public on infectious diseases, particularly Covid-19. The gallery showcases NCID's efforts in managing emerging and endemic diseases, including dengue, HIV, and tuberculosis. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat lauded the centre's dedication and collaboration with other partners during the pandemic. The gallery, open to the public, highlights NCID's research and contributions to public health, including its role in the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: London takes aim at New York with five-year financial plan
summary: London aims to surpass New York as the world's top international financial centre within five years, according to a strategy paper from TheCityUK. The UK needs to ease taxes on banks and make it easier to hire staff from abroad to compete with New York. London is currently losing ground to the US financial capital, with New York dominating in stock market listings. The finance ministry has set out reforms to make London's capital market more competitive, including amending tax and visa rules.

site_title: China's Aug exports growth unexpectedly picks up speed in boost to economy
summary: China's exports unexpectedly grew 25.6% in August, outpacing forecasters' 17.1% prediction, driven by solid global demand and resilience in its industrial sector. This boost helps alleviate pressure on the world's second-largest economy, which has faced headwinds from the Delta variant-driven Covid-19 outbreaks, high raw material prices, and slowing exports. China's trade surplus rose to $58.34 billion, and exports from neighboring countries also showed encouraging growth, with South Korean shipments accelerating on strong overseas demand.

site_title: Hot stock: Hongkong Land surges as much as 13.6% on proposed US$500m share buyback plan
summary: Hongkong Land Holdings surged 13.6% in early morning trading after announcing a proposed US$500 million share buyback plan. The plan, set to run until Dec 31, 2022, aims to reduce the company's capital. The share buyback plan follows a news release on Monday evening, and the stock's price jump is seen as a positive reaction to the move.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as traders weigh outlook, Tokyo breaks 30,000
summary: Asian markets are mixed, with Tokyo's Nikkei 225 briefly breaking 30,000 for the first time in five months, driven by expectations of Japan's new stimulus package. Despite rising Delta coronavirus cases and economic slowdown concerns, ultra-loose monetary policies continue to support markets. US traders' relief over delayed Fed policy tightening has boosted markets, and investors await Chinese trade data later in the day.

site_title: CapitaLand shares to cease trading from Sept 10
summary: CapitaLand shares will cease trading on September 9 and be suspended from trading on September 10, ahead of the group's expected delisting from the Singapore Exchange on September 21. The company's restructuring plan, approved by 97.6% of shareholders, involves privatising its development arm and listing its fund-management and property-investment business, CapitaLand Investment (CLI). CLI will list on September 20 and pay shareholders cash consideration of S$0.951 per share on September 17.

site_title: China's e-sports powerhouse status undermined by tough new gaming rules for under 18s
summary: China's strict new gaming rules, limiting minors to 3 hours of online gaming per week, threaten the country's e-sports industry, which is the world's largest. The rules, which apply to gaming companies, could lead to a shortage of talented young players, undermining the industry's growth. Top e-sports players, typically discovered in their teens and retiring in their mid-20s, may struggle to compete under the new regulations, potentially harming the industry's billion-dollar market and the 400 million-strong fan base.

site_title: UOBKH selective on Malaysian construction amid uncertain public infrastructure plans
summary: Malaysian construction companies have struggled due to the prolonged Movement Control Order 3.0, leading to disappointing earnings and supply chain disruptions. Analyst Afif Zulkaplly from UOB Kay Hian selectively maintained "buy" on Kerjaya Prospek Group and WCT Holdings, citing their strong net cash positions and asset monetization plans. The analyst expects accelerated billings to drive earnings in the fourth quarter, but notes that construction margins will remain low due to productivity issues and high costs. The sector's growth is uncertain due to the government's focus on other priorities and the lack of concrete progress on infrastructure projects.

site_title: Vietnam sees fourth straight month of activity decline
summary: Vietnam's economic activity contracted for the fourth consecutive month in August, according to the ANZ Vietnam Activity Tracker. This marks the longest streak of weakness since the pandemic hit. Google mobility data has fallen 70% below baseline, and vaccination rates remain low, with less than 20% of the population receiving their first dose and only 3% fully vaccinated. Exports have also contracted, moderating for five straight months, and other indicators such as retail sales and industrial production were in the red in August.

site_title: Temasek-backed Tikehau Capital joins race for Singapore's first SPAC: sources
summary: Tikehau Capital, backed by Temasek, is planning to raise up to S$300 million by listing a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) in Singapore, joining firms seeking to capitalize on the city-state's new listing framework. The European alternative asset manager has not identified a specific target sector, but is in the advanced stages of preparations. This move follows Singapore's September 3 launch of blank-cheque companies, with Tikehau joining firms such as Turmeric Capital and Temasek's Vertex Holdings in the race.

site_title: Bilateral cooperation between China and Asean key
summary: China and ASEAN have strengthened their bilateral cooperation, with increased high-level interactions and joint efforts to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. China has shipped medical supplies and vaccines to most ASEAN nations, donating 29% of its total vaccine donations to the region. The two parties have also agreed to enhance their strategic partnership, focusing on areas such as digitalization, environment, and supply chains. ASEAN and China will continue to cooperate on sustainable development, climate change, and infrastructure projects, including the Belt and Road initiative.

site_title: South Korea successfully launches homegrown ballistic missile : report
summary: South Korea successfully test-fired a homegrown submarine-launched ballistic missile, a significant development in its efforts to build up its forces to defend against North Korea's nuclear threats. The SLBM, believed to be a variant of the Hyunmoo-2B ballistic missile, has a range of around 500km and will be mass produced after further tests. South Korea joins only a handful of countries to have successfully developed an SLBM, and the launch marks a major step forward in its defense capabilities.

site_title: Australian court orders Allianz pay A$1.5m penalty for travel insurance sales
summary: An Australian court fined Allianz SE's local units, Allianz Australia and AWP Australia, a total of A$1.5 million for selling travel insurance to ineligible customers without proper disclosure on Expedia websites. The companies also agreed to compensate around 31,500 customers. The fine was reduced due to the companies' early admission of the issue. The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) emphasized the need for transparency and accuracy in the insurance industry.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end higher on economic recovery hopes
summary: Japanese shares closed higher on Tuesday, reaching a five-month high, as investors hope for economic recovery under new Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's stimulus package. The Nikkei rose 0.86% to 29,916.14, while the Topix jumped 1.09% to 2,063.38. A reshuffle of the Nikkei 225 also saw gains from companies like SoftBank Group, Murata Manufacturing, and Keyence. The market's optimism is driven by Suga's announcement not to seek re-election, and Kishida's proposed stimulus package, which could cushion the economic blow from the pandemic.

site_title: Japan PM candidate Kishida calls for 30t yen stimulus package: media
summary: Japan's Fumio Kishida calls for a 30 trillion yen stimulus package to cushion the economic blow from the coronavirus pandemic, if he becomes prime minister. Kishida stated that the Bank of Japan should maintain its 2% inflation target and massive stimulus program. He emphasized the need for large-scale monetary easing and fiscal stimulus to protect people's lives from the pandemic. This comes after Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's surprise announcement that he is stepping down, opening up the ruling Liberal Democratic Party leadership race.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin day on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher, extending a general advance in recent weeks fueled by recovery hopes and easing concerns about China's regulatory crackdown. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.17% to 26,207.22, while the Shanghai Composite was flat. This follows a general advance in recent weeks, as investors continue to monitor China's regulatory environment.

site_title: Singapore stocks open slightly lower on Tuesday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened slightly lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.1% to 3,098.55. The decline followed a doubling of Covid-19 cases within the week, prompting the government to urge Singaporeans to scale back non-essential social interactions. Banking stocks declined, while Hongkong Land rose 8.1%. US markets were closed for a public holiday, and European shares ended near record levels, bolstered by technology stocks.

site_title: NutryFarm bags 130m yuan sales order for Thai durians
summary: NutryFarm International has secured a 130 million yuan (S$27 million) sales order for the export of 200 containers of durian from Thailand to China. The order is part of a larger agreement with Moonda Agriculture Science and Technology, with 300 containers already committed. This deal comes as NutryFarm's fruit business contributes 91.3% of its total revenue, and the company aims to diversify its business and expand into fruit trading. Shares of NutryFarm rose 4.1% following the announcement.

site_title: Australia: Shares flat as focus turns to RBA policy meeting on Sept 7
summary: Australian shares remained flat on September 7 as investors awaited the Reserve Bank of Australia's policy meeting. The S&P/ASX 200 index remained at 7,514.9 points. Weaker iron ore prices led to losses in miners, while energy stocks gained 0.8%. Analysts are uncertain about the RBA's tapering plans. Lockdowns in Australia and the United States have led to a decline in job advertisements. Meanwhile, hopes for low US interest rates have boosted sentiment.

site_title: NEA raises S$1.65b from maiden green bond issuance under S$3b MTN programme
summary: The National Environment Agency (NEA) of Singapore successfully issued S$1.65 billion in green bonds, part of its S$3 billion multicurrency medium term note (MTN) programme. The dual-tranche issuance was announced on September 7, 2021. The green bond issuance is the first under NEA's green bond framework, arranged by DBS. The successful issuance demonstrates NEA's commitment to sustainable financing and environmental sustainability.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, extending a rally from recent sessions. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.62% or 183.20 points to 29,843.09, while the Topix index gained 0.67% or 13.64 points to 2,054.86. The market's upward trend was seen as having no fresh clues from the US market, which was closed for the Labor Day holiday.

site_title: Gold ticks up on softer dollar, doubts over early Fed taper
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,826.75 per ounce, driven by a softer dollar and doubts over the US Federal Reserve's early tapering of pandemic-era bond purchases. Investors view gold as a hedge against potential inflation and lower interest rates. The dollar index declined 0.1%, lifting gold's appeal. Meanwhile, the European Central Bank will discuss a potential cut in stimulus measures, and India's gold imports nearly doubled in August due to strong demand and weaker prices.

site_title: Funding needed to tackle life-shortening air pollution: report
summary: A global report by the Clean Air Fund found that funding for clean air initiatives is less than 0.1% of philanthropic grants and less than 1% of development spending worldwide, despite air pollution being one of the world's most lethal environmental problems, responsible for millions of deaths. Fossil fuel projects received more funding, with countries in Asia receiving over 80% of development aid to fight air pollution. The report calls for a more equitable distribution of funding, particularly in Africa, where air pollution is on the rise and deaths have increased by 31% in 10 years.

site_title: Mexican miners warn of 'major delays' from environment, water rules
summary: Mexican mining companies face "major delays" in obtaining environmental and water permits, according to Camimex President Fernando Alanis. Delays are particularly pronounced for getting the country's environment ministry Semarnat to approve environmental impact statements for mining projects. This issue is expected to impact the metals sector, which is one of the country's biggest industries.

site_title: Jobless Americans stuck in backlog nightmare as pandemic benefits expire
summary: Millions of Americans are facing uncertainty as federally funded emergency unemployment benefits expire on Labor Day weekend, leaving many without a financial safety net. The US Treasury has spent over $830 billion on unemployment insurance since the pandemic began, but antiquated systems and staffing shortages have led to delays and bureaucratic nightmares. The backlog has resulted in frustrated applicants, including Laura Ulrich, who waited months for $11,200 in benefits. Experts say comprehensive unemployment insurance reform is needed to address the issue, but prospects remain unclear due to disagreements over fraud concerns and expanded benefits.

site_title: El Salvador president unveils 200 bitcoin buy, price jumps
summary: El Salvador President Nayib Bukele announced the country's purchase of 200 bitcoins, causing the cryptocurrency's price to jump 1.39% to over $52,600. The purchase is part of the country's plan to adopt bitcoin as a legal tender, effective September 7, aiming to save Salvadorans abroad millions in commissions. However, polls show skepticism among Salvadorans regarding the use of bitcoin due to its volatility, potentially increasing regulatory and financial risks.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Healthway Medical, NutryFarm, UOB, Starhill Global Reit
summary: Healthway Medical will begin administering the Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccine at three clinics starting Sept 8, with free vaccination for 1,000 seniors aged 60 and above. NutryFarm International secured a 130 million yuan (S$27 million) sales order for durian exports to China. UOB's subsidiaries in China and Indonesia secured licenses to be cross-currency dealers, enabling them to open offshore accounts and offer cross-currency exchange services. Starhill Global Reit priced S$125 million notes with a 2.23% interest rate due 2028 to refinance existing borrowings and meet capital expenditure requirements.

site_title: Goldman Sachs cuts US growth forecast as consumer sees 'harder path'
summary: Goldman Sachs revised its US growth forecast, cutting it to 5.7% for 2021, down from the previously expected 6%. Economists attribute the weaker growth to a "harder path" for American consumers. This revised forecast is expected to have a more significant impact on 2022, with a revised growth forecast of 4.6%. The downgrade suggests a more cautious outlook for the US economy.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end near record highs as tech rallies
summary: European stocks rose 0.7% to near record levels, led by a surge in technology stocks, with the tech index reaching its highest since December 2000. German factory orders boosted sentiment, and investors are focusing on the European Central Bank's meeting this week. Media and retail stocks also performed well, while mining and healthcare sectors supported shares. The Stoxx 600 index rose to 475.19, just below its all-time high of 476.16.

site_title: Oil extends losses as Saudi price cuts raise competition stakes
summary: Oil futures dropped below $69 a barrel after Saudi Arabia cut crude prices for Asian buyers by more than double the expected amount, raising competition stakes. The move came after Opec and its allies agreed to continue boosting production, despite the resurgence of Covid-19 clouding demand. Analysts attribute the cut to increased competition and a desire to retain market share, citing factors such as the Delta variant and readiness of governments to release strategic reserves. The price cuts come ahead of key requests from Asian customers for October crude volumes.

site_title: Goldman Sachs lines up US$5b Petershill private equity asset float in London
summary: Goldman Sachs plans to float its Petershill Partners unit, a private equity asset management firm, with an IPO valued over US$5 billion. The deal, expected to raise US$750 million, will make Petershill a standalone company and give it a free float of at least 25%. The listing is set to take place around a month from now, capitalizing on a private equity boom and strong fundraising opportunities in London. This follows recent listings by Bridgepoint and Antin Infrastructure Partners, and analysts see the environment as favorable for private equity firms.

site_title: Tennis: Losing is bad enough but it now comes with death threats, say players
summary: Tennis players are facing death threats and online abuse after losses, with several players at this year's US Open sharing their experiences. American Shelby Rogers and Sloane Stephens, who is Black, received thousands of messages, including racist and sexist abuse, following their losses. The WTA Tour is working with social media companies to curb the harassment, and players are being offered support and protection. The rise in online abuse is seen as a growing concern in the sport, with many players acknowledging that it's now a part of the game.

site_title: Difference between a Covid-19 quarantine order, health risk warning and health risk alert
summary: A Covid-19 quarantine order, health risk warning, and health risk alert differ in severity. A quarantine order restricts movement, while a health risk warning advises caution, and a health risk alert signals potential transmission. These measures are issued to individuals exposed to or infected with Covid-19. The distinction aims to balance public safety with individual freedoms.

site_title: Why Lael Brainard, instead of Jerome Powell, should be Fed chair
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's reappointment by President Joe Biden is puzzling given his non-aligned views on financial regulation and macroeconomic management. The real reason for Powell's reappointment may be the divided Republican Party, now united behind a hard-money perspective, and the persuasion of Fed Governor Lael Brainard, who argues the neutral interest rate is below zero and inflation needs accommodation. A more fitting choice for Fed Chair could be Dr. Lael Brainard, a former academic economist and Under Secretary of the US Department of the Treasury, who has served on the Fed Board since 2014 and demonstrated technical skills and persuasiveness during the Trump administration.

site_title: In world's first, Cuba starts Covid-19 jabs for toddlers
summary: Cuba has become the world's first country to vaccinate children from the age of two against Covid-19, using its home-grown Abdala and Soberana vaccines. The inoculation campaign started on Monday in the central province of Cienfuegos, with the goal of vaccinating all children before reopening schools that have been closed since March 2020. Cuba's vaccines, developed using recombinant protein technology, have not undergone international scientific peer review and are awaiting WHO approval. The move aims to gradually reopen schools in October and November after a surge in coronavirus infections.

site_title: Scores of asset managers fall short on tougher UK best practice code
summary: Scores of asset managers in the UK fell short of the country's tougher best practice code aimed at preventing "greenwashing" by exaggerating climate-friendly credentials. 64 firms failed to meet the revised code, which requires asset managers to provide evidence on outcomes of their actions. 125 firms, including BlackRock and Fidelity, were endorsed under the code, with a combined £20 trillion under management. Schroders, one of Britain's leading asset managers, was among those that did not make the list, but expressed confidence it will reapply soon.

site_title: Oil falls after Saudi price cuts
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday after Saudi Arabia's sharp cuts to crude contract prices for Asia, reviving concerns over demand. Brent crude futures dropped 39 cents to settle at $72.22 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 40 cents to $68.89 a barrel. The price cuts, larger than expected, signal Saudi Arabia sees the supply-demand relationship shifting, leading traders to follow down. Global oil supplies are increasing due to Opec+ output hikes, and the US energy market is still recovering from Hurricane Ida.

site_title: UK pledges £5.4b for pandemic-hit state healthcare
summary: The UK government announced £5.4 billion in funding for the state-funded National Health Service (NHS) to treat virus cases and clear a massive backlog in routine operations. The funding, to be handed out over six months, aims to manage pandemic pressures. £2.8 billion will be allocated to virus-related costs and £1 billion to tackle treatment and operations backlogs. The NHS has struggled with soaring virus rates, diverting medics and creating long waiting lists. The funding is only for England, with other regions to receive up to £1 billion this and next year.

site_title: Philippine Air aims to complete restructuring this year
summary: Philippine Airlines aims to complete its restructuring under Chapter 11 bankruptcy by the end of the year. The airline plans to operate a leaner fleet of 70 planes, trimming its current 90 planes, with a focus on domestic and long-haul routes. It will cut US$2 billion in borrowings and secure US$505 million in equity and debt financing. No further job cuts are expected, and the airline has agreed to retain a Boeing 777-300ER from aircraft lessor Avation. The restructuring aims to ensure a competitive cost structure and emerge from bankruptcy with fresh capital.

site_title: Pele recovering after tumour operation
summary: Brazilian football legend Pele, 80, has undergone surgery for a suspected colon tumor and is recovering at the Albert Einstein Hospital in Sao Paolo. The tumor was discovered during routine examinations, and Pele had previously been in poor health, experiencing various hospitalizations and health issues in recent years. He posted on social media six days prior, denying rumors of a health issue and stating he was "in good health." Pele, a three-time World Cup winner, is considered the greatest footballer of all time.

site_title: Dollar stands tall as growth momentum fades
summary: The US dollar extended its gains against rivals, edging 0.2% higher to 92.31, driven by concerns about slowing global growth. The dollar index erased losses from a weak US jobs report last week, which showed the world's largest economy created the fewest jobs in seven months. Analysts attribute the dollar's rise to profit-taking before central bank policy meetings this week, including the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision on Tuesday.

site_title: SME banking needs evolve with digital transformation: EY
summary: A recent EY survey of 16 markets found that small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore are more likely to consider switching their main financial services provider than their global peers, driven by growing digitalisation and evolving digital needs. SMEs in Singapore hold an average of 3.8 business banking products and are increasingly using fintech and digital-only banks. Despite high overall satisfaction with their main financial institutions, 35% of SMEs are inclined to switch offerings, creating opportunities for fintech and bigtech companies to disrupt banking.

site_title: Banks not ready for ECB's historic climate tests: survey
summary: European banks are struggling to prepare for the European Central Bank's (ECB) climate stress tests, which are set to begin in 2022. A survey of 20 major European banks found that most are unlikely to be ready in time, citing a lack of client data needed to inform the tests. Banks are lobbying to delay the results, but regulators are increasing pressure on the industry to adapt. The finance industry faces significant capital requirements and potential losses if it fails to meet expectations, with investors already taking note of the potential costs.

site_title: Plenty of opportunities in Chile and Latin America for Singapore firms
summary: Singapore has numerous business opportunities in Chile and Latin America, following its recent acceptance as an Associate State of the Pacific Alliance. The alliance, formed 10 years ago, comprises Colombia, Mexico, Peru, and Singapore, boasting a combined population of 231.6 million and a GDP of over $1.8 trillion. This strategic partnership is expected to enhance trade between the Asia-Pacific region and the Latin American economies.

site_title: China says it will set prices for after-school tutoring
summary: China will set price ranges for after-school tutoring classes, with benchmark fee standards and floating ranges to be determined by local authorities. The new rules aim to reduce pressure on students and alleviate the cost burden on parents, part of efforts to boost the country's birth rate. Institutions must register as non-profit organizations, and localities will scrutinize costs, including tutor salaries, to ensure they are not significantly higher than those of public school teachers. The rules also require tutors to have a firm political stance and implement the Communist Party's education policy.

site_title: Nobel laureate Stiglitz says global tax plan should aim higher
summary: Nobel laureate Joseph Stiglitz expressed dissatisfaction with the minimum 15% global tax rate on corporations, calling it "too low" to combat the "dark side of globalization." Over 130 nations have supported the tax floor plan, aiming to prevent countries from competing for low tax rates to attract multinational corporations. Stiglitz believes the rate should be higher to effectively address tax evasion and inequality.

site_title: Heard of software as a service? Now there's a hacker equivalent
summary: A growing trend of "ransomware as a service" (RaaS) is fueling global cyber attacks, with organized groups selling hacking services on the Dark Web. RaaS gangs lease technology and operate like modern businesses, making it easier for individuals to initiate attacks. The industry is estimated to be a multibillion-dollar market, with ransomware operators taking a cut of profits or operating on a fixed fee model. Experts warn that paying ransom can embolden criminals and make companies vulnerable, while constant data backups, software updates, and endpoint security measures can help protect against these threats.

site_title: Japan's stock market clear winner of Suga's resignation
summary: Japan's stock market has surged to 31-year highs after Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's surprise resignation. The Nikkei has gained 4% and the Topix index has vaulted nearly 3% to its highest level since 1990. The market's rise is attributed to the LDP's market-friendly policies and the removal of Suga's unpopular handling of the pandemic. Investors expect Japanese shares to catch up to other stock markets as Corporate Japan's earnings rise, with a forecasted 2.9-7.8% increase in the Topix by year-end.

site_title: Johnson faces tough return to UK Parliament amid talk of tax hike on workers
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson faces a backlash from Conservative Party lawmakers and former ministers over plans to increase national insurance by £10 billion to fund social care. The move, which could alienate supporters, particularly in poorer regions, is seen as a manifesto-breaker and could risk losing voters. Opposition Labour leader Keir Starmer and former Chancellor Philip Hammond have expressed concerns that the burden would fall on lower earners, while trade unions and some Tory rebels argue it's unfair to ask low-earners to subsidize wealthier pensioners.

site_title: SPACs entry opens exciting chapter for Singapore market, but do your homework before investing
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has unveiled a new framework for special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs), introducing easier rules compared to its initial consultation in March. The framework is seen as balanced, attracting sponsors while retaining elements of investor protection. The move aims to boost the local capital markets ecosystem, particularly for tech unicorns, but investors must be aware of the risks, including valuation and dilution. The new framework should help Singapore's IPO scene, which has been unexciting, and attract listings from tech companies like Sea and Grab.

site_title: Shanghai suspends key approval on route to offshore listings
summary: Shanghai has suspended key approval for companies seeking to draw foreign investment through offshore listings, a route used by technology startups for decades. The move is aimed at tightening control over foreign investment in the sector. Those who have recently applied for permission to inject money into affiliated entities in places like the Cayman Islands are being turned away. This decision is seen as part of China's efforts to regulate foreign investment and boost domestic control over the economy.

site_title: Towards sustainable manufacturing
summary: Manufacturers must commit to clear action to achieve sustainability beyond publishing aspirational targets. To accelerate progress, they should focus on five areas: product design with sustainability in mind, material selection and ethical sourcing, forging the factory of the future, streamlining shipping and distribution, and adopting a circular economy model. By leveraging technologies and data analytics, manufacturers can drive measurable improvements across their value chain, reduce costs, and enhance social value. Ultimately, a tailored approach is necessary to create lasting sustainability outcomes, and manufacturers must consider all available options to achieve this goal.

site_title: Hollywood's problem: How to plan when it doesn't know who's watching what?
summary: The film industry is struggling to determine the success of its movies due to the pandemic and the rise of streaming services. Despite box office numbers being down, studios are unable to ascertain whether a movie is a hit or a miss. With most movies now being released simultaneously in theaters and on streaming services, traditional box office expectations are being reset. The lack of viewership data from streaming services makes it difficult for studios to assign value to their films. This shift has led to a reevaluation of what success looks like in the industry, with some arguing that success is no longer solely about strong ticket sales.

site_title: TDCX rides the digitalisation wave
summary: TDCX, a Singapore-headquartered digital enabler, has attributed its 2019 Enterprise 50 top winner success to embracing digital trends. Founded in 1995, the company provides outsourced digital customer care services in over 20 languages, employing over 9,000 staff. TDCX's innovative and client-centric solutions have powered business in the new economy and enabled digital transformation for clients. The company has achieved a compounded annual growth rate of 69% over the past two years, driven by selective entry into new strategic markets and staying agile.

site_title: BMW increases orders of batteries as electric vehicle demand grows
summary: BMW has boosted orders for battery cells to 20 billion euros, up from 12 billion euros, to keep pace with growing demand for electric cars, accounting for over 11% of deliveries in the first half of the year. The company now has contracts for more than 20 billion euros worth of batteries, with a focus on i4 sedans and iX SUVs. BMW's CEO Oliver Zipse said the company is "following the market" and aims to switch to a new generation of batteries in 2024. The increased orders come as the industry faces a crippling semiconductor shortage.

site_title: Shipping industry proposes levy to speed up zero carbon future
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping and Intercargo have proposed a global levy on carbon emissions from ships to speed up the industry's transition to a zero-carbon future. The levy would apply to ships exceeding 5,000 gross tonnage, with the collected funds used to deploy cleaner fuels in ports worldwide. The proposal, submitted to the UN's International Maritime Organization, aims to reduce the price gap between zero-carbon fuels and conventional fuels. The IMO will discuss the proposal later this year, amid growing pressure to address the sector's significant greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: Volkswagen CEO: Smart cars, not e-cars, are 'real gamechanger'
summary: Volkswagen CEO Herbert Diess stated that autonomous cars, not electric vehicles, are the "real gamechanger" for the auto industry. He believes that the shift towards electrified cars is "kind of easy" compared to the significant technological advancements required for autonomous driving. Diess aims to make software services for autonomous cars a key pillar of Volkswagen's future business, with plans to reach 1.2 trillion euros in software-enabled sales by 2030. This move comes as the European Commission proposes a ban on new petrol and diesel car sales by 2035, and environmental groups are pressuring carmakers to step up their climate change policies.

site_title: New rules set to shake up Indonesia's digital economy
summary: Indonesia's Financial Services Authority (OJK) has introduced new guidelines allowing 99% foreign ownership in local lenders, but increasing capital requirements to 6 trillion rupiah (S$566 million). This move aims to push greater financial inclusion among Indonesia's 270 million population. The new rules are expected to force a consolidation of the sector, dominated by small lenders, and could lead to a greater presence of foreign players in the country's digital economy.

site_title: Asia-Pacific companies behind on standalone ESG committees: study
summary: A joint study by NN Investment Partners and Glass Lewis found that European and US companies have the highest sustainability scores, with 26% and 28% of companies having standalone ESG committees, respectively. In contrast, companies in the Asia-Pacific region have 25% of standalone ESG committees, slightly behind. The study suggests that developed regions with more stringent ESG reporting expectations are more likely to have dedicated ESG committees.

site_title: The economic roots of the Afghan debacle
summary: The West's economic approach to Afghanistan's nation-building has failed due to the country's deeply heterogeneous society and rapid growth stagnation. Afghanistan's economy is imbalanced, relying heavily on imports and foreign transfers, with a per capita income of $500. Rapid growth created expectations of improved living conditions, but its reversal led to unrest. The US and Western financial institutions' inability to sustain imports due to limited financial resources will limit their influence on the Taliban-controlled government. This pattern is not unique, as China's growing footprint in Africa also faces similar challenges, highlighting the difficulty of advancing "Western values" in a world with deep-pocketed non-Western rivals.

site_title: China's Vice-Premier assures business of support, amid regulatory crackdown
summary: China's Vice-Premier Liu He assured businesses of government support amid a regulatory crackdown, stating that guidelines and policies for the private sector will not change. The private economy contributes significantly to China's tax revenue, GDP, and urban employment. The crackdown has left businesses operating in an uncertain environment, but Liu's remarks have calmed investor sentiment, with the A-share market experiencing renewed buying activity. The government promises to support both the private and public sectors, with a focus on increasing transparency and predictability in policies.

site_title: Evergrande contagion risk has China junk bond yields soaring
summary: China's dollar junk bonds, dominated by real estate firms, saw yields surge to 12.9% on Friday, the highest since March 2021, amid concerns over Evergrande Group's liquidity crisis. The broader selloff continued Monday, with bond prices falling 0.5 cents on the dollar. Tougher leverage rules and a regulatory crackdown on the property market are weighing on indebted real estate companies, increasing the cost of borrowing. This raises the risk of a contagion effect on the Chinese economy.

site_title: HK pet funerals aim for respectful farewell rather than landfill waste
summary: In Hong Kong, pet owners can opt for "green burials" at animal crematoriums, allowing them to give their pets a respectful farewell rather than landfill waste. The service, which costs between HK$1,400 and higher for larger animals, includes a designated room for saying goodbye, and the option to scatter ashes in a garden. Pet owners, like Joey Wong, want to provide their pets with funeral rites, just like humans, and to keep them close to their loved ones even after death. This trend promotes compassion and respect for pets' final moments.

site_title: Australia sees strong future for coal beyond 2030 despite UN call
summary: Australia's coal industry is expected to remain a significant contributor to the country's economy beyond 2030, despite a UN call to phase out the fossil fuel by 2030. Resources Minister Keith Pitt stated that coal exports have grown 26% in value to A$12.5 billion in the three months to July, and the industry's future will be decided by the Australian government, not foreign bodies. The government has expressed concerns that phasing out coal would cost thousands of jobs and billions of export dollars.

site_title: Growing signs that change is 'in the air' in UK politics again
summary: UK politics may be experiencing significant changes, particularly in Scotland and Northern Ireland. A new power-sharing deal in the Scottish Holyrood legislature between the SNP and Greens has been implemented, with First Minister Nicola Sturgeon aiming for independence in the 2020s. In Northern Ireland, Brexit's impact has led to increased calls for change. As the UK Parliament reconvenes, these developments suggest a shift in the political landscape, potentially altering the country's trajectory.

site_title: Sterling slips on signs of stuttering economic momentum
summary: The British pound slipped 0.3% against the US dollar, reaching a one-month low, amid signs of stuttering economic momentum. The UK construction industry grew at its weakest pace since 2021, while the services sector slowed down in August. Economic growth is expected to "normalise" in the third quarter, with GDP growth predicted at 2.7% quarter-on-quarter. The Bank of England's interest rate decisions and inflation forecasts will be closely watched by traders.

site_title: UBS hedge fund may offer direct access to China strategy
summary: A UBS Group hedge fund unit is considering direct access to its China strategy, despite regulatory interventions that have raised doubts about the country's investment potential. The strategy has booked double-digit gains this year, with "very positive" returns in July and August. Clients currently access the China strategy through a US$3.2 billion multi-strategy investment pool, but a separate fund is being considered. Global investors remain underweight China, seeking safer ways to invest in the country.

site_title: International flights from Kabul to start soon, say Taliban
summary: The Taliban announced plans to resume international flights from Kabul airport, with Qatar and Turkey assisting in restarting operations. Domestic flights have already started, and the group aims to launch overseas flights soon. The Taliban also plans to announce their new "inclusive" government, led by Supreme Leader Haibatullah Akhundzada and Deputy Leader Abdul Ghani Baradar. However, Iran has criticized the group for its actions in the northern Panjshir valley, and Pakistan's military spy chief is meeting with Taliban leaders to discuss security and border issues.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, down 7.60 points to 1,581.59 on the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index. The market saw 4.435 billion lots traded worth RM2.894 billion, with 624 gainers and 476 losers. The article does not provide a specific reason for the decline.

site_title: Changing hands
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The Singapore stock market saw significant changes in recent days. NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in H2. US stocks declined amid tariff threats, with Wall Street opening lower. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Meanwhile, OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, a former DBS veteran. These developments highlight market fluctuations and corporate changes in the region and globally.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit's manager prices S$125 million 2.23% notes due 2028
summary: Starhill Global Reit's manager priced S$125 million, 2.23% notes due 2028 under its S$2 billion debt issuance program. The notes will be issued primarily in Singapore and used to refinance existing borrowings, meet capital expenditure requirements, or for working capital purposes. The transaction is not expected to impact the gearing of Starhill Global Reit. The interest will be payable semi-annually, and the notes may be redeemed prior to maturity.

site_title: Will Morrison's Covid strategy work out politically for the Coalition?
summary: Australia's economy showed a 0.7% growth in the second quarter, largely due to public expenditure on hospital equipment, railway lines, and roads. This growth would have been zero without government intervention. However, economists warn that the nation's GDP could contract by 3-4% in the third quarter due to ongoing shutdowns in major cities like Sydney and Melbourne. The growth figure is a "backward look" at economic performance, and the article suggests that Will Morrison's Covid strategy may not be politically sustainable for the Coalition.

site_title: Families slam 'corrupt' Russia at MH17 crash trial
summary: Families of 298 people killed in the 2014 Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17 crash demanded justice from Russia as they testified in the Dutch trial of four suspects. The victims' relatives, who lost loved ones in the Boeing 777's downing, expressed feelings of revenge and anger towards Russia. International investigators attribute the crash to a Russian-made missile, but Russia denies involvement. The trial, set to conclude in 2022, aims to hold four Russian nationals and one Ukrainian citizen accountable for the murder.

site_title: Farewell, MMS: Messaging service set to end after mid-November
summary: MMS messaging service will be discontinued in Singapore after mid-November, marking the end of an era for a technology introduced in the early 2000s. The service, which allowed users to send images, clips, and other multimedia content via text messages, will no longer be offered by telcos. This means that SMS texts with multimedia files will need to be converted into MMS, potentially affecting older phones and users. The discontinuation follows the closure of 2G mobile networks in Singapore in 2017.

site_title: StanChart Singapore's retail bank head appointed as CEO of digital bank tie-up with NTUC Enterprise
summary: Standard Chartered Singapore's head of consumer, private and business banking, Dwaipayan Sadhu, has been appointed CEO of the bank's digital bank venture with NTUC Enterprise. The joint venture, SC Bank Solutions, was granted a full banking licence by the Monetary Authority of Singapore in December 2020. StanChart will hold a 60% stake in the venture, worth S$144 million, while NTUC Enterprise will hold a 40% stake, worth S$96 million. The digital bank is expected to launch in Singapore later this year, following the launch of StanChart's digital-only Mox Bank brand in Hong Kong last year.

site_title: China finance regulators vow tighter supervision, new rules
summary: China's finance regulators have pledged to tighten supervision in the financial services industry, closing loopholes in its financial technology regulation and boosting foreign exchange market supervision. The central bank and securities regulator will enhance financial regulation and improve channels for foreign investors, aiming to prevent systemic risks. China is also moving to plug a gap in foreign investment restrictions, following recent crackdowns on industries. The goal is to address financial fragility globally, triggered by extreme easing policies by central banks in major developed economies.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed 1.01% higher on Monday, driven by weak US jobs data fueling optimism about the Federal Reserve's stimulus delay. The Hang Seng Index rose 261.64 points to 26,163.63, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. The gains were part of a broader market trend, with other Asian markets also rising.

site_title: APAC companies behind on stand-alone ESG committees, but ahead of US in disclosure quality: study
summary: A study by NN Investment Partners and Glass Lewis found that European and US companies have the highest proportion of stand-alone ESG committees, with 26% and 28% respectively, compared to 25% in the Asia-Pacific region. Companies with these committees tend to have higher ESG scores and above-median disclosure quality. However, the quality of disclosure varies between regions, with the US having the highest proportion of poor disclosure at 38%, followed by Asia-Pacific at 33% and Europe at 18%. The study suggests that the difference in disclosure quality may be due to the varying reporting regimes in the two regions.

site_title: Global tax plan should aim higher, says economics Nobel laureate
summary: Nobel economics laureate Joseph Stiglitz praised a global tax plan on corporations, which over 130 nations support, but said the minimum 15% tax rate is too low, recommending 20-25%. The plan aims to prevent countries from competing for low tax rates and end the "dark side of globalization." Stiglitz also warned against returning to austerity measures in the European Union, citing the success of the 750-billion-euro recovery fund. The global tax reform is expected to be finalized by 2023.

site_title: Uproar as Brazil v Argentina clash abandoned following Covid controversy
summary: Brazil's World Cup qualifying match against Argentina was abandoned after Brazilian health officials intervened, halting the game just 7 minutes in, amid controversy over Covid-19 protocols. Four England-based players in Argentina's squad, Giovani Lo Celso, Cristian Romero, Emiliano Martinez, and Emiliano Buendia, were accused of breaching Covid-19 protocols by failing to disclose time spent in the UK in the 14 days before arrival in Brazil. The match was suspended with no clear resolution on replaying the game or forfeiting points.

images.alt_text: Brazil's Neymar (centre left) and Argentina's Lionel Messi (centre right) speaking with Brazilian health officials after they stopped the World Cup qualifier between the two nations at Arena do Sao Paulo stadium in Sao Paulo, Brazil.

site_title: Singapore shares advance with most regional peers amid receding taper fears
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.56% to 3,101.08, following US employment data that reduced the risk of the Federal Reserve tapering its financial support. This led to gains in most regional peers, including Japan's Nikkei 225 and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index.

site_title: Time for businesses to own up and act on climate change
summary: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Sixth Assessment Report warns of a climate catastrophe, stating the world is at a "code red for humanity." The report attributes this to unchecked industrialization and human apathy, with a focus on rampant use of carbon-heavy biofuels to boost living standards. To mitigate this, businesses must take action and work towards net-zero carbon emissions, with strong reductions in other greenhouse gas emissions. The report emphasizes the need for immediate action to prevent a climate catastrophe.

site_title: Europe wants combustion engines banned, but Italy says 'Not so fast'
summary: Italy is pushing back against a proposed EU ban on combustion engines, citing concerns over the impact on high-performance car manufacturers like Ferrari and Lamborghini. Italy's government is in talks with the EU to shield these companies from the phase-out, planned for 2035, and is seeking autonomy to produce high-performance batteries. The country plans to launch a "giga-factory programme" for large-scale battery production, which is seen as crucial for the supercar sector's transition. EU officials have declined to comment on the Italian minister's remarks, emphasizing that all car manufacturers must contribute to the reduction in emissions.

site_title: OK Lim's Second Avenue bungalow on sale by public tender
summary: OK Lim's three-storey Good Class Bungalow in Bukit Timah is up for sale by public tender, with a deadline of September 30. The property, valued at approximately $30 million to $86 million, features a well-manicured garden, swimming pool, and squash court. The sale comes after a similar property at Second Avenue sold for $52.8 million earlier this year, highlighting the current demand for Good Class Bungalows in District 10.

site_title: Philippines changes tack against Covid-19, opts for 'granular lockdowns'
summary: The Philippines is implementing "granular lockdowns" in the capital region, lifting a stay-at-home order in Manila this week. The move aims to control coronavirus cases and revive the economy, which has been strained by record infections and a shortage of nurses. Localized lockdowns will target specific households, buildings, or streets, with reduced restrictions allowing businesses to reopen and tourism to resume. The country's infection caseload has passed two million, with over 34,000 deaths, and only 19% of the population is fully vaccinated.

site_title: Marina View: Testing the 'work, live, play' concept within CBD
summary: Singapore's Central Business District (CBD) is shifting towards a "work, live, play" concept, with a focus on mixed-use developments. The government has offered incentives for older office buildings to convert into residential and commercial spaces, and a new 99-year leasehold white site at Marina View is up for tender. The site will have a large residential and hotel component, with minimal office space, and is expected to be developed into a luxury residential and hotel complex. The development could cater to high-end families and remote workers, and is seen as a potential game-changer for the CBD's transformation into a vibrant live, work, play destination.

site_title: Goldman Sachs unit Petershill to raise US$750m in London float
summary: Goldman Sachs unit Petershill Partners plans to raise at least US$750 million in a London float, valuing the company at around US$5 billion. The new vehicle will comprise 19 minority stakes in alternative asset managers, and will be operated by the Goldman Sachs Asset Management team. Petershill has no fixed assets, but holds positions in 19 alternative asset managers with US$187 billion in assets under management. The move follows other private equity funds' successful listings in London, and reflects the growing demand for alternative asset investments.

site_title: Europe: Tech shares lead stocks close to record highs
summary: European stocks rose 0.4% to near record highs, driven by gains in technology stocks. Tech shares reached a fresh two-decade high, with ASML and Prosus leading the way. Despite a US holiday expected to result in thin market volumes, Asian shares hit six-week peaks on talk of more stimulus in Japan and China.

site_title: UOB units secure licences to be appointed cross-currency dealers for yuan-rupiah
summary: UOB's wholly-owned subsidiaries, UOB China and UOB Indonesia, have secured licences to be appointed cross-currency dealers for the yuan and rupiah, respectively. The licences enable UOB to offer cross-currency exchange, financing, swaps, and forwards in the currency pair to its corporate and institutional clients in Indonesia and China. The move aims to facilitate greater bilateral trade and investment flows between the two countries, with bilateral trade between China and Indonesia reaching US$78.4 billion in 2020.

site_title: Bangkok among more Thai tourist spots set for October reopening
summary: Thailand plans to reopen more tourist destinations starting October 1, including Bangkok and Chiang Mai, with the goal of drawing foreign visitors and reviving its economy. The reopening will follow a successful model in Phuket, and additional destinations like Chiang Rai, Koh Chang, and Koh Kood may reopen for visitors in mid-October. This move is part of Thailand's "living with Covid-19" strategy to manage the pandemic and protect its economy.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: Singapore's unemployment rate rose in July, ending an eight-month streak of improvement, according to the Ministry of Manpower. The rate increased due to tightened Covid-19 curbs. Meanwhile, Peace Centre/Peace Mansion was put on the market for collective sale with a reserve price of S$650 million. The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore lifted the ban on Boeing 737 MAX aircraft operations, allowing them to return to Singapore skies. Keppel DC Reit acquired two data centre buildings in the Netherlands for S$59.9 million, and the STI rose 0.56% to 3,101.08.

site_title: Singapore steps up testing as Covid-19 cases double in a week
summary: Singapore is increasing Covid-19 testing frequency for workers in high-risk settings to once a week, starting September 13, amid a doubling of cases over the past week. The government is also distributing antigen rapid test kits to all employers to support weekly testing. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong warned that the virus's reproduction rate is over one, leading to exponential growth, and predicted potential daily cases of 1,000 or 2,000 in two weeks. The government will ramp up testing and contact tracing, but no restrictions are planned for now.

site_title: BMW orders 20 billion euros worth of batteries as EV demand grows
summary: BMW has ordered 20 billion euros worth of battery cells to meet growing demand for electric cars, up from 12 billion euros previously. The company has contracts with multiple suppliers, including Contemporary Amperex Technology and Samsung SDI, to supply cells for BMW's i4 sedans and iX SUVs through 2024. BMW's CEO Oliver Zipse said the company is following market demand and is well-positioned for electrification, but faces challenges from a semiconductor shortage that may worsen through the end of the year.

site_title: At least one in three across APAC saw changes in employment situation, driving higher demand for hybrid work
summary: At least one in three respondents across Asia Pacific saw changes in their employment situation due to the pandemic, with 70% working remotely at least some of the time in 2020. Employee value proposition shifted towards work-life balance, ranking second to attractive salary and benefits. Employers are embracing hybrid work, citing improved productivity and reduced costs, but face challenges such as implementing new policies and adjusting leadership styles. The entire company must buy into the new way of work, and productivity must be measured differently to accommodate remote work.

site_title: Asean growth tracker indicates weak start to Q3: Oxford Economics
summary: The Asean-6 growth tracker, which includes Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand, Singapore, and Vietnam, has shown a weak start to Q3 with a 6.5% year-on-year growth rate in July, down from 8% in June. Tight restrictions due to a surge in Covid-19 cases and low vaccination coverage are contributing to the decline. Oxford Economics forecasts Q3 growth at 2.7% year-on-year, with the possibility of adjusting upward, but downside risks outweigh upside risks, potentially delaying growth recovery to 2023.

site_title: Tokyo: Topix ends at 31-year high as investors eye economic recovery
summary: Japan's Topix index reached a 31-year high, closing at 2,041.22, as investors bought undervalued stocks in anticipation of a swift economic recovery. The Nikkei share average jumped 1.83% to 29,659.89. The rise followed Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's offer to resign, raising hopes for a stable government. Investors expect Japan's vaccination rate to match that of the US and Europe, driving economic reopening. Most sector sub-indices traded higher, with shippers and phone companies leading the gains.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end little changed on prospects of Fed taper delay
summary: South Korean stocks ended almost unchanged on Monday, as investors remained cautious after US payrolls data raised doubts about the Federal Reserve's tapering of its bond purchase program. The Kospi index rose 0.07% to 3,203.33. Foreigners were net buyers of 63.9 billion won worth of shares, while the won ended flat at 1,156.5 per dollar. The benchmark bond yield rose 2.5 basis points to 1.463%, while the 10-year yield rose 3 basis points to 1.973%. Investors are assessing the fallout from the September payrolls report, which showed a smaller increase in jobs than expected.

site_title: New Zealand lifts virus curbs, says Delta elimination in sight
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced the lifting of nationwide coronavirus curbs, except for Auckland, as the country nears the elimination of the Delta variant. The country had been largely virus-free until an outbreak prompted a national lockdown. Ardern said daily cases have dropped from a peak of 85 to 20, and restrictions will be eased outside of Auckland starting Wednesday, allowing the reopening of schools and businesses. Face masks will still be required in public venues, and indoor hospitality venues will be limited to 50 patrons.

site_title: European banks active in tax havens despite scandals: survey
summary: European banks continue to book significant profits in tax havens, despite scandals and public pressure, according to a study by the EU Tax Observatory. The report found that 14% of European banks' total profits, or €20 billion, are booked in 17 territories with favorable tax regimes. Leading banks such as HSBC, Deutsche Bank, and Societe Generale continue to use tax havens to shift profits out of other countries, with HSBC booking 62% of its pre-tax profits in tax havens between 2018 and 2020. The study suggests that banks' practices have not significantly changed since the Lux Leaks and Panama Papers scandals in 2014.
