Among the cases, two seniors above 70 were partially vaccinated and at risk of serious illness. Three imported cases were also detected, bringing the country's total to 68,210. The Ministry of Health (MOH) emphasized the importance of vaccination and taking necessary precautions to prevent further cases.

site_title: South Korea extends distancing curbs ahead of holiday
summary: South Korea extended social distancing curbs until October 3 to control the spread of the Delta variant, despite a vaccination campaign ahead of the Chuseok holiday. Level 4 restrictions will remain in place in greater Seoul, while level 3 curbs will apply nationwide. Restaurants in Seoul will close an hour later, and gatherings of up to eight people will be allowed for Chuseok. The government aims to deliver a vaccine dose to 70% of the population by Chuseok and complete inoculation for half the population by the end of September.

site_title: Apple to delay child safety updates after criticism
summary: Apple plans to delay its child safety updates after facing criticism from rights groups and employees over concerns about the system's privacy and potential misuse by repressive governments. The proposed feature, which aimed to scan US customer phones and computers for child sex abuse images, sparked global backlash. Critics argued the feature could be exploited for censorship and arrests, and would be difficult to verify Apple's intentions. Apple will take more time to collect feedback and improve the feature, which was initially promised last month.

site_title: Women in boardroom count toward companies' borrowing costs
summary: Companies worldwide are linking borrowing costs to gender equality, with 19 billion dollars in sustainability-linked loans sold so far this year, more than four times last year's total. This growth reflects the push for social justice since the pandemic and #MeToo movement. Companies like Majid Al Futtaim Holding and Coles Group are agreeing to pay extra interest rates if they fail to increase women in management to 30%. Improved diversity can enhance staff retention, collaboration, and decision-making, with banks expecting more such transactions on the back of increased inquiries about gender metrics.

site_title: Singapore real estate agents' transaction data now available for all residential properties
summary: The Council for Estate Agencies (CEA) in Singapore has made residential property transaction data available for all properties, including resale and rental deals of Housing and Development Board (HDB) flats and private homes. The data, published on the CEA Public Register, includes transaction information such as property location, agent representation, and property type, but does not reveal specific prices or property details. The initiative aims to increase transparency and empower consumers to make informed decisions when selecting an agent, while also promoting industry professionalism.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore retail sales in July rose 0.2% to S$3.4 billion, still below pre-Covid-19 levels. The National Wages Council will convene on Sept 6 to set guidelines by Oct end. Grand Venture plans to raise up to S$39.9m through a share placement and vendor sale. ComfortDelGro won a public EV charging infrastructure tender, and real estate agents' transaction data on HDB and private homes is now publicly accessible. The STI ended 0.2% lower at 3,083.85 points due to weak retail sales data.

site_title: Singapore's retail sector more resilient than a year ago: economists
summary: Singapore's retail sector showed resilience in July, with total retail sales growing 0.2% year-on-year and 0.8% month-on-month. Despite fluctuating Covid-19 restrictions, consumer sentiment remained promising. Key sectors like watches and jewellery sales grew, while department stores' sales declined. The food and beverage industry also experienced a decline, with restaurants' sales dropping 21.6% and cafes and food courts growing 6.6%. Economists attribute the resilience to consumers adapting to intermittent restrictions and online shopping growth. Retail sales are expected to recover further in the months ahead.

site_title: Silverlake Axis unit inks agreement with DynaFront to boost digital insurance capabilities
summary: Silverlake Axis, a fintech company, has signed a teaming agreement with Malaysia-based insurance technology specialist DynaFront Holdings to co-create insurtech innovations and achieve digital insurance leadership. The agreement does not disclose further details due to confidentiality. Silverlake Axis holds 3.5 million shares in DynaFront, representing a 4.86% interest. The deal does not have a direct financial impact on Silverlake Axis, as the company's shares ended the day at 27 Singapore cents, down 1.8%.

site_title: Sri Lanka imposes price controls to tackle food shortages
summary: Sri Lanka imposed price controls on key food items, including sugar and white rice, as the government seeks to tackle food shortages. The maximum price for a kilo of sugar is 125 rupees and for a kilo of rice is 95 rupees. The move comes amid a nationwide coronavirus lockdown and a shortage of foreign exchange to import and maintain stocks. The government blames traders for profiting from pandemic restrictions, but experts say the shortages are a result of a genuine lack of foreign exchange.

site_title: Singapore remains in preparatory stage, no further loosening of Covid-19 curbs for now
summary: Singapore remains in its preparatory stage to transition to endemic Covid-19, with no loosening of measures for now. The multi-ministry taskforce announced this decision after 216 new locally-transmitted cases were reported on Friday. Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong said the country will maintain current safe management measures to monitor the situation and ensure it remains under control before reopening further. Vaccination and testing remain key to Covid resilience, with a vaccine booster programme to be rolled out in September for the elderly and immunocompromised.

site_title: Vaccine booster shots to start in September for immunocompromised, those 60 and above
summary: The Ministry of Health in Singapore will start a vaccine booster program in September for those 60 years and above, as well as immunocompromised individuals. This follows emerging data on the waning of vaccine efficacy over time. The program aims to provide a third dose of the vaccine to these groups, with immunocompromised individuals receiving a third dose two months after their second dose and seniors receiving a third dose six to nine months after completing their vaccination regimen. This is in line with vaccination measures adopted in other countries, including Israel and Germany.

site_title: Kirin Brewery chief dies; group CEO to run unit in interim
summary: Japanese beverage maker Kirin Holdings announced the death of Takayuki Fuse, 61, head of the brewery unit, who died from ventricular fibrillation at a Tokyo hospital. Fuse, who joined Kirin in 1982, was recently appointed chairman of the Brewers Association of Japan. Kirin Holdings CEO Yoshinori Isozaki will run the beer unit in an interim capacity.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 7 points to 1,589.19, closing higher on Friday. The index saw 4.251 billion lots traded worth RM2.882 billion, with 631 gainers and 399 losers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares cap positive week with a loss
summary: Hong Kong shares ended a four-day winning streak with a 0.72% loss, closing at 25,901.99. The decline came after Alibaba fell 2.4% following a $15 billion donation to charitable causes, in response to President Xi Jinping's call for the rich to tackle inequality. The Shanghai Composite Index also dropped 0.43%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.55%. The losses came despite a strong start to the week, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.4% on Tuesday.

site_title: SGX to amend default-management process following public consultation
summary: SGX has announced that it will amend its default-management process following a public consultation. The new rules state that when a clearing member defaults, the Central Depository (CDP) will set off the member's outstanding buy- and sell-trades for each counter, reducing the number of transactions that must be liquidated. This change aims to minimize the impact on the market and better preserve the integrity and robustness of the financial system. The amendments will take effect on Monday and prioritize protecting retail investors over defaulting members and their affiliates.

site_title: ​National Wages Council to convene on Sept 6, will announce guidelines by end-October
summary: The National Wages Council (NWC) will convene on September 6 to develop its annual guidelines on wage and employment-related issues. The council will consider the domestic and global economic situation, as well as Singapore's public health measures, during its deliberations. The guidelines are expected to be announced by the end of October. This move comes as Singapore prepares to reopen its economy further.

site_title: Europe: Equities mostly flat at open
summary: Europe's stock markets remained flat at the opening on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 and Frankfurt's DAX 30 holding steady, while the Paris CAC 40 shed 0.3%. Investors turned cautious ahead of US non-farm payrolls data.

site_title: China to launch more futures contracts, increase foreign investors in trading: cabinet
summary: China plans to launch more futures contracts, including a shipping futures contract, and accelerate foreign investor participation in its futures market. The country will also establish an international, yuan-denominated commodity futures market in free trade zones. These moves aim to promote trade and investment in China's free trade zones.

site_title: Thai activists push for PM to quit as confidence vote looms
summary: Thai activists are calling for Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha to resign as a confidence vote looms in Parliament. Demonstrators plan daily protests until Prayuth leaves office, following a series of rallies since late June over the government's handling of the coronavirus crisis. Despite a ban on big gatherings, protesters vowed to continue their activities at the Asoke intersection in Bangkok. The government, led by Prayuth, has rejected opposition allegations of corruption and mismanagement, and a confidence vote is expected to go in their favor due to their coalition's majority.

site_title: Japan's Topix index hits 30-year high as Suga steps down
summary: Japan's Topix index reached a 30-year high, closing at 2,017.00, as Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga offered to resign, paving the way for a fresh government ahead of an upcoming election. The Nikkei share average rose 1.7% to 29,020, its highest level since June. Suga's decision sets the stage for a leadership race and potential change in government, boosting market hopes for a stronger administration.

site_title: Singapore retail sales in July up 0.2% as low-base effects wear off
summary: Singapore's retail sales grew 0.2% year-over-year in July, easing from double-digit growth in previous months as low-base effects wear off. On a month-on-month basis, sales rose 0.8%. Excluding motor vehicles, sales rose 2% year-over-year and 2.9% sequentially. Online sales accounted for 13.9% of total sales, down from 15.4% in June. Petrol service stations saw the biggest growth, with sales jumping 33.5% year-over-year.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher ahead of US payrolls data
summary: South Korean stocks ended higher on Friday, boosted by record closing highs on US major stock indexes. The Kospi index rose 0.79% to 3,201.06, rebounding from a 0.97% loss on Thursday. Tech heavyweights, including Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix, led gains, while LG Electronics surged 10% following media reports of Apple's potential "Apple Car" production. Foreigners were net buyers of $497.09 million worth of shares on the main board.

site_title: Troubled contractor Greatearth files to wind up company, a week after shock BTO sites closures
summary: Troubled Singapore construction company Greatearth has filed a statutory declaration to wind up its business, a week after closing five Build-To-Order (BTO) project sites affecting over 2,900 home buyers. Professional services firm PwC has been appointed as provisional liquidators. The closure of the sites has caused significant delays, and new contractors will be appointed to complete the remaining works. Greatearth was also the main contractor for two public projects, which may face possible hold-ups due to the company's financial issues, resulting in subcontractors facing heavy financial losses.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start Friday's session with loss
summary: Hong Kong stocks started Friday's session with a 0.26% decline, edging lower following four successive gains. The Hang Seng Index dropped 67.76 points to 26,022.67. US jobs data release later in the day is expected to draw attention. Meanwhile, Shanghai Composite and Shenzhen Composite Index showed minor gains.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ends up more than 2% after PM steps down
summary: Japan's benchmark Nikkei index rose over 2% on Friday after Prime Minister announced he won't run for his party's leadership, effectively ending his tenure. The Nikkei 225 jumped 2.05% to 29,128.11, while the Topix index gained 1.61% to 2,015.45. The prime minister's decision came after he stepped down, with no clear successor announced. The market reaction suggests a sense of stability and continuity, as investors await the next steps in the leadership transition.

site_title: Japan's PM Suga to step aside after just a year in office
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga announced he won't seek reelection as chief of the governing party, paving the way for a new leader after a historically unpopular tenure. Suga will focus on preventing the coronavirus instead of running for party president. A leadership election is set for September 29, with Fumio Kishida as the only declared candidate. The winner will be the heavy favorite to become prime minister after a general election, which must be held by late next month.

site_title: HSBC's CEO has his eye on China's middle class beyond Xi's crackdown
summary: HSBC CEO Noel Quinn is focusing on China's middle class, despite President Xi Jinping's crackdown on the country's wealthiest individuals. Quinn believes China's middle class presents a significant opportunity for HSBC, with plans to hire 600 wealth managers and expand its services in the country. The bank is also looking to acquire two to four "bolt-on" businesses in Asia, including in China, to fuel its expansion. Quinn aims to turn the 156-year-old lender around and is working to shift its focus towards Asia, where it made almost two-thirds of its pretax profits in the first half of the year.

site_title: New Zealand police kill 'extremist' inspired by Islamic State
summary: New Zealand police shot and killed a Sri Lankan national who stabbed and wounded at least six people in a supermarket in Auckland. The attacker, inspired by the Islamic State militant group, was a person of interest for five years. He was killed within 60 seconds of the attack, which Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern described as a "hateful, wrong, and carried out by an individual, not a faith." Three people were in critical condition, one in serious condition, and another in moderate condition.

site_title: More women participating in company boards but numbers still short of targets: Council for Board Diversity
summary: Women's participation on boards of Singapore's largest companies and statutory boards increased slightly to 18% and 28.8% respectively in the first half of 2021, but still fell short of targets set by the Council for Board Diversity. Despite this, some companies have made significant progress, with Singapore Post and Far East Hospitality Trust having boards composed entirely of women directors. The council notes that the top 100 companies need 17 more women directors to reach their 2020 target, while statutory boards require 11 more to hit their 30% target.

site_title: Top China chipmaker to invest US$8.9b in Shanghai plant
summary: Top China chipmaker Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp (SMIC) plans to invest US$8.87 billion in a new 100,000-per-month wafer plant in Shanghai, a major expansion to boost its capacity. The plant, set to be established in the Lin-Gang Special Area, will focus on more mature technology of 28 nanometers or older. SMIC will form a joint venture with Shanghai's government, with the company owning at least 51% of the registered capital. The move is seen as a significant step in China's efforts to build a world-class chip industry.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.51 points, or 0.16%, to 1,584.70 on Friday, with 443.83 million lots traded at RM188.68 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 277 to 197.

site_title: ComfortDelGro consortium wins public EV charging infrastructure tender
summary: ComfortDelGro Engineering, a subsidiary of ComfortDelGro, has won Singapore's electric vehicle (EV) charging infrastructure pilot tender with its consortium partner ENGIE South East Asia. The tender awarded over 600 EV chargers at over 200 participating public car parks across Singapore's Central, East, West, North, and North-East regions by 2022. The charging stations will have concession fees of 14.4-15.4 cents per kilowatt hour (kWh), contributing to Singapore's national target of deploying 40,000 charging points by 2030.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as PM flags quicker reopening after Covid-19 vaccine swap
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 7,522.9 on Friday, driven by a vaccine swap deal with Britain and higher iron ore prices. Prime Minister Scott Morrison flagged a quicker reopening after the deal, as more than half of the country's 25 million people are under stay-at-home orders. Investors looked through a decline in retail sales due to lockdowns, and analysts expect the cash rate to stay at 0.1% despite tapering plans. The mining sub-index rose 1.2%, with BHP Group, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals adding between 0.8% and 2.5%.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on miners, energy boost
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% on Friday, boosted by energy and mining stocks, following a strong finish on Wall Street. The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed, with miners adding 1% and energy stocks reaching a two-and-a-half-week high. The rise was also supported by a record finish on the S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

site_title: China approves US$149m coalbed methane pipeline project in northern China
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission approved a US$149m coalbed methane pipeline project in northern China, spanning 74.1km with annual gas transmission capacity of 2 billion cubic meters. The project, managed by China United Coalbed Methane Corp, aims to boost coalbed methane development. This is part of a larger pipeline connecting Shanxi and Shaanxi provinces, with another part approved in 2019.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly rise after Wall Street record with eye on jobs
summary: Asia markets rose on Friday following a record close on Wall Street, with traders focusing on US jobs data. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq finished at fresh records, and gains filtered through to Asia. However, some markets, including Tokyo, Shanghai, and Seoul, fell, while Hong Kong and Singapore dipped. Analysts expect a strong jobs reading to prompt the Federal Reserve to taper its monetary policy sooner. Meanwhile, China's Xi Jinping announced plans to set up a new stock exchange for small and medium-sized enterprises, signaling continued support for markets.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher with eyes on key US jobs data
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.25% and the Topix index up 0.27%. Investors are optimistic ahead of US job data later in the day, following recent US rallies. The US job data is expected to provide insight into the US economy, influencing global markets.

site_title: Walmart to lift wages for 565,000 US workers
summary: Walmart is increasing wages for approximately 565,000 US employees, with at least a $1 hourly increase, starting this month. The move aims to attract and retain staff in the tight American labor market. The new wage increase lifts the average hourly wage for Walmart workers to $16.40, still short of the $15 hourly target by unions and progressive allies. The company has previously raised wages for 425,000 and 165,000 employees, and also dropped fees for workers participating in an employee education program.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, ST Engineering, Olam, SingPost
summary: Singtel agreed to sell 4,000 telecommunication towers to Mitratel for S$580 million, with a 10-year lease arrangement. ST Engineering secured an S$180 million contract for MRT and LRT system renewal. Olam priced US$81 million five-year notes at 1.61% interest. SingPost agreed to sell its subsidiary Lock+Store to Triforce Investments for S$85.1 million, expected to net a S$6 million gain.

site_title: Amazon to roll out its own TV in US by October: Business Insider
summary: Amazon plans to launch its own branded TV in the US by October, according to Business Insider. The TVs, powered by voice assistant Alexa, have been in development for almost two years and are currently manufactured by third parties. This marks Amazon's entry into the US TV market, following the launch of an AmazonBasics TV in India last year.

site_title: Singapore stocks open little changed on Friday; STI down 0.02%
summary: Singapore stocks opened little changed on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.02% at 3,088.32. Gainers outnumbered losers 91 to 51, with active trading in Mercurius 5RF and Singapore Exchange (SGX) S68. Index stocks Singtel and DBS rose, while OCBC fell. In the US, equity indices closed at record highs, and European shares rose as oil stocks surged on economic growth expectations.

site_title: Yoshihide Suga, self-made politician who struggled as Japan's premier
summary: Yoshihide Suga, Japan's 72-year-old prime minister, unexpectedly announced he would not contest his party's leadership race, effectively ending his tenure after just a year in office. Suga's government faced low approval ratings due to its handling of the coronavirus pandemic, contributing to his decision. This marks a troubled and short-lived time for the self-made politician who rose to power through hard work and determination.

images.alt_text: He battled his way to the top of Japanese politics, but once Yoshihide Suga reached the prime minister's office, his tenure was troubled and short-lived.

site_title: US hedge fund executives pay US$7b to settle tax dispute: report
summary: Top executives at Renaissance Technologies hedge fund have agreed to pay US$7 billion to settle a tax dispute with the IRS. The payment includes US$670 million from hedge fund founder James Simons and additional sums from seven board members and their spouses. The settlement resolves a dispute over tax reporting on the Medallion fund between 2005 and 2015, in which the firm declared short-term gains as less heavily taxed long-term profits. The payments will also affect investors who have invested in the fund during the period in question.

site_title: Two unions end strike at world's largest copper producer
summary: Two unions at Chile's state mining company Codelco, the world's largest copper producer, have ended their strike action after reaching a three-year collective agreement. The agreement follows a 53% vote in favor by union members, resolving a dispute over a labor agreement proposal that removed health benefits and compensation for new employees. The strike, which began in mid-August, involved 1,300 workers out of 1,437 at Codelco's Andina division, which produces over 184,000 metric tons of copper annually.

site_title: New senior government appointments, including move by EDB MD
summary: Singapore's Smart Nation and Digital Government Group will have two new second permanent secretaries, Mr Chng Kai Fong and Ms Lim Wan Yong, starting October 4. Mr Chng, the current EDB managing director, and Ms Lim, the current deputy secretary for planning at the Ministry of National Development, will replace outgoing officials. Other appointments include Ms Teoh Zsin Woon as second permanent secretary at the Ministry of National Development and PSD, and Ms Lai Wei Lin as second permanent secretary for education and finance.

site_title: Why closing Yale-NUS is bad for business
summary: Singapore's policymakers emphasize openness despite rising nationalism and global rivalries, warning that closing Yale-NUS would damage its international reputation and cost investments, jobs, and opportunities. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that Singapore cannot appear hostile to foreigners, which would be disastrous for the country's aspirations.

site_title: US grounds Virgin Galactic after space flight 'mishap'
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) grounded Virgin Galactic's space flights after an investigation revealed that the company's July mission deviated from its planned trajectory. The flight, carrying Richard Branson, experienced cockpit warnings about its rocket-powered ascent, which could have jeopardized the mission. Virgin Galactic disputed the characterization of the incident, stating that the pilots responded appropriately and the deviation was within mission parameters. The FAA has not approved the final investigation report, and Virgin Galactic may not return the SpaceShipTwo vehicle to flight until public safety concerns are resolved.

site_title: WhatsApp fined 225 million euros over personal data transparency breaches
summary: WhatsApp has been fined 225 million euros by the Irish Data Protection Commission for failing to be transparent about how it handled personal information, in violation of the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation. The fine is the messaging service's first under the GDPR law, which allows for fines of up to 4% of annual sales. WhatsApp has disputed the decision and plans to appeal, while the Irish authority has ordered the service to take remedial action to bring its data processing communication into compliance.

site_title: Hurricane Ida's deluge stuns New Yorkers in its sheer intensity
summary: Hurricane Ida brought record-breaking rainfall to the Northeast, causing widespread flooding in New York City. The storm's remnants brought 15-20cm of rain, with 8cm recorded in Manhattan, breaking previous hourly records. Cars were submerged in water, and at least six residents were found dead or near death due to the floods. New York officials emphasized the scientific consensus that human-caused climate change is increasing the frequency and impact of natural disasters like Ida. The storm highlighted the need for infrastructure improvements, with Mayor Bill de Blasio calling it a "biggest wake-up call" for the US to address climate change.

site_title: Apple bends to pressure, aiming to avoid Big Tech regulation
summary: Apple has unveiled changes to its app store in response to pressure from regulators and critics, aiming to avoid deeper regulation of Big Tech. The company has agreed to allow media apps to bypass its payment system and has loosened payment restrictions on its App Store. The changes are seen as a preemptive move to avoid government action, but experts say they may not be enough to satisfy regulators and developers. Apple's concessions come as lawmakers debate legislation to curb the power of Big Tech companies, and other countries, such as South Korea, have passed laws banning forced payment systems.

site_title: Australia announces Pfizer coronavirus vaccine swap deal with Britain
summary: Australia has agreed to swap 4 million Pfizer coronavirus vaccine doses with Britain, with deliveries set to reach the country over the next few weeks. The deal, announced by Prime Minister Scott Morrison, will help double the available Pfizer shots for September. This comes days after a smaller swap agreement was announced with Singapore. The Pfizer doses will be used to boost Australia's vaccine supply amid ongoing efforts to combat the pandemic.

site_title: WTO rules for US in Chinese solar tariff dispute
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) ruled in favor of the US in a dispute with China over tariffs on solar panels, rejecting all of China's claims. The US imposed tariffs in 2018 to protect its solar producers, sparking a trade war. The duties were set to end next February but will now slide from 30% to 15% over four years. US Trade Representative Katherine Tai hailed the decision, calling it "baseless" and stating the US must invest in solar power to address the climate crisis.

site_title: UK employers keep up the hunt for staff after lockdowns and Brexit
summary: Employers in the UK continue to seek new staff despite the pandemic and Brexit, with 1.66 million job advertisements active as of August 29. This is higher than pre-pandemic levels and reflects a tight labor market. The unemployment rate remains at 4.7%, higher than before the crisis, but partly due to a rise in non-employed workers. The government's wage subsidy scheme will end by September, and employers are concerned about the impact of post-Brexit immigration rules on sectors like logistics and hospitality.

site_title: Singapore tax collection down 7.3%, first fall in over 15 years
summary: Singapore's tax collection dropped 7.3% in FY2020/21, the first decline in over 15 years, due to dampened business activities amid the pandemic. The collection, which represents 73.6% of the government's operating revenue, fell to S$49.6 billion. The main contributors to the decline were corporate income tax and property taxes, with collections decreasing by 3.7% and 34.3% respectively. Despite this, the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) disbursed a total of S$28.2 billion in grants to support jobs and businesses.

site_title: King Wan shares up 51.3% amid ongoing talks on potential joint venture
summary: King Wan Corp's share price surged 51.3% on Thursday after the company confirmed ongoing talks on a potential joint venture for retrofitting and upgrading solutions. The company stated that there's no assurance a transaction will occur, and it doesn't expect a significant impact on earnings per share or net tangible assets. King Wan is exploring opportunities to diversify its business and revenue streams, and will make announcements if necessary.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall and layoffs drop to 24-year low
summary: US jobless claims fell to 340,000 in the week ending August 28, a 24-year low, while layoffs dropped to their lowest level since 1997, suggesting the labor market is strong despite the surge in Covid-19 infections. Initial claims have dropped from a record 6.149 million in April 2020, but remain above the 200,000-250,000 range considered healthy. Economists expect job growth to continue in August, despite concerns about the impact of the Delta variant.

site_title: Oil rises on economic recovery hopes, weaker dollar
summary: Oil prices rose over $1 a barrel on Thursday, driven by optimism about global economic growth and a weaker US dollar. Brent crude and West Texas Intermediate crude surged 2% to $73.03 and $69.99, respectively, after the US reported a 7.2 million-barrel drop in crude inventories. The rally is seen as a bullish signal for investors, with Opec+ raising its demand forecast for 2022 and the US labor market showing signs of recovery despite new Covid-19 infections.

site_title: Europe: Oil stocks push bourses higher, SOBI leads gains
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Thursday, driven by oil stocks' 1.8% gain as crude prices surged on economic recovery optimism. SOBI, a Swedish drugmaker, led gains after accepting a $8 billion takeover offer. The Stoxx 600 index was boosted by mining and healthcare stocks.

site_title: 3 lessons business schools can leverage to innovate for success
summary: Business schools can innovate for success by leveraging technology, collaboration, and a willingness to take calculated risks. Three key lessons include: (1) collaborating across boundaries with other schools, departments, and organizations to foster a broader business perspective, (2) allowing room for failure to teach future leaders the importance of learning from mistakes, and (3) innovating based on specific goals and objectives, rather than just for the sake of innovation. By adopting these strategies, business schools can help students acquire the skills and abilities needed to thrive in the digital economy and become dynamic, agile, and inspiring business leaders.

site_title: The sky's the limit: Exploring the next dimension in mobility
summary: Singapore is at the forefront of advanced air mobility, with the city-state being a "living laboratory" for electric vertical take-off and landing (eVTOL) aircraft. The industry aims to provide a sustainable alternative to travel, connecting underserved locations and reducing congestion in cities. By 2050, 75% of the global population will live in cities, putting strain on streets, and eVTOL air-taxis could be worth $9 trillion. The government is driving innovation, aligning with its Smart Nation vision and zero-energy strategies, and consulting experts in global engineering and sustainable design to combine traditional and futuristic approaches.

site_title: Straits Times Index components unchanged after September review
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) constituents remain unchanged following the September quarterly review. The reserve list, consisting of Olam International, Suntec Real Estate Investment Trust, Keppel Reit, Frasers Centrepoint Trust, and NetLink NBN Trust, remains unchanged.

site_title: Why is Covid-19 surging in America again?
summary: The Covid-19 pandemic is surging in America again, primarily due to the Delta variant and low vaccination rates. Despite this, the Biden administration's approach is deemed effective, with bipartisan support in vaccine development. The federal government's limitations in addressing public health issues are acknowledged, but cooperation between the government and private companies has been successful in mobilizing scientific firepower. Staying the course and ignoring detractors is advised, as the administration's current strategies are having the best possible effect under the circumstances.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq end at records ahead of August jobs data
summary: The US stock market ended at records on Thursday, ahead of the August jobs report, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching new highs. The Labor Department reported 340,000 new jobless claims, the lowest since March 2020, and a projected 750,000 jobs added last month, resulting in a 5.2% unemployment rate. This data is expected to influence the August employment report on Friday.

images.alt_text: Major US equity indices again finished at records on Thursday following better weekly jobless claim data ahead of the closely-watched August employment report.

site_title: Two ex-UOB Kay Hian employees banned for giving false information to MAS
summary: Two former UOB Kay Hian employees, Lan Kangming and Wee Toon Lee, have been banned by the Monetary Authority of Singapore for providing false information during the due diligence process for an initial public offering. The employees were convicted of one charge each and fined S$3,000. They are prohibited from performing any regulated activity for four and three years, respectively, and from managing or being a substantial shareholder of a capital market services firm. The ban aims to protect investors and maintain the integrity of Singapore's capital markets.

site_title: Aluminium prices hit more than 10-year high as supply fears grow
summary: Aluminium prices reached a 10-year high due to supply concerns in India, the second-largest aluminium producer. Coal shortages at power plants have raised fears of disruption to domestic aluminium output. Benchmark prices rose 1.4% to US$2,727.50 a tonne on the London Metal Exchange, with China's State Reserve Bureau releasing 70,000 tonnes of aluminium ingots into the market. The move has slightly eased supply fears, but the situation is being closely monitored.

site_title: A big fight lies ahead for US labour to lock in gains made during pandemic
summary: US labor is poised to make significant gains as the pandemic's economic impact recedes, with millions of jobs being re-hired with better salaries. However, union leaders caution that these gains are fragile and may be short-lived without sustained labor protections. The Biden administration has signaled a more worker-friendly approach, but legislative efforts to raise the minimum wage and strengthen union rights remain stalled. With unemployment benefits set to expire, workers may struggle to maintain their newfound bargaining power, highlighting the need for long-term solutions to address the country's long-standing labor inequality.

site_title: Consortium wins S$180m contract to renew rail communications system
summary: A consortium led by Singapore Technologies (ST) Engineering and Siemens Mobility has won an S$180 million contract to renew and modernize the communications system for Singapore's MRT and LRT lines. The renewal program, valued at S$180 million, will replace and upgrade existing systems on 75 locations, including stations and control centers, and is expected to be fully operational by 2029. The upgrade aims to improve safety, reliability, and efficiency, contributing to a better commuter travel experience.

site_title: Building a canon of Singapore music
summary: The Foundation For The Arts & Social Enterprise in Singapore is commissioning 10 full-length music pieces covering various genres, including classical, Chinese orchestra, rock, and jazz. The project aims to create a "Singapore sound" that can be performed globally. The first commission, a 30-minute classical piece, is being composed by Kelly Tang and will be performed by the Metropolitan Festival Orchestra. The goal is to establish a lasting canon of Singapore music and promote it internationally, with the support of major funding patrons.

site_title: Goodbye, prejudice. Hello, Miss Universe Singapore
summary: Miss Universe Singapore is revamping its competition to become more inclusive, welcoming contestants with diverse physical characteristics, identities, and cultural backgrounds. The pageant aims to shift its focus from physical beauty to celebrating women's empowerment and individuality. The revamped competition will feature contestants with disabilities, Muslim women who want to wear hijabs, and women with prosthetic limbs, among others. The goal is to create a more representative and inclusive platform for women from all walks of life.

site_title: International students flocking back to London find themselves in a race for scarce housing
summary: International students are returning to London, driving up demand for housing in the city's rental market. Applicant registrations have almost doubled in the last couple of weeks, with international students making up 70% of applicants for east London's Canary Wharf district. The surge in interest is pushing up rents, with prices increasing by 15% in the past two months. Many international students are having to sign contracts without viewing properties in person, making it a "perfect storm" of high demand and limited supply.

images.alt_text: The east London district of Canary Wharf saw international students making up 70 per cent of rental applicants through property websites, according to Jones Lang LaSalle Inc.

site_title: S-Reits more leveraged but still cautious in taking up new debt obligations: IREUS
summary: Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) maintained disciplined debt management despite the Covid-19 pandemic, with average debt ratios increasing in FY2020. Hospitality S-Reits saw the largest jump, with average gearing rising to 40.4%, while office S-Reits posted the smallest increase. Retail and industrial S-Reits also experienced debt ratio increases, but at a milder pace. Some S-Reits, such as Ascott Residence Trust, have lowered their gearing, indicating a cautious approach to new debt obligations. The Monetary Authority of Singapore raised the leverage limit to 50% to offer more flexibility to S-Reits.

site_title: New York passes bill extending eviction moratorium to January
summary: New York state lawmakers have agreed to extend eviction moratoriums until January, providing protections for hundreds of thousands of renters. The move comes after the US Supreme Court rejected the Biden administration's moratorium and amid concerns about widespread evictions. The new legislation creates one of the most extensive protections in the nation, offering renters more time and stability to access rent relief programs. The measure was passed despite potential court challenges from landlord groups.

site_title: Inflation shock, ECB hawks keep euro near 1-month high
summary: The euro remains near a one-month high against the US dollar, supported by hawkish comments from European Central Bank policymakers following data showing a decade-high inflation rate. The euro also reached a six-week peak against the pound, driven by strong manufacturing growth and supply chain snarls. In contrast, the US dollar has lost 1.4% against a basket of currencies due to doubts about the Federal Reserve's stimulus unwinding timeline.

site_title: China likely to keep curbs on international flights throughout H1 2022
summary: China's aviation regulator is likely to maintain tight caps on international flights throughout the first half of 2022, according to analysts. This move has significant implications for tourism in the Asia-Pacific region, where Chinese travelers play a major role. The current restrictions, which have reduced weekly international flights to 2% of 2019 levels, may delay a full recovery in international travel until 2024. Chinese airlines expect the restrictions to remain in place until after the first half of 2022, citing low vaccination rates and rising Covid-19 cases in developing countries.

site_title: Singapore creativity on the international stage
summary: Singaporean brands are making a strong presence on the international design stage despite the pandemic, with several local designers showcasing their works at Milan Design Week and Paris. Supermama's Edwin Low will partner with a designer to showcase his collection "Social Wares" at Milan Design Week, while Mashizan Masjum is hosting a pop-up concept store "From Singapore to Paris: A Journey of the Five Senses" in Paris. Meanwhile, the Singapore Pavilion at Expo 2020 Dubai is set to open on October 1, featuring a green design and interactive elements, including a Flower Cone with native orchid varieties.

site_title: Marks of Good Design
summary: A study desk made from cardboard, called the #HBL Table, has won the Singapore Good Design Award (SG Mark) for its impact on children from underprivileged families during the Covid-19 pandemic. This year's award saw 158 submissions across seven categories, with a new category added to recognize solutions born out of the pandemic. Other winners include Singapore Airlines' Seamless Travel Experience Digital Suite, which combats changing travel situations, and the Singapore Together category, which showcases creative solutions to pandemic-related challenges.

site_title: The world needs to start travelling again; here's how to get going
summary: The world needs a global vaccine certification system to safely reopen borders and stimulate international trade, which has been disrupted by travel restrictions. A seamless, data-driven system would recognize effective vaccines for travel, track their effectiveness, and certify vaccinated individuals' status. This would be complemented by expanded genomic surveillance to update vaccine recognition based on the latest data. The G-20 can play a crucial role in establishing this system, and its success depends on the recognition of vaccines across borders, with a central list of approved vaccines and science-driven decisions on travel policies.

site_title: Sim Leisure to raise S$3.6m through sale of new shares
summary: Sim Leisure Group, a Singaporean theme park operator, plans to sell new ordinary shares to two controlling shareholders at a 5.9% discount to raise S$3.6 million. The shares will be sold to the company's non-independent non-executive director Tan Boon Seng, whose stake will increase to 26.95% of the enlarged share capital. The proposed share subscription aims to raise funds for the company's operations.

site_title: Temasek-backed Covid-19 test provider Oxford Nanopore to launch LSE IPO: Sources
summary: Oxford Nanopore, a Covid-19 test provider backed by Temasek, is set to launch an initial public offering (IPO) on the London Stock Exchange (LSE) in the coming weeks. The company aims to build on its £2.48 billion valuation and strengthen Britain's efforts to attract life science businesses to its main stock market. Bank of America, Citi, and JPMorgan are global coordinators for the listing, which is a major win for London's main market. The IPO is part of a crowded pipeline of share sales expected in London and other European centres in 2021.

site_title: DBS initiates coverage on SBS Transit with 'hold' call, S$3.44 target price
summary: DBS Group Research has initiated coverage on SBS Transit with a "hold" call and a target price of S$3.44, representing 21.7 times FY2022 price-to-earnings estimates. The research firm is cautious due to the government's fiscal measures in response to Covid-19. The target price is close to SBS Transit's 10-year mean forward P/E and P/B values, indicating a relatively stable outlook.

site_title: OCBC CEO comes full circle, with a China lens
summary: OCBC CEO Helen Wong, the first female CEO of the Singapore bank, aims to repeat her previous success in doubling wealth bankers over two years, expanding the bank's China-Asean network and data analytics capabilities. Wong, who previously led HSBC's Greater China business, seeks to build on OCBC's "very reasonable" presence in Greater China and capitalize on the upcoming Wealth Management Connect, which will allow residents of nine Guangdong cities to buy funds and other investment products from Hong Kong banks. She emphasizes the importance of collaboration, data analytics, and targeted investments to tap into emerging markets, particularly in Indonesia.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SingPost sold its General Storage Company (Lock+Store) to Triforce Investments for S$85.1 million, resulting in a gain of about S$6 million. Olam International priced S$110 million five-year notes at 1.61% interest. GK Goh Holdings appointed SAC Capital Private Ltd as its financial adviser for the sale of Boardroom to a Temasek-related consortium for around S$312 million.

site_title: Mapping Singapore's clean energy transition
summary: Singapore is transitioning to a low-carbon future, with concerns over increasing electricity demand, cost stability, and viability of clean energy sources. The country aims to balance growth with sustainability, with alternative energy sources such as solar and wind power playing a key role. Experts and policymakers will need to navigate these challenges to ensure a smooth transition and maintain affordability. A roadmap for Singapore's clean energy transition is being mapped, with key decisions to be made in the coming years.

site_title: ECB warns banks of climate-test risks that could hit capital
summary: The European Central Bank is stepping up pressure on banks to prepare for stress tests next year that will assess their vulnerability to climate change. The ECB plans to study the link between profits and carbon risk in banks' portfolios and will require banks to provide data on how their balance sheets might fare through 2050. The regulator has expressed concerns that banks are not adequately prepared for climate risks, with a study suggesting the average default probability in loan portfolios of the most vulnerable banks could rise by 30% by 2050.

site_title: Shades of Hong Kong-style dining at Pi Food
summary: Pi Food, a new Singaporean restaurant, offers a unique blend of Hong Kong-style dining with a modern twist. The restaurant's chef, an ex-sous chef from Hong Kong's Lei Garden, brings authenticity to dishes like shrimp wonton noodles and roast meats. Standouts include scrambled eggs, beef brisket, and five spice beef tripe noodles, which showcase the chef's skills. While the ambiance and hospitality need improvement, the food is promising, with some dishes hitting home but not quite adding up to perfection. Rating: 6.

site_title: US factory orders increase in July despite supply constraints
summary: US factory orders increased 0.4% in July, driven by primary metals and machinery, despite supply constraints. Orders rose 18.0% year-over-year, indicating strong demand for goods. Despite a shift back to services, businesses remain eager to restock, supporting manufacturing. The Institute for Supply Management reported an unexpected increase in August orders, and business spending on equipment remained robust, contributing to GDP growth. Supply constraints limited orders for computers and electronic products.

site_title: Going full metal
summary: Luxury watch brands are embracing the trend of metal-strapped watches, popularized by the pandemic's shift to casual wear. Brands such as H Moser & Cie, Panerai, and IWC have introduced new sporty models with metal bracelets, targeting the growing demand for rugged and informal timepieces. The H Moser & Cie Streamliner Perpetual Calendar and Panerai Submersible Blu Notte feature stainless steel bracelets, while IWC's Pilot's Watch Chronograph 41 offers a choice of metal bracelets. These watches showcase the brands' adaptability to changing consumer preferences.

site_title: US: Stocks advance in countdown to key payrolls data
summary: US stocks rose ahead of key jobs data, with the S&P 500 trading near a record. Applications for US state unemployment benefits fell to a fresh pandemic low, and Treasury yields remained unchanged. The jobs data, due on Friday, is expected to show 725,000 jobs added in August. The Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions will be influenced by the data, which will also shape forecasts for the fed funds rate. Cryptocurrency-exposed stocks climbed, while Netflix and Moderna also gained on positive news.

site_title: UK's Barratt targets pre-pandemic levels of home completions for FY22
summary: Barratt Developments Plc, the UK's largest homebuilder, aims to reach pre-pandemic levels of home completions by the end of FY22, citing strong demand for houses and a preference for larger homes during the pandemic. The company plans to complete 17,000-17,250 homes, up from 17,856 in the pre-pandemic year of 2019. Barratt's forward sales stand at £3.94 billion, and the company declared a final dividend of 21.9 pence per share. This forecast follows similar predictions from other UK homebuilders, despite recent data suggesting a cooling housing market.

site_title: BitConnect founder charged with US$2b cryptocurrency fraud
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has charged BitConnect founder Satish Kumbhani with allegedly raising about US$2 billion from thousands of retail investors through fraudulent means. The SEC also charged promoter Glenn Arcaro with lying about BitConnect's ability to generate profits and violating registration laws. The SEC seeks to impose fines and recoup ill-gotten gains, and has already obtained judgments requiring two other BitConnect promoters to pay over US$3.5 million. Arcaro pleaded guilty to a related criminal wire fraud conspiracy charge and will be sentenced on November 15.

site_title: For France, American vines still mean sour grapes
summary: In southern France, American grape varieties, banned since 1934, are thriving, defying the French government's efforts to eradicate them. Despite claims they produce bad wine and harm human health, these hybrids have become a lifeline for some winemakers, particularly in rural areas where climate change has devastated traditional vineyards. The French government's prohibition is based on flawed arguments, and a growing movement is advocating for the legalization of these American grapes, which could revitalize France's wine industry and open it up to new, sustainable practices.

site_title: Indonesia tells banks to give 30% of loans to small firms
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, has required lenders to disburse at least 30% of their loans to small companies, known as MSMEs, by 2024. This move aims to revive slow credit growth and support the nation's economic recovery. The rules apply to both Islamic and non-Islamic lenders, with a maximum penalty of 5 billion rupiah for those failing to meet the threshold. The goal is to boost credit to Indonesia's 64 million MSMEs, many of which lack access to formal financing.

site_title: Online broker CMC sounds profit warning as market volatility eases
summary: Online trading platform CMC Markets has issued a profit warning, cutting its annual earnings outlook by up to £80 million due to reduced market volatility and lower transaction volumes. The company now expects fiscal year 2022 operating income of £250-280 million, down from earlier guidance of £330 million. Client numbers remain up around a third from pre-pandemic levels, and assets under management remain near record levels, despite higher operating costs.

site_title: Seven in 10 Singaporeans consume SPH content and many are willing to pay: survey
summary: A survey in Singapore found that 7 out of 10 Singaporeans consume content from Singapore Press Holdings (SPH), with The Straits Times reaching 44% of the population weekly. SPH's news properties are available across various platforms. Meanwhile, a popiah king made a mandatory offer for the rest of PSC at S$0.40 per share, and US shoemaker Levi reported revenue growth despite facing 190% tariffs.

site_title: Singtel's JV company to sell 4,000 telecommunication towers to Indonesian company
summary: Singtel's joint-venture company, PT Telekomunikasi Selular (Telkomsel), has entered into a sale-and-purchase agreement to sell 4,000 telecommunication towers to PT Dayamitra Telekomunikasi (Mitratel) for IDR6.2 trillion (S$580 million). The deal includes a 10-year lease arrangement for tower space, allowing Telkomsel to optimize its capital structure and focus on digital connectivity services. The transaction is expected to strengthen Mitratel's position as a business consolidator in the telecommunication tower business in Indonesia.

site_title: Australia: Shares end at two-week low as BHP tumbles on ex-div trade
summary: Australian shares ended 0.6% lower at a two-week low, dragged by BHP Group's 7% drop after trading ex-dividend and a slump in iron ore prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 7,485.7. Gold stocks fell 2% despite unchanged bullion prices, while healthcare stocks declined 1.1% due to concerns over Covid-19 lockdowns. In contrast, biotech firm Mesoblast rose after investors snapped up cheapened shares following a disappointing earnings report.

site_title: US second-quarter productivity revised lower
summary: US worker productivity grew at a 2.1% annualized rate in the second quarter, down from the initially reported 2.3% pace. This was slower than economists' expectations of a 2.4% rate. Productivity increased 4.3% in the first quarter and 1.8% compared to the second quarter of 2020. Hours worked rose 6.0% and unit labor costs grew 1.3%, while hourly compensation increased 3.4%. The slower productivity growth may be attributed to the pandemic's impact on lower-wage industries, such as leisure and hospitality.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall; layoffs at 24-year low
summary: US jobless claims fell to 340,000 in the week ended Aug 28, the lowest level since mid-March 2020. Layoffs dropped to a 24-year low in August, with 15,723 job cuts announced, a 17% decrease from the previous year. Economists expect the employment report to show the economy continued to add jobs rapidly in August, despite new Covid-19 infections. The pandemic has created worker shortages, but the government-funded unemployment benefits are set to lapse on Sept 6, which may ease the labor crunch.

images.alt_text: The number of Americans filing new claims for jobless benefits fell last week, while layoffs dropped to their lowest level in more than 24 years in August, suggesting that the labour market was charging ahead even as new Covid-19 infections surge.

site_title: Portfolio of 9 villas at Oei Tiong Ham Park for sale at S$100 million guide price
summary: Singapore conglomerate Wywy Group is selling its 9 villas at Oei Tiong Ham Park Residences for S$100 million, with a guide price of S$8-13 million per unit. The villas, ranging from 3,401-5,888 sq ft, are priced at S$2,500 per sq ft. The freehold luxury development comprises three blocks, each with an apartment occupying each storey. The sale marks a significant move in the Singapore property market, with villas typically commanding higher prices than apartments.

site_title: ST Engineering, Siemens Mobility win S$180m contract to renew communications system for Singapore's rail lines
summary: ST Engineering and Siemens Mobility have won a S$180 million contract to renew and modernize Singapore's rail communications systems. The renewal program will upgrade existing systems on the North South and East West Lines, as well as select stations on the Bukit Panjang LRT line. This marks the first major upgrade since the lines began operations over 20 years ago.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end the day lower
summary: Malaysia's shares ended the day lower, closing at 1,582.19, down 4.7 points. The FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index saw 4.048 billion lots traded worth RM2.762 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 574 to 434.

site_title: China's restrictions on international flights could last to 2022
summary: China's top airlines predict international flight restrictions could last into 2022, hindering a full recovery until 2024. The "Five One" policy limits airlines to one international flight per week and caps passenger capacity at 75%. Analysts expect China to reopen with countries like Singapore and South Korea, prioritizing high vaccination rates. Despite a domestic rebound in 2021, fresh Covid outbreaks stalled progress, and the situation has been brought under control. The prolonged restrictions will likely impact global travel demand.

site_title: China to set up Beijing stock exchange for SMEs, says Xi
summary: China plans to establish a stock exchange in Beijing to serve small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), according to President Xi Jinping. The move aims to deepen financial reforms and support innovation-driven development of SMEs. The Beijing stock exchange will be the primary platform for innovation-oriented SMEs, and China's securities regulator will study and implement the proposal. The goal is to create more possibilities for cooperation and support the growth of the services sector in Belt and Road countries.

images.alt_text: China's President Xi Jinping on Thursday said the country would set up a stock exchange in its capital, Beijing, to serve small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).

site_title: Eleven of Singapore's smaller Reits enter FTSE EPRA Nareit Global Real Estate Index
summary: Eleven Singaporean Real Estate Investment Trusts (Reits) have been added to the FTSE EPRA Nareit Global Real Estate Index series, marking an increase in additions due to lowered investable market cap thresholds. The entrants include Aims Apac Reit, ARA Logos Logistics Trust, and Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit, among others. Managers of the Reits hailed the inclusion as a milestone, citing enhanced trading liquidity and visibility to investors worldwide. The review is subject to changes until September 3, with the new constituents taking effect on September 17.

site_title: Food prices are at risk as the world runs short of workers
summary: A global labor shortage is threatening food supply chains, with workers in key roles such as fruit pickers, slaughterhouse workers, and truckers in short supply. This has led to significant wage increases, with some employers offering bonuses and perks to attract new staff. The shortage is expected to push up food prices, which were already up 31% in July from the same month last year. The pandemic has exacerbated the issue, with border restrictions and Covid outbreaks affecting production and supply chains. Employers are being forced to invest in automation and robotics to address the labor shortage, but it will take years for these solutions to fully materialize.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end 1% lower ahead of US jobs data; snaps four-day rally
summary: South Korean stocks ended a four-day rally 1% lower on Thursday ahead of US jobs data, which may influence the Federal Reserve's stimulus reduction timeline. The Kospi dropped 31.17 points, with tech giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix falling 1.04% and 1.39%, respectively. Foreigners sold 382 billion won worth of shares, and investors await US non-farm payrolls data for clues on the Fed's plans.

site_title: Medtech firm Baxter to buy hospital-bed maker Hill-Rom for US$10.5b
summary: US medtech firm Baxter International is set to acquire rival hospital-bed maker Hill-Rom Holdings for approximately $10.5 billion, adding smart hospital beds to its portfolio. The deal, valued at $156 per Hill-Rom share, is a 7.5% premium to the stock's last close. Baxter expects the acquisition to close early next year and drive earnings growth by over 20% within three years. Analysts have expressed mixed views, with some citing concerns over Hill-Rom's slow-growing revenue. The deal is the latest in the medical equipment sector's recovery from the pandemic-driven slump.

site_title: Hot stock: King Wan shares up 51.3% amid ongoing talks for potential joint venture
summary: King Wan Corporation shares rose 51.3% amid ongoing talks for a potential joint venture with an undisclosed party to carry out retrofitting and upgrading solutions. The company has disclosed the discussions in response to the Singapore Exchange's query on unusual trading activity. Despite uncertainty about the outcome, King Wan expressed confidence in its business expansion and revenue diversification efforts. The company's shares ended at 5.9 Singapore cents, marking the second consecutive day of heavy trading.

site_title: Olam prices JPY9b 5-year notes at 1.61% in private placement
summary: Olam International priced JPY 9 billion (US$81 million) 5-year notes at 1.61% for a private placement, part of its US$5 billion euro medium term note programme. The notes mature on September 2, 2026, and will be used for working capital and general corporate purposes. Societe Generale (Singapore) managed the transaction.

site_title: Singapore PMI dips alongside weakening manufacturing sentiment in Asia
summary: Singapore's manufacturing PMI dipped 0.1 point to 51, still indicating growth for the 14th consecutive month. However, the dip is attributed to a "slightly softer" external environment, slower growth in new orders, exports, and factory output, and global supply chain disruptions. Economists expect the PMI to moderate further in the months ahead due to new Covid-19 variants and restrictions. The decline in manufacturing PMI follows weaker readings in China, Taiwan, and South Korea, and reflects the significant impact of Covid-19 outbreaks on Asian economies.

site_title: Paralympics: Singapore swimmer Yip Pin Xiu retains S2 50m backstroke title for second gold in Tokyo
summary: Singapore swimmer Yip Pin Xiu won her second gold of the Tokyo 2020 Paralympics, retaining the S2 50m backstroke title with a time of 1:02.04 seconds. This victory maintains her record in the event, achieved at the 2016 Rio Paralympics. Japan's Miyuki Yamada took the silver and China's Feng Yazhu won the bronze. Yip, 29, also holds the world record in the S2 100m backstroke, which she won last week.

site_title: Singapore stocks little changed on Thursday amid cautious trading; STI up 0.03%
summary: Singapore stocks remained largely unchanged on Thursday, closing up 0.03% at 3,088.84 points, amid cautious trading due to increasing Covid-19 cases. Despite 80% of the population being fully vaccinated, concerns over reopening plans led to a cautious market. Top performers included Mapletree Logistics Trust and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, while local banks like DBS, UOB, and OCBC closed lower. Asian markets were mixed, with some indices, such as the Hang Seng and Nikkei 225, rising, while others, like the Kospi, fell.

site_title: No change to components on the Straits Times Index after September review
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) constituents will not undergo any changes following the September quarterly review. The reserve list of non-constituents, including Olam International, Suntec Real Estate Investment Trust, and Keppel Reit, will replace ineligible constituents through corporate actions before the next review in December. The STI, jointly calculated by FTSE Russell, Singapore Press Holdings, and the Singapore Exchange, is reviewed quarterly to include eligible initial public offering stocks and accurately represent the investable universe for benchmarking purposes.

site_title: Malaysia uses Phuket 'sandbox' to reopen Langkawi
summary: Malaysia plans to reopen Langkawi island as part of its effort to rebuild the economy after the pandemic. The island will open to locals under a travel bubble plan starting Sept 16, with other destinations allowed to operate when the local vaccination rate reaches 80%. The country is preparing to live with Covid-19, with a current vaccination rate of over 84% among adults, and aims to reach 100% by end of October. This follows Thailand's tourism-reopening plan based on a pilot project in Phuket.

site_title: Heliconia, with AUM over S$2b, hunts investments in new consumer trends
summary: Heliconia Capital, a Temasek unit, has exceeded S$2 billion in assets under management (AUM) and is investing in companies that capitalize on shifting consumer behavior. The firm focuses on product companies with strong branding and user communities, such as luxury handcrafted pop culture collectibles maker XM Studios and e-sports chair manufacturer Secretlab. Heliconia's CEO Derek Lau attributes the surge in consumer spending towards products to the pandemic, citing the rise of direct-to-consumer models and global consumer lifestyle investments.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes up for fourth straight session
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index rose 0.33% to 28,543.51 for a fourth consecutive session, driven by cautious trade ahead of US jobs data. The broader Topix index also edged up 0.14% to 1,983.57. The gains come as traders await US jobs data and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Taliban close to forming government as women protest
summary: The Taliban is nearing the formation of a new government in Afghanistan, with dozens of women protesting for the right to work under the new regime. Despite pledging a softer rule, the group's hardline leader Sher Mohammad Abbas Stanikzai expressed skepticism about women's participation in the Cabinet. Women in the western city of Herat held a rare protest, chanting for education, work, and security. The Taliban's economic hurdles and public mistrust pose significant challenges as they transform from an insurgent group to a governing power.

site_title: Tax collection down by 7.3% to S$49.6b due to Covid-19: Iras
summary: Singapore's tax collection fell 7.3% to S$49.6 billion in the last financial year due to dampened business activities amid the pandemic. This represents 73.6% of the government's operating revenue and 10.6% of the country's GDP. The decrease is attributed to the economic impact of the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: SingPost to sell General Storage Company for S$85.1 million
summary: SingPost announced the sale of its General Storage Company (Lock+Store) to Triforce Investments for S$85.1 million. The move is part of SingPost's strategy to recycle capital through divestment of non-core assets, resulting in a potential gain of S$6 million. Proceeds from the sale will be used for transformation initiatives and long-term growth. The transaction is expected to be completed on Oct 15, with the General Storage Company and its subsidiaries no longer part of the SingPost Group.

site_title: 187 new locally transmitted Covid-19 cases in Singapore, 113 are unlinked
summary: Singapore reported 187 new locally transmitted Covid-19 cases, with 113 unlinked cases, bringing the total to 67,991. Among the cases, three seniors aged above 70 who are partially vaccinated are at risk of serious illness. Four imported cases were also detected, with one case arriving in Singapore and three developing the illness while in isolation. The Ministry of Health will provide more details on Thursday night.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS initiates coverage on SBS Transit with 'hold', S$3.44 target price
summary: DBS Group Research has initiated coverage on SBS Transit with a "hold" rating and a target price of S$3.44, representing 21.7 times FY2022 price-to-earnings estimates. The analysts note that the future trajectory of commuting remains uncertain and that average daily rail ridership is likely to take time to recover. They project a 7% on-year increase in FY2022 revenue, partially to make up for unchanged public transport fares, but also expect a tapering of government support measures.

site_title: Europe: Stocks edge higher in cautious trading
summary: European stocks edged higher on Thursday, supported by oil and chemical companies, but gains were limited due to concerns over monetary policy and slowing global growth. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.1% as Asian shares declined due to worries over the Chinese economy. Investors remained cautious ahead of US jobs data on Friday, which could influence the Federal Reserve's policy tightening.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.24% to 26,090.43. The gains came despite a crackdown on the tech sector, with China giving several ride-hailing firms a dressing down. Meanwhile, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.84% and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.41%.

site_title: Asia: Most markets rise as dealers focus on recovery outlook
summary: Asian markets rose as investors focused on the recovery outlook amid easing Covid concerns. The Federal Reserve's cautious approach to tapering monetary policy and maintaining low interest rates boosted equities. Hong Kong led gains, followed by Shanghai and other regional markets. Despite a weak US private employment report, analysts expect the Fed to stick to its word and delay interest rate hikes, supporting risk assets. Oil prices extended losses after Opec agreed to lift output.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: Singaporeans consume 7 in 10 SPH content, with a willingness to pay; Binance.com flagged on Investor Alert List by MAS; MAS to collaborate on CBDCs for international settlements; Apple to loosen App Store payment policies; 11 smaller Reits enter FTSE EPRA Nareit Global Real Estate Index; Singapore stocks little changed, up 0.03%.

site_title: Gold little changed as US jobs data looms
summary: Gold prices remained steady at US$1,814.54 per ounce ahead of the US non-farm payrolls data, which is crucial to the Federal Reserve's tapering plan. The National Employment Report showed private employers hired fewer workers than expected in August, but the labor market continued to recover. The dollar index hovered near multi-week lows, and gold is considered a hedge against inflation and currency debasement. Global factory activity lost momentum in August due to the pandemic, and the euro zone economy is recovering from the pandemic with only "surgical" support needed.

site_title: China orders ride-hailing firms Didi, Meituan to stop 'disorderly expansion'
summary: China's regulators have ordered ride-hailing giants Didi Chuxing and Meituan to stop "disorderly expansion" and "vicious competition" tactics, citing poor behavior such as recruiting unqualified drivers and shifting operational risks to drivers. The companies must investigate internal problems and immediately rectify issues, including reducing their transaction fees and protecting passengers' personal data. This move is part of a national crackdown on the tech industry, with regulators also investigating cybersecurity concerns and considering a ban on overseas IPOs of tech firms handling sensitive user data.

site_title: Apple plans to loosen App Store payment policy
summary: Apple plans to loosen its App Store payment policy, allowing media apps to direct customers to their websites without paying a 30% commission. The change, set to be implemented early next year, follows an agreement with the Japan Fair Trade Commission to end an investigation. The modification will spare reader apps from paying the commission, allowing them to link to their websites for account creation and management. The move aims to protect user privacy and trust, and is part of a broader effort to address scrutiny over the App Store's tightly controlled online marketplace.

site_title: China slams 'incorrect' politics in show business, high actor pay
summary: China has instructed broadcasters to avoid artists with "incorrect political positions" and effeminate styles, as part of a crackdown on its entertainment industry. The move follows recent celebrity scandals involving tax evasion and sexual assault. China's communist authorities have stringent rules on content, including video games, movies, and music, and can censor anything deemed to violate core socialist values. The crackdown aims to cultivate a "patriotic atmosphere" in the industry.

site_title: Tesla's China output halted for days last month on chip shortage: sources
summary: Tesla temporarily halted production at its Shanghai factory in August due to a global semiconductor shortage, affecting its Model Y sports utility vehicle. The halt, lasting about four days, was caused by a lack of key electronic control units. Production is now back to normal. The shortage impacts the global automotive industry, with Toyota Motor cutting production by 40% and Maruti Suzuki India reducing volumes by 40%. Chinese EV upstart Nio is also struggling with supply chain issues.

site_title: SGX to allow SPAC listings from Friday, with minimum market cap of S$150m
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has announced that it will allow Special Purpose Acquisition Companies (SPACs) to list on its mainboard, starting from this Friday. The new rules, which were introduced after feedback from investors and market participants, include a minimum market capitalization of S$150 million, a lower minimum IPO price of S$5 per share, and increased sponsors' equity participation. The rules aim to provide greater certainty and choice for investors, while also protecting them from potential risks. The introduction of SPAC listings is expected to boost listing activity on the SGX, which has seen limited activity this year.

site_title: China expected to keep curbs on international flights throughout H1 2022: Air China to analysts
summary: China's aviation regulator is likely to maintain tight caps on international flights through the first half of 2022, according to analysts citing Air China. The current restrictions, which have limited international flights to 2% of 2019 levels, are expected to push a full recovery further out to 2024. Chinese airlines have warned that the recovery of outbound travel will be slower than in the US and Europe due to low vaccination rates in developing countries, and that restrictions may not be loosened until after the first half of 2022.

site_title: Indonesia tells banks to disburse 30% of loans to small firms
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, has required banks to disburse at least 30% of their loans to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) by 2024, aiming to revive slow credit growth and boost the economic recovery. The new rules apply to both Islamic and non-Islamic lenders, with penalties of up to five billion rupiah for those failing to meet the threshold. The move aims to support Indonesia's 64 million SMEs, which have been hindered by the protracted Covid-19 outbreak and limited access to formal financing.

site_title: Eleven of Singapore's smaller Reits enter FTSE EPRA Nareit Global Real Estate Index
summary: Eleven Singaporean smaller Real Estate Investment Trusts (Reits) have been added to the FTSE EPRA Nareit Global Real Estate Index series, up from 17 previously. The additions include AIMS APAC Reit, ARA Logos Logistics Trust, and Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit, among others. The increased number of additions is due to updated thresholds for the Developed Asia series, with the market cap threshold lowered to 0.1% for additions and 0.05% for deletions. Managers of the Reits say inclusion in the index will enhance trading liquidity and visibility to investors worldwide.

site_title: MAS bans Binance.com from unlicensed payment services, red flags it with Investor Alert List
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has banned Binance.com from providing unlicensed payment services to Singapore residents and added it to the Investor Alert List. The move follows similar crackdowns by regulators worldwide and is part of MAS's efforts to regulate the crypto exchange. Binance Asia Services, the Singapore unit of Binance, has submitted a licence application and is currently exempt from holding a licence for digital payment token services. The MAS will continue to review BAS's application and expects it to meet requirements under the Payment Services Act.

site_title: Are Singaporeans ready for retirement?
summary: Singaporeans face significant retirement concerns due to Covid-induced uncertainties, inflation, and longer life expectancies. A recent shift in OCBC's leadership, with Tan Teck Long named as the incoming CEO, highlights the need for effective retirement planning. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Additionally, Chinese banks struggle with a consumer lending push from Beijing, and Japan's MUFG plans to boost its US securitization business. These developments underscore the importance of addressing the pressing retirement challenges and economic uncertainties in the region.

site_title: Robo adviser StashAway launches digital wealth app in Thailand
summary: Singapore-based robo adviser StashAway has launched its digital wealth app in Thailand, its fourth overseas market. The move aims to cater to Thailand's increasing interest in overseas investments, with the goal of diversifying portfolios.
