StashAway's managing director, Tim Niranvichaiya, stated that the app offers easy access to globally diversified portfolios with a transparent, all-inclusive fee. The company currently manages over $1 billion in assets and has operations in Hong Kong, Malaysia, and the UAE. This launch follows similar moves by peer Syfe, which plans to enter the Hong Kong market in the next two quarters.

site_title: MAS to work with BIS, central banks to test CBDCs for international settlements
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is collaborating with the Bank for International Settlements (BIS) Innovation Hub, Reserve Bank of Australia, and others to test central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) for international settlements through Project Dunbar. The project aims to develop prototype shared platforms for cross-border transactions using multiple CBDCs, potentially cutting transaction time and cost. The prototypes will be demonstrated at the Singapore Fintech Festival in November and are expected to impact future platforms for global and regional settlements.

site_title: China's Hainan province eyes international carbon trading platform
summary: China's Hainan province is considering establishing an international carbon emissions trading platform to connect its national trading scheme with the global market. The move is part of the province's efforts to become a free trade port by 2035, aiming to streamline commodity, capital, and talent flow. China's national carbon trading scheme was launched in July, but experts say linking it with overseas counterparts could take at least a decade due to the need for market establishment. The proposed platform would be a mid- to long-term vision for cooperation between China and the European Union.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop over 1% on BHP losses, Covid-19 worries
summary: Australian shares dropped 1.1% to 7,444.3, their biggest fall in about one-and-a-half months, due to a slide in BHP Group and other mining stocks amid concerns about the coronavirus. The decline was the second straight day for miners, which hit their lowest in one-and-a-half weeks.

site_title: ABBA set to unveil 'sensational' musical comeback
summary: ABBA, the Swedish supergroup, is set to announce a "sensational comeback" after nearly four decades of disbanding. The group, composed of Agnetha Faltskog, Bjorn Ulvaeus, Benny Andersson, and Anni-Frid Lyngstad, will release new songs and perform a hologram "Abbatars" show, "Abba Voyage," in London's Olympic Park. The announcement is expected to be made on Thursday, September 2, 2021, and will mark the group's first new music and performance since the 1980s.

site_title: Binance founder says its US crypto exchange arm targets IPO in three years
summary: Binance's US crypto exchange arm, Binance.US, plans to go public through an initial public offering (IPO) in the next three years, according to founder Changpeng Zhao. The US arm has generated $800 million to $1 billion in profit last year and is set to close a large private fundraising round in the next two months, which will reduce Zhao's control on the board. This move comes after the resignation of Brian Brooks, CEO of Binance.US, just three months into his role. The IPO is seen as a response to global regulatory pressure on the company.

site_title: Bank of Japan policymaker warns of growing risks to country's economic recovery
summary: Bank of Japan policymaker Goushi Kataoka warned that the coronavirus pandemic may weigh on Japan's economy longer than expected, posing heightened risks to the country's moderate recovery. Kataoka stressed the central bank's readiness to ramp up stimulus if needed and emphasized the need for continued ultra-loose monetary policy. He also called for the BOJ to strengthen monetary easing to push down borrowing costs and boost capital expenditure. The warning comes as Japan's economy remains in a "severe state" due to pandemic-related curbs.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.67% at open, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 175.23 points to 26,203.52. The move follows investors waiting for US jobs data, scheduled for release at the end of the week.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 6.04 points, or 0.38%, to 1,592.93. A total of 245.61 million lots were traded, worth approximately RM108.18 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 200 to 168.

site_title: US aiming new lawsuit at Google over ads: report
summary: The US Justice Department is preparing a new antitrust lawsuit against Google over its power in the online advertising market, potentially by the end of the year. Google maintains it competes fairly in the market, citing the presence of many options for publishers and advertisers. This comes after similar cases were filed by US states and lawmakers advanced legislation in June to curb the power of Big Tech firms, including Google, Apple, Amazon, and Facebook. The outcome of the package remains unclear, with lawmakers from both sides breaking from their parties.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OUE C-Reit, Sim Leisure, Venture Corp, EuroSports Global, Grand Venture
summary: OUE Commercial Reit (OUE C-Reit) will be included in the FTSE EPRA Nareit Global Developed Index on Sept 20, boosting its market presence. Sim Leisure Group plans to sell new shares to controlling shareholders, increasing their stakes. Venture Corporation appointed a new independent non-executive director. EuroSports Global and Grand Venture Technologies announced leadership changes and plans to transfer listings to the mainboard, respectively.

site_title: ICHAM is first Singapore fund manager to receive allocation under China's scheme for global asset managers
summary: ICHAM, a Singapore wealth management company, has received US$200 million from the Chongqing government under China's Qualified Domestic Limited Partnership (QDLP) scheme, making it the first Singapore company to do so. The fund will primarily be invested via Singapore-backed digital securities exchange ADDX, founded by Danny Toe. The Chongqing government's QDLP quota is US$5 billion, and the partnership was among its first batch of quota recipients. This move aims to empower Chinese institutions and high-net-worth individuals to diversify their portfolios globally.

site_title: Former LTA deputy group director jailed five-and-a-half years for S$1.24m graft case
summary: A former Land Transport Authority (LTA) deputy group director, Henry Foo Yung Thye, was sentenced to 5½ years in jail for taking approximately S$1.24 million in bribes from contractors and sub-contractors. Foo, 47, also ordered to pay a penalty of S$1,156,260, pleaded guilty to seven counts of corruption. His gambling disorder was considered a mitigating factor, but the judge found his persistent loan requests and debt settlement methods limited its impact.

site_title: Singapore stocks open slightly higher on Thursday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened slightly higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.1% to 3,092.15 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 94 to 44, with Metal Component Engineering rising 0.4% to 4.1 cents after signing a term sheet to invest in an Indonesian healthcare company. The US and European markets closed mixed, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average slipping 0.1% and the Nasdaq Composite Index gaining 0.3%.

site_title: China warns US climate cooperation at risk on political tensions
summary: China's State Councillor and Foreign Minister Wang Yi has warned US climate envoy John Kerry that political tensions between the two countries could undermine their joint efforts to combat climate change. Wang stated that while China has shown sincerity in cooperation, the relationship is intertwined with broader diplomatic issues. US Secretary of State Kerry reaffirmed the US commitment to tackling the climate crisis and encouraged China to reduce emissions. Climate watchers hope the talks will lead to more ambitious pledges from both countries, but tensions between the two nations may hinder progress.

site_title: OUE C-Reit to join FTSE Russell's Global Developed Index series
summary: OUE Commercial Reit (OUE C-Reit) will be included in the FTSE EPRA Nareit Global Developed Index series, effective September 20, 2021. This marks a significant milestone for the Reit, enhancing its visibility and investability among global investors. The inclusion is a result of OUE C-Reit's commitment to driving long-term sustainable growth, including its transformational merger with OUE Hospitality Trust in 2019. The Reit's units ended flat at 41 Singapore cents on Wednesday.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.48% and the Topix index advancing 0.21%. The gains come after a mixed close on Wall Street, with investors awaiting US jobs data due this week.

site_title: South Korea's Q2 GDP up 0.8% q-o-q, ticks up from earlier estimate
summary: South Korea's economy grew 0.8% seasonally adjusted in Q2, above the 0.7% estimated earlier. Private consumption and facilities investment drove growth, while construction investment shrank 2.3% and exports decreased 2.0%. This is the fastest annual expansion in a decade, with Q2 GDP growth revised to 6.0% from 5.9% in preliminary estimates.

site_title: Sim Leisure to raise S$3.6m through sale of new shares
summary: Sim Leisure Group plans to raise S$3.6 million by selling new ordinary shares to two controlling shareholders at a 5.9% discount. Tan Boon Seng's stake will increase to 26.95%, while Desamal Capital's stake will rise to 25.74%. The funds will be used for growth and expansion (70%) and general working capital (30%). The company will convene an extraordinary meeting to seek shareholder approval for the proposed subscription, following the current limited financing options available.

site_title: US SEC charges BitConnect founder with US$2b cryptocurrency fraud
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has charged BitConnect founder Satish Kumbhani with US$2 billion cryptocurrency fraud, alleging he lied about the platform's ability to generate profits and violated registration laws. Glenn Arcaro, a promoter, pleaded guilty to a related charge and faces sentencing on November 15. The SEC also sued five other BitConnect promoters, seeking fines and other relief, and has obtained judgments requiring some to pay over $3.5 million and 190 bitcoin.

site_title: In 'pain and anger', Pentagon looks to lessons of 20-year war
summary: US Defence Chiefs express "pain and anger" after the 20-year Afghan war, acknowledging the loss of 2,461 American troops and widespread criticism of the withdrawal. Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin and Joint Chiefs Chair General Mark Milley vowed to study the lessons of the conflict, with Gen Milley suggesting possible future cooperation with the Taliban to counter the Islamic State-Khorasan group. The US will also continue to support Afghan refugees and allies in the region, with Austin planning to visit the Gulf next week.

site_title: Europe: Stocks make strong start to September, record high in sight
summary: European stocks rose 0.5% to 473.12 points, nearing their record high of 476.16, as investors shrugged off concerns about rising inflation. Retail and travel & leisure stocks led the gains, while mining and healthcare sectors also performed well. The rally was driven by hopes for more stimulus and offsetting signs of weakness in Asian economies.

site_title: Evergrande's billionaire boss exudes calm as debt risks grow
summary: Evergrande Group's billionaire chairman, Hui Ka Yan, appeared calm at a centenary celebration of the Chinese Communist Party, despite the company's mounting debt risks. Evergrande, China's No. 2 developer, has 1.97 trillion yuan in liabilities, triggering warnings from regulators. The company warned of default risks if it fails to dispose of assets and renew loans. Hui's highly leveraged business strategy is unraveling, with his net worth estimated at US$13.4 billion, down from US$45.3 billion in 2017.

site_title: Facebook invests in new partnerships with Argentine press
summary: Facebook has invested $1.5 million in Argentine media outlets to train 3,000 journalists and promote online development through its "Facebook Journalism Project". The three-year agreement with over 150 media outlets aims to support digital transformation and expand the audience through social and interactive formats. This investment, part of Facebook's $1 billion global plan, follows its $600 million investment since 2018 to support digital development in the news industry.

site_title: Temasek's Heliconia invests in luxury art collectibles maker XM Studios
summary: Temasek's Heliconia Capital has invested 9.2% in luxury art collectibles maker XM Studios, a Singapore-based business founded by brothers Ben and Seng Ang. XM Studios designs and produces handcrafted, porcelain statues of characters from various pop culture brands, such as Marvel and Star Wars. The company has seen a surge in demand during the pandemic, with revenue doubling to S$16.9 million and profit after tax reaching S$4.2 million. Heliconia plans to help XM Studios expand into other intellectual property verticals, including sports and entertainment, and aid the company's entry into new markets.

site_title: Changes at Miss Universe Singapore
summary: Miss Universe Singapore has revamped its pageant to promote inclusivity and diversity, welcoming contestants of all shapes, sizes, and backgrounds. The event now encourages plus-sized, Muslim, and physically disabled women to participate, aiming to redefine traditional beauty standards. This shift towards inclusivity reflects the changing attitudes towards beauty and body image in the era of diversity and acceptance.

site_title: Australian doctors warn health system may 'capsize' when Covid-19 curbs ease
summary: Australian doctors have warned the country's hospitals are unprepared for the easing of Covid-19 curbs, despite higher vaccination rates. The Australian Medical Association (AMA) fears the health system may "capsize" under an expected surge in cases when lockdown rules lift. The AMA has called for new modelling to assess staffing levels in hospitals. Vice-president Chris Moy warned that the system is at risk of a "permanent cycle of crisis" if safety nets are not in place. The warning comes as some states prepare to transition from virus suppression to living with Covid-19.

site_title: South Korea's August inflation stays at 9-year peak, beats forecast
summary: South Korea's inflation remained at a 9-year peak in August, rising 2.6% from the previous year, beating forecasts of a 2.3% increase. This marks the fifth consecutive month inflation has stayed above the central bank's 2% target. Core inflation, which excludes volatile food prices, rose 1.3% year-on-year, the fastest growth since June 2018. Month-on-month inflation also rose 0.6%, the best reading since January.

site_title: Moderna submits application to US regulator for Covid booster shot
summary: Moderna has submitted an application to the US Food and Drug Administration for authorization of a Covid-19 booster shot, following trial data showing a significant increase in antibodies against variants. The booster, mRNA-1273, was given to 344 participants six months after their second dose and increased neutralizing antibody levels against variants of concern by 42.3-fold against Delta, 43.6-fold against Gamma, and 32-fold against Beta. Moderna plans to submit similar data to the European Medicines Agency and other regulatory authorities, as the US administration begins offering third Covid vaccine doses to immunocompromised people and plans to widen boosters to everyone eligible.

site_title: Ronaldo breaks all-time international scoring record with 110th Portugal goal
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo broke the all-time international scoring record with his 110th Portugal goal in a World Cup qualifier against Ireland. The 36-year-old scored an 89th-minute equalizer after missing a first-half penalty. Ronaldo surpassed Iranian great Ali Daei's record, marking a milestone in his illustrious career.

site_title: KPMG 'misled' on Carillion audit: regulator
summary: The UK's Financial Reporting Council accused KPMG of providing false and misleading information during its audits of collapsed construction company Carillion in 2016 and IT company Regenersis. A disciplinary tribunal will hold a hearing on January 10, 2022. This is the latest in a series of criticisms against the "Big Four" accountancy firms, including PwC, EY, and Deloitte, for failing to foresee high-profile bankruptcies. The regulator emphasized that the complaint does not allege improper audit preparation.

site_title: Extensive Ida storm damage hurts oil industry recovery effort
summary: Hurricane Ida caused extensive damage to the US Gulf Coast, particularly in Louisiana, where energy companies are struggling to restore operations. Oil refineries could take weeks to restart, and pipelines and platforms are being surveyed to assess damage. About 80% of the region's oil output was halted, with 1.4 million barrels of oil and 1.88 billion cubic feet of natural gas offline. The economic cost is estimated to be $70 billion to $80 billion, with many losses stemming from the oil industry and supply chain delays.

site_title: State firms to take big stake in Ant's credit-scoring JV: sources
summary: State-backed firms, including Zhejiang Tourism Investment Group Co, Hangzhou Finance and Investment Group, and Zhejiang Electronic Port, will each own 35% of a new personal credit-scoring firm with Ant Group, according to sources. The venture aims to handle Ant's vast data on over 1 billion consumers and could help revive the company's IPO, which regulators halted after a botched debut in November. The plan follows a government push for state control over the fintech industry, with the goal of establishing China's third private credit-scoring firm by October.

site_title: US: Stocks end mixed amid contradictory economic signs
summary: US stocks ended mixed on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average slipping 0.1% to close at 35,312.53, while the S&P 500 ended flat at 4,524.09. The Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.3% to reach an all-time high of 15,309.38. Weak private hiring data and a manufacturing index showing growth despite hiring difficulties were key factors. Economists expect the Labor Department's jobs report for August to be released on Friday, which could impact the Federal Reserve's stimulus efforts, potentially delaying its tapering plans.

site_title: Twitch video gamers go offline to protest 'hate raids'
summary: Twitch users staged a virtual walkout on September 1, 2021, to protest "hate raids" - torrential abuse on the platform. The protest resulted in nearly 4,000 fewer channels streaming than the daily average for the week. Minority users, particularly those from the LGBTQ+ community, have been subjected to racist, sexist, and homophobic abuse. The phenomenon has been ongoing for months, and the extent of the protest remains unclear. The walkout highlights the need for increased measures to combat hate speech and create a safer environment for all users on the platform.

site_title: Temasek-backed Oxford Nanopore to launch £2.48b London IPO in coming weeks: sources
summary: Oxford Nanopore, a UK-based life sciences firm backed by Temasek, is set to launch a £2.48 billion initial public offering (IPO) on the London Stock Exchange in the coming weeks. The company, which provides DNA/RNA sequencing technology, aims to build on its £2.48 billion valuation achieved in a funding round in May. Bank of America, Citi, and JPMorgan are global coordinators for the listing, marking a major win for London's main market as it competes with other European centers for life science listings.

images.alt_text: Oxford Nanopore, a provider of rapid Covid-19 tests to the UK's national health service, is working with banks to launch an initial public offering (IPO) on the London Stock Exchange in the coming weeks - a deal that would strengthen Britain's efforts to lure life science businesses to its main market.

site_title: China's Afghan moment has arrived
summary: China is poised to play a significant role in Afghanistan's post-American era, potentially signaling the country's emergence as a global power. Both China and Afghanistan have a history of resisting Western influence, with China recovering from a century of national humiliation and Afghanistan rebuffing external orders. China could act as a balancer in the region, avoiding the pitfalls of Western power and promoting stability in Afghanistan. By taking a nuanced approach, China may be able to prevent the Taliban from becoming a major terrorist hub and instead promote a more inclusive and sustainable government.

site_title: Darco appoints Kong Chee Keong as new CEO
summary: DARCO Water Technologies has appointed Kong Chee Keong as its new CEO, replacing Poh Kok Hong, who was terminated due to unresolved differences in opinions on material matters. Poh cited issues with the Gaoyi project, financial statements, and the Wuhan Kaidi whistleblower report. Kong will step down from certain committees, and shares of Darco last traded at 18.6 Singapore cents before the announcement.

site_title: Taking a bite of the plant-based meat market
summary: The Social Kitchen, a plant-based food company, is expanding its presence in Singapore with a cloud kitchen at PLQ Mall, supported by Unilever. The Social Kitchen aims to promote sustainable and nutritious food, with half of its workforce comprised of special needs beneficiaries and underprivileged individuals. The company plans to grow to 50 kitchens across Singapore, encouraging consumers to adopt a more plant-based lifestyle. Unilever supports The Social Kitchen's mission, sharing its vision of making sustainable living commonplace and working together to drive positive change.

site_title: Zen and Jaan get top Michelin honours
summary: Singapore's 49 Michelin-starred restaurants, announced in a virtual ceremony, include two three-star restaurants, Zen and Jaan, with Jaan being the only new entrant in the two-star category. The awards, delayed due to the pandemic, recognize restaurants that have survived and thrived despite the challenges. Chefs and owners expressed gratitude for the recognition, which they believe will boost their businesses. The Michelin Guide's focus on creativity and positivity from chefs during the pandemic was a key factor in the awards.

site_title: Why illicit trade is thriving amid the pandemic
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Despite pandemic-related border closures, illicit trade is thriving globally, with criminal syndicates exploiting economic hardship to smuggle goods worth billions. In Singapore, seven lorries carrying electronic vaporizers and other banned products were intercepted in June 2021, highlighting the brazen attempts of smugglers. The pandemic has created new opportunities for illicit trade, with consumer spending declining and governments struggling to enforce controls. The World Economic Forum estimates $2.2 trillion was lost to illicit trade in 2020, and stronger legislation and enforcement are needed to combat this growing threat. Consumers must also be vigilant and disciplined.

site_title: Climate disclosures important, but audit assurance must also focus on fraud
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) proposes that listed companies disclose climate change's impact on their businesses, with external assurance by independent bodies required. The proposed rules, if implemented, could benefit the auditing industry, as 51% of companies with sustainability reports provide some level of assurance. A study found 63% of these assurance engagements were conducted by audit or audit-affiliated firms. The move aims to enhance transparency and credibility in sustainability reporting.

site_title: CEOs are scaling down business travel - maybe for good
summary: Business travel is scaling down significantly post-pandemic, with companies worldwide reducing travel budgets by 20-40% and cutting internal and external in-person meetings. According to a Bloomberg survey, 84% of large businesses plan to spend less on travel, with corporate trips potentially dropping to $1.24 trillion by 2024. Airlines and the hospitality industry are among the biggest casualties, with some predicting a dip of up to 18% in hotel revenue and $126 billion in airline losses in 2020. While some CEOs believe travel will return to pre-pandemic levels, many are embracing virtual communication tools for efficiency and sustainability.

site_title: Engineering 5G innovation and beyond with advanced substrates
summary: The semiconductor industry is pushing the limits of Moore's Law with the development of advanced substrates, enabling faster, more efficient, and more powerful chips. The industry's four new megatrends - 5G, connected smart devices, and autonomous vehicles - will drive demand for semiconductors, doubling the market size by 2030. To meet this demand, the industry must collaborate across verticals and regions, leveraging innovations in materials and manufacturing. As the global semiconductor market expands to $1 trillion by 2030, companies like Soitec are investing in research and development to create next-generation materials and support the growth of new technologies.

site_title: Indonesia's Bukalapak posts sales jump in first report since record IPO
summary: Indonesian e-commerce operator PT Bukalapak.com posted a 35% increase in first-half revenue to 864 billion rupiah, driven by surging demand for online shopping. Transactions processed reached almost US$4 billion, with net losses shrinking to 766 billion rupiah. The company's share price has fluctuated since its IPO, but analysts remain bullish, recommending buying shares. Total processing value is set to reach US$9 billion this year, with Mitra Bukalapak contributing 33% of the company's revenue.

site_title: China hedge funds pay top grads richly to beat Wall Street
summary: China's top hedge funds are offering lucrative salaries to top college graduates, including annual wages of up to $300,000, to attract talent away from the US. The shift is driven by the pandemic and rising emerging market wealth, as companies like Ubiquant and Shanghai Minghong Investment Co. compete for hires in areas like artificial intelligence and computer science. This trend is also seen in other industries, with entry-level salaries at top investment banks increasing to six figures, and China's private quant funds pushing salaries up due to a persistent shortage of new talent.

site_title: With Kabul airport closed, fearful Afghans rush for the border
summary: Thousands of Afghans are rushing to the borders with Iran, Pakistan, and central Asian states in an attempt to flee the country amid an administrative vacuum following the Taliban's takeover. With Kabul's airport inoperable, private efforts focus on arranging safe passage. The UN Security Council urged the Taliban to permit safe passage, but no safe zone has been created. The Taliban has declared an amnesty for those who worked with foreign forces, but human rights concerns persist, with reports of violence against women. The international community is seeking to address a looming humanitarian crisis, with up to half a million Afghans potentially fleeing.

site_title: Catalist-listed Grand Venture proposes transfer to SGX mainboard
summary: Grand Venture Technologies, a Catalist-listed fabricated metal products manufacturer, plans to transfer its listing to the mainboard of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to increase trading liquidity, public float, and shareholder count. As part of the proposal, the company will also conduct a placement of new ordinary shares.

site_title: Age is just a number? Not so for real estate
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated structural shifts in the real estate industry, creating a two-tiered market where prime assets continue to hold value while non-prime assets deteriorate due to functional obsolescence. Investors are gravitating towards newer assets, and asset owners are repurposing underperforming assets through adaptive reuse, acquiring them at a discount, and reducing competition. The trend is driven by uncertainties around occupier demand, the shift towards hybrid working models, and the need for sustainability. Traditional sectors like office, retail, and hospitality are struggling, while the industrial sector is experiencing growth due to e-commerce consumption, and sectors like life science are seeing increased demand.

site_title: China moves to cap cost of renting home in cities
summary: China's government has introduced a cap of 5% annual rent increase in cities to provide more affordable housing. The move aims to narrow wealth disparities and address the plight of low-income households. Rental housing demand is high in China's largest cities, where young people and new residents often face difficulties buying homes due to high prices. Authorities will also crack down on abusive practices by real estate firms and online property platforms. The cap and new measures are part of a sweeping clean-up of the property market over the next three years.

site_title: Warnings as South-east Asia's biggest economies ease Covid-19 curbs
summary: Indonesia and Thailand, the largest economies in South-east Asia, are easing Covid-19 curbs despite low vaccination rates and high case numbers. Indonesia reported 10,534 new cases, down 5 times from its peak, while Thailand reported 14,802 new cases, down 37% from its peak. Experts warn that relaxations could lead to a surge in cases due to the highly transmissible Delta variant and low vaccination rates. The two countries have vaccination rates of around 30% each, with Indonesia fully vaccinated at 17% and Thailand at 11%.

site_title: Wing Tai, GuocoLand boards should do more to address their stock price's big discounts to book value
summary: Two Singapore property developers, GuocoLand and Wing Tai Holdings, reported decent financial results for FY 2021, with GuocoLand's net profit increasing 48% and Wing Tai's net profit rising 173%. However, their minority shareholders may be concerned about the significant discount between their shares and book value. The companies' boards should consider increasing free floats, realising book value through REITs or divestments, or exploring corporate restructuring to boost returns and narrow the discount.

site_title: UK house prices unexpectedly pick up in August
summary: UK house prices rose 2.1% in August, exceeding economists' expectations, to reach 11% higher than last year. Despite the phasing-out of a tax break for purchases in England and Northern Ireland, the increase bucked forecasts of a slowdown. The Nation-wide chief economist attributed the rise to demand for spacious housing and the lack of available homes priced between £125,000 to £250,000, which still benefits from the tax break until the end of September.

site_title: Re-opening theme sees South-east Asia flip from worst to best
summary: South-east Asian stocks and currencies have seen a significant rebound in the past month, with the MSCI AC Asean Index jumping over 5% in August, its largest gain in nine months. Rising vaccination levels and falling infection rates have contributed to the recovery, with countries such as Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia experiencing declining new cases and easing restrictions. Money managers are optimistic about further gains, citing pro-growth policies and attractive valuations, with some firms favoring Indonesia's equities and Singapore due to vaccination progress and re-opening plans.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: VENTURE Corporation appointed Temasek-owned Vertex Venture Holdings group president and chief executive Chua Kee Lock as independent non-executive director. EAGLE Hospitality Trust received a US$23.5 million offer for its Delta Woodbridge Hotel in New Jersey. Alpha DX will invest US$50 million in a joint venture with the Republic of Uzbekistan to develop a university. Meanwhile, companies like NTT DC Reit and Creative Technology reported oversubscription and potential revenue shortfall, respectively. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for its £10 billion upgrade, and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case.

site_title: Shell to install 50,000 on-street EV chargers in UK by 2025
summary: Royal Dutch Shell plans to install 50,000 on-street electric vehicle chargers in the UK by 2025, expanding its existing network of 3,600 chargers. The UK government will cover 75% of the installation costs, while Shell will cover the remaining 25%, subject to commercial terms. The move aims to support the UK's goal of having 150,000 public chargers by the middle of the decade, ahead of the ban on new petrol and diesel car sales in 2030.

site_title: Covid-19 cases linked to bus interchange clusters rise to 314
summary: Singapore reports 314 Covid-19 cases linked to bus interchange clusters, with 29 new cases. The Boon Lay Bus Interchange cluster has 66 cases, while the Toa Payoh Bus Interchange cluster has 93 cases, with 8 new infections. The Health Ministry attributed the rise in cases to staff at these interchanges.

site_title: US social security fund to be insolvent a year earlier than previously forecast
summary: The US Social Security fund is expected to become insolvent a year earlier than previously forecast, with the trust fund depleting in 2033. This is due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on government revenues and strain on the program. The Disability Insurance Trust Fund is now expected to be depleted by 2057, 8 years earlier than previously thought. Medicare's finances are expected to hold steady, but its hospital trust fund is projected to be unable to pay all bills beginning in 2026.

site_title: Yangzijiang a beneficiary of e-commerce boom, shipping demand
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings, a China-based shipbuilder, has seen its shares rise 72.8% this year, making it the best-performing constituent of the Straits Times Index. The company secured record orders, including 167 vessels worth over $8.6 billion, driven by an e-commerce-fueled sea freight boom. However, profit margins have fallen due to rising steel costs and a strengthening yuan, and investors should consider the impact of a stronger yuan on future profits. Yangzijiang's other businesses, including logistics and chartering, are growing and delivering improved profitability.

site_title: S Korea passes bill to curb Google, Apple commission dominance
summary: South Korea's Parliament approved a bill banning major app store operators like Google and Apple from forcing software developers to use their payment systems, effectively stopping commissions on in-app purchases. The move, dubbed the "Anti-Google law," aims to reduce Big Tech's influence and promote fair competition for innovative startups. The bill also allows the government to regulate app market operators and protect users' rights. The decision is seen as a significant step in the fight for a fair app ecosystem, with similar legislation being introduced in the US.

site_title: Legislation will give workers more protection against discrimination: Manpower Minister
summary: Singapore is set to enact anti-discrimination laws, covering gender, age, race, religion, and disability, to give workers more protection against workplace discrimination. The move was announced by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong at the National Day Rally and will provide enforcement agencies with the power to sanction and penalize errant employers. Manpower Minister Tan See Leng stated that the laws will help nudge small companies in the right direction and reinforce Singapore's transparency about workplace fairness, despite low rates of workplace discrimination.

site_title: In Indonesia, drone deliveries provide lifeline for isolating Covid patients
summary: A team of seven drone enthusiasts in Makassar, Indonesia, is providing a contactless medicine and food delivery service to Covid-19 patients isolating at home. Armed with five drones, they deliver essential items up to five times a day, avoiding direct contact and helping contain the spread of the virus. Indonesia, one of the countries worst affected by the pandemic, has reported over 4 million cases and 131,000 fatalities. The initiative is expanding to nearby islands and aims to support 800 people in isolation.

site_title: Didi, JD.com set up staff unions in unprecedented move
summary: Chinese ride-hailing giant Didi Global and e-commerce powerhouse JD.com have established staff unions in a move unprecedented in the country's tech sector. The unions are guided by the government-backed All China Federation of Trade Unions and aim to improve workers' rights and share wealth as part of China's "common prosperity" drive. The move comes amid regulatory crackdowns and criticism of companies for exploiting workers, with Didi facing an investigation and criticism for not paying its drivers fairly.

site_title: Euro holds near one-month high after inflation jolt
summary: The euro reached a one-month high against the US dollar after a higher-than-expected inflation reading in the euro zone, with the euro zone inflation increasing to 3% in August, above the European Central Bank's 2% target. Strong institutional demand at bond auctions and rising bond yields underpinned the euro's gains, forcing traders to cover their bearish bets on the single currency. Despite hawkish comments from the ECB governor, the euro failed to make significant progress above the US$1.18 level.

site_title: Production snags may delay debut of Apple's next smartwatch
summary: Apple's upcoming smartwatch, Apple Watch 7, may face production snags due to a new design featuring a larger screen and faster processor. Manufacturers are adjusting to the upgrade, causing challenges and potential supply constraints or shipment delays. The company has not announced a release date, giving it options to delay or ship smaller quantities. This comes after previous Apple Watch models experienced production issues, including the first version delayed in 2015. The new watches will also feature improved screen technology, expanding the appeal of smartwatches for Apple.

site_title: China's kids get schooled in 'Xi Jinping thought'
summary: China has introduced a new curriculum that incorporates "Xi Jinping thought" into primary school education, starting from ages 7. The education ministry aims to instill patriotism and socialism in young students, with textbooks featuring the president's quotes and images. The curriculum includes chapters on China's civilisation, poverty alleviation, and Covid-19 pandemic, as well as lessons on patriotism and duty. The move has sparked concerns about indoctrination and brainwashing, with some parents and internet users expressing discomfort.

site_title: Asia factories hit by Pandemic-related supply disruptions
summary: Asia's factory activity declined in August due to pandemic-related disruptions, including virus outbreaks, supply bottlenecks, and high raw material prices. China's factory activity contracted for the first time in nearly 1-1/2 years, while Vietnam, Indonesia, and Malaysia saw significant declines. Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan also experienced slower manufacturing growth. The weakening of Asia's factory sector is a concern for the global economy, contrasting with Europe's expected brisk factory expansion. The pandemic's damage to Southeast Asia's economies and manufacturing sectors is ongoing.

site_title: Opec+ sticks to agreed schedule for oil-production increases
summary: Opec+ agreed to maintain the existing schedule for oil-production increases, including a 400,000 barrel-a-day supply hike scheduled for October. The decision was made in a brief video conference, marking one of the quickest meetings in recent memory. The agreement contrasts with previous drawn-out negotiations.

site_title: A century of relationships
summary: Nomanbhoy & Sons, a Singaporean spice and agricultural produce trader, has built a century-long business on "a century of relationships" with clients and partners. Despite global trials, including the pandemic, these abiding partnerships have endured, exemplified by a client's loyalty during Italy's oxygen shortage. The company's fourth-generation scion, Hanif Nomanbhoy, credits these relationships for the business's success, emphasizing the importance of trust and a handshake over contracts.

site_title: Son of ex-EuroSports Global CEO takes up deputy CEO role in subsidiary
summary: Joshua Goh Yi Shun, the son of EuroSports Global's former CEO Melvin Goh Kim San, has taken up the role of deputy CEO and director of EuroSports Technologies, a subsidiary of the luxury car distributor. The appointment comes amid an ongoing investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department into Melvin Goh's activities. Joshua Goh will assist with the overall operations of EuroSports Technologies and its subsidiaries, and his promotion was approved by the board following a nomination committee's recommendation.

site_title: WHO monitoring new Mu coronavirus variant
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is monitoring the new Mu coronavirus variant, B.1.621, which has been classified as a "variant of interest" due to its potential for immune escape and resistance to vaccines. The variant was first identified in Colombia in January and has been reported in South America and Europe. Singapore reported 177 new locally transmitted cases, with 90 unlinked cases, the highest recorded in a day. The WHO urges further studies to better understand the variant's properties and risks.

site_title: China new home price growth slowest in five months, private survey shows
summary: China's August new home prices rose at the slowest pace in five months, increasing 0.2% from July, according to a private survey. Demand has cooled in major cities following restrictions to stabilize surging prices. This slowdown follows a series of measures to curb price growth, including cooling measures and increased regulatory oversight. The data from China Index Academy suggests a decrease in red-hot demand, indicating a potential shift in the country's property market.

images.alt_text: Guangzhou on Tuesday introduced a pricing reference for resale homes to curb its red-hot market. Around 10 cities including Shanghai and Shenzhen have already implemented similar pricing systems.

site_title: US manufacturing expands at faster pace, backlogs swell
summary: US manufacturing expanded at a faster-than-expected pace in August, with the Institute for Supply Management's gauge of factory activity rising to 59.9 from 59.5. This marked the highest ISM reading for bookings in three months and firmer production, but also showed a significant increase in order backlogs. Persistent bottlenecks and supply chain challenges are impacting manufacturers globally, with many producers constrained by Covid-19 outbreaks and raw-materials shortages.

site_title: Former Biden interpreter left behind in Afghanistan: Media
summary: A former US Army interpreter, working with President Joe Biden in a 2008 Afghan snowstorm, is in hiding after failing to join the Kabul evacuation airlift. The interpreter, whose identity is protected, helped rescue Biden and two other lawmakers amid concerns of a Taliban attack. Thirteen years later, he and his family are now in hiding due to a potential crackdown by the Taliban. The US government has expressed a desire to help the interpreter, with White House Press Secretary Jen Psaki stating that the US will honor his service and get him out.

site_title: Paralympic official defends Malaysian's disqualification
summary: The International Paralympic Committee defended the disqualification of Malaysian shot putter Muhammad Ziyad Zolkefli, who was stripped of a gold medal for turning up late to the call room. Ziyad won the gold medal in the F20 final in Tokyo, but was later disqualified along with two other athletes for no justifiable reason. The committee's spokesman, Craig Spence, stated that the Ukrainian athlete was unfairly targeted, and that the latecomers had not provided a valid reason for their tardiness. The decision sparked widespread outrage in Malaysia.

site_title: Blockchain fund run by serial entrepreneurs and corporate leaders raises US$100m
summary: TRUE Global Ventures (TGV) has closed its TGV 4 Plus fund with a US$100 million raise, dedicated to investments in blockchain companies, particularly in Series B and C rounds. The fund, backed by serial entrepreneurs and corporate leaders, has already invested in five companies, including Animoca Brands and QuantumRock. TGV's partners provide commercial relationships, investment promotions, and introductions to lenders, helping portfolio companies grow. The fund's 40 partners contributed 27% of the total, with entrepreneurs, business angels, and institutional investors contributing to the rest.

site_title: The proliferation of plastics and toxic chemicals must end
summary: The US must address the interconnected challenges of climate change, plastic pollution, and toxic chemicals. The petrochemical industry's increasing production of plastics and chemicals from fossil fuels poses a significant threat to human health and the environment. To combat this, the federal government should end subsidies to the oil and gas industry, pause new plastic production facilities, and invest in renewable energy and safer chemicals. The EU's circular economy approach and innovative technologies can serve as models for a healthier planet. Strong legislation and continued investment in research and technology are necessary to address these pressing issues.

site_title: Amazon plans to add 40,000 workers to US corporate ranks
summary: Amazon plans to add over 40,000 new corporate employees in the US, marking its largest-ever recruiting and training event. The positions are open at various locations, including Seattle, Arlington, and New York. This hiring spree follows a surge in US employees during the pandemic, with the company now employing 950,000 people in the US and 1.3 million worldwide.

site_title: Construction spending rises in July amid broad gains
summary: US construction spending rose 0.3% in July, exceeding expectations, with a 9.0% year-over-year gain. Private sector projects saw a 0.3% increase, driven by robust demand for housing. Residential projects advanced 0.5%, while private non-residential construction declined 0.2%. Public sector projects rebounded 0.7% after a 1.6% drop in June. The gains are attributed to increased spending on state and local government projects, despite a 1.1% drop in federal government spending.

site_title: Chinese state firms to take big stake in Ant's credit-scoring JV
summary: Chinese state-backed firms, including Zhejiang Tourism Investment Group and Hangzhou Finance and Investment Group, will take a significant stake in Ant's personal credit-scoring venture, which aims to establish China's third licensed credit-scoring firm. The joint venture, valued at $77.4 million, will collect and manage consumer data to score people's credit, loosening Ant's grip on its 1 billion-user data treasure trove. The move is part of Ant's restructuring ordered by regulators to revive its IPO plans.

site_title: Family KTV operators make formal appeal to Gan Kim Yong to reopen from Sept 15
summary: Family KTV operators in Singapore have submitted a formal appeal to Minister Gan Kim Yong, requesting to reopen for business from Sept 15 as the country achieves its 80% national vaccination rate and moves into an endemic state. The proposal includes a clear exit path for nightlife operators, protection against potential lawsuits from landlords and stakeholders. The appeal comes after the industry has been severely impacted by the pandemic, with many operators struggling to survive.

site_title: Best offer for EHT's struggling hotel in New Jersey was US$23.5m
summary: EHT's Delta Woodbridge Hotel in New Jersey received a best offer of US$23.5 million following three months of marketing efforts. The hotel had been foreclosed by Wells Fargo National Association for approximately US$37.6 million, but the outstanding mortgage loan balance will continue to be payable by EHT. A virtual public auction was held for the hotel's assets, but no bids were received. The rent receiver offered US$100 for the assets, and EHT managers had previously received a notice of default and demand for payment for a US$35 million mortgage in 2019.

site_title: India's factory activity improved in Sept as demand strengthened
summary: India's factory activity improved in September due to a recovery in the economy from the pandemic-induced slump, with the Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index rising to 53.7 from 52.3 in August. Demand and output strengthened, but firms reduced headcount at the sharpest pace since May. The recovery is expected to continue, supported by ultra-easy monetary policy and fiscal spending, with no interest rate hike planned until the next fiscal year.

site_title: US private firms add just 374,000 jobs in August
summary: US private firms added 374,000 jobs in August, a modest gain over July, according to ADP. This data is seen as a preview of the government's employment report, which is expected to show a gain of 750,000 jobs nationwide. The job market's recovery has been undermined by the Delta variant of Covid-19, leading economists to trim their forecasts. The leisure and hospitality sector was particularly hard hit, but added 201,000 positions last month. Despite this, job growth remains strong but at a slower pace than recent months.

site_title: Venture names Temasek-owned Vertex Venture CEO as independent non-executive director
summary: Venture Corporation announced the appointment of Chua Kee Lock, group president and CEO of Temasek-owned Vertex Venture Holdings, as an independent non-executive director. The appointment was approved by the board after reviewing his qualifications and expertise. This move is part of the company's efforts to diversify its board composition. Shares of Venture Corporation ended the day at S$19.17, up S$0.01, following the announcement.

site_title: Insurers may take US$18b hit from Hurricane Ida, say industry experts
summary: US insurers are expected to face a US$18 billion hit from Hurricane Ida, according to catastrophe modeling company Karen Clark & Co. The storm made landfall in the US as a Category 4 storm, causing widespread flooding and damage. Insurer losses are expected to surpass those from Hurricane Laura in 2020 and winter storm Uri at US$15 billion. The storm's insured loss is divided between the Caribbean (US$40 million) and US wind and storm surge losses.

site_title: Axington appoints AJCapital Advisory managing director as independent non-executive director
summary: Axington appoints Luke Anthony Furler, managing director of AJCapital Advisory, as an independent non-executive director. The board believes his experience and capabilities make him suitable for the role. Furler has previously advised distressed corporations and acted as an insolvency practitioner. Axington faces delisting unless it acquires a new business by March next year. The company has suspended trading since August last year following controversies involving its controlling shareholders. Furler will also serve on the audit and remuneration committees.

site_title: 177 new locally transmitted Covid-19 cases; 90 unlinked
summary: There were 177 new locally transmitted Covid-19 cases in Singapore, with 90 unlinked cases reported, the highest in a single day. Of these, 54 linked cases were already quarantined, while 33 linked cases were detected through surveillance.

site_title: Haircuts and dine-in return as Thai malls reopen after virus cases ease
summary: Thailand reopened shopping malls and restaurants in Bangkok after nearly three months of restrictions, as the country's COVID-19 cases decreased. The move comes after the government eased lockdown measures to ease economic pressure. Thailand reported 14,802 new cases and 252 deaths on Wednesday, with overall 1.2 million cases and 11,841 fatalities. The partial reopening allows customers to get temperatures checked and maintain social distancing, with restaurants operating at half capacity. The move is expected to support Thailand's struggling economy.

site_title: King Wan says talks for a potential joint venture could be behind heavy trading
summary: King Wan Corporation, a building services company, attributed its recent unusual trading activity to ongoing discussions with a potential joint venture partner for retrofitting and upgrading solutions. The company declined to conclusively attribute the trading activity to the joint venture talks, stating it would make further announcements in compliance with the Singapore Exchange's Corporate Disclosure Policy.

site_title: China's private-sector crackdown is of concern for Singapore economy, analysts say
summary: China's private sector crackdown has raised concerns for the Singapore economy, with 30% of forecasters citing a slowdown in China as a potential risk. Regulatory tightening in China also poses a risk to capital markets, and supply-chain disruptions are a concern. The MAS survey found rising gloom over Singapore's manufacturing and trade outlook, with 40% of respondents expecting no growth in factory output. Despite this, Moody's Analytics economist Denise Cheok notes that the US may be replacing China as the region's growth driver, mitigating some of the slowdown's impact on Singapore's exports.

site_title: US: Stocks open on a high note
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, despite concerns over private jobs data and the Delta variant of Covid-19. The Dow Jones, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index rose, with the Nasdaq gaining 0.6% to a record high. Investors seemed unconcerned by a miss in private hiring data, which was lower than expected, and were boosted by news of Walmart's plans to add 20,000 permanent positions.

site_title: Malaysia examines need for booster shots as virus spreads
summary: Malaysia is studying the need for booster Covid-19 vaccine shots as the delta variant spreads. An expert committee will assess the necessity of a third shot by the end of the month, with a focus on those who haven't received their first dose. Only 46% of Malaysians are fully vaccinated, and the country is experiencing a record surge in new cases, with 18,762 new infections reported on the same day. Health Minister Khairy Jamaluddin prioritizes vaccination efforts and aims to reopen the economy by October when Malaysia reaches herd immunity.

site_title: Singapore stocks show strong start to September; STI up 1.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.1% to 3,087.84 points on September 1, 2021, driven by investors shrugging off weak regional manufacturing PMI figures. Advancers outnumbered decliners 302 to 193, with 1.59 billion shares changing hands.

site_title: UOL unit secures S$540m sustainability-linked Sora-based loan
summary: UOL Group's wholly-owned subsidiary, UOL Treasury Services, secured a S$540 million sustainability-linked loan pegged to the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora) for five years. The loan is being financed by UOB, DBS, and OCBC, with each bank extending S$180 million. UOL will be eligible for an interest rate reduction if its sustainability targets are met. This is UOL's first sustainability-linked and Sora-pegged loan, and CEO Kwa Bing Seng sees it as a key step in the company's sustainability journey.

site_title: Thailand to start collecting tax from foreign tech firms
summary: Thailand will begin collecting Value Added Tax (VAT) from foreign technology companies, including Facebook, Google, and Grab, starting Wednesday. The goal is to raise at least 5 billion baht (S$207.9 million) in additional revenue annually. Companies with over 1.8 million baht in revenue will pay 7% VAT monthly. The move is expected to generate 5 billion baht, a minimum target set before the pandemic.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: China's private-sector crackdown has raised concerns for Singapore's economy, with 30% of respondents in a MAS survey citing a slowdown in China as a potential risk. Meanwhile, the International Plaza collective sale reached a record S$2.7 billion reserve price, and Fortune Park's second collective sale attempt set an indicative price of S$115 million. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 1.1% on Wednesday, despite weak manufacturing PMI figures, as investors shrugged off the economic concerns. Bank of Singapore hired former UBS executive Vivienne Chia as global head of investment advisory solutions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finish with fresh gains
summary: Hong Kong shares ended the day with gains, adding 0.58% to the Hang Seng Index, driven by bargain-buying of tech firms hit by China's regulatory crackdown. The Shanghai Composite Index also rose 0.65%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.49%. The gains follow a recent rally supported by investors seeking value in the sector.

site_title: Michelin Guide Singapore unveils newly starred restaurants and first Young Chef award
summary: The Michelin Guide Singapore has unveiled its fifth edition, promoting three-starred restaurants Zén, Odette, and Les Amis, and introducing the first Michelin Guide Young Chef Award to Mark Tai of Cloudstreet. Five restaurants received two stars, while 41 eateries received one star, with 12 new restaurants entering the one-star category. The guide also celebrates its fifth anniversary in Singapore, marking a return after a one-year hiatus due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Rakuten plans to list online banking unit
summary: Rakuten Group Inc plans to list its online banking unit, Rakuten Bank Ltd, in an initial public offering (IPO) to raise funds and gain more autonomy. The move aims to mitigate losses from its low-cost mobile communications network expansion. Rakuten, a Japanese e-commerce firm, reported an operating loss of 101 billion yen in the six months to June. The IPO is expected to provide equity funding to support the company's growth and financial strategies, including its mobile network technology sales globally.

site_title: BT's Top Stories from Last Week
summary: Singapore's stock market has seen a decline in retail investor interest, with the STI rising just 13.5% over the past 10 years, compared to the S&P 500's 295.3% growth. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is exploring ways to regain investor confidence. Meanwhile, Singapore is considering a potential return to a zero-Covid strategy to boost tourism from Hong Kong and mainland China. In other news, a law firm is relocating from Raffles Place to High Street, and Cargill has acquired Aalst Chocolate's 50% stake.

site_title: Business sentiment among European firms in Asean rebounds to pre-Covid levels: survey
summary: European firms' business sentiment in ASEAN has rebounded to pre-Covid levels, with 82% expecting to expand trade and investment in the region over the next five years. This is up from 73% in 2020, mirroring the 2019 figure of 84%. The survey of 389 respondents across 10 ASEAN member states found positive sentiment among various services and manufacturing industries.

site_title: Terminals 1 and 3 of Changi Airport reopen to the public
summary: Changi Airport's Terminals 1 and 3 reopened to the public after a three-month closure due to a Covid-19 cluster. Retail staff returned to work, with some expressing hope for increased crowds, particularly during the upcoming school holidays. The airport has implemented extra precautions, including segregated arrival halls and improved air conditioning systems, to minimize the risk of transmission. Staff members expressed concerns about the Covid-19 situation but were generally hopeful about the airport's safety measures.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 14.49 points to 1,586.89. The decline was attributed to a narrow loss-gain margin, with 562 losers outnumbering 510 gainers. The stock market's performance was also influenced by global economic trends, including the ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff threats.

site_title: Improving aircraft air-con systems
summary: Liebherr-Aerospace Singapore is expanding its investment in the Republic to offer new maintenance services and technology, focusing on renewing and overhauling aircraft air-conditioning systems. The company aims to provide more efficient and reliable services, leveraging digital solutions to reduce costs and environmental impact. This move follows the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the aviation industry, with Liebherr developing solutions for airlines' evolving needs and acquiring new customers. The company's expansion will also contribute to Singapore's strategic development initiatives and its role as a key service and logistic hub in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Will the Fed end the stock market rally?
summary: The US stock market has experienced a 90% rally over the past 18 months despite the COVID-19 pandemic, largely due to the Federal Reserve's ultra-loose monetary policy. The Fed has doubled its balance sheet to over $8 trillion, injecting $4 trillion into the US financial system and lowering bond yields and real interest rates. This has made cash an unattractive investment option, allowing investors to leverage at low costs and fueling the massive equities rally. The Fed's actions have played a key role in helping markets navigate the "wall of worry" posed by the pandemic.

site_title: Malaysia to make construction sector more digitalised and sustainable: minister
summary: Malaysia plans to launch the National Construction Policy 2030 to accelerate technology adoption in the construction sector, aligning with the country's goal of decarbonizing and achieving the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. The policy aims to promote smart infrastructure development, efficient use of financial resources, and social cohesion. The country has committed to becoming a carbon-neutral nation by 2050 and aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions intensity of GDP by 45% by 2030. The construction industry has suffered significant losses due to the pandemic, estimated at RM42 billion, and the government is pushing for digitalization to boost growth.

site_title: Oil prices settle up on US stocks draw, rising fuel demand
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday after US crude stocks fell to their lowest levels in three years, with US West Texas Intermediate crude futures increasing 2.5% to $72.23 a barrel and Brent crude futures rising 2.5% to $76.19 a barrel. The US Energy Information Administration reported that US crude inventories fell by 3.5 million barrels to 414 million barrels, while refining activity recovered from recent storms. Strong demand and low inventories are supporting prices, despite potential interest rate increases from the US Federal Reserve.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: Singapore's population shrank 4.1% to 5.45 million in June 2021 due to the Covid-19 pandemic. South-east Asian startups saw a record high in investments in the first half of 2021, with total capital invested falling as investors focused on smaller deals. BlackRock CEO Larry Fink called on Singapore to help emerging countries with the net-zero transition. The Singapore stock market fell 0.73% amid concerns over Evergrande and China's energy shortages.

site_title: Malaysia's glove industry appeals for inflow of foreign labour amid Covid-19 curbs
summary: Malaysia's rubber glove manufacturers are appealing to the government to allow foreign workers to enter the country due to a critical shortage of 25,000 workers since 2019. The Malaysian Rubber Glove Manufacturers Association (Margma) cited intense competition from China and a need to maintain production capacity to fulfill orders. The industry, which supplies around two-thirds of the world's rubber gloves, is facing a shortage that could impact global demand. Margma is prepared to fulfill terms and requirements for hiring foreign workers, including Covid-19-related procedures.

site_title: UK warship makes rare transit through Taiwan Strait
summary: A British warship, HMS Richmond, sailed through the Taiwan Strait on Monday, challenging Beijing's claim to the waterway. This is the first time a non-US military vessel has made the transit. The move comes as China intensifies its military threats towards Taiwan and solidifies control over the disputed South China Sea. The UK's defence ministry did not respond to a request for comment, while China's military warned the British vessel of "evil intentions". The transit is seen as a challenge to Beijing's claims and a demonstration of freedom of navigation by the UK.

site_title: The green pivot: ENGIE's Thomas Baudlot
summary: Thomas Baudlot, CEO of ENGIE's Asia Pacific energy solutions, emphasizes the necessity of green energy, even for traditional utilities groups. ENGIE, a French utility company, shifted its focus to green energy six years ago, after realizing the world's carbon-intensive operations and heavy coal exposure. Today, ENGIE has over 170,000 employees, offering a range of services and solutions through its three businesses. Baudlot notes that accelerated switch from brown to green energy is happening globally, with governments and businesses taking climate change seriously. ENGIE designs and implements efficient data centers using carbon capture and green hydrogen, and partners with companies to provide greener solutions, aiming to make sustainability a priority for enterprises.

site_title: Robust measurement of emissions important
summary: Singapore aims to establish a robust carbon credit marketplace to tackle climate change, with a focus on standardizing and transparently pricing carbon credits. The city-state's Climate Impact X project, backed by Temasek and other institutions, seeks to overhaul the voluntary carbon market. Measuring carbon intensity of crude oil production is also crucial, with S&P Global Platts launching upstream calculations to provide transparency. This is a necessary step towards becoming net-zero by 2050, as awareness of carbon intensity of existing commodities is a key first step.

site_title: Handcrafted homes
summary: Architect Sim Boon Yang, founder of eco.id Architects, has a strict criteria for selecting clients for his high-end home designs. He believes in a personal touch and compatibility between the client and architect. After a "dating game" interview process, he partnered with Futuristic Store Fixtures' CEO David Low to design a modern, 17,000 sq ft Good Class Bungalow near the Singapore Botanic Gardens. The design prioritizes functionality and optimizes the land's value, reflecting Sim's modernist design philosophy. The project showcases the beauty of handcrafting and highlights the importance of matching the client's vision with the architect's expertise.

site_title: Good food: Singapore companies' role in securing our food supply sustainably
summary: Singaporean companies are playing a crucial role in securing the country's food supply sustainably, particularly in the wake of climate change and growing global population demands. Innovative farming methods, such as urban farming and aquaculture, are being implemented by companies like Archisen and Barramundi Group, which utilize technology to increase productivity and efficiency. The government aims to increase local food production to 30% by 2030, with companies like WhatIF Foods and Shiok Meats exploring alternative protein sources like cell-based meat and seafood. As the global indoor farming technology market is projected to reach $24.8 billion by 2026, Singapore is poised to become a hub for agritech innovation, with companies expanding overseas and establishing themselves as leaders in sustainable food production.
