"Sustainability is not enough anymore - the planet needs regeneration. The planet needs restoration," says Stephen Langwallner, WhatIF Foods.
WhatIF partners with communities who grow regenerative crops, which it buys and turns into instant noodles, soups, shakes and milk.

site_title: The return of empty shelves and panic buying
summary: Supply chain issues are causing empty shelves in US and European supermarkets, not due to panic buying but due to congestion at every stage of the supply chain. Rising prices and patchy availability are expected to lead to shoppers purchasing in bulk to avoid future sticker shock. Congested ports, shortages of workers, and surging virus cases are adding to the pressures, affecting sectors such as beverages and food. Retailers are re-engineering their supply chains, and consumers may switch to cheaper products, buy in bulk, or flock to discounters like Aldi and Lidl to cope with the rising costs.

site_title: How the US debt limit became 'a hostage that's worth ransoming' once again
summary: The US debt limit, a hostage to negotiations between Democrats and Republicans, has become a recurring issue. The ceiling on debt the US can take on is set to expire, threatening a potential default in October, which could devastate the economy. A decade ago, a similar standoff led to a downgrade in the country's credit rating, and Senate Republicans, led by Mitch McConnell, describe the debt limit as "worth ransoming." Negotiations continue, with Democrats seeking to increase the limit and Republicans refusing to back it.

site_title: An orchestra of flavours
summary: Pan Pacific Hotels Group's Pan Pacific Dining Collection presents a culinary journey with 18 acclaimed restaurants and bars in Singapore. The collection features a variety of dining options, including progressive Chinese, exquisite Japanese, farm-to-table cuisine, and familiar local favorites. Notable restaurants include Peach Blossoms, Keyaki, Si Chuan Dou Hua, Ginger, and Peppermint, each offering unique and expertly crafted dining experiences. The collection aims to showcase the best of Singapore's culinary scene, with a focus on quality, authenticity, and creativity.

site_title: Xi tells UN China will stop funding coal projects overseas
summary: China's President Xi Jinping announced at the UN General Assembly that the country will stop funding coal projects overseas, ending a major source of support for a dirty energy contributing to climate change. This move comes as China vows to accelerate efforts to help the world battle the climate crisis. China has been investing heavily in coal at home, but will no longer finance new coal-fired power projects abroad. The country aims to peak coal consumption by 2030 and go carbon neutral by 2060, as momentum builds for a UN conference in Glasgow later this year.

site_title: Sembcorp on a corporate journey to go from brown to green, Sustainability Impact Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Sembcorp Industries' unit has delayed the acquisition of a 49 MW hydropower asset in Vietnam. The project, valued at $30 million, was initially expected to be completed in 2023. However, due to unforeseen circumstances, the project's timeline has been pushed back. Sembcorp Industries will now need to reassess the project's feasibility and provide an updated timeline for completion. The delay is expected to have a minimal impact on the company's overall financial performance. The revised timeline has not been disclosed, and further updates will be provided as more information becomes available.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's factories experienced 10th consecutive month of growth in August, driven by sustained electronics strength, despite a dip in biomedical manufacturing. The labour market remains partially recovered, with employment data showing a gradual recovery. Real estate news included IReit Global acquiring a Barcelona office building and Edmund Tie partnering with One RHT to create digital real estate solutions. The Straits Times Index (STI) slipped 0.49% due to concerns over Evergrande and the pandemic.

site_title: Star jewellery
summary: Luxury jewelry brands are partnering with celebrities to increase their appeal to younger audiences. Brands such as Cartier, Tiffany, Bvlgari, Louis Vuitton, and Chaumet have launched new collections featuring celebrity ambassadors, including Kaya Scodelario, Roseanne Park (Rosé), Zendaya, Lalisa Manoban (Lisa), Alicia Vikander, and Song Hye Kyo. These partnerships showcase the brands' unique designs and values, with collections ranging from avant-garde to classic and elegant.

site_title: A dream kitchen to call his own
summary: Celebrity chef Willin Low has completed his dream kitchen in his first home in Singapore, featuring high-end appliances including a Sub-Zero fridge, Wolf gas hob, and steam convection oven. Low, who is also a lawyer and restaurateur, designed the space with a minimalist aesthetic and practical features such as an island for food preparation and entertainment. He chose the appliances based on their performance, durability, and design, and has developed a strong relationship with local distributors. The kitchen serves as a "cave and sanctuary" for Low, where he can relax and recharge after a long day at work.

site_title: Retailoring the modern man
summary: Ermenegildo Zegna's Fall/Winter 2021 collection challenges traditional notions of masculinity and menswear, embracing a fluid and adaptable aesthetic that transitions seamlessly between indoor and outdoor settings. The new collection focuses on comfort and versatility, with signature pieces like the overshirt, available in various fabrics. The brand's #WhatMakeAMan campaign features five inspiring individuals who embody modernity, adaptability, and reinvention, redefining the idea of modern masculinity and reaffirming relevant values.

site_title: Fall/winter fashion stays safe
summary: Luxury fashion brands have adopted a cautious approach to the world's reopening, focusing on timeless and commercial pieces that prioritize comfort and practicality. Key trends include oversized jackets, bold colors, and logo-heavy designs. Classic tailoring is being reimagined with a dystopian twist, while smaller, more minimalist accessories like mini bags and varsity jackets have become popular. Vibrant colors and saturated shades dominate the runways, offering a sense of optimism for a post-pandemic world.

site_title: A hundred ways to see
summary: Museum director Kennie Ting emphasizes the importance of appreciating beauty in small details. He started his fascination with street signs and manholes in New York in 2011, but now surrounds himself with ornate artefacts from history and mythology. Ting believes that analyzing material, emotional response, and historical connections is key to appreciating any object. He aims to educate the public on aesthetics and beauty through the Asian Civilisations Museum, promoting a mutual exchange of ideas between East and West.

site_title: The language of style
summary: Joanna Low, a fashion chameleon, defies traditional style definitions, embracing a wide range of designers and styles. A self-proclaimed lover of beautiful things, she views fashion with an artistic sensibility, appreciating lines, curves, and colors. Low's eclectic wardrobe features designers like Balmain, Dior, and Cecilie Bahnsen, alongside fast fashion brands like H&M. Despite the pandemic's impact on the fashion industry, Low continues to indulge in fashion, citing its ability to express resilience and optimism. Her passion for aesthetics extends to art and history, with a home decorated with Malaysian art and a planned online course in art history.

site_title: Shophouses: the latest collectors' items?
summary: Singapore's shophouse market is experiencing a surge in transaction volume and prices, driven by high net-worth investors seeking collector's items. In the first half of 2021, 118 shophouse transactions valued at S$836.1 million were recorded, with average prices reaching S$4,425 per square foot, a 16.3% increase from 2020. Co-living providers are capitalizing on the trend, managing shophouses to generate yields of 4.5-6% for owners. The market is expected to remain buoyant, with limited supply and growing demand from family offices, private funds, and ultra-high net worth individuals.

site_title: Singapore biotech startup Mirxes in talks for US$1.2b SPAC listing in US
summary: Singapore biotech startup Mirxes is in talks to go public via a US$1.2 billion SPAC listing with Summit Healthcare Acquisition. The deal could value the combined entity at around $1.2 billion, with a potential transaction by early next year. Mirxes, specializing in cancer diagnostics, may opt for a traditional IPO in Hong Kong instead, given waning enthusiasm in the US SPAC market. The startup, founded in 2014, has raised over $130 million in funding, including a recent $77 million round.

site_title: More Americans lost to Covid-19 than 1918 flu pandemic
summary: The US has now surpassed 675,722 Covid-19 deaths, surpassing the 675,000 US deaths during the 1918 flu pandemic. Despite being the deadliest event in human history, the US has borne a disproportionate 14% of global Covid fatalities, with 24% of US adults remaining unvaccinated. Effective treatments, such as vaccines and monoclonal antibodies, have been developed, but misinformation and vaccine hesitancy have hindered efforts to combat the pandemic.

site_title: Ahead of his time
summary: Hendi Widodo, a managing director of an Indonesian shipping company, has a vast collection of watches and streetwear items, accumulated over two decades. His watch collection features rare pieces from luxury brands like Richard Mille and Patek Philippe, while his streetwear collection includes limited-edition sneakers and clothing from brands like Nike, Adidas, and Chanel. Widodo values good design and timeless craftsmanship, taking pride in his knowledge of his possessions and ensuring they remain in good condition for future generations.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Timed to suit your style
summary: Watch sales have been on a steady recovery trend despite industry predictions of decline. Traditional watchmakers have adapted to the market by creating timepieces tailored to specific styles and tastes. Luxury brands like Cartier, Hublot, and Patek Philippe offer high-end watches with unique features, such as the Santos-Dumont XL "No 19" and the Reference 5236P-001 In-line Perpetual Calendar. Meanwhile, brands like Breguet and Audemars Piguet cater to women who appreciate technical sophistication and mechanical complexity. The market also sees a rise in smartwatches, with mobile phone makers entering the market.

site_title: Creating a better way
summary: Benjamin Swan, founder of Sustenir Agriculture, has revolutionized sustainable farming in Singapore with his patented, high-tech indoor farm. The system uses 95% less water than traditional farms, grows non-native crops like kale and strawberries without pesticides, and has expanded to Hong Kong and Malaysia. Swan aims to create a more resilient food system, reducing reliance on imported produce and increasing local food production. His vision is to make all of Singapore's land productive, converting existing farms to yield four to five times more than current levels.

site_title: How British crime dramas became appointment TV
summary: British crime dramas have become appointment TV, drawing record-breaking viewership due to their unpredictable plots, unexpected character deaths, and lack of binge-watching options. Shows like Line of Duty, Bodyguard, and Vigil have attracted double-digit millions of viewers, with some episodes reaching the most-watched status of British television drama in the 21st century. The BBC's World Productions credits this success to defying traditional genre expectations, introducing elements of threat to characters, and allowing viewers to obsessively dissect and discuss the plots between episodes.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ends down over 2% on China debt crisis fears
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index plummeted 2.17% or 660.34 points to 29,839.71, following Wall Street's decline due to fears of Evergrande's debt collapse. This marks a second consecutive day of losses for the benchmark index. The broader Topix index also fell 1.70% or 35.62 points to 2,064.55. The losses are attributed to concerns over the potential impact of Evergrande's debt crisis on global markets.

site_title: Autumn flavours at La Dame de Pic
summary: Chef Anne-Sophie Pic's three Michelin-starred restaurant La Dame de Pic in Raffles Hotel Singapore has launched a new Autumn menu with exciting flavors and ingredients. Chef Francesco di Marzio, a 10-year veteran of Michelin restaurants, has taken the reins, aiming to elevate the dining experience. The new menu features dishes such as Matsutake mushrooms, figs, and Nashi pears, incorporating Asian inspirations and aromatic complexity, with dishes like Organic Welsh Lamb and Japanese Nashi Pear and White Tea. The restaurant's signature Berlingots have also been revamped with dried leek, adding a fresh twist.

site_title: 30-year SGS (Infrastructure) bonds issue likely to have 'decent demand': DBS
summary: DBS Group Research predicts decent demand for the upcoming 30-year Singapore Government Securities (SGS) (Infrastructure) bonds, set to be issued on Oct 1. The expected auction size is close to S$2 billion, according to rates strategist Eugene Leow. The 30-year SGS yield of 1.89% is one of the highest globally, and Leow attributes this to a scarcity of AAA-rated government bonds in the current market. The issue will be created under the Significant Infrastructure Government Loan Act (SINGA) and will rank pari passu with the current SGS category.

site_title: Wong Kar Wai auctions off first NFT
summary: Hong Kong film director Wong Kar Wai is auctioning off the first NFT of his film "In The Mood For Love" through Sotheby's, featuring unseen footage from the 2000 film's first day of production. The 90-second NFT, shot in 1999, will be sold as part of the Modern Art Evening Sale on October 9. The auction also includes a yellow leather jacket worn by Leslie Cheung in "Happy Together" and 30 collectibles from Wong's archives, marking milestones in his career.

site_title: Super connector: Charles Li, ex-CEO of HKEX
summary: Charles Li, former CEO of HKEX, emphasizes Hong Kong's status as a "super converter and connecter" between international and Chinese markets. He credits his role in shaping the city's growth as a global financial hub, particularly in linking it with China's rise. Li notes the exchange's evolution from a capital formation center to a capital connectivity center, and its potential to become a currency connectivity center. He describes his own career as driven by efficiency, creativity, and connection in finance. Li is now a digital entrepreneur, co-founding the Numa Group and launching Micro Connect, a platform providing tailored funding for Chinese small businesses. He believes his approach is on the right side of regulations and aims to leverage the network of digitization to provide transparency and growth opportunities for micro-enterprises.

site_title: All eyes on Evergrande's bond payment
summary: Evergrande Group, a cash-strapped Chinese property developer, is set to make key bond payments on Thursday, testing its ability to meet obligations to bondholders amidst a liquidity crisis. Investors are pricing in a high likelihood of default, with one note trading at less than 30% of face value. The company's debt pile exceeds $300 billion, and policymakers have injected $14 billion into the financial system to soothe nerves. A default could stoke fears of contagion, prompting Chinese authorities to take action to prevent a broader credit market collapse.

images.alt_text: Evergrande has vowed to repay all of its matured wealth management products as soon as possible.

site_title: Hanwell aims to double top line with expanded offerings
summary: Hanwell Holdings, a Singapore-based manufacturer and distributor of consumer essentials, aims to double its top line in three to five years by expanding its offerings. The company plans to cast its sourcing net wider to the global market, offering canned food, frozen food, and ready-to-eat meals. Hanwell's consumer business reported a 5.6% drop in revenue in the first half of FY2021 due to a high base last year. The company is building its e-commerce platform and reconfiguring its premises to optimize usage and store more goods.

site_title: 837 new Covid-19 cases in S'pore; new cluster at All Saints Home in Jurong East
summary: Singapore reported 837 new COVID-19 cases, with 755 in the community, 77 in dormitories, and 5 imported cases, bringing the total to 73,131. A new cluster of 10 cases emerged at All Saints Home in Jurong East, with 9 residents and 1 staff member. The number of cases more than doubled from last week, with 231 seniors above 60 years old affected. 809 patients are currently in hospital, with 59 seniors requiring oxygen supplementation.

site_title: South Korean antitrust agency fines Google 207b won for abusing market dominance
summary: South Korea's antitrust regulator fined Alphabet's Google 207 billion won (S$237.1 million) for abusing its market dominance in the mobile operating system market. The Korea Fair Trade Commission (KFTC) accused Google of blocking local smartphone makers from using other operating systems. This is the latest antitrust setback for Google in South Korea, following a bill passed by Parliament earlier this month to ban app store operators from forcing developers to use their payment systems. The fine is the KFTC's ninth-largest ever.

site_title: Remote work goes 'luxury', but many may be left out
summary: Big Tech companies are introducing premium remote work tools, such as virtual reality meetings and high-end digital hot desking, but many Americans struggle to access basic remote work tools due to lack of internet access and affordable equipment. 42 million Americans, or 13% of the population, cannot get broadband internet, and many workers have to buy their own equipment, making remote work a luxury for many. Experts warn that the digital divide exposed by the pandemic may increase inequality, with those who can't afford the latest tools being left out of the hybrid work model.

site_title: UK lawmakers urge Bank of England to penalise fossil fuel financing
summary: UK lawmakers urge the Bank of England to penalize banks that finance the fossil fuel industry, calling for increased investment in green finance. A cross-party group of 51 lawmakers wrote to BoE Governor Andrew Bailey, stating the financial sector is underpricing climate-related risk and not enough money is being spent on green finance. The group recommends the BoE bolster green lending by providing cheaper credit to banks lending to sustainable projects and introduce measures to reflect the higher risk of lending to the fossil fuel sector in regulation.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOBKH upgrades ST Engineering to 'buy' as share price weakens
summary: UOB Kay Hian has upgraded its call on ST Engineering to 'buy' with a target price of S$4.25, citing the company's post-results price decline and concerns over H2 FY2021 earnings. Analyst K Ajith believes the group's defence and public security (DPS) business will drive growth, and recent secured contracts and orders will lead to a gradual pick-up in aerospace earnings by mid-2022. The analyst sees minimal downside risk to the stock from its current levels.

site_title: Lessons from the business of tuition: Are we paying attention?
summary: Singapore's tuition industry has grown into a billion-dollar market, with average household spending on tuition increasing from S$79.90 to S$88.40 per month between 2012/2013 and 2017/2018. Despite efforts to address the issue, including reforms to the Primary School Leaving Examination and expanded direct school admission, the industry remains unregulated, fueling concerns of an unlevel playing field. Experts argue that a complete ban on tuition would be ineffective and that the industry plays a role in promoting learning, but also notes that it exacerbates inequality and creates pressure on students.

site_title: US: Stocks rise as consumer inflation moderates
summary: US stocks rose early Tuesday as consumer prices moderated in August, supporting the Federal Reserve's argument that recent inflation is due to temporary factors. Consumer prices climbed 0.3% in August, below analyst forecasts, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.2%. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained 0.2% and 0.3%, respectively. This moderation in inflation reduces the likelihood of an abrupt shift in monetary policy, with the Fed expected to make a taper announcement in November or December.

site_title: Grand Venture to raise up to S$39.9m through share placement and vendor sale
summary: Grand Venture Tech has entered into a placement agreement to raise up to S$39.9 million through the issuance and sale of up to 25 million new shares at S$1.14 each. The placement, facilitated by CGS-CIMB Securities, also involves the sale of up to 10 million shares by Metalbank Singapore, the company's controlling shareholder. The funds raised will be used to build competencies, customer base, and scale capacity. The transaction is expected to strengthen the group's financial position and support future strategic investments and acquisitions.

site_title: Evergrande: China's fragile housing giant teetering on the brink of bankruptcy
summary: China's largest private conglomerate, Evergrande, is on the brink of bankruptcy due to crippling debt. The company's Hong Kong-listed shares have collapsed by 80% this year, and its ability to complete developments and service debts is in doubt. Evergrande, which employs 200,000 people and indirectly generates 3.8 million jobs, has warned of "risks of defaults on borrowings" and faces major repercussions on the country's economy and possibly the world. A managed restructuring is the most likely endgame, with other developers taking over its uncompleted projects in exchange for a share of its land bank.

site_title: Porsche to open Malaysia factory, first outside Europe
summary: Porsche plans to open its first factory outside Europe in Malaysia, with a final assembly site in the northern state of Kedah, set to be operational next year. The move aims to meet local demand and reduce high tariffs on imported vehicles. The factory, established in collaboration with a local partner, will produce specific models for the local market. This strategic decision signifies Porsche's commitment to Southeast Asia, where the country's growing middle class has driven robust growth rates, despite a recent coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Jurong industrial development for sale at S$22m indicative price
summary: A single, four-storey industrial development in Jurong Industrial Estate is up for sale at S$22 million. The 127,123 sq ft site, zoned B2 for heavy industrial use, features a 20,000 sq ft warehouse with a 14.9-metre ceiling height and 31,000 sq ft yard space with an overhead crane fixture. The development includes office space, a canteen, and an indoor badminton court. The site benefits from connectivity to nearby PSA terminals and MRT stations. The sale is seen as a rare opportunity for investors and owner-occupiers in industries such as chemicals and engineering.

site_title: Singapore is at the forefront of urban revolution
summary: Singapore is transforming into a hub for urban innovation, with its meticulous approach allowing ideas to be turned into action quickly. The city-state has become a living laboratory for urban development, with a focus on mobility and other sectors. This transformation has been evident in its 50th anniversary celebrations in 2013, where the city's civil service sought to focus on the future rather than the past. Today, Singapore is recognized for its efficiency, cleanliness, and order, and its ability to propel innovation in various fields.

site_title: Swedish IPO frenzy propels stock market into Europe's big league
summary: Sweden's stock market is experiencing a surge, becoming one of Europe's top-performing equity markets and offering investors the most choice in the region. With nearly 1,000 listed companies, including over 80% small caps, Sweden outstrips larger countries like Germany and France. The market is expected to see its busiest year for IPOs in over two decades, driven by a thriving startup scene and deep investor base. The vibrant market reflects Sweden's unique ecosystem of investors and is set to see more companies, including Truecaller and Storskogen Group AB, go public.

site_title: What difference did 9/11 make?
summary: The 9/11 terrorist attacks marked a turning point in US history, changing public psychology and US foreign policy. Despite initial doubts that the attacks would be fatal to American power, the US responded with a "global war on terror," invading Afghanistan and Iraq, and resulting in significant economic costs, over 15,000 US military fatalities, and widespread devastation. Historians may regard 9/11 as a pivotal moment, similar to the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, as it shifted the US focus from isolationism to global engagement. The long-term effects of the US withdrawal from Afghanistan are still unfolding, but President Biden's strategy aims to balance the rise of China and maintain US influence in Asia.

site_title: Google sees future work as 'hybrid'
summary: Google has ramped up cloud collaboration tools for businesses, expecting "hybrid" work routines to remain after the pandemic. The company has created a hybrid work handbook and software for efficient meetings, and has introduced new Workspace offerings that integrate its apps for meetings, email, calendars, documents, chat, and more. Google's product management director, Dave Citron, said the 40-hour work week in a cubicle may not be permanently dead, but rather a mix of on-site and remote work. The company's new tools are designed to bridge the gaps of virtual and in-person collaboration.

site_title: Evergrande contagion fear returns as bonds drop to record low
summary: Evergrande Group's dollar bonds plummeted to a record low of 28.5 cents, sparking a selloff in other junk-rated developers, including Kaisa Group Holdings and Guangzhou R&F Properties. The move raises concerns for Chinese authorities, who are weighing support for billionaire Hui Ka Yan's embattled property empire. A potential default could have significant economic implications, with investors and regulators alike fixated on the ramifications. Evergrande's total liabilities rose to a near-record 1.97 trillion yuan, and cash reserves fell to a six-year low, fueling fears of further defaults and consolidation in the property industry.

site_title: Alpha DX to manage and establish university in Uzbekistan via a joint venture
summary: Alpha DX, a learning solutions company, will manage and establish the Asnaro University of Uzbekistan (AUU) via a joint venture with the Uzbekistan Ministry of Higher Education. The $50 million investment will be used to develop and grow the university, which is expected to open in the third quarter of 2022 with two campuses in Tashkent and Andijan. This partnership marks Alpha DX's first public-private venture and may expand to transform Uzbekistan's public education system. The move is expected to drive the company's growth and diversification.

site_title: Myanmar junta agrees to Asean call for ceasefire to distribute aid
summary: Myanmar's military rulers have agreed to a ceasefire until the end of the year to ensure distribution of humanitarian aid, following an Asean call. The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) proposed the ceasefire in a video conference with Foreign Minister Wunna Maung Lwin, and the military accepted it. The agreement aims to ensure the safety and security of humanitarian workers distributing aid, not a political ceasefire. Asean had pledged $8 million in aid for Myanmar, amid ongoing violence and allegations of irregularities in a recent election.

site_title: Apple offers small concession in easing App Store rules for Netflix and others
summary: Apple has relaxed some App Store rules, allowing content companies like Netflix to provide website links for paid accounts. The change, part of a settlement with Japan's anti-trust regulator, lifts a ban on reader apps offering separate payment links. The concession, set to take effect early next year, retains Apple's control over which apps qualify as reader apps. The move comes amid ongoing antitrust challenges, including a lawsuit by Epic Games and regulatory actions in the US, Europe, and India.

site_title: Power trip: Mapping the transition to Singapore's clean-energy future
summary: Singapore is working to transition to a clean-energy future, but faces challenges such as high electricity spot prices and a reliance on natural gas. Despite these issues, the city-state has made significant progress in liberalizing its energy market, attracting new investments, and shifting towards more efficient generation technologies. Solar power is seen as a key source of renewable energy, with plans to quadruple solar deployment to 1.5GWp by 2025. Regional power grids and imports from neighboring countries, such as Malaysia and Australia, are also being explored to fill the energy gap. However, the transition to a low-carbon future will require significant investment and infrastructure development.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.71 points, or 0.11%, to 1,583.30 on Tuesday, with 242 gainers outnumbering 137 losers. The country's shares opened higher despite global market volatility, with European stocks down due to bank and healthcare concerns, and US stocks near records despite tariff threats.

site_title: The business of giving: Koh Choon Hui, ex-chairman, Singapore Pools
summary: Former Singapore Pools chairman Koh Choon Hui shares his experiences in the world of legalized gambling, charity, and social services. During the 2020 Circuit Breaker period, Singapore Pools lost over S$2 billion but still managed to collect over S$200 million in revenue. Koh emphasizes the importance of responsible gambling and has implemented measures to prevent excessive spending. He highlights the organization's efforts to give back to the community, donating to various causes and funding major projects such as the National Stadium and Gardens By The Bay. Koh is proud of his time at Singapore Pools, citing a strong leadership team and commitment to integrity.

site_title: Release figures of daily Covid tests, triggers for clarity
summary: A letter to the editor expresses concern over the lack of clarity in COVID-19 data, specifically the number of daily tests and cases in intensive care. The writer suggests that reporting the number of daily tests, triggers for testing, and the number of cases added and removed from intensive care lists would provide more meaningful insights into the pandemic's progression. The writer hopes the authorities will consider providing these numbers to better inform the public.

site_title: Malaysia's new government inks deal with opposition to boost stability
summary: Malaysia's new government, led by Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob, has signed an agreement with the opposition to cooperate on reforms in exchange for a promise of cooperation. The deal aims to bring stability after intense political turbulence and fuel hopes that officials can focus on fighting the coronavirus outbreak. The agreement covers areas such as parliamentary reform, judicial independence, and Covid-19 response, and is seen as a bid to put aside political differences. The opposition, led by Anwar Ibrahim, has agreed to support the government in exchange for reforms.

images.alt_text: Mr Ismail Sabri (right) and representatives of the opposition, led by Mr Anwar (left), signed the agreement in Parliament, as the legislature convened on Monday for the first time since the new premier took power.

site_title: StanChart veteran named CEO of Singapore digital bank venture with NTUC
summary: Standard Chartered has appointed DWAIPAYAN Sadhu as CEO of its digital bank venture with NTUC Enterprise, a move that comes after the joint venture was granted a full banking licence by the Monetary Authority of Singapore in December 2020. The bank will hold a 60% stake in the venture, valued at S$144 million, while NTUC Enterprise will hold a 40% stake, valued at S$96 million. The launch date for the digital bank is yet to be decided, but it is expected to start operations in early 2022, joining four other digital banks that were also awarded licences last year.

images.alt_text: Dwaipayan Sadhu has more than two decades of industry experience spanning wealth management, payments, deposits, consumer lending, and digital banking.

site_title: Changing hands: Major GCB sales in the past
summary: Major foreign governments and corporations have sold large plots in Singapore's Good Class Bungalow Areas (GCBAs) since the 1990s. Embassies, banks, and corporates, such as Standard Chartered Bank, Goodyear Tyres, and HSBC, have been major sellers. The British government has also reduced its presence in GCBAs, while foreign governments like Russia, Indonesia, and Brunei still have significant footprints. Today, foreign governments and property groups, including City Developments and Far East Organization, own large plots in GCBAs, while the State also owns 46 bungalows.

site_title: IWC Big Pilot's Watch 43 stays true to its roots
summary: IWC has introduced the Big Pilot's Watch 43, a smaller version of its popular Ref 5002 model. The new watch measures 43mm, still larger than average, but smaller than the original 46mm Ref 5002. It features an in-house Calibre 82100 Pellaton bi-directional winding system, quick strap-change system EasX-CHANGE, and interchangeable straps. The watch boasts a clean dial, three hands, and a 60-hour power reserve, making it suitable for daily wear. Designed for B-urh fans who want a sensibly-sized watch with the DNA of the original, the BP43 is a dream come true.

images.alt_text: The Big Pilot 43 measures 43mm and comes with the Calibre 82100 winding system and a quick strap-change system.
